FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT 4 One of the Court's main objectives and part of its mandate in promoting transparency and accountability is to bring the European Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens.
It is therefore a great pleasure for me to welcome you as a reader of the European Court of Auditors' first annual activity report.
The report aims to provide an overall picture of the Court and to give an account of its activities in 2007, the year in which it celebrates its 30th anniversary as the European Union's external auditor, which according to its mission is to improve EU financial management contributes and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union.
The Court's main contribution is through its audits and reports, which enable the auditee to improve its financial management and support the discharge authority (European Parliament and Council) in their scrutiny of the implementation of the EU budget.
This report provides an overview of the audit reports published in 2007 and highlights the main conclusions regarding the implementation of the 2006 EU budget and the sound financial management of EU funds.
The Court not only reports on the financial management of previous years, but is also actively involved in building an EU financial control framework.
The year 2007 was an important one for EU financial management.
The section “The Court's view” outlines the Court's views on significant developments related to Member State accountability and the Court's contribution to the public consultation on budgetary reform launched by the European Commission.
None of the Court's achievements in 2007 would be possible without the commitment, know-how and competence of its 850 staff.
Human resources are the most important asset of a future-oriented agency that strives for constant improvement.
This first annual activity report details the Court's reform process, which started in 2006 with a self-assessment.
2007 saw progress in implementing the resulting action plan and by the end of the year a peer review process was launched, led by a group of auditors drawn from the national audit offices of Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal.
A first result of this reform process was the following statement of the Court's mission, mission, values and strategic objectives, which will guide future activities and on which the Court will report in due course.
I hope you enjoy reading the first annual activity report and that you find it useful.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
6 MISSION, MISSION, VALUES AND STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES MISSION MISSION The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances under the Treaty.
As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
7 VALUES Independence, integrity & impartiality Professionalism Added value Excellence & efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality for the body, its members and staff.
Supplying its target group with appropriate examination results, whereby any form of influence through external instructions or pressure is rejected.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports that are based on sound evidence and evidence, address the needs of its audience, and contain important and meaningful statements.
Contribute to effectively improving the management of the EU budget and contribute to increasing accountability for the management of EU funds.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.
STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES In order to fulfill its mandate, the European Court of Auditors has committed itself to the following strategic objectives: Professionalism Output Target group Development & growth Established audit methods, appropriate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit benchmarks for EU funds, cooperation with EU SAIs, effective “community control framework” selection of relevant audit topics, timeliness, clarity and readability of reports, quality of performance audits, increasing the impact of reports deepening relationships with audited entities to bring about a better understanding of the audit process and a achieve broader acceptance of exam results; Developing contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as budgetary and discharge authorities; communicating effectively with EU citizens using the experience of the peer review process to strengthen and develop the organisation, methods, processes and results in order to achieve maximum efficiency; pursuing an effective and dynamic human resources policy; quality professional training; modernization of infrastructure; Implementation of IT strategies
8 ROLE AND WORK OF THE COURT WHAT ROLE DOES THE COURT HAVE?
The budget of the European Union is around EUR 120 billion, which is around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 member states.
Compared to the national budgets, this represents a minor proportion.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities. The total budget volume roughly corresponds to the GNI of some countries, such as Romania.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agriculture and cohesion policies being the main spending areas (see Box 1).
The budget is determined annually - on the basis of a seven-year financial framework - by the Council, ie representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission is responsible for implementing the budget, but shares a significant proportion of the administrative tasks with the Member States, particularly when it comes to spending on agriculture and cohesion policy.
Depending on the spending regime, national authorities may be responsible for setting spending strategies, selecting beneficiaries and projects, and making payments.
A particular feature of Community spending is the high percentage of payments that are based on corresponding claims from the beneficiaries themselves, be they farmers or project managers anywhere in the Union.
9 BOX 1 - HOW DOES THE EU SPEND ITS MONEY?
Much of the EU budget goes to different purposes than national budgets, partly due to differences in areas of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a large part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which usually takes the form of payments to farmers throughout the Union, has represented the bulk of budgetary expenditure, although the trend is currently decreasing.
In 2008, slightly less than half of the budget is earmarked for conservation and management of natural resources, mainly agriculture and rural development.
Since the 1980s, a significant part of the expenditure has gone to the area of cohesion - ie regional and social development - to co-finance a wide range of projects from road construction in Slovakia to training courses for the unemployed in Denmark.
For 2008, spending on sustainable growth, the lion's share of which goes to cohesion, has been estimated at 38% of the budget.
This heading also includes a large part of the EU funds earmarked for research.
Around 6% of the budget is spent on the administration of the Community institutions.
EU spending Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1% The European Union as a global actor 6% Administration 6% Cohesion - Sustainable growth 38% Agriculture - Conservation and management of natural resources 49%
Democratic societies require complete and accurate publicly available information to inform discussion and decision-making, both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
In its capacity as the EU's external auditor, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds, wherever they are used, are correctly accounted for and spent in accordance with the law, with due regard to the best use of funds.
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Commission, Parliament and Council, as well as by Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, numerous national control authorities audit EU funds where they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
Overview of internal and external control of the EU budget EU level 10 Commission (DG, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing bodies European Court of Auditors National control authorities National level External control Internal control
WHAT TEST RESULTS DOES THE COURT DELIVER? The Court applies three different types of audits 1: financial, compliance (checking compliance with legal requirements) and performance audit, depending on which of the following three questions the starting point of the audit is: 11 • • • Conveys the financial statements in all material Do a true and fair view of the financial position, results and cash flows for the year comply with the applicable accounting framework?
The Court is required under the EC Treaty to issue such a statement - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual declaration of assurance is commonly known by the French acronym DAS (“Déclaration d'Assurance”).
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
The Court conducts its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA), which apply to both the public and private sectors.
Together with the national control authorities, the Court actively participates in the further development of international auditing standards promoted by the standardization bodies (Intosai, IFAC) 2 .
In order to provide assurance that payments comply with the legal and regulatory framework, the Court relies on the results of both its examination of the supervisory and control systems designed to prevent or detect and correct errors in legality and regularity and one Sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
When systems are checked and found to be reliable, the number of transactions that the Court has to examine in order to reach a valid conclusion as to their legality and regularity is correspondingly reduced.
In selecting the topics for our performance audits, the Court endeavors to identify audit areas where the greatest impact is expected in terms of demonstrated potential for improvement in terms of economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending.
12 2 Intosai (International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions – IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Federation of Accountants.
13 BOX 2 - THE COURT'S ON-THE-SPOT AUDITS OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU BUDGET The Court does not have the resources to audit all EU budget transactions in detail.
The Court traces these transactions down to the final recipient of the aid, such as a farmer in southern Germany.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks - such as measuring the size of the agricultural area - to determine whether the relevant information in the support application corresponds to the actual situation.
Population from all agricultural payments Due to the fact that it is a statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the relevant population, ie a specific revenue or expenditure area, and together with information resulting from the system evaluation, as a basis for an audit overall judgement.
This chart shows how the Court works to identify transactions for in-depth verification purposes.
In practice, the Court's sampling procedures are more complex, for example a two-stage sampling procedure is used to improve the efficiency of the audit work.

14 GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATION STRUCTURE OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, with one member from each Member State.
As shown in the organizational chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (conservation and management of natural resources - structural policies, transport, research and energy - external policies - own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, institutions and bodies of the Community and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or Coordination, Communication, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development) is responsible for 'horizontal' issues such as coordination on the Statement of Assurance, quality assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, an Administrative Committee, composed of members from all audit groups, is responsible for the preparatory handling of all administrative matters requiring a formal court decision.
THE MEMBERS The members of the Court are appointed by the Council, after consultation of the European Parliament, according to the proposals of each Member State, for a six-year term, renewable.
In addition to their function within the college, which is responsible for the final decision-making on audits and opinions as well as on broader strategic and administrative issues, each member is responsible for their specific tasks, primarily in the audit area.
The member then takes on the task of presenting the report to the audit group or the Court and, after its adoption, to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
With the accession of Bulgaria and Romania on 1 January 2007, the Court welcomed two new members, Ms Nadezhda Sandolova and Mr Ovidiu Ispir.
A year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court admitted three more new members, Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) and Mr Harald Noack (Germany), as their predecessors' terms of office had expired.
In addition, the Council extended the terms of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for a further six years.

16 THE PRESIDENT The European Court of Auditors is headed by the President, who is elected by the members from among their number for a term of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The President's role is that of primus inter pares.
The President represents the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, the other institutions of the European Union and the supreme audit institutions of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, the Portuguese Member, was elected the Court's 11th President.
THE SECRETARY-GENERAL The Secretary-General is the most senior official of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a six-year term, renewable.
The Secretary-General is responsible for the human and administrative management of the Court, including professional development and the Directorate for Translation, with one unit for each official language (22), excluding Gaelic.
The Secretary General is also responsible for the General Secretariat.
The term of office of the Court's current Secretary-General, Mr Michel Hervé, was renewed on 1 July 2007.
THE COURT'S STAFF The European Court of Auditors has a staff of around 850 (836 on 31 December 2007) and includes auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff.
The Court's auditors have a wide range of educational backgrounds and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, particularly in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, law and economics.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States.
18 OVERVIEW OF THE COURT'S AUDIT REPORTS AND 3 OPINIONS The results of the Court's financial and compliance audits mostly feed into the annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Funds (EDFs), as well as the specific annual reports on the agencies and bodies the Union.
The results of the performance audits are published in special reports throughout the year.
The Court also publishes opinions on draft legislation affecting financial management.
ANNUAL REPORTS FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2006 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET As the Court has repeatedly stated in its annual reports on the implementation of the general budget of the EU, adequate and appropriate internal control systems put in place by the Commission and the Member States are essential to ensure the proper management of the EU budget of central importance.
In recent years, the Court has recognized the Commission's efforts to promote and apply improved internal control and management procedures, both in terms of the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions reported therein.
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas for improvement, sometimes significant, as well as identifying major areas of spending where the situation remains unsatisfactory.
The Court concluded that the 'Final annual accounts of the European Communities', which show the implementation of the EU budget for 2006, give a true and fair view of the Communities' financial position and results in all material respects, except for the Disclosure of excessive amounts in the accounts payable and pre-financing in the asset overview.
Further improvements are therefore deemed necessary in order for the newly introduced accruals based accounting system to function fully satisfactorily and to realize its full potential as a reliable management and control tool.
3 This section introduces the Court's reports and opinions rather than summarizing them.
More detailed information can be found in the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
Among the areas of expenditure reported in the "Final Annual Accounts of the European Communities" where most of the payments are made - agriculture [mainly agricultural expenditure not subject to the Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS)], structural measures, internal policies and large parts of external policies – the Court gives a negative opinion on legality and regularity and concludes that these areas of spending remain affected by material error.
For payments in these areas, the supervisory and control systems have only partially limited the risk of irregularities in legality and regularity in transactions.
The Court stresses that complicated or unclear eligibility criteria or complex legislation had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of transactions.
However, the Court found a significant reduction in the estimated total error rate in agricultural transactions and concluded that IACS, when properly applied, is an effective system to mitigate the risk of irregular expenditure.
In addition, the Court found that the transactions underlying the commitments and revenue were free from material error; this also applies to payments related to administrative expenditure, most of the pre-accession strategy and parts of external actions (see Box 3). 19
18 BOX 3 - SUMMARY OF THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF THE UNDERLYING TRANSACTIONS BY AREA OF EXPENDITURE The table summarizes the overall assessment of the supervisory and control systems as set out in the relevant chapters of the Annual Report 2006 and provides a high level summary of the results of the audits of the Court in relation to representative samples of transactions.
Systems are classified as "partially satisfactory" when some controls are found to be functioning adequately while others are not.
As a result, overall, they may not be able to contain the errors in the underlying operations to a tolerable level.
The report draws attention to some shortcomings regarding the "operation of the supervisory and control systems".
Only the core statements are highlighted in the table. However, the respective details cannot be shown in full.
Readers are encouraged to refer to the main body of the 2006 Annual Report for the full analysis.

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUNDS (EDFs) In 2007 the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Funds (EDFs).
Whilst the Court was able to give an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the EDFs, the opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the payments authorized under the responsibility of the delegations in the recipient countries was qualified given the material level of error in these transactions.
OTHER ANNUAL REPORTS A further 28 specific annual reports on the European Agencies and other decentralized bodies and an annual report on the audit of the administrative efficiency of the European Central Bank were also published in 2007. 21
SPECIAL REPORTS PUBLISHED IN 2007 In 2007 the Court published a total of nine special reports.
The reports related to investigations into financial management issues in many different areas, ranging from cooperation in the field of VAT (No. 8/2007) to capacity building in countries as far away as Angola and Vietnam (No. 6/2007 ).
The Court's audits revealed problems of all kinds, with all kinds of consequences.
The weaknesses identified by the Court in relation to the EU institutions' expenditure on buildings (2/2007) show that not all EU funds in this area have been well spent.
The shortcomings identified in the report on the systems for monitoring, inspection and sanctions relating to the rules governing the conservation of Community fisheries resources (7/2007) could have serious consequences not only for aquatic resources but also for the future of the fisheries industry.
Notwithstanding the different ways in which funds are spent in different areas of the EU budget, several common themes emerge in the Court's reports, which can be outlined as follows: 22 • • • While spending funds should be both timely and efficient, it can When trying to achieve these two goals at the same time, a tension arises.
This subject is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No. 1/2007) as well as the report on the management of the CARDS program by the Commission in the Western Balkans (No. 5/2007).
While planning is no guarantee of effectiveness, it is of significant importance.
Questions related to strategic and long-term planning appeared in the reports on the EU institutions' expenditure on buildings (No. 2/2007) and on the evaluation of the EU framework programs in the field of research and technological development (RTD) (No. 9/2007). ) as well as in two reports related to external assistance, one on the CARDS program (5/2007) and the other on the effectiveness of technical assistance in capacity building (6/2007). .
The Commission's evaluations are a key element of its performance management system, assessing performance and identifying areas for improvement where necessary.
If evaluations take place too early in the programming cycle, this means that the state of progress is insufficient and there is not enough relevant data for evaluation purposes.
On the other hand, evaluating at a later stage may reduce the opportunities to make timely changes during the current period and improvements before the next begins.
The issue of the correct timing of evaluations has been addressed in both the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No. 1/2007) and the report on RTD evaluation (No. 9/2007).
23 • • Evaluations, like audits, are more difficult to carry out when the objectives of the spending programs are unclear. This was another issue raised in the latter two reports.
The management and controls of EU spending are subject to complex regulations that need to be clear and unambiguous to ensure that funds are used for the intended purposes.
Having clear definitions and rules in place is essential if funds are to be collected or used as planned.
This was the subject of the reports on the European Refugee Fund (No. 3/2007) and on Member States' goods and substitution controls on the export of agricultural products (No. 4/2007).
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors that can affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of the data coming from different Member States.
This can have consequences when the data become the basis for decisions such as resource allocation.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2007 The Court also helps to improve EU financial management by providing opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the process of adopting financial regulations 4 or may be issued at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community 5 . The Court may also issue opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions can address issues relating to specific areas of expenditure, such as the two opinions of 2007 on new regulations for the European Development Funds (2/2007 and 9/2007).
But they can also cover broader issues of EU financial management, such as the Court's Opinion on the annual summaries, the national declarations and the audit work of national audit bodies (6/2007).
Opinions draw on the Court's expertise in EU financial management issues, acquired over the years through its audits, and in some cases reference is made to specific audits.
For example, in the Opinion on Ensuring the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation (3/2007), the Court refers to a recommendation in a previous special report that the Commission should take action to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud.
The need for simplification is a recurring theme in the Court's opinions (see, for example, Opinion No. 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities).
In a 2007 opinion (6/2007) the Court explains its position on the annual summaries as well as on the so-called national declarations submitted voluntarily by some Member States on their own initiative.
This opinion is discussed in more detail in the section entitled 'The Court's position'.
4 5 Article 279 of the Treaty.
Article 248 paragraph 4.
Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website.
26 FOLLOW-UP AND IMPACT Public financial control plays a key role in modern democratic societies from the point of view of efficient financial management.
Audit activities account for those at the end of the information chain, in this case European citizens, on whether their taxpayers' money is being spent properly and appropriately.
In this sense, public audit is a central part of accountability and a useful basis for public debate.
In this regard, the Court's work has significant potential for impact.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for the decision-makers in the institutions concerned – primarily the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States in the European context.
They can take action based on this information, with or without reference to the audit conclusions.
Although the Court's audit work has its main impact through its published reports, some impact is made throughout the audit itself.
In particular, all audits result in the production of detailed audit findings, which are sent to the auditee to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations.
The final text of the report is also subject to an "adversarial procedure".
The replies of the auditee - namely the Commission - are published together with the reports.
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results are evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their political task of monitoring the use of the budget.
As part of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form a basis for the relevant Council recommendation and Parliament's decision.
In the discharge procedure for the 2006 budget, particular attention was paid to the conclusions put forward by the Court in the area of structural actions.
In its 2006 discharge resolution, Parliament makes direct reference to an action plan proposed by the Commission as a direct consequence of the conclusions of the Court's annual report and requests quarterly reports on the progress of its implementation.
Parliament is also asking for better insight into the corrective actions taken to address the errors and weaknesses.
The special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, due to the fact that they are published throughout the year, the presentation of the special reports and their discussion in Parliament and Council meetings have usually taken place earlier.
A good example of a possible follow-up is provided by the recent Special Report on Building Expenditure (No. 2/2007).
In fact, Parliament has already entrusted its administration with preparing a report examining the feasibility of creating a European Building Authority to be responsible for the construction and maintenance of the buildings of the European Union's institutions and bodies .
The Court's audit report on controls carried out by Member States on exports of agricultural products (4/2007) can be cited as another example.
The Council and Commission promptly responded to the Court's recommendations by amending the applicable legislation.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by promoting them in the relevant media, which attracts more attention and stimulates public discussion.
The media are the most direct source of information for citizens.
The media coverage of the Court's annual report is generally quite extensive, although some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
The fisheries report (No. 7/2007) attracted a great deal of media attention.
An Extraordinary Fisheries Council was convened to discuss the Court's report and the Commission started a process that may result in legislative changes to address the deficiencies identified.
This is an example of a report that, because of its relevance and timeliness, was able to make a particularly valuable contribution to the decision-making process.
Some guidance on the impact of the court reports published in 2007 has been provided in this section.
Details of the Court's follow-up to previous observations are provided in the relevant chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequent observation in its last annual report is that, despite the action taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially addressed.
When looking at the impact of the Court's work, the opinions should also be taken into account.
The Court intends to increasingly analyze the long-term implications of its work, both audits and opinions.
This can be illustrated by the example set out in Box 4.
27 BOX 4 - THE COURT'S OPINION ON THE 'SINGLE AUDIT' Over the years, the Court has published several opinions identifying ways to strengthen the overall internal control system for the EU budget.
A trend-setting contribution was made in this regard with the statement on the “single audit” (No. 2/2004) in 2004.
In this opinion, the Court proposes embedding the definition and implementation of all internal control in a single Integrated Control Framework, which includes common principles and targets and ensures that costs and benefits are proportionate.
The opinion on the "single audit" became a reference document for the Commission, but also for the Court, for example in its 2007 observations on the definition of effective and efficient internal control in the updated Implementing Rules of the Financial Regulation (Opinion 1/2007).
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission's 2006 action plan towards an integrated internal control framework.
The Commission has taken steps to emphasize the role and responsibilities of Member States in the area of internal control. This includes the new obligation to provide annual summaries of opinions, statements and audits carried out under the regulations applicable to each spending area.
28 THE COURT'S POSITION NATIONAL SUMMARIES AND STATEMENTS Initiatives have been taken by the Commission and Member States to increase Member States' involvement in the accountability cycle for EU funds.
This aims in part to address the problem of material error rates in terms of legality and regularity in the main spending areas of the budget, particularly in those areas where management is shared between the Commission and the Member States.
Significant recent developments include the obligation for Member States to provide annual summaries of available audit results and declarations, voluntary initiatives by some Member States to issue national declarations and the decision by some national control authorities to issue audit reports on the management of EU funds.
In its Opinion 6/2007, the Court considers that all these elements, if properly implemented, could result in improved management and control of EU funds.
The opinion explains the conditions under which these elements add value and can be used by the Court in compliance with the requirements of international auditing standards.
As the Annual Summaries form part of the internal control system, the Court will assess to what extent they improve the functioning of internal control as part of its usual audit procedures.
Annual summaries, insofar as they highlight strengths and weaknesses, can lead to better overall control of EU funds in areas of shared management.
National declarations are based on voluntary initiatives by certain Member States; they are made at the highest level and submitted to national parliaments.
Although not conclusive audit evidence on their own, they can be understood as a novel element of internal control and can provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court recognizes the potential usefulness of national declarations and national audit work in raising awareness in Member States of the importance of internal control of EU funds.
The audit work of the national control authorities (national audit reports) related to the legality and regularity of the EU expenditure or to the national declarations could provide audit evidence for the Court if it can satisfy itself on the usefulness and quality of the audit work in line with international auditing standards.
In this case, the Court will take account of the audit opinions issued by national control authorities when planning and conducting its own audits.
National statements and national assurance reports contain statements about control systems.
National declarations may also include specific audit opinions on the legality and regularity of transactions.
Experience shows that the main risk to the legality and regularity of transactions is the reliability of the information provided by beneficiaries when applying for EU funds, rather than the way in which that information is processed by Member States and the Commission.
A declaration that systems are functioning as required by EU regulations cannot, by itself, guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions concerned.
Recognizing the need for a stronger role for national audit authorities in the overall accountability framework for EU spending, the Contact Committee of EU Supreme Audit Institutions has set up a working group to harmonize auditing standards and benchmarks specific to the EU context.
Common audit approaches and methodologies increase the Court's ability to rely on the work of national control authorities, provided the quality of that work is directly demonstrated.
EU BUDGET REVIEW In September 2007, the Commission published a consultation paper to launch an open debate on EU finances as part of a wide-ranging budget review.
At the beginning of April 2008, the Court presented its contribution to the debate, in which it outlined the main principles to be taken into account when designing new programs so that they have European added value in terms of clarity of objectives, a quest for simplification, a sense of reality , transparency and accountability.
Among other things, the Court recommended that the following aspects be taken into account: • • • • targeting spending programs not by input but by output; better use of the concept of tolerable risk in the design and adoption of spending programmes; degree of discretion to be granted to national or regional authorities in the management of spending programs and the related accounting; Considering whether the VAT resource is still a useful part of the own resources system, arguing for a review of all compensation mechanisms, guided by the guiding principles of the own resources system: fairness, transparency, cost-effectiveness, simplicity and contributing capacity of each Member State . 29
30 THE COURT'S WORK IN 2007 AND BEYOND AUDIT WORK DONE IN 2007 Each year the Court sets out its future audit work in a work program submitted to the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament and publicly available on the Court's website.
The Court monitors the implementation of the work program as a basis for improvements in subsequent years.
2007 was marked by a significant increase in the number of adopted specific annual reports on the European Agencies and other decentralized bodies.
The number of special reports and opinions was similar to that of previous years.
The annual reports on the general budget and the European Development Funds were published as planned.
Results (number) 2004 2005 2006 2007 Special reports 10 6 11 9 Annual reports (including EDF) 1 1 1 1 Special annual reports 23 20 23 29 Opinions 2 11 8 9 In the field of financial and compliance audit (checking the observance of legislation), the Court applied its new assurance model for the first time in 2007 in order to obtain sufficiently robust results in the most efficient way.
The Court also decided to provide more detailed information on the results of its Statement of Assurance, in particular on the results of the individual transaction test.
In the Court's view, this provides useful information for monitoring purposes, together with a schematic presentation of the results of the systems assessments, against which progress in financial management can be measured.
ACTION PLAN AND PEER REVIEW PROCESS The Court constantly seeks improvements in all aspects of its work.
In 2005 the Court decided to undergo a peer review process.
It involves senior officials from a small number of SAIs assessing the organization or results of a sister body against professional standards and against the background of their respective professional experience.
Since all supreme audit institutions have similar responsibilities, peer review processes can provide an invaluable contribution to the improvement of audit bodies.
In preparation for the peer review process, the Court carried out a self-assessment in 2006, which gave the institution an opportunity to identify its strengths and weaknesses.
In 2007 the Court adopted an action plan to address the weaknesses identified.
The plan covered a total of 23 actions, six of which were the subject of task forces involving members of the Court and staff from different areas and levels of the institution: Organization 3. Internal performance indicators 4. People and internal communication 5. External stakeholders and communication approaches, external communication strategy 6. Improving the quality of reports The results of these task forces presented in 2007 included new statements of mission, mission and values and strategic goals for the Court, a new strategy and guidelines for internal communications and a report on ways to improve reporting quality. The peer review process started at the end of 2007.
QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE IMPROVEMENT OF AUDIT WORK Several of the strategic objectives adopted concern the institution's output.
The Court strives to make the impact of its audits more visible through the selection of relevant topics, timeliness and making its reports clearer and more reader-friendly.
It has also started to increase the number of its performance audits and improve their quality.
In 2007, considerable efforts were made to further develop the methodological basis of the Court's work, which is essential for high-quality audit work.
A new manual for financial and compliance audits was developed with a great deal of work and is due to be completed in 2008.
The Court's new performance audit manual was adopted at the end of 2006 and was therefore available to the auditors for guidance for the first time in 2007.
To further improve the quality of the Court's performance audit work, additional guidelines have been developed and a number of seminars and training events have been held.
In addition, the Court set new ambitious targets for the use of information technologies.
In the new IT strategy adopted in 2007, the Court announces its intention to increase its capacity to perform IT audits and to make the use of Computer Assisted Audit Techniques (CAATs) common practice in financial and performance audits .
It is important that the quantity and quality of the Court's output can be properly assessed.
The Court is in the process of developing performance indicators which should allow it to provide a variety of performance data in future annual activity reports.
For the future, the Court plans to develop a methodology to assess the institution's cost-effectiveness. 32
33 The Court's 30th anniversary In 2007, the European Court of Auditors celebrated its 30th anniversary as the external audit body of the European Union.
The celebrations began with an increased presence of the Court (seminars, information stands, etc.) in most European Union capitals as part of Europe Day 2007 activities.
In addition, on October 17, 2007, an exhibition entitled "30 years of the Court of Auditors" was opened, which included a series of thematic display boards, an audiovisual slideshow with more than 150 photos and video excerpts, and numerous documents.
The Luxembourg central bank issued a silver commemorative coin to mark the occasion.
On 18 October 2007, the European Court of Auditors organized a seminar entitled 'The Future of Public Audit in the EU', which was attended by a number of high-level experts from EU circles and executives from the institution.
IMPROVING NON-AUDIT ASPECTS AT THE COURT Many of the tasks envisaged in the Action Plan relate to communication, to which increased efforts were devoted in 2007.
Among other things, a new website was launched, information material on the annual report was published in a more accessible format, and the Court approved a new procedure for presenting its special reports to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control.
Other developments, most of which were directly or partly linked to the action plan, concerned the modernization of the Court's accounting system and new policy documents in the areas of human resources and IT.
The Court also started modernizing its information systems in the areas of audit, translation, knowledge and communication, management information and human resources.
In addition, in 2007 the Court made progress in preparing for a second extension of its main building, necessitated by recent and planned staff growth.
AUDIT WORK TO BE DONE IN 2008 7 In 2008, as in previous years, the Court will present, in addition to its annual report on the general budget of the EU, an annual report on the European Development Funds and specific annual reports on the European agencies and other bodies.
The planning of expenditure within the framework of the general budget of the EU takes place in seven-year cycles, so-called financial frameworks.
2007 was the first year of the new financial framework, which focuses on the implementation of the political strategies.
The Court takes this opportunity to dwell on an earlier innovation, namely the Commission's move to activity-based budgeting and management and the breakdown of the budget into 31 policy areas with around 220 activities.
The annual report for the financial year 2007 is structured into groups of policy areas, which are largely, but not entirely, based on the new headings of the financial framework.

36 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH THE EU'S NATIONAL AUDIT BODIES According to the EC Treaty, the European Court of Auditors is to carry out its audit in "liaison" with the Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) of the Member States, while the Amsterdam Treaty later added: "The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies work together in a spirit of trust while maintaining their independence.” This rule was extended in the Treaty of Nice by expressly requesting the Court of Auditors in the 18th declaration of the Final Act to set up a committee for contacts with the national audit bodies, in which all SAI- Presidents and the Court meet annually to discuss matters of common interest.
Ongoing contacts are maintained by the liaison officers appointed by each SAI.
Working groups have been set up to help develop common positions and approaches.
In 2007, a delegation from the Court attended the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of Presidents of SAIs of the European Union in Helsinki on 3 and 4 December, hosted by the Finnish Court of Accounts.
The session focused on “Risk management, acceptable risk and integrated internal control in the management of EU funds” and discussed the role of SAIs in this area.
The Court will host the next Contact Committee meeting on 1-2 December 2008.
In 2007, two Liaison Officers meetings were held in preparation for the Contact Committee meeting.
The first meeting took place on 23rd and 24th April in The Hague and the second on 11th and 12th October in Luxembourg, chaired by the European Court of Auditors.
Both sessions discussed recent developments in EU financial management and highlighted the work of the Cooperation Task Force, which looks at the Contact Committee itself, how it works and how it can be improved; in this context, suggestions were made for a more efficient design of work processes.
The meeting also covered the activities of the various working and expert groups set up by the Contact Committee to deal with specific issues of common interest.
The Court attended meetings of the network of candidate countries and candidate countries 'in the future' (Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Turkey).
The Presidents of the SAIs of the candidate and future candidate countries and the European Court of Auditors met on 11 and 12 June 2007 in Skopje (former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia).
An important aspect in any effort to improve practical cooperation in auditing EU funds concerns the auditing principles used.
Against this background, the Contact Committee decided in 2006 to set up a working group, chaired by one of the Court's Members, Mr Josef Bonnici, to "develop common auditing standards and comparable auditing benchmarks based on internationally recognized auditing principles and adapted to the EU context (... ) should develop".
In 2007, the first meetings took place at the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
In December 2007, a progress report from the working group was presented to the Helsinki Contact Committee and a related resolution was adopted.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active involvement and contribution to the improvement of international auditing standards through its membership of European and international public audit organizations, namely Eurosai and Intosai respectively.
Within the framework of Eurosai, the Court is represented in the environmental working group and in the IT working group and participates in the Eurosai training committee.
The Court hosted a seminar entitled “Analysis of the most common IT problems faced by SAIs” in Luxembourg on 17 and 18 April 2007 and a seminar entitled “Performance Audit – where do we stand?” on 4 and 6 December 2007 .
Since becoming a full member of Intosai in 2004, the Court has actively participated in the Subcommittee on Financial Audit Guidelines (FAS), the Subcommittee on Legal Compliance Auditing (CAS) and the Subcommittee on Performance Auditing (PAS).
The Court attended all FAS meetings held in 2007 and provided active input into the guidance issued and addressed.
The FAS appointed the ECA representative (Mr. Jesús Lázaro Cuenca) as one of the FAS representatives for the Professional Standards Committee Steering Committee project on Audit Quality. The Court also attended the January 2007 CAS meeting in New Delhi.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate provided resources for the linguistic revision of a document in Spanish and German.
Furthermore, the court on the XIX. Intosai Congress (Incosai) from November 5th to 10th, 2007 in Mexico, where two main topics were discussed: "Government Debt, its Management, Accountability and Audit" and "Evaluation Systems of Performance by Commonly Accepted Key Indicators - Targets and Performance Indicators". “.
In 2008, the Court will continue its active participation in the Eurosai and Intosai working groups, seminars and meetings.

38 HUMAN RESOURCES HUMAN RESOURCES The Court's most important asset is its people.
They come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recent modernization of human resources policy has focused on recruitment, training, career development and improving working conditions.

The visits are usually to central and local authorities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as to the respective final recipients.
Audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners and the length of an audit trip can be up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance.
In 2007, travel expenses related to audit trips amounted to EUR 0.49 million (compared to EUR 0.43 million in 2006).
This represents a significant investment to ensure adequate audit coverage of all levels and locations of EU funds management.

43 BOX 6 - THE FISHERIES REPORT - RESULT OF A SUCCESSFUL TEAM EFFORT The report adopted by the Court in 2007 on the systems of surveillance, inspection and sanctions in fisheries resources (Special Report No. 7/2007) excited both policy makers and business communities media attention.
Articles in numerous newspapers and the rapid response from both the Commission and the Council proved the relevance and timeliness of the report.
The starting point of this success was a team of a dozen auditors from the Court, working closely with the rapporteur, Mr Kikis Kazamias, and his cabinet.
Mr Emmanuel Rauch, a French auditor who has worked at the Court for several years, and his Spanish colleague Mr Alejandro Ballester were the audit team leaders during the preparatory phase in autumn 2005.
The audit included trips to six Member States, from Denmark to Italy, both to central managing authorities to gain insight into the control systems and to the main ports to assess how the systems work in practice.
Where the language skills of the team members were not sufficient, translators from the Court's language service provided assistance.
The audit team is very proud to have contributed to ensuring that policy makers begin to realize the serious consequences of the way in which the Community fisheries policy is implemented.
Other auditing bodies have also shown interest in the audit because it provides suggestions and know-how, for example, for an upcoming audit on a similar topic in the Baltic Sea countries.

INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE The Court's internal audit service aims to help the Court achieve its objectives through a systematic, methodical assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes suggestions to increase the efficiency of the Court.
In general, it is about assessing the performance of individual departments in the implementation of strategies, programs and measures with the aim of continuous improvement.
In 2007 the Court's internal audit service focused on the financial audit (including supporting the work of the Court's external auditor), the audit of the ex ante verification, the implementation of the internal control standards, the most recent extension of the farm (the so-called K2 building) and the recruitment procedures of the farm.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert, oversees the work of the internal auditor and ensures his independence.
It also examines and approves the work program and reports of the internal auditor and assigns specific audit tasks to the auditor when the need arises.
The Committee met eight times in 2007.

FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT The Court of Auditors, as the EU's independent audit body, makes a unique contribution to improving EU financial management and promoting transparency and accountability by providing audit services and setting an example.
For the Court, 2008 was marked by a significant number of significant advances and important developments in the area of EU financial management, which are detailed in this annual activity report.
A defining event was the peer review of the European Court of Auditors by an international panel of experts, which led to a positive conclusion on the adequacy of the Court's audit management framework and on the independence and objectivity of its work.
In its annual report for the financial year 2007, published in November 2008, the Court gave for the first time an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the EU accounts.
However, as in previous years, it found excessive rates of legality and regularity error in the areas of the EU budget that account for the bulk of spending.
In 2008, the Court also acknowledged developments at EU and national level that should lead to significant improvements in EU financial management in the future.
Two examples given in this annual activity report concern the ongoing process of reviewing the EU budget, to which the Court has contributed actively, and the communication on the tolerable risk of error issued by the Commission.
In the area of international relations, the Court took the lead in organizing the deliberations of the Contact Committee of Presidents of Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) of the European Union on EU budget reform and the revised Lisbon Strategy, and hosted a recent workshop on the role of the EU SAIs in the context of response to the current financial crisis.
The rapidly changing nature of its audit environment prompts the Court to adapt through internal reforms in order to better meet its Treaty obligations and effectively fulfill its mandate.
A significant step taken by the Court in 2008 to fulfill its mandate and mission statement was the development of an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012.
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximizing the overall impact of audits and improving efficiency by making best use of resources.
These objectives will inform the Court's work programs over the period, as well as its efforts to continuously improve and capitalize on the key challenges and opportunities identified in the peer review process in terms of realizing potential for improvement.
Thanks to their competence and commitment, the Court's staff plays a central role in carrying out the audit work that the Court carries out as the independent guardian of citizens' financial interests with a view to improving financial management.
On behalf of the court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all the staff for their commitment and professional work over the past year.
Special thanks go to our former Secretary General, Mr. Michel Hervé, who left at the end of 2008 for his personal commitment and commitment.
I hope you enjoy reading this Annual Activity Report, which provides an insight into the Court and an overview of the activities carried out in 2008.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
MISSION, MISSION AND VALUES MISSION According to the Treaty, the European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances.
MISSION An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognized for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, offering valuable support to its constituency with a view to improving EU financial management.
VALUES Independence, integrity and impartiality Independence, integrity and impartiality for the body, its members and staff.
Professionalism Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Value Produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports that are based on sound evidence and evidence, serve the interests of the audience, and contain important and meaningful messages.
Excellence and Efficiency Recognizing the worth of the individual, supporting the development of special skills and rewarding performance.
THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK THE COURT'S WORK STARTS WITH THE EU BUDGET The budget of the European Union is around €120 billion, which is around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities. The total budget volume corresponds approximately to the GNI of some member states.
The European Union's revenues mainly consist of Member States' contributions derived from their gross national income (GNI - 65.4%) or based on the Value Added Tax (VAT - 16.9%) levied by the Member States.
Customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources – 16.5%) also account for a significant part of revenues.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agriculture and cohesion policies being the main spending areas (see Box 1).
BOX 1  HOW DOES THE EU SPEND ITS MONEY?
The EU budget is financed from financial contributions from Member States (mainly based on national GNI) and from customs and agricultural duties.
The EU budget is largely used for different purposes than national budgets, partly due to different areas of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a significant part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural spending, usually in the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has represented the major part of budgetary spending, albeit currently on a decreasing trend.
In 2009, 45.3% of the budget is earmarked for conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development.
Since the 1980s, a significant part of spending has gone to cohesion policies, ie regional and social development. This involves co-financing a wide variety of projects – from road construction projects in Poland to training measures for the unemployed in Spain.
39.6% of the budget is foreseen to be spent on sustainable growth in 2009, with the lion's share going to cohesion measures.
This budget area also includes the bulk of EU research funding.
In addition, significant amounts of EU funds go to development and humanitarian aid, as well as to countries that have close ties with the Union or are candidate countries.
6.7% of the budget is used for the administration of the Community institutions.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union as a global player Administration Agriculture - Preservation and management of natural resources 45.3% 1.2% 7.2% 6.7% EU spending Cohesion - Sustainable growth Source: General budget of the European Union for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009). 39.6%
The budget is determined annually – on the basis of a seven-year financial framework – by the Council, ie representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission draws up the budget and is also responsible for its implementation.
The major part of the budget - especially in the area of expenditure for agricultural and cohesion policy - is implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community spending is the high percentage of payments that are based on corresponding claims from the beneficiaries themselves, be they farmers or project managers anywhere in the Union. 8th
Democratic societies require complete and accurate publicly available information to inform discussion and decision-making, both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
Like its Member States, the EU has an external audit body that plays the role of an independent guardian of citizens' financial interests.
In its capacity as the EU's external auditor, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds, wherever they are used, are correctly accounted for and spent in accordance with the law, with due regard to the best use of funds.
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as by the Member States to improve EU financial management.
The Court's work forms an important basis for the annual discharge procedure, during which Parliament decides, based on recommendations from the Council, whether the Commission has fulfilled its responsibility for the implementation of the budget in the previous year.
Despite its name, the court has no judicial powers.
In the budget areas under shared management, Member States work with the Commission to set up supervisory and control systems - ie internal control - to ensure that funds are used appropriately and according to the rules.
Internal control thus has both a European and a national dimension.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities audit EU funds where they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
9 OVERVIEW OF INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF THE EU BUDGET EU level Internal control External control Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) European Court of Auditors Member States Implementing bodies National control authorities National level
(Performance Audit) HOW DOES THE COURT REPORT ITS RESULTS?
The Court publishes the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: Annual Reports - containing the results of the financial audit in the form of a Statement of Assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on the activities of the European Development Funds3.
Special annual reports - containing the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and bodies of the Communities.
Special reports - with the results of selected profitability or Compliance Checks.
10 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 Under the EC Treaty, the Court is required to issue such a statement - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In this context, the underlying transactions are usually payments to the final beneficiaries from the EU budget.
The annual declaration of assurance is commonly known by the French acronym DAS (“Déclaration d'Assurance”).
Contrary to the practice in the Member States, the Court makes such a statement on the EU budget as a whole.
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based on both international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries
The Court conducts its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA), which apply to both the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing standards do not fully cover the compliance audit performed by the Court.
Together with the national control authorities, the Court is actively involved in the further development of international auditing standards promoted by the standardization bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to provide assurance that payments comply with the legal and regulatory framework, the Court relies on the results of both its examination of the supervisory and control systems designed to prevent or detect and correct errors of legality and regularity and one Sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
When systems are checked and found to be reliable, the number of transactions that the Court has to examine in order to reach a valid conclusion as to their legality and regularity is correspondingly reduced.
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In performing performance audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess the management and control systems and to evaluate the performance data against the criteria derived from the legislation with a view to the principles of sound financial management.
In selecting the topics for our performance audits, the Court endeavors to identify audit areas where the greatest impact is expected in terms of demonstrated potential for improvement in terms of economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending. 11 were concluded, as well as Council decisions on the association of Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see policy group External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
The investment facilities under the EDFs are managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and are not subject to the Court's audit mandate.
4 INTOSAI (International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions – IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Federation of Accountants.
12 BOX 2  THE COURT'S ON-THE-SPOT AUDITS OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU BUDGET The Court does not have the resources to audit all transactions financed from the EU budget in detail.
In connection with the preparation of the DAS, he therefore uses statistical sampling methods to obtain a result that is representative of the population as a whole.
The sample is selected by randomly selecting a representative sample of underlying transactions from all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, for detailed examination.
The Court traces these transactions down to the final recipient of the aid, such as a farmer in France.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks – e.g. B. Measurement of the size of the agricultural area - to determine whether the relevant information in the funding application corresponds to the actual circumstances.
Due to the fact that it is a statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the relevant population, ie a specific income or expenditure area, and together with information resulting from the system evaluation can serve as the basis for an auditor's overall assessment.
In practice, to determine what the audit opinion should be, the Court compares the results of its audits of statistical samples to a certain upper limit that we consider reasonable – the so-called materiality threshold.
Random selection of a representative sample Payment to an agricultural holding in France Population of payments in the agricultural sector
GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATION STRUCTURE OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, with one member from each Member State.
All audit reports and opinions are accepted by the College.
The court is divided into five audit groups to which individual members are assigned.
As shown in the organization chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budget areas (Conservation and Management of Natural Resources - Structural Policies, Transport, Research and Energy - External Policies - Revenue, Banking Activities, Administrative Expenditure, Institutions and Bodies of the Community and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or Coordination, Communication, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development) is responsible for 'horizontal' issues such as coordination on the Statement of Assurance, quality assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a management committee is responsible for the preparatory work of all administrative matters requiring a formal decision by the Court.
THE MEMBERS The members of the Court are appointed by the Council, after consultation of the European Parliament, on the basis of proposals from each Member State for a six-year term; Re-election is permitted.
The members carry out their activities in full independence for the general good of the European Union.
In addition to their function within the college, which is responsible for the final decision-making on audits and opinions as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each member is responsible for their specific tasks, primarily in the audit area.
The actual examination work is usually the task of the examiners in the individual examination departments and is coordinated by the responsible member with the support of his cabinet.
The member then takes on the task of presenting the report to the audit group or to the Court and, after its adoption, to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
On January 1, 2008, three new members - Mr. Michel Cretin (France), Mr. Harald Noack (Germany) and Mr. Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) - succeeded their respective predecessors at the end of their term of office.
In addition, the mandates of four members - Mr Hubert Weber (Austria), Mr Maarten B. Engwarta (Netherlands), Mr David Bostock (United Kingdom) and Mr Ioannis Sarmas (Greece) - were renewed by the Council for a period of six years.
THE PRESIDENT The European Court of Auditors is headed by the President, who is elected by the members from among their number for a term of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The President represents the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, the other institutions of the European Union and the supreme audit institutions of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, the Portuguese Member, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, was elected the Court's tenth President. 14
THE SECRETARY-GENERAL The Secretary-General is the most senior official of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years; Re-election is permitted.
The Secretary-General is responsible for the administration of the Court's staff and affairs, including professional development and the Translation Directorate, with one unit for each official language (22), excluding Irish.
The Secretary General is also responsible for the Secretariat of the Court.
The former Secretary General, Mr Michel Hervé, left the Court on October 31, 2008.
On October 9, 2008, Mr. John Speed was appointed Secretary General mdWdGb.
On 10 March 2009 the Court appointed Mr Eduardo Ruiz García as the new Secretary-General with effect from 16 March 2009. THE COURT'S STAFF The 2008 budget foresees 858 posts (at 31 December 2008) for the European Court of Auditors.
The Court's auditors have a wide range of educational backgrounds and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, particularly in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, law and economics.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States. The staff is subject to the EU Staff Regulations.

OVERVIEW OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS5 ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2007 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET The annual accounts give a true and fair view of the financial position and the results of the EU in all material respects.
The qualifications expressed in last year's annual report on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 are no longer valid for 2007 because of the improvements made in the meantime.
In some areas, such as the Union's administrative expenditure, the Court gives unqualified opinions on legality and regularity.
However, the Court cannot give an unqualified opinion on most areas of spending.
Although most of the payments audited by the Court were made in compliance with the legislation, the Court still considers the level of error in payments to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and promoters of EU-funded projects, to be too high.
With the exception of the cohesion actions, which have an error rate of at least 11%, the Court's estimated error rate for these policy groups is between 2% and 5%.
In some areas of spending, notably those formerly falling under internal and external policies respectively, the estimated level of error has fallen, but not so much as to change the overall picture.
The result does not imply that these breaches of the law are due to fraud or that most operations in these areas are illegal and/or irregular.
THE SITUATION IN SPECIFIC AREAS In three areas – administrative and other expenditure, economic and financial, and revenue – the Court's audits of a representative sample of transactions have shown low estimated levels of error.
In the Union's largest spending area - agriculture and natural resources - the estimated total error rate remains material.
Rural development, with its often complex regulations, accounts for a disproportionate share of this error rate.
For European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) expenditure, the value of the Court's estimated level of error is just below the 2 % materiality threshold.
As in previous years, the area most affected by error is cohesion measures, which account for more than a third of the budget.
Based on the Court's sample estimation of the proportion of transactions affected by errors, at least 11 % of the total amount of reimbursements should not have been paid.
5 This section introduces the Court's reports and opinions rather than summarizing them.
For more information, see the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
19 WAYS TO IMPROVE MONITORING AND CONTROL The high level of error in areas such as cohesion is partly due to the inherent risk of the large number of beneficiaries applying for EU funding under complex schemes and legislation.
The deficiencies in the design and functioning of the systems also contribute to the deficits identified.
Most programs financed with EU funds contain corrective action provisions, which provide for the recovery, on a multiannual basis, of funds unduly paid due to errors.
However, no information is available on the impact of these measures.
This means that it cannot be specifically established whether they are effective in reducing the proportion of illegal and/or irregular expenditure.
The Commission has been working on a reform program to improve the management of the EU budget since 2000, which includes a 2006 action plan.
By the end of 2007, the Commission had implemented two thirds of the sub-measures from the action plan.
However, it is still too early to assess the impact of these measures.
Improved high-level controls – such as the Commission's monitoring of Member States' control activities – cannot compensate for poor lower-level controls such as on-the-spot checks.
However, the benefits of carrying out more on-the-spot checks must be weighed against the costs.
The Court recommends that the political authorities of the Union define what level of risk of error would be appropriate.
To reduce the error rate in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying rules and legislation, streamlining internal control measures and improving monitoring and reporting.

19 BOX 4  INTERPRETATION OF OPINIONS An auditor can issue the following types of opinions: • an unqualified opinion when there is evidence that the accounts are reliable or the underlying transactions, ie payments, are legal and regular, in all material respects; • negative opinion when the level of error in the underlying transactions is material and pervasive or the accounts are unreliable; • Denial of an opinion when the auditor is unable to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support his or her opinion and the potential impact is both material and widespread; • Qualified opinion, when an unqualified opinion cannot be given, but the implications of the disagreement or limitations in scope are not so material or extensive that they require a negative opinion or a disagreement with the opinion.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2008 The Court also helps improve EU financial management by providing opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the process of adopting financial regulations7 or may be given at the request of one of the other Community institutions8.
In addition, the Court can issue opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions can cover issues relating to specific areas of EU spending, such as the amendment to the Financial Regulation of the European Aviation Safety Agency (No 1/2008), or issues relating to EU revenue, such as the amendment to the Regulation on the system of the Communities' own resources (No. 2/2008).
Opinions draw on the Court's expertise in EU financial management issues, acquired over the years through its audits, and in some cases reference is made to specific audits or opinions.
For example, in its opinion on the new financial regulation of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor), the Court refers to its annual report for the financial year 2006, in which it had already drawn attention to high risks regarding the legality and regularity of payments for research aid .
