FOLLOW-UP AND IMPACT Public audit plays a central role in promoting accountability and makes a useful contribution to public debate.
Audit activities account for those at the end of the information chain, in this case European citizens, on whether their taxpayers' money is being spent properly and appropriately.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for the decision-makers in the institutions concerned – primarily the Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States in the European context.
They can take action based on this information, with or without reference to the audit conclusions.
Whilst the Court's audit work has its main impact through the published reports, some impact is made throughout the audit itself.
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results are evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their political task of monitoring the use of the budget.
As part of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form a basis for the relevant Council recommendation and Parliament decision.
29 Examples of this can be found in the 2007 budget discharge procedure, where the European Parliament calls on the Commission and Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules in order to reduce the risk of error, tighten controls and reduce costs.
This applies both to areas with shared management - such as spending on agricultural and cohesion measures - and to areas with direct management - such as spending on research or on culture and education.
The special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, due to the fact that they are published throughout the year, the presentation of the special reports and their discussion in Parliament and Council meetings have usually taken place earlier.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by promoting them in the relevant media, which attracts more attention and stimulates public discussion.
The media coverage of the Court's annual report is generally quite extensive, although some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
An example of this is the special report on cross-compliance (No. 8/2008) published at the time of the adoption of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) Health Check.
Due to the importance of the cross-compliance regulation and its central role within the CAP, as well as due to the timing of its publication, the report received a wide response in the various media: television, newspapers, specialist press, Internet publications (press, agricultural associations, MEP websites, web blogs, etc.).
The report was also discussed extensively in the European Parliament and almost all of the Court's recommendations were taken up in the draft discharge report.
Details of the Court's follow-up to previous observations are provided in the relevant chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequent observation in its last annual report is that, despite the action taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially addressed.
The Court intends to increasingly analyze the long-term implications of its work, both audits and opinions.
As an example, the Court uses a Commission database of the follow-up to its audit recommendations as a basis for assessing the impact of its audits.
The assessment may trigger separate in-depth reviews leading to further findings and recommendations.
These may feed into a subsequent special report on the area concerned, or be recorded in a report on follow-up and the impact of recommendations on financial management.
THE COURT'S POSITION THE CONCEPT OF TOLERABLE RISK OF ERROR In relation to the development of a Community internal control framework, the Court, in its Opinion No 2/2004, considered that when approving EU spending rules the level of the to decide the risks they are willing to accept.
The Court suggested that Parliament and Council should agree on a reasonable balance between the costs and benefits of controls, in other words on the tolerable residual risk of errors in expenditure.
The cost of controls should be proportionate to the monetary and political benefits they bring.
Since the publication of this opinion, both the European Parliament and the Council have expressed in their discharge resolutions the wish to follow up the issue and to reach a common understanding of the tolerable level of risk.
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a Communication entitled Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerable risk of error.
The Court welcomed this communication and sent a reply to the Commission identifying certain limitations and setting out the main issues to be considered in future follow-up of this issue.
In its Communication, the Commission states that any decision on a tolerable risk of error should be based, among other things, on the potential for further simplification.
The Court also highlights the importance and benefits of further simplification and the potential impact on reducing errors and irregularities.
The concept of "tolerable risk of error" should be clearly separated from the notion of materiality threshold as defined and applied by the Court. The latter is the responsibility of the external auditor10.
In the Court's view, cost-benefit analysis of spending programs could provide information not only for discussions about tolerable risk, but also for reviewing the regulatory framework and governance of the programs concerned.
In this context, the relevant question may not be whether there is a tolerable risk of error, but whether the risk of error is so high that the scheme or program in question should be abolished/discontinued or fundamentally modified.
Specific attention should also be paid to the concept of tolerable risk when designing spending (and revenue) schemes or programmes.
It would be useful if spending programs had sufficient information, at the time of their adoption, of the risks involved and the cost of the controls envisaged to reduce those risks to an acceptable level.
In this way decisions would be made in an informed manner and with explicit consideration of the risks and costs involved.
The budgetary reform process may provide an opportunity for reflection on this issue, as suggested by the Court in its reply to the Commission's communication 'Reform the budget, transforming Europe'11.
31 10 The term "materiality" is defined in the international auditing standard ISA 320 as follows: "Information is material if its omission or misstatement could influence the economic decisions made on the basis of financial statements by users of financial statements.
Materiality depends on the magnitude of the item or error arising from the particular circumstances of the omission or misrepresentation.
Thus, materiality is more of a threshold or threshold than a primary qualitative requirement that information must have in order to be useful.” 11 See the European Court of Auditors' response to the Commission's Communication 'Reform the budget, transform Europe', April 2008

AUDIT STRATEGY The audit strategy is based on the Court's strategic objectives.
33 STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES Professionalism Output Audience Development and growth Established auditing methods, appropriate auditing strategy, further development of auditing practice in the public sector, development of common auditing standards and comparable auditing standards for EU funds, cooperation with EU SAIs, effective "community control framework" selection of relevant auditing topics, Timeliness, clarity and readability of reports, quality of performance audits, increasing the impact of reports. The aim of the audits we carry out and the reports we produce is to help improve EU financial management and protect the EU's financial interests for the benefit of EU citizens.
The following key aspects are taken into account when formulating the strategy underlying the Court's activities: IMPACT EFFICIENCY Reports Audit work Work program In 2008, the Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 in order to implement its mandate and mission statement.
A summary of this document is available on the Court's website.
The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximizing the overall impact of audits and improving efficiency by making best use of resources.
These objectives will have a major impact on the Court's work programs over the period and its efforts to continuously improve.
The Court aims to maximize the overall impact of its audits over the period in question by: • selecting and designing audits that focus on risk-related issues and are of most interest to the Court's audience; • continue to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement, and follow up on whether these suggestions are implemented; • conduct a wider range of audits and produce new types of audit products to complement current annual and special reports; • created a larger number of special reports and improved their timeliness and user-friendliness; • further develops its relations with its key stakeholders, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public. The Court aims to improve efficiency over the period in question by making the best use of its resources.
These include: • better governance; • an effective and dynamic human resources policy; • the rationalization of examination tasks; • the improvement of IT tools; • the development of professional competence; • developing relationships with the auditees. 34
AUDIT WORK TO BE CARRIED OUT IN 200912 As in previous years, the work program for 2009 includes the preparation of annual reports presenting the results of the financial audits that the Court is required to carry out under the EC Treaty and other EU legislation.
For 2009, the Court has identified a number of audit topics relating to policy developments and EU financial management issues.
In terms of developments in EU policies, the following themes have been selected: • growth and employment; • climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as a global partner; • better regulation.
In addition, in the area of EU financial management, the Court highlights the following issues, which it considers deserve special attention: • the completion of the 2000-2006 spending programmes, particularly in the area of the Structural Funds; • EU accountability and reform; • Progress of the Commission's action plan towards an integrated internal control framework, taking into account the concept of tolerable risk; • Management and control measures at Member State level.
The Court aims to cover these issues in its annual reports, special reports and some new report types (see below) from 2009 onwards.
The Court intends to publish a series of special reports and related novel reports based on the audit tasks it has selected.
The planning and implementation of these selected audit tasks and the related reporting usually extend over a period of more than one year.
Therefore, most reports published in a given year are based on audit work initiated in previous years.
Box 5 contains the selected audit tasks that have been completed or are nearing completion and the results of which are therefore expected to be published in special reports in 2009 or early 2010.

The follow-up to the recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management.

DEVELOPING AND IMPROVING ACTION PLAN AND PEERREVIEW PROCESS In 2006 the Court carried out a self-assessment which identified its strengths and weaknesses.
An action plan to eliminate the vulnerabilities was then drawn up.
The Action Plan comprised a series of actions, as a result of which the Court: • defined its mission statement, its mission, its strategic objectives and its strategic planning; • developed internal performance indicators that will be phased in (see section below); • Adopted an internal communication strategy, which is already being implemented and which has opened up new channels for better dissemination of information within the institution; • took various measures to improve the quality of its reports, such as a new graphic design to improve readability and external evaluations; • Adopted a progressive strategy to improve the Court's relations with its stakeholders, the press and the general public.
In 2009, as part of its efforts to improve, the Court will endeavor to take up the observations and recommendations made in the international peer review report on the European Court of Auditors published in December 2008, which is an important stage in the Court's ongoing reform process.
The peer review was carried out by representatives of the national control authorities of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal.
The peers carried out their work in 2008 and in this context also contacted the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament. The final report was presented at the end of 2008.
The aim of the peer review process was to assess the design and functioning of the Court's audit framework.
The review covered the following areas: • planning and auditing procedures for financial and performance audits; • reporting on the test results; • Services that support the Court in achieving its objectives.
The peer review team concluded that the design of the Court's audit framework is consistent with international auditing standards and good practice for SAIs.
The peers also noted that: • the Court conducts its work independently and objectively; • the Court's audit reports are based on sufficient and appropriate audit evidence as required by international auditing standards; • the stakeholders interviewed place a high level of trust in the Court's reports and generally find them to be fair, factual and objective.
The Court welcomes the peers' constructive comments and recommendations, identifying ways in which it can further strengthen its role as Supreme Audit Institution and highlighting the challenges involved.
These include the need to: • develop a culture that focuses on a consistent approach by the Court as an audit body; • Strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities with the aim of coherent interpretation and application of its audit strategies and methods; • Develop risk-based audit strategies to best use resources to meet the diverse needs of stakeholders.
The peer review report acknowledges that most of the recommendations contained in the pre-process action plan have already been anticipated.
The Court intends to include the remaining recommendations in its audit strategy for 2009-2012, following exchanges with its staff and stakeholders, and will endeavor to implement them during this period.
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS INTERNATIONAL PEER REVIEW OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS 38
KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008 the Court decided to introduce a system of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for its audit and non-audit activities to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and the targets set in the Annual Work Programme.
ZLI serve to strengthen internal and external accountability and to increase work efficiency and quality. The ZLI will be gradually introduced in 2009 and 2010.
WHY KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management on how successful the Court as an institution is in delivering on what it has set out to do; • to support the decision-making process by drawing the institution's attention to efficiency issues and encouraging improvements; • to provide information to the audience on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance.
They are intended to reflect the Court's performance as a 'company' and will become an integral part of the Court's management system.
The volume and quality of audit work can also be improved by considering the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They are being developed with a view to their inclusion in the Court's 2010 annual work programme.
As a test, the Court measured performance in 2008 using ZLI 5 and 6.
ALI 5 - Number of reports adopted versus number of reports planned In 2008 the Court adopted 79% of the number of reports planned.
The annual report and most of the special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the 20 special reports planned, only 12 were adopted.
As of December 31, 2008, the remaining eight special reports were still being drafted.
ALI 6 - Number of reports adopted on time In 2008 the Court adopted 73% of its reports on time.
The annual report and all special annual reports were approved on time; however, further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of special reports.
ZLI 7, which measures the number of key audit communications produced on time, will provide useful performance information and will be finalized in 2009.
A ZLI (8) covers aspects related to the Court's financial management.
Two ZLIs (9 and 10) are designed to improve staff satisfaction and optimize the use of CPD as a tool for ongoing updating of knowledge of the latest auditing methods and techniques.

INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH EU NATIONAL AUDIT BODIES According to the EC Treaty, the ECA is to carry out its audit in “liaison” with the Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs), while the Amsterdam Treaty later added: “The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies work together in a spirit of trust while preserving their independence.” This rule was extended in the Treaty of Nice by expressly requesting the Court of Auditors in the 18th declaration of the Final Act to set up a committee for contacts with the national audit bodies, in which all SAI Presidents and the Court meet annually to discuss matters of common interest.
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of EU SAI Presidents.
The session focused on the reform of the EU budget and the revised Lisbon strategy for the period 2008-2011.
The Contact Committee seeks to increase cooperation among its members in order to improve external audit and accountability in the EU area.
The role of the Contact Committee has evolved over the years in parallel with European integration.
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between SAIs and the ECA, this body has enabled significant advances in effective cooperation between the various control bodies.
At its 2007 meeting in Helsinki, the Contact Committee recognized the need to address emerging or new issues in a timely manner and agreed to provide a standing agenda item to address such topical issues.
Accordingly, at its 2008 meeting, the Contact Committee discussed the economic and financial crisis and agreed to hold a workshop on the role of EU SAIs in the context of the crisis.
A network was then set up to promote cooperation on audits related to the Lisbon Strategy and EU crisis management actions.
The Court attended meetings of the network of SAIs of candidate countries and candidate countries 'to be' (Turkey, Croatia, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Montenegro).
These meetings coincided with the Liaison Officers' meetings in May and October.
A delegation from the Court also attended a workshop on auditing/evaluation of systems of public internal finance organized by the network on 8 and 9 July in Ankara (Turkey).
Throughout 2008 the Court actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee.
The Working Group on Common Auditing Standards, which aims to develop common auditing standards and comparable auditing benchmarks tailored to the EU environment based on internationally recognized auditing principles, met four times in 2008, chaired by the Court.
With effect from December 2008, the ECA took over the (rotating) presidency of the working group on VAT and the agricultural expert network resumed its work, chaired by a member of the ECA.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and contribution to the improvement of international auditing standards and practices through its membership in European and international public audit organizations, namely EUROSAI and INTOSAI respectively.
A delegation from the Court attended the VII EUROSAI Congress, which took place in Kraków (Poland) from 2 to 5 June.
The main topics of discussion included the introduction of audit-related quality management systems in an SAI, the audit of social programs in the field of education and the professional integration of disabled people.
The President of the Court made a contribution on the role of senior management in establishing a quality management system for auditing.
Within the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the environmental working group and in the IT working group and participates in the EUROSAI training committee.
He also participates in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress to develop a guide to best practices for achieving quality in an SAI.
In addition, the Court is a member of the EUROSAI Task Force on Auditing Disaster Aid Funds. 42
At the EUROSAI Congress, the European Court of Auditors was appointed as auditor for the period 2009-2011 together with the Supreme Audit Institution of the Slovak Republic.
Since becoming a full member of INTOSAI in 2004, the Court has been an active contributor to the Subcommittee on Financial Audit Guidelines (FAS), the Subcommittee on Legal Compliance Auditing (CAS), and the Subcommittee on Performance Auditing (PAS).
The Court provided input to the subcommittee on promoting best practice and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews.
Since 2008, the ECA has chaired the Working Group on Accountability and Auditing of Disaster Relief (the successor body to the INTOSAI Tsunami Task Force).
A first meeting of this working group was organized by the Court as host from 30 June to 2 July 2008.
At this meeting, the draft work program for the period 2008-2010 was discussed and adopted.
The main objective is to develop guidance on accountability and auditing in this area, reaching out to all stakeholders through the appropriate standard setting body.
In addition to its coordinating role, the Court has taken responsibility for a number of tasks, two of them in cooperation with the Norwegian Court of Accounts.
Chairing this working group also means that the Court is represented in the meetings of the INTOSAI Governing Board. 43
Of the 857 staff (officials and temporary and contract staff but excluding members, seconded national experts and trainees) on active duty at 31 December 2008, 501 were examiners and assistant examiners, 163 were translators and 173 were administrative staff support duties and 20 in the services of the President.
They come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
For human resources, the court has defined the evaluation of the degree of satisfaction of the court's staff as a key performance indicator (ZLI 9).
A satisfaction survey was carried out to provide information on this topic and to support the decision-making process in this area.

In 2008 the Court recruited 97 staff: 48 officials, 18 temporary agents and 31 contract agents.

Due to the lack of suitable candidates, the Court was not able to recruit as many new staff as planned in many units, so the total number of vacancies (69) at the end of 2008 was higher than at the end of 2007.
However, it should be noted that towards the end of the year a significant number of hirings were in progress and these staff are expected to begin work during the first quarter of 2009.
The Court is currently trying to reduce the delays in its recruitment procedures.
TRANSLATION Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and to comply with its legal obligation to publish in 22 languages.
Translation volume increased by 17% in 2008, mainly due to the acceptance of a higher number of special reports.
The vast majority of translations are done in-house and during busy periods when the translation units exceed their normal capacity, translation work is outsourced to the Translation Center (CTOU) or to external translation agencies.
In addition, the translators take part in audit trips and support the auditors before, during and after the audit trips, including the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
The translators provide constant support in updating the content of the intranet and the website in English and French.
They also support INTOSAI working groups and meet other specific needs related to the Court's activities.
The Court's Translation Directorate actively participates in the work of the Interinstitutional Committee for Translation and Interpretation (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences related to the development of electronic tools for translation and documentation.
AUDIT VISITS The Court's audit work requires auditors to travel to Member States and other recipient countries of EU funds in order to obtain appropriate audit evidence.
The visits are usually to central and local authorities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as to the respective final recipients.
Audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners and the length of an audit trip can be up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in liaison with the SAIs of the visited Member State , which provide useful logistical and practical support. 47
In 2008, costs of 3.29 million euros were incurred in connection with examination trips.
This major investment is necessary to ensure adequate audit coverage of all levels and locations of EU fund management.
The graphs below give an overview of the number of audit missions carried out by the Court in 2008 in the EU Member States and outside the Union.

PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT The auditor's profession requires continuous development.
In 2008, the Court's staff completed an average of ten days of professional development.
The number of specialist training measures increased considerably compared to 2007.
In 2008 the Court increased its support for the participation of its staff in ongoing programs to acquire or maintain professional qualifications and degrees in external audit, internal audit and IT audit.
Language courses accounted for 48% of the total number of training days in 2008 (compared to 52% in 2007).
Excluding the language courses, the examiners completed seven days of professional training in 2008.
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective of “development and growth” and the master plan for training for the years 2008-2011 and the training pathways adopted in 2008, the Professional Training Unit has made improvements in the content of the training activities and new training courses in accordance with the priorities decided by the Court developed.
In addition, cooperation with the other institutions and interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration continued successfully.

4 FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT 4 Welcome to the European Court of Auditors' Annual Activity Report 2009.
The aim of this report is to provide readers with an overview of the main results and progress made by the Court during the year and also to inform them of the main developments in its audit environment and internal organisation.
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, marked by the election of a new European Parliament, the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and the start of the process of selecting a new European Commission.
The new treaty confirms the Court's role and mandate, its status as an EU institution, and introduces changes to the way EU funds are managed and controlled, reinforcing the role of the European Parliament and stressing Member States' responsibility for implementing the budget becomes.
We believe that these developments will present good opportunities to improve EU financial management.
The Court's view section summarizes our opinion on the risks and challenges that the new Commission will face.
Great importance is attached to improving the quality of EU spending.
We have made significant progress during the year in implementing our 2009-2012 audit strategy and towards achieving our goals of increasing the impact of our work and making better use of our resources.
A key step was our decision to submit new Rules of Procedure to the Council of the European Union for approval, designed to streamline our procedures for adopting reports and opinions.
In addition, the number of reports produced by the Court increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009.
I am also pleased to report that our flagship product, the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, has once again been well received by our key institutional stakeholders, who have endorsed many of our recommendations.
During 2009, the Court continued to work actively with Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) to develop common approaches to auditing EU funds and to reflect on how SAIs support governments in managing financial and economic challenges to support the economic crisis.
The Court's performance depends on the competence and motivation of its 880 employees.
Their satisfaction is a key factor in the farm's success and is quantified for the first time in this report.
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tireless and dedicated work in enabling the Court to fulfill its mission.

As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

8 THE COURT'S ROLE AND WORK 8 THE COURT'S WORK STARTS WITH THE EU BUDGET The budget (2010) of the European Union is around €123 billion, which represents around 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities and compared to the GNI of several Member States, the total budget is significant.
The European Union's revenue mainly consists of Member States' contributions derived from their gross national income (GNI - 76%), customs and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources - 12%) and a contribution based on those levied by the Member States Value Added Tax (VAT – 11%).
BOX 1 - WHAT DOES THE EU SPEND ITS MONEY ON?
The EU budget is financed from Member States' financial contributions (mainly based on national GNI), customs and agricultural duties and VAT contributions.
The EU budget is largely used for different purposes than national budgets, partly due to different areas of responsibility.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1.1% Preservation and management of natural resources (mainly agriculture) 47.3% The largest single area of EU spending is agriculture and rural development - primarily in the form of payments to farmers -, accounts for almost half of household expenditure.
Another big part is the Cohesion Actions - regional and social development - which co-finance a wide range of projects, from road projects in Latvia to training for the unemployed in the Netherlands.
This area accounts for about a third of household expenditure.
The European Union as a global player EU expenditure Source: General budget of the European Union for financial year 2010. Administration 6.4% 6.3% Sustainable growth (mainly cohesion) 38.8%
The budget is approved annually – on the basis of seven-year financial frameworks – by the Council, ie representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament.
The European Commission draws up the budget and is also responsible for its implementation.
Most of the budget - particularly in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure - is implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community spending is the high percentage of payments that are based on corresponding claims from the beneficiaries themselves, be they farmers or project managers anywhere in the Union. 9
10 WHAT ROLE DOES THE COURT?
Democratic societies need accurate, publicly available information to inform discussion and decision-making, both to improve financial management and to ensure accountability.
In its capacity as the EU's external auditor, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds are correctly accounted for, wherever they are spent, and that they have been spent in accordance with the relevant legislation and with due regard to the need for value for money.
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Commission, Parliament and Council, as well as by Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities audit EU funds where they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
OVERVIEW OF INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF THE EU BUDGET EU level Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing bodies European Court of Auditors National control authorities National level Internal control External control
(FINANCIAL AUDIT) 2. Are the financial operations in all material respects in accordance with the relevant legal and other regulatory framework?
(COMPLIANCE CHECK) 3. Is the financial management sound, ie has the use of resources been kept to a minimum (economy), have the results been achieved with the least possible use of resources (efficiency) and have the intended goals been achieved (effectiveness)?
The Court publishes the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: Annual Reports - containing the results of the financial audit in the form of a Statement of Assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on the activities of the European Development Funds3.
Special annual reports - containing the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and decentralized bodies of the Union.
11 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 The TFEU requires the Court to issue such a statement - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual declaration of assurance is commonly known by the French acronym DAS (“Déclaration d'Assurance”).
12 HOW DOES THE COURT APPROACH ITS AUDITS?
The Court conducts its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with international auditing standards, which apply to both the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing standards do not cover the compliance audit performed by the Court.
Together with the national control authorities, the Court is actively involved in the further development of international auditing standards promoted by the standard-setting organizations (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to provide assurance that payments comply with the legal and other regulatory framework, the Court relies on the results of both its examination of the supervisory and control systems designed to prevent, or detect and correct, legality and regularity errors and also a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Other sources, such as the declarations of management of the audited entities in the form of the annual activity reports of the Commission's Directors-General and the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In performing performance audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess the management and control systems and assess the performance data against criteria derived from the legislation and against the principles of sound financial management.
In selecting the topics for our performance audits, the Court endeavors to identify audit areas where the greatest impact is expected in terms of demonstrated potential for improvement in terms of economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending.
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based both on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries, and on Council decisions on association from Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see policy group External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
4 INTOSAI (International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions) – International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions; IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) – International Federation of Accountants.
BOX 2 - THE COURT'S AUDIT OF A SAMPLE OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU BUDGET 13 The Court does not have the resources to audit all transactions related to the EU budget in detail.
Therefore he uses statistical sampling techniques to present a result representative of the populations concerned.
The Court traces these transactions down to the final beneficiary of the grant, for example a promoter in Italy.
The court then checks – often on the spot – whether the application corresponds to the actual circumstances.
The fact that the sample is representative allows the results to be extrapolated to the relevant population, ie a specific area of income or expenditure, and together with information resulting from the assessment of management and control systems and other sources, as a serve as the basis for an overall audit opinion.
SELECTION OF A SAMPLE OF TRANSACTIONS Random selection of a representative sample Universe of payments in the Cohesion area Payment to a promoter in Italy
14 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES5 14 GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, with one member from each Member State. The members are appointed by the Council after consultation of the European Parliament for a term of six years.
The members elect a president from among their number for three years, with the possibility of re-election.
Five audit groups, to which individual members of the Court are assigned, prepare the reports and opinions for the Court's adoption.
As can be seen from the organization chart, there are four thematic audit groups covering different budget areas and another audit group dealing with 'horizontal' issues.
In addition, a management committee composed of members of the Court is responsible for the preparation of the Court's administrative decisions.
At the end of 2009, the Court submitted a proposal to the Council to amend its Rules of Procedure to allow certain categories of Court opinions and reports to be adopted by the College of Chambers rather than the entire College.
These changes make the Court's decision-making streamlined and more efficient, including by reducing the time taken to adopt decisions.
Each chamber has two areas of responsibility: the first is the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions, the second is the preparation of draft observations for the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds and draft opinions for adoption by the college .
As for the Court, decisions are taken by a majority of the members of the Chamber.
Members can attend meetings of any chamber, but have voting rights only in the chamber to which they have been assigned by the Court.
Of course, the whole college continues to meet to discuss and adopt those documents for which the Court alone is responsible, such as the annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Funds.
The role of the Management Committee will be strengthened.
The Committee is composed of the President of the Court, who presides, and the Dean of the Chambers.
Administrative matters requiring a Court decision to be dealt with, as well as decisions on procedural, policy or strategic issues, are prepared by the Committee before being submitted to the Court for adoption.
The member then presents the report to the scrutiny group and to the Court and, once the report has been approved, also presents it to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
5 Further details are available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
THE COURT'S STAFF The 2009 budget foresees 880 posts (at 31 December 2009) for the European Court of Auditors.
The Court's audit staff are responsible for planning and conducting audits and preparing the resulting draft reports.
The auditors work in teams of different sizes: in some specific audits there is a team of four or five auditors, while in some of the Court's broader audits (e.g. financial/compliance audits in the area of agricultural and cohesion spending on the preparation of the annual statement of assurance) 20 or more auditors are involved.
As a rule, the auditors have to obtain audit evidence as part of an audit through various processes: desk reviews in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission and "on-the-spot" audit visits to the Member States where the revenue flowing into the EU budget is created and the revenue from it actions funded by the EU budget are carried out.
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers across the Union. In addition, the Court's audit work has to be in contact with authorities and other bodies across the Union.
This would not be possible without the Court's translators, who translate its reports and opinions (almost all in English or French) into 22 of the official languages of the Union.
They also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies as needed and, in some cases, assist the auditors in conducting audit visits to Member States.
The Court's administrative staff are responsible for a wide range of support tasks arising in a multinational entity operating in the EU context.
This concerns finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technology, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the Court's most senior official and is responsible for the management of human resources and the administration of the Court. 15

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET: SIX KEY MESSAGES • The annual accounts of the European Union give a true and fair view of the financial position and results. • As regards the legality and regularity of transactions, the overall results for 2008 reflect improvements in financial management over the past few years. • The overall progress achieved in 2008 is mainly due to better results in the largest policy group, 'Agriculture and natural resources'.
For rural development, the estimated level of error is lower than in previous years, but still significant.
For the first time, the Court does not give a negative audit opinion on Agriculture and Natural Resources as a whole. • The second largest policy group, 'Cohesion', which accounts for almost a third of the budget, remains problematic as the budget area most affected by errors.
According to the Court's estimate, at least 11 % of the total reimbursement payments should not have been made. • The recommendations made by the Court in the past to improve the supervisory and control systems remain valid.
They are to be seen as part of an ongoing process in which the relevant measures can only be considered effective after some time. • In addition, particular attention should be paid to those areas of expenditure where the Court continues to find a high level of error.
In many cases, the errors are a result of overly complex rules and regulations.
Therefore, simplification remains a priority. 19
20 Unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts The Court has come to the conclusion that the annual accounts of the European Communities for 2008 give a true and fair view of the financial position of the European Communities and the results of its operations and cash flows, in all material respects.
Unqualified opinions For 2008, the Court gave unqualified opinions on 'Revenue', commitments in all policy groups, payments in 'Education and citizenship' and 'Administrative and other expenditure'.
Qualified opinions Payments in policy group 'Agriculture and natural resources', with the exception of rural development, were legal and regular in all material respects.
Payments under the policy group 'Economy and finance', with the exception of expenditure on the sixth framework program for research and technological development (FP6) covered by this policy group, were legal and regular in all material respects.
Negative audit opinions The Court issued negative audit opinions on the thematic areas of 'Cohesion', 'Research, Energy and Transport' and 'External Aid, Development and Enlargement'.
Payments in these policy areas were affected by material error, albeit to varying degrees.
Need for improvement in monitoring and control systems The monitoring and control systems in the thematic areas of "Research, Energy and Transport", "External Aid, Development and Enlargement" and "Education and Citizenship" were defective in terms of preventing or detecting and correcting the reimbursement of excessive or non-reimbursable costs conditionally effective.
In the case of policy group 'Agriculture and natural resources', the Court also concluded that the supervisory and control systems were partially effective.
However, he pointed out that the integrated administration and control system (IACS) is still an effective control system in general.
However, improvements are needed in some areas, notably rural development, where there have been shortcomings.
In the case of the policy group 'Economy and Finance', the supervisory and control systems were found to be effective in two of the three areas audited.
In the third area, 'Enterprise', the systems were rated as only partially effective, largely due to shortcomings related to FP6.
In the case of policy group 'Cohesion', the Court found that the Member States' systems dedicated to correcting errors detected during national controls were in most cases at least partially effective.
The Commission, Member States and other beneficiary countries need to make further efforts to implement the necessary improvements on the above issues in order to adequately manage the risk of irregular spending.
BOX 3 – INTERPRETATION OF OPINIONS 21 An auditor can issue the following types of opinions: • an unqualified opinion when there is evidence that the accounts are reliable or the underlying transactions, ie payments, are legal and regular in all material respects; • negative opinion when the level of error in the underlying transactions is material and pervasive or the accounts are unreliable; • • Denial of an opinion when the auditor is unable to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support his or her opinion and the potential impact is both material and widespread; Qualified opinion when an unqualified opinion cannot be given, but the implications of disagreements or limitations in scope are not so material or extensive as to require a negative opinion or a disagreement with the opinion.

THE 2008 AUDIT OPINION ON THE EDFs The Court concluded that the 2008 accounts of the EDFs give a true and fair view of the financial position of the EDFs in all material respects.
As regards the legality and regularity of transactions, the Court gave an unqualified opinion on the EDF's revenue and commitments.

SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS In addition, in 2009 a further 37 special annual reports on the agencies and other decentralized bodies of the European Union for the financial year 2008 were adopted.
The agencies of the Union perform a variety of tasks at different locations within the Union.
Each agency has a specific mandate and manages its own budget.
The audits of the Union's agencies and other decentralized bodies are the subject of specific annual reports, which are published separately.
With the exception of the European Police College, the Court issued unqualified opinions on the reliability of the accounts and on the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions for all agencies. 23
24 SPECIAL REPORTS7 Performance and compliance audit topics are selected and designed based on criteria such as risk related to the economics of specific income and expenditure or their compliance with legislation, volume of expenditure, time of last audit, forthcoming developments in the regulatory or operational environment, and political and public interest.
Since performance and compliance audits are complex and require a lot of detailed work, their complete implementation from the preliminary study to the final reporting usually takes more than a year.
In 2009 the Court adopted a total of 18 special reports.
The special reports are available directly on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) and a notice of their publication appears in the Official Journal.
As in previous years, the reports examined financial management issues in a wide range of areas, ranging from, for example, EU food aid to the needy (6/2009) to treasury management at the Commission (5/2009).
In addition to the 18 special reports, in 2009 the Court analyzed the use of EU funds towards the goal of making the Chernobyl site environmentally safe.
Recommendations on how to improve the management of EU funds channeled through the EBRD were sent to the President of the Commission in a letter (unpublished) from the Court President.
The special reports adopted by the Court in 2009 are listed below, broken down by subject.
A concise report is presented for each thematic area to illustrate the nature of the issues addressed and the conclusions drawn.
7 Special Reports are available on the Court's website or by electronic order form from the EU Bookshop.
SUSTAINABLE GROWTH • No. 3/2009 "Effectiveness of expenditure on structural measures for waste water treatment during the programming periods 1994-1999 and 2000-2006" • No. 7/2009 "Management of the development and validation phase of the Galileo program" • No. 8 /2009 "Networks of Excellence and Integrated Projects in Community Research Policy: Have the objectives been met?" • No. 13/2009 "Has the delegation of implementation tasks to Executive Agencies proved to be a useful tool?" • No. 17/2009 "From the European Social Fund co-financed vocational training actions for women' 25 Management of the development and validation phase of the Galileo program We audited the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme, which was launched with the aim of creating a European Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and explained the Causes of the identified undesirable developments.
He concluded that the development and validation phase was poorly managed.
If the reorientation of the EGNOS (Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service for Europe) and Galileo programs undertaken in mid-2007 is to be successful, the Commission needs to significantly improve its program management.
The report contains a number of recommendations designed to facilitate the Commission's task.
Finally, should the EU decide to engage in other major infrastructure programmes, the Commission must ensure that it has appropriate management tools at its disposal.
PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES • No. 6/2009 “European Union food aid for the needy: assessment of objectives, means and methods used” • No. 10/2009 “Information and promotion measures for agricultural products” • No. 11/2009 “ Sustainability of LIFE-Nature projects and their management by the Commission” • No. 14/2009 “Have the market management tools for the milk and milk products market achieved their main objectives?”
26 Have the market control instruments for the milk and milk products market achieved their main objectives?
The Court took stock of the functioning of the milk and milk products market since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and examined the Commission's approach to managing the gradual deregulation of the milk sector that began in 2003.
The situation at the end of 2008 forms the basis of the Court's recommendations to the Commission: prevent new overproduction, monitor the price formation process in the food chain, deepen reflection on the future of producers in disadvantaged areas and on the impact of geographical concentration of milk production on the environment, continuing to focus milk production on meeting the needs of the European internal market and on milk products with high added value that can be exported to the world market without budget support.
CITIZENSHIP, FREEDOM, SECURITY AND JUSTICE • No. 2/2009 "The European Union Public Health Program (2003-2007): an effective route to better health?" The European Union Public Health Program ( 2003-2007): an effective route to better health?
The Court analyzed the European Union's Public Health Program (PHP) for the period 2003-2007.
The purpose of the Court's audit was to determine whether the framework for projects funded by the EU budget has been defined in a way that effectively complements Member States' actions to protect and improve public health.
The report contains detailed conclusions and recommendations on the design, implementation and management of the programme.
Based on its findings, the Court questions the usefulness of certain program components of European public health programs such as the PHP.
The Commission and Member States are asked to reconsider the EU's approach to public health funding.
THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER • No. 1/2009 "Banking activities in the Mediterranean under the MEDA program and the previous protocols" • No. 4/2009 "Management of the Commission's involvement of non-state actors in Community development cooperation" • No. 12 /2009 "Effectiveness of the Commission's projects in the field of Justice and Home Affairs for the Western Balkans" • No. 15/2009 "EU assistance delivered through United Nations agencies: decision-making and control" • No. 16/2009 "The management of pre-accession assistance to the Turkey by the European Commission” • No 18/2009 “Effectiveness of EDF Assistance for Regional Economic Integration in East and West Africa” 27 Management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission We examined the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission.
In particular, the first implementation period of the pre-accession assistance (2002-2006) was characterized by many weaknesses that had already been identified in previous pre-accession programmes.
The objectives set by the Commission in relation to the grants were not specific enough to allow for an assessment of project impact; moreover, the Commission did not have the information needed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the pre-accession assistance.
Nonetheless, the projects audited have delivered the planned outputs and the project results are likely to be sustainable.
The Commission has already made some significant improvements; nevertheless, the Court makes recommendations for further corrective action.
Areas where improvement is most needed include defining strategic goals for the grant, setting more realistic deadlines for goal achievement, and monitoring actual project performance and results against clear goals and appropriate indicators.
28 ADMINISTRATION • No 5/2009 "Treasury management at the Commission" • No 9/2009 "Efficiency and effectiveness of the European Personnel Selection Office's personnel selection activities" Efficiency and effectiveness of the European Personnel Selection Office's personnel selection activities The Court focused on the issue , how the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) managed the sharp increase in the number of competitions due to the enlargement of the European Union and whether it provided timely lists of suitable candidates, containing the required number of successful candidates and geographically balanced.
He concluded that EPSO had successfully managed the increase in the number of competitions due to the enlargement of the European Union.
However, the following weaknesses were identified: the institutions' staffing needs were not reported to EPSO in a timely manner, the staff selection process took too long, the selection procedures produced on average only two thirds of the intended number of successful candidates (who were included in the shortlist) and the management information were not consistently reliable or complete.

These opinions are required as part of the procedure for the adoption of financial legislation8 or may be issued at the request of one of the other institutions of the Union9.
In 2009, the Court adopted an opinion on the proposal to amend the regulation of the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market on the Office's financial rules ('the Financial Regulation').

29 FOLLOW-UP AND IMPACT The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned – primarily the Commission, Parliament, Council and Member States in the European context.
This information allows them to take action, with or without reference to the Court's audit conclusions.
Although the Court's audit work has its main impact through the reports and opinions it publishes, some impact is made throughout the audit process itself.
29 As examples of the impact of the Court's work, actions taken by the Commission in response to the 2007 budget discharge resolution (which had an impact mainly in 2009) can be cited ): In the area of agricultural expenditure The management and control system for expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been aligned with the guarantee system of the EAGF, so that the widely recognized benefits of this system also apply to EAFRD expenditure (see paragraph 5.54 of the 2004 annual report and paragraph 5.57 of the 2007 annual report).
In the field of cohesion The Commission continues to work on a revision of the rules applicable for 2007-2013 in order to simplify the system for reporting irregularities. It has committed itself to report in early 2010 on the actions taken in 2009 and the first impact of all actions of its action plan to strengthen the Commission's supervisory role in the management of structural actions (see paragraph 1.53 and paragraph 6.36(a) of the annual report concerning the financial year 2007).
In the area of External Policies In order to strengthen controls at implementing organization level, the Commission plans to develop a specific tool to better support these organizations in managing EU funds and complying with EU rules (see paragraph 8.33(a) of the 2007 Annual Report ).
In the field of internal policies, including research The Commission has established a multi-annual control strategy for the Sixth Framework Programme. This is based on the detection and correction of errors that could not be detected through desk reviews prior to the execution of the payment.
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund, which significantly reduced the number of ex-ante financial controls and safeguards to be implemented (see paragraphs 7.43(b), 10.34 and 2.42(a) of the annual report for the financial year 2007).
Source: Report from the Commission to the European Parliament on the follow-up to the 2007 discharge decisions.
The special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure.
Due to the fact that they are published throughout the year, the presentation of the special reports and their discussion in Parliament and Council meetings have usually taken place earlier.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by promoting them in the relevant media, which attracts more attention and stimulates public discussion.
In general, media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite extensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with media focus primarily on improvements in agricultural spending.
Several special reports were also followed with interest by the press.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No. 14/2009), which assessed the extent to which market governance instruments for milk and milk products have achieved their main objectives, was the subject of intensive discussions in Council and Parliament. It also generated widespread media and professional coverage at a time when the sector is grappling with a variety of issues.
The Court is working to further analyze the impact of its work.
In 2009, it began developing a systematic follow-up process for its special reports, designed to identify and document the auditees' progress in addressing weaknesses identified and recommendations made.
This process will provide the Court - as well as Parliament and other stakeholders - with additional feedback on the impact of its work.
31 THE COURT'S POSITION OPINION NO. 1/2010 - IMPROVING FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court issued its first opinion on measures taken at EU budget level to reduce the level of irregular payments and improve the quality of spending (economy, economy and effectiveness) could be improved.
The Court concluded that in order to build on recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, legislation in high-risk areas needs to be simplified and more cost-effective control systems put in place.
Such reforms should take place in the context of the ongoing broader review of EU spending rules.
The Court considers that improving the quality of spending is an important priority, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value when setting spending priorities and by addressing the specific problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of spending programs and grant schemes .
TARGETING THE AREAS MOST AFFECTED BY IRREGULAR PAYMENTS Although the level of irregular payments from the EU budget as a whole has decreased, it remains in the thematic areas of 'Cohesion' and 'External Assistance, Development and Enlargement', as well as the Framework Program for Research and Technological Development and high in rural development spending.
Most irregularities stem from beneficiaries reporting ineligible expenditure, over-reporting of eligible expenditure and non-respect of payment terms, for example in the area of public procurement rules.
They are mainly due to the complexity of the regulations and payment terms, as well as deficiencies in the risk management systems at the level of the final beneficiaries.
SIMPLIFY THE RELEVANT REGULATORY FRAMEWORK AND IMPROVE SUPERVISION AND CONTROL The Commission should address the specific systemic weaknesses identified by the Court in the high-risk areas and improve its oversight.
However, with more and more controls and correspondingly decreasing error rates, the point is reached at which the control costs are no longer proportionate to the benefit achieved.
Therefore, simplification should remain a priority.
Rules and legislation that are clear to interpret and easy to apply not only reduce the risk of error, but also the cost of controls. 31
32 IMPROVING THE DESIGN OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMS In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure that clear objectives are set when revising existing measures and designing new ones.
More realism, transparency and accountability are often required.
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen the existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular the ex ante evaluation and the impact assessment.
CONSIDERING EUROPEAN ADDED VALUE WHEN PRIORITIZING EXPENDITURE The Court proposes clarifying the concept of European added value in an appropriate policy statement or in EU legislation, in order to guide EU political authorities when setting spending priorities.
SEIZING THE OPPORTUNITY OF BUDGET REFORM TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF EXPENDITURE In the Court's view, the Commission should complete the budget review as soon as possible and take the results into account when preparing the financial framework starting in 2014.
Improving the quality of spending should be a priority for the institutions of the European Union and thus a key objective of the new Commission.
33 THE COURT'S WORK PLANNING FOR 201010 Each year the Court sets out its future audit work in a work program which is submitted to the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament and is publicly available on the Court's website.
The work program provides interested parties with information on new and ongoing audits and planned reports.
The Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 based on two priority objectives: maximizing the overall impact of audits and improving efficiency by making best use of resources.
These objectives will shape the Court's work program for 2010 and its drive for continuous improvement.
The Court aims to maximize the overall impact of its audits over the period in question by: • selecting and designing audits that focus on risk-related issues and are of most interest to the Court's audience; • continue to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement, and follow up on whether these suggestions are implemented; • conduct a wider range of audits and produce new types of audit products to complement current annual and special reports; • created a larger number of special reports and improved their timeliness and user-friendliness; • further develops its relations with its key stakeholders, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public. The Court aims to improve efficiency over the period in question by making the best use of its resources.
These include • better governance; • an effective and dynamic human resources policy; • the rationalization of examination tasks; • the improvement of IT tools; • the development of professional competence; • developing relationships with the auditees.
33 10 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's work program 2010, available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
34 For the 2010 work program the Court has selected certain audit priorities, including: • the multiannual nature of much of the Community's expenditure, including flat-rate corrections and recoveries; • Innovation and the internal market; • human capital; • sustainable energy; • Commission's strategy to simplify the legal framework for businesses and citizens.
CELEBRATION OF THE FOUNDATION STONE FOR A NEW BUILDING On July 1, 2009, the foundation stone was laid in Luxembourg for a new building, the second extension of the European Court of Auditors.
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Luxembourg Minister for Building, Patrick Gillen, President of the "Fonds d'urbanisation et d'aménagement du Kirchberg", and Eduardo Ruiz García, Secretary General of the Court, gave the signal with the symbolic groundbreaking ceremony the start of construction work.
This extension of the European Court of Auditors' complex, which already consists of two buildings, will accommodate the staff recruited as a result of successive enlargements of the Union.
In 2009-2012 the Court will endeavor to broaden its range of audit-related report types.
To this end, he will coordinate with his key external stakeholders to ensure he gains a clear understanding of their diverse needs and how best to meet their expectations in the performance of his mandate under the Treaty.
A significant proportion of the resources available to the Court are devoted to auditing the accounts with a view to drawing up a Statement of Assurance (the so-called "DAS").
This requires the examination and verification of the accounts and transactions of the general budget of the EU for each financial year.
Separate Statements of Assurance are prepared for the European Development Funds and each of the 40 European agencies and bodies.
The audit work extends from June of year n to June of year n+1 in order to allow the annual reports to be published in November of year n+1 in accordance with the Financial Regulation.
Thus, in 2010, the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2009 will be prepared and published and at the same time the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2010 will start11.
The aim of the Court's work is to provide clear conclusions on the state of accounting and financial management in each area of the general budget and to make relevant and cost-effective recommendations where improvements can be made.
The Court's annual report on the general budget for the financial year 2009 will continue to follow the structure introduced in 2007, reflecting the reorganization of the budget12.
Findings are presented within the framework of chapters related to related groups of policy areas (themes). This structure largely, but not entirely, corresponds to the headings of the new financial framework.
Furthermore, the Court will be particularly concerned to present its findings and conclusions in an even clearer and more coherent manner, in order to make them easier to understand and read and to facilitate comparison within and between thematic groups and between financial years.

12 We set up a DAS think tank to reflect on various aspects of the DAS audit approach. In this context, consideration is also being given to redesigning the areas of specific assessments.
36 36 MEASURING AND IMPROVING PERFORMANCE KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008 the Court decided to introduce a system of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for its audit and non-audit activities to measure performance in meeting the Court's strategic objectives and those set out in the annual work programmes to measure goals.
ZLI serve to strengthen internal and external accountability and to increase work efficiency and quality. WHY KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management on how successful the Court as an institution is in delivering on what it has set out to do; • to support the decision-making process by drawing the institution's attention to efficiency issues and encouraging improvements; • to provide information to the audience on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance.
The ZLI primarily relate to the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives, as they cover audit quality, output, impact and the efficient use of the Court's resources.
They reflect the Court's performance as a 'company' and are an integral part of the Court's management system.
THE COURT'S KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS 37 ALI 1 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work by the main users of the Court's reports ALI 2 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work by the auditee ALI 3 Rating of the content and presentation of the Court's reports by a panel of external experts ALI 4 Percentage of audit recommendations that are a) accepted by the audited entity b) implemented by the audited entity within a specified number of years ALI 5 Number of reports accepted versus number of reports planned ALI 6 Number of Reports adopted on time ALI 7 Percentage of audit statements issued on time ALI 8 External assessment of the Court's financial management: a) Opinion of the independent auditor b) Decision of the discharge authority ALI 9 Level of satisfaction of the Court's staff ALI 10 Average number of training days per person The quantity and quality of audit work can also be improved by considering the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They have been included in the Court's 2010 annual work programme.
38 Number of reports adopted versus number of reports planned In 2009 the Court adopted 91 % of the number of reports planned.
The annual report and all special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the 24 special reports planned, only 18 were accepted.
As of December 31, 2009, the remaining six special reports were still in the final drafting phase.
Number of reports adopted on time In 2009, the Court adopted 67% of its reports within the given timeframe.
The annual report and all special annual reports were approved on time.
Due to delays in the special reports, the Court missed the target for the ZLI 6. Further efforts are needed to improve the respect of the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports.
Measuring the number of key audit reports produced on time The Court communicates its preliminary audit results to the auditee in an audit report.
It aims to increase the proportion of audit communications delivered on time by 10% annually, with the long-term goal of producing 80% of audit communications within the specified timeframe (two months after the final audit visit).
In 2009, the number of audit reports prepared on time increased by 16% compared to 2008.
External assessment of the Court's financial management: a) Opinion of the independent auditor, b) Decision of the discharge authority The Court's independent auditor gave an unqualified opinion on the accounts and the use of resources and the European Parliament granted discharge following a positive recommendation from the Council.
Level of satisfaction of the Court's staff In an internal staff satisfaction survey carried out in 2009, 86 % of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their job (target: 80 %), while the overall level of staff satisfaction was 2.8 on a scale of 4 (target: 2.5).
Average number of training days for auditors (excluding language courses) In line with guidelines published by the IFAC (International Federation of Accountants), the Court aims to provide auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
In 2009, the average was four days.
39 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court actively and fully pursued its international cooperation through the following fora: • the Contact Committee, composed of the Presidents of the EU Member States' SAIs and the ECA, • the Network of Country SAIs , which have applied for EU membership, • in the European Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI) and • in the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI).
The Court contributed to the annual meetings of these organizations and to the improvement of international auditing standards and practices, and was also actively involved in the committees and working groups set up by these organisations.
In particular, he took on the following tasks: • Chairing the working groups on “Common Auditing Standards” and “VAT” set up by the Contact Committee; • Participation in the Working Groups “Reports of National SAIs” and “Structural Funds” set up by the Contact Committee; • Participation in the EUROSAI Environment Working Group and IT Working Group, in the EUROSAI Group preparing a Guide on Good Practices for Quality Achievement, in the EUROSAI Training Committee and in the EUROSAI Task Force on Auditing Disaster Aid Funds; • Chair the INTOSAI Working Group on Accountability and Audit of Disaster Relief; • Participation in the INTOSAI subcommittees on guidelines for financial audit, legal compliance and performance auditing, and in the task force on the global financial crisis. 39
40 40 STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES The Court's most important asset is its people.
As at 31 December 2009, the Court had 880 staff (officials and temporary agents but excluding members, contract agents, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the staff, 525 (including 115 staff in Members' private offices) were involved in audit-related tasks; 163 were employed as translators, 171 as administrative support staff and 21 in the services of the President.
The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and commitment is reflected in the Court's output.
BREAKDOWN OF THE COURT'S POSTS AT 31 DECEMBER (occupied and vacant posts) Translation Administrative support The Court is committed to achieving its strategic objective of improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
Therefore, in 2009 he continued to explore and exploit the potential for efficiency gains in all his activities by simplifying procedures and streamlining services.
In particular, resources made available by support services through efficiency gains have been diverted from these services as much as possible and made available for audit-related tasks.
This process is ongoing and its impact will be even more apparent in 2010.
For human resources, the Court has defined the evaluation of the degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff as a key performance indicator (ZLI 9) (see page 37).
A satisfaction survey was carried out to provide information on this topic and to support the decision-making process in this area.
The Court is implementing measures to ensure that opportunities to achieve better results in the years to come are fully exploited.
