RECRUITMENTS The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both officials and temporary staff.
Open competitions for posts at the Court are organized by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also offers internships for a limited number of university graduates for periods of between three and five months.
In 2009 the Court recruited 112 staff: 69 officials, 14 temporary agents and 29 contract agents.
Recruitment is subject to the availability and sufficient availability of reserve lists of EPSO competitions.
In 2009 the Court managed to recruit an adequate number of new staff.
The 73 vacancies as of December 31, 2009 were reduced by 33% to 49 by January 26, 2010. The number of vacancies will continue to fall sharply in the coming months as more audit staff will come into service in the wake of the recent wave of recruitment.
As of December 31, 2008, 68 positions were vacant.
The reserve list for recruitment on the basis of EPSO competition AD/126/08 was published in August and the first successful candidates entered the Court's service in early November, just three months later.
PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT The auditor's profession requires continuous development.
In addition, due to the specific nature of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need a good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the Court's staff completed an average of nine days of professional development.
Language courses accounted for 64% of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared to 48% in 2008).
Excluding the language courses, the examiners completed four days of professional training in 2009 (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This number is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff are required to complete a mandatory training programme.
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective “evolution and growth” and the master plan for training for the years 2008-2011, as well as the training pathways adopted in 2009, the “Professional Training” Unit has made improvements in the content of the training measures and in line with the priorities decided by the Court new training courses developed.
In addition, cooperation with the other institutions and with interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration continued successfully.
Box 5 provides a portrait of the staff of an audit unit within the Court to give the reader an idea of the work carried out and the people involved. 43
40 BOX 5 – THE TEAM RESPONSIBLE FOR THE AUDIT JUSTICE AND HOME AFFAIRS IN THE WESTERN BALKANS The Western Balkans region has historically been marked by violence.
The interest of the European Union in this region is to promote security and long-term stability.
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are basic requirements for EU accession and pose a major challenge in the Western Balkans.
The European Commission is the main donor of funds in the region.
The Court's 2009 report on the effectiveness of the Commission's Justice and Home Affairs projects for the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) provided an insight into the situation in this particularly important area.
The audit covered both investment projects and institution-building projects in the four areas of asylum, integrated border management, the judiciary and the police.
33 completed projects were inspected on the spot, including an asylum centre, a prison in Albania and a human rights and war crimes court in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
A number of EU-funded border crossing points in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were also visited to assess whether the EU's actions were leading to improvements.
The team responsible for conducting the audit worked closely with the rapporteur, Maarten B. Engwarta.
The Heads of Unit responsible for supervising the audit were Raija Peltonen and Ossi Louko; Jussi Bright was responsible for team management.
The examiners involved were Enrico Grassi and Miroslav Matej, with Horst Fischer and Jan Pieter Lingen from Maarten B. Engwarta's cabinet also playing an important role.

TRANSLATION Translation is an important audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfill its mandate and achieve its communication goals.
In 2009, the total translation volume increased by 5.2% compared to 2008.
The proportion of translation services rendered on time was over 95%.
Linguistic support for auditors in connection with audit visits and when drafting reports has been increased.
The Directorate for Translation also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the Court's audit work.
A new IT application (Artemis) was launched in January 2010 to manage translation work more efficiently.
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology provides auditors with essential tools and services.
The main developments in 2009 were: • to simplify processes and continue the move towards a paperless office by using automated permits (visas) and e-forms, introducing e-signatures and starting work on setting up an archive database; • Improving the security of the Court's IT infrastructure by establishing a data recovery center and deploying an evolved version of the Lotus Notes platform, the backbone of the Court's messaging and audit documentation/archiving systems; • Adoption of a long-term IT plan for the period 2010-2012 to align information technology with the Court's key audit policy objectives and continue to strive for quality service delivery. 45
46 ADMINISTRATION AND INFRASTRUCTURE The Finance and Support Services Directorate is responsible for administrative services and infrastructure.
This includes internal controls and accounting as well as administrative and logistic services.
In 2009, the Directorate focused on reorganizing its services to improve efficiency and effectiveness and free up staff to be redeployed to the audit services.
This reorganization led to a reduction in the number of units belonging to the Directorate (from five to three) and the conversion of several posts to audit services.
An important activity of the directorate concerned the construction of a new courtyard building (the "K3 building").
In 2009, following a call for tenders, a project manager was appointed.
Construction work will start in March 2010 and is expected to be completed in 2013.
The time and cost framework specified for the project will continue to be met.
AUDIT VISITS The Court's audit work requires auditors to travel to Member States and other recipient countries of EU funds in order to obtain appropriate audit evidence.
The visits are usually to central and local authorities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as to the respective final recipients.
Audit teams typically consist of two to three examiners and audit trips can take up to two weeks, depending on the nature of the audit and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in liaison with the SAIs of the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support.
The graph below gives an overview of the number of audit visits carried out by the Court in the EU Member States in 2009 (300).
In addition, 36 audit visits took place outside the Union in 2009.

50 INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE The Court's Internal Audit Service aims to help the Court achieve its objectives through a systematic, methodical assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative processes.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to increase the Court's efficiency.
This requires a constant assessment of the internal control systems within the Court to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit service focused its work mainly on financial audits (reviews of financial statements), an ex-ante control review, payroll and custodial accounts audits, a follow-up of contracts and procedures of the public procurement and an analysis of the promotion process.
Most of the audit recommendations made by the Internal Auditor in 2009 were accepted by the auditees and incorporated into corrective action plans.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee oversees the work of the internal auditor and ensures his independence.
It also examines and approves the work program and reports of the internal auditor and assigns specific audit tasks to the auditor when the need arises.
In 2009, the Internal Audit department was audited and certified by an independent auditor, Deloitte SA.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE COURT The independent auditor's report on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2008 was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 23 October 2009 (OJ
C 254 of 23.10.2009). In its opinion, the Court's independent auditor (PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL) came to the following conclusions: On the financial statements: "In our opinion, the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2008, and of the results of operations and of cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No. 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and Commission Regulation (EC, Euratom) No. 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 with implementing provisions for the above Council Regulation and the accounting regulations of the European Court of Auditors." Regarding the use of resources and the control procedures: "Based on our work steps described in this report, we have not come across any facts from which we would have to conclude that in all material matters and under consideration of the exact Assessment criteria can be: a) the funds allocated to the Court have not been used for the intended purposes and b) the control procedures put in place do not provide the necessary guarantee that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations in force.” 51

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2010
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS MISSION MISSION VALUES The Court of Auditors is committed to the following values: The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances under the Treaty.
As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognized for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, offering valuable support to its constituency with a view to improving EU financial management.
INDEPENDENCE, INTEGRITY AND IMPARTIALITY PROFESSIONALITY ADDED VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the body, its members and staff Produce relevant, timely reports of high quality, based on sound findings and evidence, reflecting the concerns of its constituencies and important as well as leading statements include recognizing the worth of the individual, helping to develop special skills and rewarding performance promoting team spirit through effective communication providing its audience with appropriate examination results, while refusing any form of influence from external direction or pressure maintaining a high and exemplary standard degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work Actively contributing to the further development of public auditing at EU level and worldwide Increasing the efficiency of all aspects of his work Contribute to effectively improving the management of the EU budget and contribute to increasing accountability for the management of EU funds

4 FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the fourth edition of the European Court of Auditors' Annual Activity Report. This year we have taken the opportunity to reorganize the content into two main sections, “Our Operations” and “Our Management”, and for the first time present an overview of all key performance indicators.
In 2010, the Court of Auditors had two important opportunities to contribute to the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court delivered an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges in improving EU financial management, and towards the end of the year an opinion on the Commission's proposals to amend the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU.
With a view to 2011, the court will continue to implement its values and continue to expand on the level of performance and results achieved.
We will again provide high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions that help improve EU financial management and promote accountability and transparency. In particular, the Court will continue to follow closely developments in the area of EU economic governance and will address the new legislative proposals affecting EU financial management after 2013.
We plan to publish 45 annual reports, ie the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, as well as the specific annual reports on the agencies, bodies and other bodies.
Special reports provide an important opportunity to add value as they focus on areas of increased risk and on issues of particular relevance to the audience. In particular, the Court intends to report on the quality of EU spending in a wide range of areas, ranging from financial instruments and the SME Guarantee Facility to EU-funded projects in eGovernment and the Single Payment Scheme in agriculture.
As we continue to implement our strategy for 2009-2012, the Court hopes to reap the full benefits of its recent reforms, including streamlined decision-making procedures. The Court will continue its efforts to recruit suitable staff, to keep vacancies to a minimum and to encourage the professional development of its staff.
We would not have achieved what we have achieved in 2010 without the commitment and professionalism of all the Court's staff.
Vítor Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President 5 7 2010 AT A GLANCE OUR ACTIVITIES o Annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Fund for the financial year 2009 o 40 specific annual reports on the different EU agencies, bodies and bodies for the financial year 2009 o 14 special reports , mainly on performance audits o Opinion on improving EU financial management o Five other opinions on new or amended EU legal acts, including the proposal to amend the Financial Regulation o Active involvement in issues relating to international audit practice in the field of public audit and the professional community, among others the elaboration of the new standards for supreme audit institutions (ISSAI) o pilot project with coordinated audits on the regularity of agricultural expenditures involving the supreme audit institutions of the Netherlands and the Czech Republic OUR MANAGEMENT o Presentation of an overview of all KPIs showing that key stakeholders are fairly satisfied with the quality of the Court's work o Revision of the Court's Rules of Procedure introducing Chambers to streamline decision-making processes o Recruitment of 97 new staff, resulting in the proportion of vacant posts fell below 5% for the first time o Continued redeployment of staff to audit services as a result of efficiency gains in support services
9 OUR ACTIVITIES AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: o Annual Reports - containing the results of its financial and compliance audits on specific financial years (this includes the separately published specific annual reports on the agencies, bodies and others bodies of the European Union); o Special Reports – to be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits, mainly performance audits assessing economy, efficiency and effectiveness in selected EU revenue and expenditure areas; o Opinions on draft legal acts with financial implications.

The key messages of the annual report were as follows: • The annual accounts of the European Union fairly present the financial position and the results of operations and cash flows in all material respects Expenditure”), payments from the budget continue to be affected by a material level of error. • The Court estimates that the most likely error rate for Cohesion policy spending was significantly lower than in previous years and for the budget as a whole the Court's estimated error rate has been decreasing in recent years. • The Commission has improved its information on recoveries of unduly paid amounts and other corrections.

12 Special reports adopted in 2010 In selecting and designing its performance and compliance audit tasks, the Court is always mindful of achieving maximum impact while making the best use of the resources dedicated to those tasks.
In selecting the topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the amount of income or expenses; • the time elapsed since any previous check; • forthcoming developments within the relevant legal or operational framework; • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the required audit evidence, the selected performance and compliance audits must be carefully planned and performed. The Court also gives the audited entities the opportunity to comment on its findings and formulate replies before the report is published.
As a result, these exams typically take more than a year to complete.

In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of the "Design Studies" and "Development of New Infrastructures" support measures in the Sixth Research Framework Program (Special Report No 2/2010) - "Design Studies" aim to examine feasibility aspects in potential future research organisations and the measure "Development of new infrastructure" aims to support the development of new infrastructure or the improvement of existing ones.
During the audit, the Court examined whether the two actions contributed effectively to the achievement of the objectives of the infrastructures activity of the sixth research framework program for 2002-2006. • Impact assessments in the EU institutions: do they help in decision-making?
(Special Report No 3/2010) – Impact assessments are one of the cornerstones of better regulation policy to improve and simplify EU legislative proposals. The audit analyzed whether the Commission's impact assessments have effectively supported decision-making in the EU institutions. The observations of this report are also relevant for other areas of the budget.
• Do the design and management of the mobility actions of the Leonardo da Vinci program allow for effective results?
(Special Report No. 4/2010) - The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci program enable organizations active in the field of vocational education and training to arrange study visits in another European country for participants. The measures are part of the integrated program for lifelong learning. The audit examined whether the measures are likely to achieve their objectives through an assessment of the design and management by the Commission and the national agencies. • Improving transport performance on the trans-European rail axes: have EU investments in rail infrastructure been effective?
(Special Report No. 8/2010) (see box 'A close-up of a performance audit'). • Are the EU expenditures for structural measures in the area of water supply for households used optimally?
(Special Report No. 9/2010) – In the programming period 2000-2006, more than 4 billion euros were made available from the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund to support projects in the field of water supply infrastructure for households. We examined whether these funds were used effectively to address a range of needs, such as increasing water availability, extending geographic coverage, improving the efficiency of water supply systems and increasing the quality of service. 15
16 PERFORMANCE AUDIT CLOSE-UP IMPROVING TRANSPORT PERFORMANCE ON THE TRANS-EUROPEAN RAILWAY AXES: HAS EU INVESTMENT IN RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE EFFECTIVE? SPECIAL REPORT NO. 8/2010 The audit focused on EU co-funding of railway infrastructure, examining whether it was making an effective contribution to improving the performance of the trans-European axes.
With the revision of the TEN-T guidelines due in 2011, the Court's report comes at a particularly opportune time. The Court recommended that the Commission: • work with the Member States and the railway authorities to identify on which trans-European corridors there are significant needs and, where necessary, improve knowledge and analytical bases; • to put more emphasis on reducing the practical constraints in cross-border rail traffic; • to encourage and facilitate cooperation between Member States' institutions responsible for the rail sector, so that developments can be planned together and common solutions to practical problems can be found.
17 “The audit presented a number of challenges for the team,” reports Gareth Roberts, lead audit team. “We had to get to grips with the realities of European rail transport very quickly and we saw some successful examples of fantastic modern railways, but also some sections of the network that seemed to come from another age.
We wanted to explore how the European rail transport system is gradually evolving from a patchwork quilt to a network.
The on-site work involved up to 10 examiners as we had to cover many different languages.” “I really enjoyed working on this exam.
Since then I've become something of a railroad fan!” says Andrej Minarovič, the inspector responsible for the work in Germany and Austria.
At the end of the stage, Fernando Pascual Gil earned the nickname "Mole" within the team for having spent considerable time in railway tunnels in the Alps and Pyrenees. The audit team visited eight Member States and examined the impact on trans-European rail transport of 21 rail projects co-financed by the European Union under the trans-European transport networks and cohesion policy.
To do this, the team members drove freight trains across and through the Alps and visited large tunnel construction sites.
These visits were a valuable addition to the knowledge that the auditors had gained from reviewing reports, interviewing railway workers and routine financial analysis.
18 Preserving and managing natural resources With a budget of €413 billion for 2007-2013, the EU has wide powers and political responsibilities in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. Three quarters of the funds are spent on agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers. These payments are financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the 'first pillar' of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
Rural development support, funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second 'pillar' of the CAP, accounts for more than a fifth of spending.
Agriculture and rural development are managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementing the Leader approach to rural development (Special Report 5/2010) - Leader is a bottom-up approach to rural development based on local partnerships rural area. The audit examined whether the implementation of the Leader approach resulted in additional benefits over the traditional top-down approach, while minimizing the risks to sound financial management. • Has the sugar market reform achieved its most important goals?
(Special Report No. 6/2010) - The EU carried out a major reform of its sugar sector in 2006, with the aim of ensuring the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilizing markets and ensuring supplies, and adequate income for the farming community to secure livelihood.
This has resulted in a transition to greater regional participation and more flexible decision-making. In the course of the audit, the effectiveness of the special measures after the reform was examined. The EU as a global partner In addition to enlargement, the EU has three main objectives in the area of external relations: achieving stability, security and prosperity in its neighborhood ("The EU and its neighborhood policy"); active support for sustainable development at international level ("The EU as a partner for sustainable development"); Promoting global political "governance" and ensuring strategic and civil security ("The EU as a global player").
Most of the expenditure is managed by the Commission directly through its central services or its delegations.
Some funding measures are also jointly managed with international organisations. • Commission management of the system of veterinary controls on meat imports after the 2004 reform of the hygiene legislation (Special Report No. 14/2010) - Veterinary controls at imports are an essential part of EU food safety policy and help to reduce the risk of diseases and Health crises erupt, with potentially high costs to the EU budget. The audit examined how the Commission monitors the EU system of veterinary checks at border inspection posts, introduced as part of the reform of food hygiene legislation that came into force in 2006.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • The Commission's management of GBS in ACP, Latin American and Asian countries (Special Report No. 11/2010) - GBS is used by many donors, including the European Commission, generally regarded as the most effective way of delivering development aid.
The audit examined whether the Commission was effectively managing its budget support programs in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries, Latin America and Asia. 19
20 • EU development assistance for basic education in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (Special Report No. 12/2010) – Through the Education for All initiative and the Millennium Development Goals, the EU and the international donor community have committed to ensuring primary education for all children, committed to eliminating gender inequalities and improving the quality of education. The audit examined whether EU development assistance contributed to the achievement of these goals in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia and whether the Commission managed its interventions satisfactorily.
Revenue The budget of the European Union is mainly financed from own resources and other revenue. Traditional own resources - mainly customs duties - account for around 12% and the VAT resource for another 12% of total revenue. The bulk of the EU's own resources (70%) come from GNI-derived own resources, which as residual revenue ensure that the budget is always in balance. • Has the new European Neighborhood and Partnership Instrument in the South Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia) been successfully launched and is it delivering results?
(Special Report No. 13/2010) - The European Neighborhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) provides a framework for planning and delivering assistance to partner countries and territories.
Since 2007, more than 311 million euros have been made available for three countries in the southern Caucasus. The audit examined whether the ENPI was successfully launched there and whether it is achieving results.
In 2010, the Court adopted a special report on • Simplified customs procedures (1/2010) - Simplified customs procedures allow authorized economic operators to benefit from accelerated customs clearance and a simplified system for paying customs duties, which are part of the EU's revenue.
The audit assessed the effectiveness of the legal framework and the control approach of the Commission and the Member States. Opinions issued in 2010 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legislation with a financial impact.
21 22 THE COURT'S PERSPECTIVE ON THE REVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL REGULATION Opinion 6/2010 concerns an important Commission proposal for a revision of the Financial Regulation, which governs how the EU budget is collected, spent and accounted for.
Furthermore, based on what we said in Opinion 1/2010 (see above), the Court points out that in order to improve the quality of EU spending in certain spending areas of the EU budget, simpler and better legislation and other measures to support Promotion and demand for economic behavior on the part of managers at the Commission, in the other institutions and in the Member States.
Ongoing contacts are maintained by liaison officers appointed by each SAI.
The pilot project will be completed in 2011. 24 Network of SAIs of the Candidate and Potential Candidate Countries The Court actively participated in meetings of the Network of SAIs of the Candidate and Potential Candidate Countries (Turkey, Croatia, the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Montenegro, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia)4 , which took place in parallel with the meetings of the Contact Committee.
4 Status February 2011. Other forms of cooperation The Court continued its active involvement and contribution to the improvement of international auditing standards and practices through its membership in European and international organizations of public audit bodies, namely INTOSAI5 and its European regional group EUROSAI.
A delegation of the court took on XX. INCOSAI Congress, held in South Africa from November 22-27, 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of INTOSAI, it has actively participated in the subcommittees on the different audit types. In addition, the Court provided input to the Subcommittee on Promoting Best Practices and Quality Assurance through Voluntary Peer Reviews and supported the increased capacity-building activities of INTOSAI members.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Accountability and Audit of Disaster Relief.
A key objective of this working group is to develop guidance, identify and disseminate good practice in the area of accountability for disaster relief, focusing on stakeholder (multilateral, aid, government, private auditor) activities. The working group's interim report was presented to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis. Within the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the environmental working group and in the IT working group and participates in the EUROSAI training committee.
The Court also participated in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress in 2008 to develop a guide on best practices for achieving quality within an SAI. In addition, the Court is one of the auditors of EUROSAI. 25
26 OUR MANAGEMENT IMPLEMENTING THE STRATEGY FOR 20092012 In recent years, following a self-assessment and peer review process (2008) on the framework of its audit management, the Court has embarked on an internal reform process.
A strategy for the period 2009-20126 was then developed to address the identified weaknesses. The overall objectives for the period are to: o Maximize the overall impact of the audits; o Improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
Many of the priority actions foreseen in the strategy have already been completed. The other measures will be implemented in 2011 and 2012. The main achievements in 2010 were: o meeting the target of 12 to 15 performance audit reports per year; o New product development - a risks and challenges document for the new Commission (Opinion 1/2010) and the establishment of a new system for reporting on the follow-up of the Court's recommendations from 2012; o the revision of the Court's Rules of Procedure to streamline decision-making processes through the introduction of Chambers and to strengthen the governance structure; o creating an overview of all performance indicators; o the further development of the approach for the annual audit of the implementation of the EU budget (statement of assurance) based on recommendations from an internal expert panel supported by external experts; o the redeployment of a number of posts from support services to audit services.
6 The "Audit Strategy 2009-2012" is available on the Court's website.
27 INTRODUCTION OF CHAMBERS DUE TO THE NEW RULES OF PROCEDURE One of the main recommendations that emerged from the Court's reform process was that the Court should benefit from the possibility provided for in Article 287(4) of the Treaty, while maintaining the principle of collegiality, of certain categories of reports and opinions from Chambers accept, make use of.
Chambers were set up on 1 June 2010 following the Council's approval of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure. These are composed of members of the Court and adopt special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft legislation. Previously, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the whole College, and this is still the case for the annual reports on the EU budget and the EDFs.
Although most of the Court's reports are now adopted by the Chambers, the Chambers have the option to refer their documents to the Court for acceptance.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they are not members without the right to vote.
The members of the court
28 MEASURING THE COURT'S PERFORMANCE IN 2010 Since 2008, the Court has progressively developed a set of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to: o inform management on progress towards the implementation of the 2009-2012 objectives; o to support the decision-making process; o provide performance-related information to the Court's stakeholders.
As an overview of all indicators is available for the first time for 2010, this year serves as a reference year for future progress assessments. The Court is very pleased with the results it achieved in 2010 on its key performance indicators, particularly on the quality and impact of its work.
Even more important, however, is the fact that the indicators clearly show where progress is needed and where issues need to be addressed in order to improve future performance.
29 Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports through user judgements, peer reviews and follow-up to its recommendations.
Users' assessments Through a survey, the Court asked the main users of its reports (European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and the Council's Committee on Budgets) and the main auditees (mainly European Commission staff) to assess the quality and impact of those published in 2009 Annual reports (on the general budget and on the EDFs) and special reports.
The assessment should be based on a five-point scale (1 - very bad, 2 - bad, 3 - fair, 4 - good, 5 - very good).
2010 Target A key user's assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's reports 4.2 ≥4 The auditee's assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work The result shows that the key users of the Court's reports rate them as 'good' on average .
The farm endeavors to maintain this level of performance or to improve it.
Expert reviews Two external bodies checked the content and presentation of a sample of the Court's reports published in 2009 and 2010. The auditors assessed eight special reports and the annual report on the general budget and EDFs for both years and rated the quality of various aspects of the reports on a four-point scale from 'seriously impaired' (1) to 'high quality' (4).
2010 Target 3.0 ≥ 3 3.7 ≥4 External expert reviews of the content and presentation of the Court's reports The result shows that the reviewers consider the quality of the Court's reports to be 'satisfactory'.
The reviews provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports.
30 Follow-up to recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations to help improve financial management. For changes to take place, the Court's recommendations must first be accepted by the auditees and then implemented. The indicator is based on the recommendations in the annual and special reports published in 2009, ie the latest available.
2010 Target 90% ≥ 90% Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the auditee The Court aims to maintain or even improve on this high level of acceptance of its recommendations.
In 2010, the Court put in place a system to monitor the audited entities' implementation of the recommendations.
In the coming years, this system should serve as a basis for another indicator of the extent to which recommendations are put into practice and lead to improvements.
In addition, it will provide the Court with valuable insights for improving the quality of its recommendations and thus increasing their acceptance by the audited bodies.
31 Efficiency and effectiveness in use of resources The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources in terms of its ability to submit reports and audit findings in a timely manner, to fulfill its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and professional competence of its staff. Timeliness of reports The Court aims to adopt all scheduled reports within the set deadlines.
Deadlines laid down in legislation must be observed for the publication of the annual report and the specific annual reports.
For special reports for which there is no statutory publication date, the planned acceptance date is the deadline.
2010 target Number of reports adopted versus number of reports planned 90% 100% Proportion of reports adopted on time 80% 100% Overall, the Court fell short of the 2010 target.
The Court accepted fewer reports in 2010 than planned; the level of performance is comparable to that of the previous year (91% in 2009). In addition, while the proportion of reports adopted on time increased in 2010 (80% compared to 67% in 2009), there is still room for improvement.
While all annual reports and all but one special annual report were adopted and published on schedule, only three special reports were.
Adoption of six special reports was delayed until 2011.
The Court aims to achieve the targets by the end of 2012 by initiating further actions to improve the management of special report processes.
2010 Target Percentage of audit communications delivered on time 54% 80% by 2012 Performance in 2010 is still below the required level, but there has been significant progress towards the target over the past two years (43% per year 2009 and 27% in 2008).
The Court will continue its efforts to achieve the target. External assessment of financial management The Court aims to obtain an unqualified opinion on the annual accounts and the use of resources from its independent auditor and discharge from the European Parliament following a favorable recommendation from the Council.

Professional development In line with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court aims to provide auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional development.
2010 Target Average number of training days per person 5.7 days ≥ 5 days 33 In 2010 the required performance level was achieved, which means an improvement compared to 2009 (average of 4 days).
Level of staff satisfaction In an internal staff satisfaction survey carried out in 2009, 86 % of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their job, with an overall staff satisfaction level of 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4. Any score above 2.5 indicates overall satisfaction. The Court aims to maintain or improve on this result when a similar survey is carried out at the end of 2012.
34 AUDIT SUPPORT The success of the Court's audit work depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its technical services. These services provide the logistical and professional/technical know-how that enables the Court to: o recruit, retain and motivate its staff and develop their professional skills; o to disseminate the exam results in all official EU languages; o make the best possible use of information technology; o manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; o Conduct audit trips to all countries where EU funds are spent.
Staff Allocation of staff The Court's most important asset is its staff. At 31 December 2010 the Court's staff totaled 889 (officials and temporary agents but excluding members, contract agents, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 557 work in Audit Chambers (including 123 staff in Members' private offices), 151 in the Translation Directorate, 157 in administrative support services and 24 in the President's services. With a view to the goal of the best possible use of resources, in 2010 possibilities for increasing efficiency by simplifying processes and rationalizing services were again explored and implemented in all activities.
Wherever possible, posts freed up by efficiency gains outside the audit area have been transferred to the audit service, increasing the number of posts used for audit tasks by 6%. This process will continue in 2011.

37 Professional development The auditing profession requires constant training to keep up with new developments and acquire new skills.
Efforts were made in 2010 to implement the staff redeployment plan approved by the Secretary-General, which aims to transfer posts and staff from the Translation Service to the Audit Service in 2011. Based on the master plan for training 2008-2011 and the training pathways adopted in 2009, in 2010 the Professional Training Unit improved the content of the training activities and developed new training courses in line with the priorities decided by the Court.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate provided valuable linguistic support to auditors on missions and in the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
The Directorate for Translation also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the Court's audit work.
Work on the Artemis project to improve the functionality of this important IT application for translators continued in 2010. In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate actively participated in interinstitutional and international technical fora.
38 Information Technology Information Technology (IT) plays a key role in achieving the overall objectives of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy. Developments in 2010 were: • Launch of a collaborative platform in line with the IT Strategic Plan 2010-2012 to support knowledge sharing, particularly in the audit area; • Continued efforts to streamline and simplify internal processes through electronic workflows to increase efficiency and effectiveness; Management and infrastructure The Directorate for Finance and Support Services is responsible for providing the Court's auditors with adequate support in an efficient, effective and timely manner, and for ensuring that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are in place to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2010, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness in order to free up resources to be reallocated to the audit service. • Use of smart phones and laptop computers to enable audit work to be carried out efficiently anywhere and anytime, including as part of the Court's contingency plan.
Due to an agreement reached with the budgetary authority at the end of 2008 on the financing of the K3 building, one of the main activities in 2010 was the preparation of tenders for the construction and ancillary services and their publication by the project manager.
A large proportion of the orders for this project were awarded during the year. The time and budget framework of the construction project is adhered to. Completion is scheduled for the end of 2012.

AUDIT AND ACCOUNTABILITY Internal Audit The Court's Internal Audit Service aims to help the Court achieve its objectives through a systematic, methodical assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative processes. In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to increase the Court's efficiency based on assessments of the effectiveness of the Court's internal control systems.
In 2010, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on the follow-up of its recommendations from previous years, the review of the reform of the Court's ex ante verification system, the audit of the implementation of the SOS II/SAP system and compliance of the video surveillance system with data protection rules and requirements.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit service was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognized standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL - on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2009 was published in October 20107.

Audit Chambers I to IV cover various revenue and expenditure areas, while the fifth, CEAD Chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters. The chambers are supported by examination directorates.
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the field of auditing. The members submit audit proposals and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible to the relevant Chamber and the Court.
Members are assisted by their cabinet staff and the team of auditors assigned to the audit task.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2011
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS MISSION MISSION VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances under the Treaty.
As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognized for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, offering valuable support to its constituency with a view to improving EU financial management.
INDEPENDENCE, INTEGRITY AND IMPARTIALITY PROFESSIONALITY ADDED VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and collaborators.
Impartial scrutiny that takes the views of stakeholders into account but rejects any form of influence from outside direction or pressure.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Participation in the further development of public auditing at EU level and worldwide.
Produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports that are based on sound evidence and evidence, address the needs of its audience, and contain important and meaningful statements.
Contribute to an effective improvement of EU management and contribute to increasing accountability for the management of EU funds.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.
Increasing efficiency in all aspects of his work.

4 FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the European Court of Auditors' Annual Activity Report 2011.
In 2011, in the wake of the economic and financial crisis, there were significant developments in the EU's economic governance, which have important consequences for the future use of public funds.
Against this background, in May the Court published a position paper showing the impact on accountability, transparency and public audit of the measures taken to address the financial and economic crisis.
Later in the year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of EU Member States' supreme audit institutions (SAIs) and the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public audit are always applied when dealing with involves the use of public funds are duly observed.
In particular, the SAIs of the euro area called for appropriate arrangements for public external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
This resulted in a decision to set up an Audit Committee for the Stability Mechanism, which will include a member proposed by the Court.
In 2011, the results of our key performance indicators continue to be encouraging, particularly in relation to the follow-up of recommendations accepted by our auditees and the assessment of our audit work by users and external experts.
We increased our output in terms of the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011; nevertheless, we did not succeed in achieving the ambitious goals that we set ourselves with regard to the punctuality of reporting.
Our annual reports now contain even more detailed information and a new chapter on performance aspects. We also produced 42 special annual reports and 16 special reports, along with seven opinions and one position paper.
The scope of our institution's audit powers over the Union's revenue and expenditure, in particular the VAT resource in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011.
From 2012 we will be able to report on the extent to which our recommendations are being followed in practice.
We will also peer review our performance audit methodology with the aim of continuing to improve the process of producing our special reports.
In 2011 we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework and revised the Court's audit strategies and guidelines to streamline the audit workflow and reporting process.
In addition, we will launch a new employee satisfaction survey in 2012.
Looking ahead, in 2012 we will complete the preparation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017.
Some of the key challenges are already clear: the EU's regulatory environment will continue to evolve and we must continue to push for proper compliance with the principles of accountability, transparency and public audit.
The need for high quality and timely assurance on the use of EU funds is ever increasing and we need to evolve our audits and reports accordingly.
As the EU is constantly changing, we will endeavor to use our audit experience to the best of our ability to support policy makers in improving financial management.
Strengthening the EU's financial accountability is a goal we share with other actors and we will seek to combine our efforts by entering into strategic partnerships.
Finally, like the other EU institutions and bodies, we need to be prepared to do more with less to make our organization more efficient.
Meeting these challenges will depend crucially on the efforts of all the Court's staff.
The development of the excellence of our employees - a fundamental value of our institution - is and remains an important concern for us.
Looking at the professionalism, commitment and results achieved by our staff in the past, I am confident that the Court will be able to achieve these future goals.
Vítor Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President 5th
