Number of reports and opinions 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 Annual reports (EU general budget and EDF) 2 2 2 2 2 Annual specific reports on EU agencies and decentralized bodies 29 29 37 40 42 Special reports 9 12 18 14 16 Opinions and other communications 9 5 1 6 8 The full version of each report and opinion is available on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in 22 official EU languages.
This led to the release of the 2010 Annual Report, including the seventeenth Statement of Assurance (DAS), on November 10, 2011.
The 2010 annual report featured some changes to improve clarity and information.
These include a redesign of the policy groups (and corresponding annual report chapters) under which the Court groups expenditure, the publication of estimated error rates by policy area (see below), an increased focus on recommendations to improve financial management and a new chapter on performance aspects.
For the first time, the Court published estimated error rates for both the EU budget as a whole and for individual policy groups.
The error rates are obtained by extrapolating the quantifiable errors found in the sample of transactions checked.
The Court compares the estimated level of error to a materiality threshold of 2 % to determine whether the error is material, taking into account other evidence.
Error rates are not a measure of fraud but reflect the Court's estimate of the extent to which the rules governing expenditure have been breached.
This includes breaches of public procurement rules, ineligible or incorrectly calculated costs in projects co-financed by the EU, or over-declarations of area provided by farmers.
T he annual report 2010 key messages were as follows: o The annual accounts for the financial year 2010 fairly present the financial position of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year as a whole.
The payments on which these annual accounts are based, however, are afflicted with errors to a significant extent; the estimated error rate for the EU budget as a whole is 3.7%.
Overall, the control systems were partially effective in ensuring the regularity of payments. o The error rate estimated by the Court for spending on cohesion, energy and transport (the EU's most error-prone spending area) was 7.7%, higher than in 2009. o In the remaining EU spending areas, the error rate remained relatively stable.
In the area of agriculture and natural resources, the estimated error rate was 2.3%, which was above the materiality threshold.
However, the direct payments to farmers were free of material errors. o The share of advance payments - pre-financing - within the EU budget has increased significantly.
Accounting rules and supervisory arrangements have not been adapted accordingly. o When planning EU spending programmes, the Commission and Member States should pay more attention to setting SMART targets, ie specific, measurable, achievable, relevant and timed targets, but also to acknowledging any risks that may arise during implementation identify and contain.
ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUNDS 2010 In its Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDFs) for the financial year 2010 (published on 10 November 2011), the Court concluded that the 2010 annual accounts of the EDFs present the financial situation of the EDFs and the results of their Appropriately present transactions and cash flows in accordance with the financial regulations in all material respects.
The EDF's revenues are free from material error.
The EDF commitments were legal and regular, notwithstanding the non-quantifiable errors found in the area of procurement.
However, EDF payments for projects were affected by material errors; the estimated margin of error is 3.4%.
The errors found concerned non-compliance with eligibility conditions.
The Court's assessment was that, overall, the control systems put in place at the EDF only provide a limited guarantee of the regularity of payments.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE EU AGENCIES, DECENTRALIZED BODIES AND OTHER BODIES FOR 2010 In December 2011, the Court published specific annual reports on the financial year 2010 for all 42 EU agencies, decentralized bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other bodies (in particular the efficiency the administration of the European Central Bank).
The Court gave an unqualified opinion on all audited entities except for the European GNSS Agency because certain assets were not accounted for and for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking because the budget outturn account was not included in the annual accounts.
The EU agencies and decentralized bodies were set up by the EU legislator to carry out specific tasks.
Each agency has a mandate, board of directors, director, staff and budget.
The agencies work in many areas, such as security, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
11 President Caldeira presenting the 2010 annual report to the plenary session of the European Parliament
12 SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2011 In addition to its annual reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year containing the results of the performance and compliance audits that the Court carries out on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice.
In selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court aims to maximize impact and use its resources in the best possible way.
When selecting the topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: o the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; o the amount of the respective income or expenses; o the time elapsed since any previous check; o forthcoming developments within the relevant legal framework; o the political and public interest.
In 2011 the Court adopted 16 special reports on a range of subjects, an increase on the 14 special reports adopted in 2010.
These special reports are presented below in concise form under the relevant headings of the financial framework – the EU's multiannual budget.
The special reports are available in full in 22 EU languages on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu or via the EU Bookshop.
SUSTAINABLE GROWTH 13 Sustainable growth is about growth and jobs and has two themes: competitiveness includes fostering research and technological development, connecting Europe, education and training, fostering competitiveness in a fully integrated single market, the social policy agenda and the dismantling of nuclear facilities.
EU spending for growth and jobs over the period 2007-2013 amounts to €89.4 billion, ie 9.2% of the total, of which almost two-thirds goes to research and development. Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns the cohesion policy implemented in the form of funds dedicated to specific areas of activity – European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund and European Regional Development Fund.
The funds are spent under shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 is €348.4 billion (35.7% of the total EU budget).
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Effectiveness of the SME Guarantee Facility (Special Report No 4/2011) from the point of view of its design and planning, as well as the management of its related operations and the achievement of objectives.
The SME Guarantee Facility (SMEG Facility) is a financial instrument managed by the European Investment Fund on behalf of the European Commission. This facility provides financial intermediaries with guarantees or counter-guarantees for loans made by financial institutions to SMEs, thereby increasing the availability of debt financing. o Effectiveness of tourism projects co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report 6/2011) in terms of expected results, their sustainability, European added value and project design.
The audit was based on a broad survey of projects in new Member States and 26 regions.
In the period 2000-2006, the ERDF provided EU funds totaling 4.6 billion euros for physical investments in tourism projects. Projects are selected and managed by managing authorities in the Member States.
14 o Effectiveness of eGovernment projects funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report No. 9/2011) focusing on the programming period 2000-2006 and the four Member States Spain, France, Italy and Poland.
The audit assessed whether the co-financed projects were selected on the basis of identified needs, whether they were implemented according to plan and whether they were relevant and sustainable.
With the help of these 6.7 billion euros from the ERDF for the promotion of the information society, new secure technologies were to be developed, infrastructures expanded and regions connected via broadband. o Effectiveness of the Commission's management of state aid control (Special Report No. 15/2011).
The audit examined whether the procedures and systems ensure that the Commission deals with all relevant State aid cases, that cases are dealt with effectively and within the foreseen deadlines, and that they allow the Commission to monitor the impact of its state aid control.
It is the Commission's task to ensure that state aid granted by Member States is compatible with the European Union's internal market.
Member States must first notify aid measures to the Commission and obtain the Commission's approval before granting state aid. o Implementation of the EU financial support for the decommissioning of nuclear power plants in Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia (Special Report No. 16/2011) to assess whether the measures of the nuclear decommissioning programs were tailored to the needs, whether they were implemented as planned and whether the accountability and management structures were in place to ensure the effective use of EU funds.
As part of their EU accession negotiations, Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia committed themselves to the early shutdown and subsequent decommissioning of eight nuclear reactors that cannot be upgraded.
In response to the exceptional burden, the EU made available €2.9 billion in grants for the three country programs over the period 1999-2013.
The EU has high political responsibilities in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 is €413.1 billion, ie 42.3% of the total budget.
Three-quarters of spending concerns direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the 'first pillar' of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
More than a fifth of spending goes to EU support for rural development, funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second 'pillar' of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES In 2011 the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Single Payment Scheme under the Common Agricultural Policy (Special Report No 5/2011) - See box: "A close-up of a performance audit" o How well is it designed and managed of the funded agri-environmental measures? (Special Report No. 7/2011).
This report assesses whether agri-environment policy is designed and monitored in a way that delivers tangible environmental benefits, whether farmers are adequately supported through appropriate guidance and correctly set aid amounts, and whether the management of agri-environment policy takes specific environmental needs into account.
The aim of agri-environmental policy is to meet the increasing societal demand for environmental services by encouraging farmers to introduce or maintain production methods compatible with protecting and improving the environment.
Management of this area is shared between the Commission and the Member States. o Recovery of undue payments under the Common Agricultural Policy (Special Report No. 8/2011) to assess the effectiveness of the systems set up and operated by Member States to recover identified debts.
This audit examined whether Member States are properly recording and processing claims, whether Member States' actions to recover identified wrongful payments are successful, whether Member States deal with the derecognition of bad debts properly, and whether the Commission's monitoring and oversight is effective .
The European Union spends around 55 billion euros on agriculture and rural development every year. Some of the funds are wrongly disbursed due to irregular or incorrect claims. 15
16 o Effectiveness of the School Milk and School Fruit schemes (Special Report 10/2011) to assess whether EU support has a direct impact on consumption by beneficiaries and whether the schemes are capable of having the intended educational impact and influence future eating habits.
These EU programs aim to encourage children to eat healthily by consuming dairy products and fruit and vegetables; another objective is to help improve market conditions for these products.
The EU currently provides annual funds of 180 million euros for these two programmes. o Is the design and management of the Geographical Indications regime enabling it to be effective? (Special Report No. 11/2011).
As part of this audit, the reliability of the control system, the attractiveness of the scheme for producers and its awareness among consumers were assessed.
The aim of the EU regime for geographical indications is to protect the names of products that have a link between their characteristics and the geographical area from which they originate.
The scheme offers economic opportunities for farmers and food producers and can have a positive impact on rural economies in EU regions. o Effectiveness of EU measures to adapt fishing fleet fishing capacity to existing fishing opportunities (Special Report No. 12/2011).
The audit examined whether there was a clear framework for reducing fleet capacity and whether the specific measures were precisely defined and implemented.
The audit took place at the Commission and in Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Poland, Portugal and the UK.
The aim of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy is to promote sustainable fisheries by establishing a balance between fish stocks and the fishing fleet in order to avoid overfishing of stocks.
Overcapacity in the fishing fleet has been a problem for many years. It threatens both the sustainability of fish stocks and the long-term viability of the fisheries sector.
EUR 4.3 billion will be made available from the European Fisheries Fund for the 2007-2013 programming period.
17 PERFORMANCE AUDIT CLOSE-UP SPECIAL REPORT NO. 5/2011 SPECIAL PAYMENT SCHEME: ISSUES FOR BETTER FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT This performance audit covered the sound financial management of payments under the SPS currently applied in 17 of the 27 EU Member States.
Expenditure related to this scheme amounted to around EUR 28.8 billion in 2009.
The introduction of the SPS was a key element of the 2003 reform of the EU's Common Agricultural Policy.
The aim of this scheme was to encourage farm owners to be more responsive to market demands and to provide them with income support.
In the course of the reform, the link between support and production was broken ("decoupling").
Instead, farmers must have eligible agricultural land and 'payment entitlements'.
From 2006 the Court undertook a series of audits of the procedures put in place at the Commission and in the Member States to ensure the accuracy of payment entitlements and the correctness of payments to farmers.
These audits covered all 17 Member States applying the scheme. The results of these audits fed into the 2006 and 2007 annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget.
Based on these results, the Court decided to carry out a performance audit focusing on: o the beneficiaries of the scheme, access to SPS and the definition of eligible land; o the contribution of the scheme to the objectives of income support for farmers and keeping farmland in good agricultural and environmental condition; o the specific consequences of using the different models to implement the scheme.
Audit visits took place in 2009 and 2010 at the Commission, France, Italy and the UK.
The conclusion of the resulting Special Report No 5/2011 was that the SPS has contributed to the achievement of the two main objectives of the Common Agricultural Policy: it has encouraged farmers to be more responsive to market demands and it has supported the income of the farming sector as a whole .
Generally speaking, however, several questionable features have emerged in the implementation of the scheme, such as the definition of the beneficiaries of this policy, the types of eligible parcels and activities, the impact of the scheme on the environment, the distribution of the aid from Member State to Member State and within of the Member States and the particular impact of the historical and regional models.
18 The Court recommends in the report that it is better if the SPS goes to active farmers and non-agricultural parcels and activities that do not contribute to increasing agricultural productivity or actively maintaining the environmental value of the land are excluded from support.
In addition, the Court recommends that the level of SPS takes into account the costs of environmental and other externalities and that a more balanced distribution of support among farmers is sought.
The calculation of the SPS should be based on current farming conditions.
The examination was conducted by a multidisciplinary team of eight Chamber I examiners. The audit work not only shed further light on the concept of the decoupled SPS, but also on how the transition process from the previous coupled support scheme to the current scheme is affecting it.
According to team leader Sven Kölling, examining the diverse models and variants for implementing the scheme, together with the juxtaposition of national and regional management strategies and their impact on the economy and effectiveness of the payment, presented a particular challenge.
Audit visits to the final beneficiaries and on-the-spot checks at the premises proved essential to obtain the audit evidence to support the findings and conclusions.
Many of the Court's recommendations have been reflected in the Commission's proposals for the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy after 2013 (under discussion at the time of writing this report), including the definition of an 'active farmer' and minimum activities on certain areas, distribution of premium payments to beneficiaries, reducing the variety of implementation models for the SPS and better considering environmental externalities in the calculation of SPS.
Test team from left to right: (first row) Heike Walz, court member Michel Cretin, Aurelia Petliza, (second row) Pietro Puricella, Dirk Pauwels, Sven Kölling, Sylvain Lehnhard
THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER 19 The EU's external relations activities focus on enlargement, bringing about stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, actively supporting sustainable development at international level, promoting global political governance and ensuring the strategic and civil security.
The EU has earmarked EUR 55.9 billion for the period 2007-2013, ie 5.7% of its total planned expenditure, for these objectives.
Most of the expenditure is managed by the Commission directly through its central services or its delegations.
Some funding measures are also jointly managed with international organisations.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Has the devolution of the management of external assistance from the Commission's central services to its delegations led to better delivery of aid?
(Special Report No. 1/2011).
The purpose of the audit was to examine the management arrangements and their impact on speeding up the delivery and improving the quality of aid and establishing stable financial procedures.
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid, with much of this aid (€8.4 billion in 2009) managed by the Commission under its management system. Under this system, from 2002, powers were delegated to the Commission's field offices in the partner countries. o Efficiency and effectiveness of EU contributions channeled through United Nations agencies in conflict-affected countries (Special Report No. 3/2011) with a focus on projects in Afghanistan, Iraq and Sudan in 2006-2008.
In the period 2005-2009, EuropeAid provided around 4 billion euros via UN organisations.
The EU can provide funds as a sole donor or jointly with other donors, as contributions to trust funds without earmarking the funds for specific activities or objectives, or as a contribution to the general budget of a UN agency. o Effectiveness of EU assistance in improving Croatia's ability to manage post-accession funds (Special Report No. 14/2011) to assess the Commission's planning of assistance and whether the projects financed with EU funds are achieving the intended results became.
The aim of EU pre-accession assistance is to help candidate countries build their administrative capacity to prepare them to manage the larger EU grants to which they will be entitled as Member States.
EU pre-accession assistance for Croatia has amounted to EUR 150 million annually since 2007.
The budget of the European Union is mainly financed from own resources and other revenues.
Traditional own resources - mainly customs duties - account for around 12% and the VAT own resource for another 12% of total revenue.
The bulk of the EU's own resource (70%) comes from the Gross National Income-derived own resource, which ensures that the budget is always in balance.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Management of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) (Special Report No. 2/2011) evaluating the measures taken to implement the recommendations of the previous Special Report No. 1/2005 of the Hofes have been taken on this subject.
The starting point of the audit was whether OLAF has now shifted the focus of its activities to its investigative function and is more efficient in its investigations, how it demonstrates the effectiveness of its investigative work and whether the role of the Supervisory Committee has been clarified.
OLAF's mission is to fight fraud and any other illegal activity affecting the EU budget.
The Office is attached to the Commission but has full independence in conducting its investigations and employs around 500 staff. Its annual expenses amount to around 50 million euros.
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: o Does the control of customs procedure 42 prevent and detect VAT evasion? (Special Report No. 13/2011). As part of this audit, we examined whether there is a sound legal framework for tackling VAT evasion under customs procedure 42.
Tests were carried out in Belgium, Denmark, Spain, France, Austria, Slovenia and Sweden.
Customs procedure 42 is a mechanism used by an EU importer to obtain a VAT exemption.
The procedure applies when goods imported into one Member State from outside the EU are transported to another Member State.
In such cases, VAT is due in the Member State of destination.
OPINIONS AND POSITION PAPERS ISSUED IN 2011 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legislation with a financial impact.
These opinions are issued at the request of the other EU institutions and are used by the legislative authorities - the European Parliament and the Council - in their work.
The Court can also issue position papers on other issues on its own initiative.
In 2011, the Court adopted seven opinions: o 1/2011: Proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 215/2008 on the financial rules applicable to the tenth European Development Fund as regards the European External Action Service o 2 /2011: Financial Regulation of the Clean Sky Joint Undertaking o 3/2011: Proposal to amend the Financial Regulation of the European Schools o 4/2011: Commission Green Paper on Modernizing European Public Procurement Policy o 5/2011: Proposal for a Regulation (Euratom) of the Council on the rules for the participation of undertakings, research centers and universities in indirect actions of the framework program of the European Atomic Energy Community and for the dissemination of research results (2012-2013) o 6/2011: Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1073/1999 on investigations by the European Office for Anti-Fraud (OLAF) and repealing Regulation (Euratom) No 1074/1999 Opinion 7/2011 concerned proposals for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on cohesion spending, covering up to 45% of EU Overall expenditure for the period 2014-2020 could be eliminated.
The contribution made by the EU budget to the Europe 2020 targets therefore depends to a large extent on the economical, efficient and effective use of these funds.
This will also affect the credibility and legitimacy of EU action.
The EU remains challenged to achieve good quality results from a regime where funds are pre-allocated among Member States and absorption of these funds is an implicit objective.
Effective monitoring and accountability by the Commission would help Member States to use the funds successfully.
The opinions are available in full in all official EU languages on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu. 21
22 COURT POSITION PAPER: IMPLICATIONS OF THE CURRENT FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS ON PUBLIC ACCOUNTABILITY AND PUBLIC FINANCIAL CONTROL WITHIN THE EU AND ON THE ROLE OF THE COURT The ongoing global financial and economic crisis has had far-reaching consequences for the European Union.
To address the crisis, the EU took action to ensure the long-term sustainability of the financial sector, support economic recovery and growth, provide financial assistance to Member States and strengthen fiscal and economic policy coordination between Member States.
In addition, these measures have a decisive influence on how public funds, ie EU citizens' taxpayers' money, are spent in the Union.
These changes in the Union's regulatory fabric pose new challenges in terms of accountability, transparency and public audit.
In the Court's view, the principle that applies to the implementation of these new measures is that whenever public funds are involved, there should be appropriate arrangements for transparency, public accountability and public auditing.
The Court therefore adopted on 19 May 2011 a position paper on the implications of the current financial and economic crisis for public accountability and public auditing in the EU and for the role of the Court.
In this position paper, the Court concluded that we will cover the new supervisory authorities, the support mechanisms with EU budgetary guarantees and, where possible, the Commission's activities in the context of the European Semester in our audits.
In the Court's view, the treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism should provide for some form of external public financial control.
Finally, the Court notes that in a number of cases, accountability and transparency issues need to be reconsidered by the relevant EU institutions, in particular the European Parliament and the Council.
COOPERATION WITH OTHER SAIs The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) mainly in the following bodies: o Contact Committee of SAIs of EU Member States; o Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; o International organizations of public sector audit bodies, in particular the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
CONTACT COMMITTEE In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies work together in a spirit of trust while respecting their independence.
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of the EU Member States through the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee brings together the Presidents of the EU SAIs and the Court once a year.
The Contact Committee provides a forum for cooperation and the exchange of expertise and experience in the field of auditing EU funds and other EU issues.
Working groups have been set up to help develop common positions and approaches.
In 2011, the Court was Acting Chair of the Contact Committee, continued to provide administrative support to the Committee and actively participated in the various working groups and networks.
The 2011 annual meeting of the Contact Committee took place on 13 and 14 October 2011 at the Court's premises.
The session focused on a seminar on the impact of the European Semester and other recent developments in EU economic governance on EU SAIs and the Court.
In this context, the regulation and supervision of financial systems and financial institutions, state aid to the financial sector and the examination of the mechanisms to deal with the euro crisis were dealt with, among other things.
The Contact Committee adopted a declaration addressed to the European Parliament, the European Council and the European Commission, as well as the parliaments and governments of the EU Member States.
In addition, the Contact Committee adopted a resolution to address the call from the SAIs of the euro area countries for adequate external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism.
The statement and resolution are available on the Contact Committee website (www.contactcommittee.eu).

28 OTHER ACTIVITIES POWERS OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS RELATED TO THE AUDIT OF VAT OWN RESOURCES On 15 November 2011 the Court of Justice delivered its judgment in Case C-539/09 Commission v. Federal Republic of Germany concerning the audit powers of the European Court of Auditors in the field of own resources, derived from Value Added Tax (VAT).
The case stems from the refusal by the German Federal Ministry of Finance in 2006 to allow the European Court of Auditors to carry out audits on administrative cooperation between Member States in the field of VAT under Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 in Germany .
In preparing its Special Report No 8/2007, the Court decided to carry out audits in eight Member States, including Germany.
The German authorities objected to the Court's right to carry out the audit in question.
The reason given by the German government was that the administrative cooperation between the Member States, regulated by Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003, had no direct link with EU revenue, since VAT is a national tax and therefore part of the VAT own resource be different.
The latter are established following a series of calculations and represent a relatively small proportion of the amounts collected as VAT by Member States.
The Court of Justice firmly rejected the German Government's argument based on a strict distinction between Member States' VAT revenue and the Union's own VAT resource.
Following the arguments put forward by the Commission, the European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors, the Court of Justice emphasized the dependence of the VAT own resource on the VAT revenue of the Member States.
The Court of Justice confirmed that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 on administrative cooperation in the field of VAT extended to establishing cooperation mechanisms between Member States enabling them to combat VAT evasion more effectively and collect VAT more effectively.
This also affects the availability of the VAT own resource for the EU budget.
Cooperation between national authorities, if carried out effectively and in accordance with the Regulation, can contribute to reducing fraud and the effective collection of VAT in the Member States, as well as keeping the VAT-based own resource at the level required by the various relevant legal acts of the EU, and thereby to maintain the overall balance of own resources.
The Court of Justice concluded that the Court of Auditors was competent to carry out the envisaged audit in relation to administrative cooperation in the field of VAT, since it related to the EU's revenue from the point of view of its legality and sound financial management and was therefore directly linked to the powers conferred on the Court of Auditors by the Treaty.
In Case C-539/09, the Court of Justice had to rule explicitly for the first time on the scope of the Court's audit powers.
The Court's ruling is valuable and encouraging because it clarifies and underpins the institution's powers of scrutiny over Member States.

This inaugural award commemorated Jesús Lázaro Cuenca, a former Director of the Court who over many years contributed to the development of the institution's audit methods and approaches.

ETHICAL GUIDELINES FOR THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS Following the recommendation of the peer review carried out by an international panel of experts in 2008, the Court strengthened its audit management framework by adopting ethical guidelines based on the INTOSAI Code of Ethics and the International Standard on Quality Assurance build within the SAI3.
In this context, the Court has put in place a process to provide reasonable assurance, on an annual basis, that its auditors comply with the relevant ethical requirements.
Adherence to the values of impartiality, objectivity, loyalty and professional secrecy set out in the ethical guidelines ensures that the Court's staff act in the public interest, uninfluenced by external pressure and uninfluenced by personal or financial interests.
The Court's framework for professional conduct promotes the credibility of the information presented to its audience.

MEASURING THE COURT'S PERFORMANCE IN 2011 33 Since 2008, the Court has progressively developed a set of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to: o inform management on progress towards the implementation of the 2009-2012 objectives; o to support the decision-making process; o to provide the target group with performance-related information.
The indicators are designed to measure core parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, paying particular attention to the perspective of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
2011 is the second year that all indicators were available.
The Court continues to be encouraged by the results of its key performance indicators, particularly when it comes to the quality and impact of its audit work.
In addition, the indicators clearly show where progress is needed and where issues need to be addressed in order to improve performance in the future.
2010 2011 4.2 4.0 ≥ 4.2 3.7 3.7 ≥ 3.7 Key users' assessments of the quality and impact of the Court's reports 2011 target Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work by the audited bodies The result shows that the main users of the Court's reports rate them as 'good' on average.
In particular, the clarity and usefulness of the reports and the professionalism of the Court's auditors are appreciated.
34 EXPERT REVIEWS Two external bodies reviewed the content and presentation of a sample of the Court's reports published in 2011.
The auditors assessed four special reports and the 2010 annual reports on the general budget and the EDFs.
They rated the quality of various aspects of the reports on a four-point scale from “seriously impaired” (1) to “high” (4).

The reviews provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports.
FOLLOW-UP TO RECOMMENDATIONS The Court's recommendations help to improve financial management.
The indicator is based on the recommendations in the annual and special reports published in 2011.
2010 2011 90% 93% ≥ 90% Target for 2011 Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the auditee In 2011 the Court started to systematically monitor the implementation of the recommendations by the auditees.
From 2012, the Court can report on the extent to which the recommendations are being put into practice and making improvements.
EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF RESOURCE USE The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources in terms of its ability to submit reports and audit findings in a timely manner, to fulfill its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and professional competence of its staff.
TIMELINESS OF REPORTS The Court aims to adopt all audit reports within the set deadlines.
Deadlines laid down in legal regulations must be observed for the annual reports and special annual reports.
For special reports that do not have a statutory publication date, the planned acceptance date is used as a measure of timeliness.
35 4 2010 90% Number of reports adopted on time 80% 2011 83% 90% 75% 90% Overall, in 2011 the Court did not fully meet its targets.
The very high target for the number of reports was not met, but the overall target of 12-15 special reports per year was exceeded and the output was higher than in 2010.
All annual reports and, with one exception, all special annual reports were accepted as planned and published on time.
4 The targets for these indicators have been changed from 100% (2008-2010) to 90% to take account of unexpected events.
TIMELINESS OF AUDIT FINDINGS Audit communications detail specific audit findings and are produced following audit visits to Member States or the Commission.
The Court uses them to have the audited entities confirm the accuracy of its findings. Audit notifications are therefore an important stage in the audit process.
The Court has previously found that there is room for significant improvement in the production of the audit notes in relation to timeliness. The target to be reached by the end of 2012 is to produce 80% of the audit communications within two months of the relevant audit visit.
2010 2011 Percentage of audit communications on time 54% 58% Target for 20114 Number of reports accepted vs. planned reports Target for 2011 80% by 2012 The Court improved the timeliness of audit communications in 2011, but the target was met not reached yet.
Significant progress has been made over the past three years (in 2008 only 27% of audit communications were timely) and the Court will continue to strive to improve its performance.
36 EXTERNAL EVALUATION OF FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT The Court aims to obtain an unqualified opinion on the accounts and use of resources from its independent auditor and discharge from the European Parliament following a favorable recommendation from the Council.
PROFESSIONAL TRAINING In line with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court aims to provide auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training (excluding language courses).
LEVELS OF STAFF SATISFACTION In an internal staff satisfaction survey carried out in 2009, 86 % of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their job, with an overall staff satisfaction level of 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4. Any score above 2.5 indicates overall satisfaction.
The Court aims to maintain or improve on this result when a similar survey is carried out in 2012.
SUPPORT TO AUDIT ACTIVITIES The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its technical services.
These services provide the logistical and professional/technical know-how that enables the Court to: o recruit, retain and motivate its staff and develop their professional skills; o to disseminate the exam results in all official EU languages; o make the best possible use of information technology; o manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; o Carry out on-the-spot verification visits to the countries where EU funds are collected and spent.
37 STAFF ALLOCATION OF STAFF The Court's most important asset is its staff.
As at 31 December 2010, the Court had 887 staff (officials and temporary agents but excluding members, contract agents, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 564 work in audit chambers (including 123 staff in Members' offices), 148 in the Translation Directorate, 148 in administrative support services and 27 in the President's services.
With a view to the goal of the best possible use of resources, in 2011 possibilities for increasing efficiency by simplifying procedures were again explored and implemented in all departments.
Wherever possible, posts freed up by efficiency gains outside audit have been transferred to the audit service, accounting for more than half of the 12.6% increase in audit posts since 2008.

38 RECRUITMENTS The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and commitment is reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both officials and temporary staff.
Open competitions for posts at the Court are organized by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also provides for a limited PROPORTION OF MEN AND WOMEN Like the other EU institutions, the Court applies an equal opportunities policy in its human resources and recruitment policies.
After steadily increasing the proportion of women over the years, the Court has now achieved a gender balance among its staff.
In 2011, the Court recruited 75 staff: 23 officials, 24 temporary agents and 28 contract agents.
In particular, the Court succeeded in recruiting new staff for auditor posts.
As of December 31, 2011, there were 25 vacancies - significantly fewer than in 2010 (44).
As a result, the rate of vacancies fell below 3% for the first time.

Of the 65 directors and heads of unit, 18 (28%) are women, which is in line with the trend over the last few years.
However, most of them work in the Translation Directorate and in the administrative services.
After the last waves of recruitment, 45% of staff in grades AD5 to AD8 are women.

39 3.8% 16.3% 20.7% 19.2% 17.5% 11.5% 7.6% 3.4% PROFESSIONAL TRAINING The auditing profession requires constant training to keep up with new developments can and acquire new skills.
In 2011, the Court's staff completed an average of 9.3 days of professional development.
Language courses accounted for 54% of the total number of training days (compared to 57% in 2010).
In addition to language courses, auditors completed 6.1 days of professional development in 2011, thereby meeting an important objective of the institution.
In 2011, improvements were made to the content of the training measures and new courses were developed to meet the priorities in the examination area.
The Court has also streamlined the management system for training activities.
TRANSLATION Translation is an important audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfill its mandate and achieve its communication goals.
In 2011, the translation volume was comparable to the workload of 2010.
Over 99% of the translation services were rendered on time.
In 2011, further posts and employees were transferred from the Translation Directorate to the Audit Service.
The Court's Translation Directorate also provided valuable linguistic support to auditors on missions and in the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
In addition, the Directorate for Translation provided support to the INTOSAI Contact Committee, working groups, and other specific needs related to the Court's audit work.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate actively participated in interinstitutional and international technical fora.
40 INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology (IT) plays a key role in achieving the overall objectives of the Court's strategy for 2009-2012.
In 2011 the Court took the following actions: o increased its investment in knowledge management by initiating the development of a new version of the audit support tool (project called 'Assyst2') based on the recently established collaborative platform; o actively pursuing its efforts to streamline internal processes through electronic workflows in areas such as mission and training management, and electronic archiving of personnel files to continuously increase efficiency and effectiveness; o Continued support for mobility through the use of smartphones and laptop computers, and launching a project for an extranet, which will also play a key role in facilitating electronic exchanges with a wide range of ECA partners (including auditees, budgetary authority, newly recruited employees, suppliers).
These developments have been carried out while strengthening operational security and emergency preparedness to ensure the required availability and quality of all the Court's IT services.
ADMINISTRATION AND INFRASTRUCTURE The Directorate for Finance and Support Services is responsible for providing the Court's auditors with adequate support in an efficient, effective and timely manner, and for ensuring that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are in place to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2011, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness in order to free up resources to be reallocated to the audit service.
Due to an agreement reached with the budgetary authority (Parliament and Council) at the end of 2008 regarding the financing of the K3 building, a priority activity in 2011 was the construction of the second extension building to the main building of the court.
The construction work was completed during 2011 and the shell was weatherproofed at the end of the year.
Great progress was made in the interior design.
The time and budget framework of the construction project is adhered to.
The court is expected to take possession of the building by the end of 2012, with the moves to take place in the first quarter of 2013.
Analysis carried out in 2009 and 2010 led the Court to conclude that its security objectives could best be achieved and risks managed most efficiently and cost-effectively if reception and security services were provided in-house.
This was achieved in April 2011 by replacing the external security services contractor with a small team of contract staff.
Annual costs will be more than 0.5 million euros lower in 2012 than in 2009.
AUDIT VISITS The Court's audit work requires auditors to travel to the Member States and other beneficiaries of EU funds, as well as to the headquarters of international organizations such as the United Nations.
The purpose of these audit visits is to obtain direct audit evidence.
The visits are usually to central and local authorities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as to the respective final recipients.
Within the EU, the audit visits are often carried out in liaison with the SAIs of the visited Member State.
Audit teams typically consist of two to three examiners and audit trips can take up to two weeks, depending on the nature of the audit and the distance.

A similar number of audit visits were made to the EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg.

46 AUDIT AND ACCOUNTABILITY INTERNAL AUDIT The role of the Internal Audit Service is to provide independent and objective assurance and advice designed to add value and improve the Court's activities.
It supports the Court in the achievement of the institution's objectives by applying a systematic and rigorous approach to assessing and making recommendations to improve the effectiveness of risk management, control and governance processes.
In carrying out its task, the Internal Audit Service acts in accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, the legislation applicable to EU officials and the International Standards of Internal Auditing Practice.
In 2009, the Court's internal audit service was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognized standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE COURT The annual accounts of the European Court of Auditors are audited by an independent auditor.
This is a core part of the Court's efforts to ensure that it applies to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the entities it audits.
In 2011, the Court's internal audit service issued reports on: the implementation of the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012; Implementation of the key performance indicators; construction of the Court's new K3 building; Using the escrow account to make payments to Eligible Beneficiaries; Follow-up to previous recommendations.
The internal audit service fully assisted the Court's independent auditor in his audit of the Court's accounts and the effectiveness of its internal control procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee advises on internal audit matters and oversees the related internal control environment as part of the institution's risk management processes.
In 2011, the Internal Audit Committee and the Internal Auditor analyzed the results of the internal audit service's audits, the implementation of the action plans affecting the internal control environment and the risks to the governance of the institution.
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL - on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2010 was published in September 20116.

GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union, based in Luxembourg.
The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body of 27 members, with one member from each Member State.
Its members are appointed by the Council for a six-year term after consultation with the European Parliament.
The members elect a president from among their number for three years, with the possibility of re-election.
The court is organized by chambers to which the members are assigned.
The Chambers prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
Audit Chambers I to IV cover various revenue and expenditure areas, while the fifth, CEAD Chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters.
The chambers are supported by examination directorates.
Since the amendment of the Court's Rules of Procedure in 2010, certain categories of Court reports and opinions can be adopted by chambers rather than by the Court's entire College.
The Management Committee is chaired by the President and is composed of the Dean of the Chambers and the Secretary-General (responsible for the Court's administrative and support services).
The Committee has a coordinating role and prepares the Court's decisions on strategic planning, performance management and administrative matters.
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the field of auditing.
The members submit audit proposals and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible to the relevant Chamber and the Court.
Once a report has been adopted, it is presented by the "Rapporteur Member" to the European Parliament, the Council and other relevant stakeholders.
Members are assisted by their cabinet staff and the team of auditors assigned to the audit task. 49

3 EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS MISSION MISSION VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances under the Treaty.
As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management, promotes accountability and transparency and acts as the independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
INDEPENDENCE, INTEGRITY AND IMPARTIALITY PROFESSIONALITY ADDED VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its collaborators.
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Active participation in the further development of public auditing at EU level and worldwide.
Produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports that are based on sound evidence and evidence, address the needs of its audience, and contain important and meaningful statements.
Contribute to effectively improving the management of the EU budget and contribute to increasing accountability for the management of EU funds.
Promoting team spirit through effective communication.
5 Contents page 6 Foreword of President 8 2012 on a look 9 Our activities 9 Examination reports and statements 30 Cooperation with other top invoice control authorities 34 Our management 35 Change in the college of the court 36 measurement data for the performance of the court 44 Support of the examination activities 49 Financial information 52 Exam and accountability 53 DECLARATION BY THE AUTHORIZING OFFICER BY DELEGATION 54 35 YEARS DEDICATED TO MAKING THE EU BETTER FUNCTIONING 6 FOREWORD BY THE PRESIDENT Welcome to the European Court of Auditors' Annual Activity Report 2012!
In 2012, a major focus of our work was to prepare the Union for the major financial management challenges after 2013.
At the beginning of the year, the Court adopted its opinion on some proposed regulations relating to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), arguably the most well-known EU policy.
The draft regulation was part of the package of legislative proposals related to the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020.
With a series of opinions and reports published in 2012, the Court actively contributed to strengthening the new rules that will govern EU revenue and expenditure over this period.
In addition, in 2012 we continued to closely monitor the impact of EU economic governance developments on public accountability and auditing.
That year the treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism entered into force and the Audit Committee of this new body, which includes a representative of the Court, held its first meeting.
In December 2012, the Council of the European Union agreed its position on the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism to ensure the supervision of euro area credit institutions and the Court provided EU policymakers with its position on public accountability and financial control.
Many changes in the area of economic governance and the EU budget result from the need to achieve better policy outcomes with fewer public resources, while at the same time increasing democratic legitimacy and accountability.
The Court's unique powers and perspective combined with the audit experience and partnerships it has built up over its 35-year history are well placed to help the EU meet these challenges.
Building on our achievements in recent years, our aim is to maximize our contribution to improving EU accountability over the period 2013-2017.
The farm is currently celebrating its 35th anniversary.
Europe has changed fundamentally since the Court began its work in 1977.
The layout of the Court and the way it conducts its trials reflect these changes.
The Court's audit scope has expanded with the accession of new Member States, the transfer of competences to the Union and the creation of numerous bodies at EU level.
The Court has also grown as a body, from nine members and 120 staff in 1977 to 27 members and almost 900 staff in 2012.
This growth has enabled the Court to build a professional, dedicated and experienced workforce.
2012 was the last year covered by the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012.
The Court recorded encouraging results over this period.
As evidenced by this Annual Activity Report, output has increased, external experts rate the quality of our reports as good, and key institutional stakeholders find them useful.
The level of acceptance of the Court's recommendations by the Commission has remained consistently high and the Court's new follow-up report highlights the positive impact of the recommendations.
The Court can also demonstrate efficiency gains in administration and translation, which led to 40 additional staff being deployed in the audit area at the end of the period.
In order to achieve the 2013-2017 targets, the Court will prioritize products to improve EU accountability and develop and expand its partnerships, professionalism and efficiency.
In 2013, an international peer review team will examine the Court's performance audit practice and follow up on the results of the previous peer review of 2008.
Other key actions to be launched in 2013 include streamlining the Court's reporting processes and making even better use of our collective knowledge, expertise and expertise.
With these and other initiatives, we aim to help the EU address its growing public accountability and audit challenges in the coming years.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 7

9 OUR ACTIVITIES AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: o Annual Reports - containing the results of its financial and compliance audits on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Funds (EDFs); in addition, specific annual reports on EU agencies, decentralized bodies and agencies are published separately; o Special Reports – which may be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits on specific budget or management areas; these are mainly performance audits; o Opinions on draft legal acts affecting financial management and statements and position papers on other issues at the Court's own initiative.
Since 2008, the number of the Court's special annual reports and special reports has increased significantly.
The annual reports have also been further developed: more analytical information is now available, the presentation of the data has been more harmonized to facilitate comparison both between domains and over time, and a new chapter on performance-related questions has been added.
The significant increase in opinions issued is due to the fact that the Court was consulted on the large legislative proposals related to the new financial framework (2014-2020).

10 AUDIT VISITS IN 2012 While the vast majority of audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also visit the EU institutions, agencies and decentralized bodies, Member State authorities and other beneficiaries of EU funds ( also at the headquarters of international organizations such as the United Nations in Switzerland).
The audit visits usually target central and local authorities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as the respective final recipients.
Within the EU, the audit visits are often carried out in liaison with the SAIs of the Member States visited.
Audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners and the duration of an audit trip can range from a few days to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and the distance.
In 2012, the Court's auditors spent 6 816 days on-site – 6 054 in Member States and 762 outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports, the specific annual reports and the selected tasks.
They spent a similar amount of time with the EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg.

11 Highlights of the Annual Report 2011 o The annual accounts for the financial year 2011 fairly present the financial position of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year concerned.
Revenue and commitments were not affected by material error.
However, the payments were affected by a material level of error, with the estimated error rate for the EU budget as a whole being 3.9%.
This error rate is comparable to that of 2010, which was 3.7%. o All individually assessed areas of EU spending are affected by a material level of error, with the exception of external relations, external assistance and enlargement, and administrative expenditure.
This shows that improvements are still needed in the management of EU funds. o The Court's estimated error rate for spending on rural development, environment, fisheries and health (the most error-prone spending area) was 7.7%.
The estimated level of error for the policy group regional policy, energy and transport remained high at 6.0%. o Commission reservations have increased, with the amount considered at risk by Commission Directors-General increasing from €0.4 billion in 2010 to €2.0 billion in 2011.
This is because the Commission has recognized the existence of a high risk of error in some areas, notably rural development, cohesion and research. o Overall, the control systems examined are only partially effective in ensuring the regularity of payments and do not prevent or detect and correct errors to the extent that it would be reasonably possible.
Many cases were identified where the controls failed. o The Commission's self-assessment of its performance has evolved, with welcome improvements compared to previous years.
Nonetheless, our 2011 performance audits found that good quality needs assessments are often lacking, weaknesses in program design hamper reporting of results and impacts and the need for the Commission to demonstrate European added value.
ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2011 The Court devoted most of its financial and compliance audits during 2012 to the implementation of the EU budget for 2011.
The 2011 annual report resulting from this work was published on November 6, 2012.
The objective of the annual report is to help the European Parliament, the Council and citizens to assess the quality of EU financial management and to recommend useful improvements by providing findings and conclusions.
The 18th annual Statement of Assurance ("DAS") on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the underlying transactions is the core element of the annual reports for the financial year 2011.
Two new chapters have been added to the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2011, providing more focused results for the areas of agriculture and cohesion.
The former chapter on agriculture and natural resources has been replaced by the chapters 'Agriculture: market support and direct payments' and 'Rural development, environment, fisheries and health'.
In addition, the separate chapters "Regional Policy, Energy and Transport" and "Employment and Social Affairs" replace the former chapter on Cohesion, Energy and Transport.
12 EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUNDS ANNUAL REPORT 2011 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are financed by the EU Member States but managed outside the EU budget. They are subject to their own financial regulations.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of measures financed from EDF funds.
Through the European Development Funds (EDFs), the European Union provides development cooperation assistance to the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCT) countries, on the basis of the 2000 Agreement Cotonou Agreement.
This spending is aimed at reducing and eventually eradicating poverty, in line with the goals of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP and OCT countries into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars, namely development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2011 annual report on the EDFs was published in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget on 6 November 2012.
The Court found that the 2011 accounts of the EDFs fairly present the financial position of the EDFs and the results of their operations and cash flows.
However, 33% of EDF transactions were affected by errors, including an estimated 5.1% rate of payments affected by error.
SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS ON EU AGENCIES, DECENTRALIZED BODIES AND AGENCIES FOR 2011 In 2012, the Court published 50 special annual reports, mostly covering the financial year 2011, on the agencies, decentralized bodies (e.g. Joint Undertakings) and other bodies of the EU EU.
The EU agencies and decentralized bodies are set up on the basis of EU legal acts to carry out specific tasks.
President Caldeira presenting the Annual Report 2011 to the plenary session of the European Parliament (November 2012)
SPECIAL REPORTS ADOPTED IN 2012 In addition to its annual reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year containing the results of the performance and compliance audits that the Court carries out on specific budget areas or management issues of its choice.
In selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court aims to achieve maximum impact, thereby making the best use of its resources.
When selecting the topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: o the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; o the amount of the respective income or expenses; o the time elapsed since a previous test; o forthcoming developments within the relevant legal framework; o the political and public interest.
In 2012, the Court adopted 25 special reports covering a wide range of topics.
This is a significant increase from the 16 special reports adopted in 2011 (and 12 in 2008).
All special reports are available in full in 22 EU languages on the Court's website http://eca.europa.eu or through the EU Bookshop.
The following pages present the subjects of the special reports adopted in 2012, each under the relevant headings of the 2013-2017 financial framework – the EU's multiannual budgetary programme.
14 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK - SUSTAINABLE GROWTH EU spending on sustainable growth covers two areas: Competitiveness involves promoting research and technological development, connecting Europe through EU networks, education and training, promoting competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social policy agenda and the decommissioning of nuclear facilities.
EU spending for the period 2007-2013 for growth and jobs amounts to €89.4 billion, ie 9.2% of the EU budget, of which almost two thirds goes to research and development.
Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns the cohesion policy implemented through funds dedicated to specific areas of activity: European Social Fund (ESF), European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and Cohesion Fund (CF).
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 is €348.4 billion or 35.7% of the total EU budget.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Financial instruments for SMEs co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (No. 2/2012) - This special report examined the efficiency and effectiveness of the 2000-2006 and 2007 programming periods - Financial engineering measures co-financed by the ERDF evaluated in 2013. The audit covered a sample of projects in Germany, Portugal, Slovakia, Hungary and the UK and also included an examination of the management, monitoring and information systems of the Commission and the Member States.
The Court concluded that the effectiveness and efficiency of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) spending on financial instruments in favor of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has been hampered because the regulatory framework does not have an adequate basis for the use of the different Types of financial instruments bot.
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the backbone of the EU economy, providing jobs, innovation and prosperity.
However, SMEs may not be able to meet their financial needs in the form and amount they need.
To support them, the EU uses its enterprise and cohesion policies, mainly in the form of grants, and increasingly in the ERDF framework through financial instruments.
Financial instruments are redeemable, revolving instruments.
According to the figures provided by the Commission, the ERDF allocations for financial instruments are 1.6 billion euros and 10.4 billion euros for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods, respectively.
o Structural Funds - Has the Commission effectively responded to weaknesses identified in Member States' management and control systems?
(3/2012) - This special report examined the extent to which the Commission took appropriate corrective action, ensured its timely implementation and had reasonable assurance that its action would result in appropriate financial corrections to past irregularities and improvements in achieved by the systems in order to avoid the recurrence of irregularities.
The audit was primarily based on a review of 40 programs where significant deficiencies had been identified.
The Court found that the Commission was fairly good at ensuring the correct application of financial corrections in relation to the weaknesses in the Member States' management and control systems, but that it was less able to gain assurance that its actions would lead to improvements in the systems of the Member States led.
Expenditure on the Structural Funds is under shared management between the Commission and the Member States.
Member States draw up multiannual programmes, which are examined and approved by the Commission and then implemented by the Member States.
When significant weaknesses are detected in Member States' management and control systems, the Commission endeavors to ensure that irregularities are corrected and systems improved. o Using Structural and Cohesion Funds to co-finance transport infrastructure in seaports: an effective investment?
(No. 4/2012) - This special report assessed the effectiveness of the objectives and outputs of 27 projects co-financed by the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund under the 'Transport infrastructure' reporting code over the period 2000-2006 .
We found that investments in seaport transport infrastructure made under cohesion policy were only effective in 11 of the 27 projects audited.
Maritime transport is the second most important mode of transport in the EU.
The Commission forecasts growth from 3.8 billion tonnes in 2006 to 5.3 billion tonnes in 2018.
Since the year 2000, the EU has made around 6.2 billion euros available from the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund for the co-financing of the seaport infrastructure.

16 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – SUSTAINABLE GROWTH o Does structural measures support for municipal waste management infrastructure projects ensure effective support to Member States to achieve EU waste policy objectives?
(No. 20/2012) - This special report evaluated the performance of 26 sampled waste management infrastructure projects. The achievement of the goals of the EU waste policy and the implementation of accompanying measures in the eight regions in which the infrastructures are located were checked.
We found that the effectiveness of EU structural measures support for municipal waste management infrastructure was hampered by poor implementation of accompanying measures and weaknesses in EU legislation and guidelines.
In 2010, each citizen of the 27 EU Member States generated on average around 500 kg of waste which, if not properly collected, treated and disposed of, can have a negative impact on the environment.
The EU has established common standards and targets in the form of directives for municipal waste management and co-finances waste management infrastructure in certain regions.
In the period 2000-2013, the EU earmarked €10.8 billion for waste management infrastructure. o Cost-effectiveness of investments in energy efficiency under Cohesion Policy (No. 21/2012) - This special report assessed whether investments in energy efficiency under Cohesion Policy were cost-effective by examining whether the planning and financing took into account the the right conditions were in place to enable cost-effective energy efficiency investments and whether the energy efficiency projects implemented in public buildings were cost-effective.
We found that the average payback period for EU investments in energy efficiency is more than 50 years (up to 150 years in extreme cases). This means that funds could be used more cost-effectively for these types of investments.
The costs of increased energy consumption, depletion of fossil fuel reserves and the impact of human activity on global climate change are driving recent EU policies to increase energy efficiency.
The European Union has spent nearly €5 billion on co-financing energy efficiency measures in Member States since 2000 as part of the cohesion policy. o Has the revitalization of brownfield sites and military sites been successfully promoted within the framework of EU structural measures?
(No 23/2012) - This special report examined whether the project objectives were met, whether the targeting of EU funding was based on sound criteria and whether the results achieved were achieved at the lowest possible cost to the EU budget.
We audited the performance of 27 brownfield regeneration projects using EU co-funding totaling €231 million and analyzed the brownfield regeneration tools that frame the specific co-funded actions in Germany, Poland , the Czech Republic, Hungary and the United Kingdom.
(The conclusions of this special report are scheduled for publication on April 18, 2013.)
In the past few decades, more and more derelict industrial and military land (so-called “wasteland”) has become available.
Many brownfields are contaminated.
The revitalization and reuse of brownfield sites is funded within the framework of EU structural measures with the aim of protecting human health and the environment and counteracting urban sprawl.
EU funding for this area totaled 5.7 billion euros in the years 2000-2013.
o Response of the European Union Solidarity Fund to the 2009 Abruzzo earthquake: Relevance and cost of actions (n°24/2012) - This special report assessed whether the actions funded were in compliance with the EUSF Regulation and whether the "CASE" construction project, which accounted for the bulk of the expenditure, was well planned and designed and carried out with due attention to the aspect of economy.
We found that while the other funded projects were eligible, the CASE project was not in compliance with the EUSF Regulation.
Weaknesses were also noted in the planning of the CASE project and in ensuring the economy of its implementation.
The 2009 earthquake, centered in the Italian region of Abruzzo, caused more than 10 billion euros in damage.
The European Union supported the Italian disaster response with a contribution of 0.5 billion euros from its solidarity fund, which was used for rescue operations, the provision of emergency shelters and makeshift schools and the CASE project to build earthquake-proof houses.
L'Aquila Cathedral in Italy almost four years after the 2009 earthquake o Are there tools to monitor the effectiveness of European Social Fund spending on older workers?
(25/2012) - This special report has examined whether and to what extent Member States and the Commission have developed and implemented adequate tools to assess the achievement of the targets for older workers.
Six programs worth €222 million were selected. The programs concerned four Member States: Germany, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
The Court found that neither the Member States nor the Commission can say to what extent the measures supported by the ESF actually benefited older workers.
From 2007 to the end of 2013, the ESF will spend more than €75 billion to support Member States in the area of employment, representing around 8% of the total EU budget.
One of the most important disadvantaged groups are older workers.
