18 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES The EU has high political responsibilities in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2007-2013 is €413.1 billion, ie 42.3% of the total EU budget.
Three-quarters of spending concerns direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the 'first pillar' of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
Another fifth of spending goes to rural development support, funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second 'pillar' of the CAP.
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: o Reform of the common organization of the market in wine: progress made so far (7/2012) - This special report assessed progress towards one of the key objectives of the wine reform, namely progress in achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
The focus of the audit was on the measures 'grubbing-up premium' and 'restructuring and conversion of vineyards', which are the two main areas of expenditure and are crucial to achieving the objective of achieving a better balance between supply and demand.
We found that these two measures contradicted each other and that the structural oversupply was not significantly reduced.
For the three-year period of application of the clearing measure (2008/2009 to 2010/2011), the EU made budget funds totaling 1.1 billion euros available.
EUR 4.2 billion has been allocated for the ten-year period up to 2010 for restructuring and conversion. o Targeting of support for farm modernization (8/2012) - This special report examined whether EU support for farm modernization was targeted to EU priorities and specific needs in Member States .
We found that the farm modernization measure could potentially have been more effective by better targeting funds to meet EU priorities and specific needs in Member States on the one hand and by actually using selection procedures on the other.
This aid concerns the financing of investments in agricultural holdings, which can range from investments in simple items such as farm equipment or wooden crates for fruit to investments in complex projects such as biogas plants.
The EU budget for this support (which comes from the EAFRD) totals €11.1 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period, representing around 11% of all EU spending budgeted for rural development. o Audit of the control system governing the production, processing, distribution and importation of organic products (9/2012) - This special report examined whether the control system for organic products provides sufficient assurance to that the key requirements for the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products are met.
It has been examined how the various bodies involved (EU Commission and Member State Competent Authorities, Accreditation Bodies and Control Bodies) have performed their tasks within the EU and in the management of import regimes.
The Court found that the competent authorities in the Member States encountered difficulties in ensuring the traceability of organic products. Added to this were weaknesses in the system which need to be addressed in order to provide reasonable assurance that the system is working effectively and to ensure that consumer confidence is not undermined.
The aim of the EU legal framework for organic production is to create a basis for the sustainable development of organic production, to ensure fair conditions of competition, to protect consumer interests and at the same time to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market.
A control system has been set up, as part of which every entrepreneur in the supply chain is checked and certified. o Direct aids for suckler cows and ewes and goats under the partial implementation of the single payment scheme (No. 11/2012) - This special report examined whether the aid was targeted at the most relevant regions in the Member States, whether it was relevant in terms of maintaining a specific production and therefore effective in preventing negative social, economic and environmental impacts and whether it has been subject to proper monitoring and evaluation by the Commission and the Member States.
We found that direct CAP support for dam herds does not deliver better results than decoupled support.
Following the 2003 CAP reform, agricultural aid that was previously granted in the form of direct payments linked to the production of specific agricultural products (so-called "coupled" aid) should no longer be linked to production (i.e., they have been decoupled).
However, some exemptions from full decoupling have been provided for specific sectors and regions to limit the potential negative impact of an immediate move to such a regime.
The budget funds available for this direct aid for 2011 totaled 1.0 billion euros.

20 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK - CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES o Implementation of EU hygiene rules in the slaughterhouses of the countries that have joined the EU since 2004 (n°14/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission and those concerned Member States have taken the necessary measures to ensure that the slaughterhouses have made the appropriate adjustments to EU hygiene rules.
The monitoring, the orientation support, the implementation and the financing of the measures to comply with the hygiene regulations were checked.
We examined slaughterhouses in Poland, Romania, Slovenia, the Czech Republic and Hungary that had received EU funds.
While the Court found that the systems put in place by the Commission and the competent authorities to monitor hygiene rules were overall adequate, the audit revealed a number of weaknesses in the implementation of these systems, which underscore the need for greater rigor at all levels to mitigate risks.
The Member States that joined the EU since 2004 have had to ensure that their slaughterhouses comply with EU hygiene rules.
As these rules generally contained much stricter requirements than the respective national rules, EU funds were made available to help slaughterhouses to comply with hygiene rules and modernize them.
Around EUR 117 million has been allocated to 241 slaughterhouses under the special pre-accession program for agriculture and rural development (Sapard programme).
Funding then continued under the EAGGF and EAFRD. o Effectiveness of the SAPS scheme as a transitional system to support farmers in the new Member States (No. 16/2012) - This special report has examined the main weaknesses, such as payments to beneficiaries who have no (or only a marginal) agricultural engaged in activities, payments for land abandoned or used for non-agricultural activities, payments to government bodies, and aid concentrated in a few large beneficiaries.
We found that some of the aid was paid to beneficiaries with only marginal or no agricultural activity, including public bodies, and that the distribution of the aid did not take into account the regional specificities of the agricultural activity, nor the farmers' contribution to production public goods.
In addition, the vast majority of farmers receive only very small amounts of aid.
The SAPS is a simplified income support scheme for farmers in the Member States that have joined the EU since 2004.
In 2011 payments amounted to around 5 billion euros.
HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK - FREEDOM, SECURITY AND JUSTICE In 2012 the Court adopted the following special report in this area: o Do the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund contribute effectively to the integration of third-country nationals?
(No. 22/2012) - This special report assessed whether the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund, which are part of the EU's General Program "Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows" for the period 2007-2013 (SOLID), are effective for integration of third-country nationals into the EU, whether the results were supported by efficient monitoring and evaluation of the programme, whether the design of the funds contributed to the effective implementation of the funds, and whether the systems for implementing integration measures under the SOLID program are working properly were managed.
The Court found that while positive results could be observed for individual projects audited, inadequate systems had been put in place to measure the success of the funds.
The effectiveness of the funds was reduced by the design of the program and there was insufficient coordination with other EU funds.
The EU promotes measures to integrate third-country nationals in EU Member States and increases solidarity by sharing the financial burdens of managing common external borders and implementing common policies in the areas of asylum and immigration.
Expenditure under the EU budget for SOLID is expected to total €4.0 billion over the period 2007-2013.

22 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK – THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER The EU's external relations activities focus on the following areas: enlargement, bringing about stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, actively supporting sustainable development at international level, promoting global political governance and ensuring strategic and civil security.
The EU has earmarked EUR 55.9 billion for these objectives for the period 2007-2013, ie 5.7% of its total planned expenditure.
Most of the expenditure is managed by the Commission directly through its central services or its delegations.
In 2012, we adopted the following special reports in this area: o Effectiveness of European Union development assistance for food security in sub-Saharan Africa (1/2012) - This special report assessed the effectiveness of EU development assistance in sub-Saharan Africa development assistance for food security provided in the Sahara by analyzing whether EU development assistance for food security is relevant to countries' needs and priorities and whether EU action has been effective.
The audit focused on EU direct development assistance for the three pillars of food security: food availability, access to food and nutritional balance.
We concluded that EU development assistance for food security in sub-Saharan Africa is mostly effective and makes an important contribution to achieving food security.
However, the Commission did not sufficiently consider the possibilities for EU support to other countries also affected by chronic food insecurity and did not give adequate priority to the nutrition aspect.
Food security is a major and persistent problem in sub-Saharan Africa, where hunger affects 30% of the population.
In the period 2002-2010, the EU financed food security measures in this region from the European Development Fund (EDF) for a total of more than 3.2 billion euros. o The Common RELEX Information System (CRIS) (5/2012) - This special report examined whether CRIS had been designed to effectively meet the needs of the Commission and whether the information it provided was reliable .
The audit included a review of the Commission's documentation for CRIS and an examination of the data contained in CRIS.
We concluded that CRIS is mostly effective in meeting the Commission's information needs on external actions.
However, after ten years of development, it still has weaknesses.
CRIS is the information system set up by the Commission to support the management of external actions.
The functions of the system have been continuously expanded since it went into operation in 2002.
It is now the main reference information system for managing, documenting and reporting on external actions and is funded from both the general EU budget and the European Development Funds (EDF).
o European Union assistance to the Turkish Cypriot community (6/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission prepared an assistance program that was consistent with the objectives of the instrument, whether appropriate implementation modalities were in place and whether the individual projects had their respective achieved target results.
The purpose of the audit was not to assess whether the program had contributed to the achievement of the political goal of reunification.
We found that the program met its objectives as a financial support tool for the Turkish Cypriot community and that, despite significant constraints, it had generally established appropriate modalities.
Some results have already been achieved, but their sustainability is often questionable and the largest project in the program could not be built.
We checked around a third of this amount using our sample of contracts. o European Union development assistance for drinking water and basic sanitation in sub-Saharan Africa (n°13/2012) - This special report examined the Commission's assessment of the EU development assistance to improve drinking water and basic sanitation in sub-Saharan Africa managed to produce effective and sustainable results.
We found that EU support improved access to drinking water and basic sanitation.
On the other hand, less than half of the projects audited satisfactorily met the needs of the beneficiaries and the benefits will only be sustained if non-levy revenues are secured.
Improvements in water and sanitation are critical to achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
The supply of clean drinking water and sanitary facilities contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction.
EU spending on water and sanitation in sub-Saharan Africa for the period 2001-2010 was around €1.0 billion; as funding for water and sanitation is also earmarked under other areas of assistance, the Commission has provided a higher amount overall.

24 HEADING OF THE FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK - THE EU AS A GLOBAL PARTNER o Contribution of the European Development Fund (EDF) to a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa (n°17/2012) - This special report examined whether the EDF is making an effective contribution to the sustainability of the road network in sub-Saharan Africa, whether EDF-supported road infrastructure is sustainable and whether the Commission has effectively promoted the sustainability of road infrastructure.
The audit focused on the technical, financial and institutional sustainability of road transport infrastructure. 48 programs funded since 1995 under the eighth, ninth and tenth EDFs in six partner countries were audited.
We concluded that the Commission's support for a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa is partially effective.
The partner countries we visited do not make sufficient efforts to ensure the sustainability of road infrastructure, which affects roads to varying degrees from premature wear.
Roads and other transport infrastructure are essential for regional integration, economic growth, social development, effective public administration and security.
In sub-Saharan Africa, road transport is the main mode of transport for passenger and freight transport, accounting for more than 80% of all goods and services traffic, with transport needs growing rapidly.
The EU committed around €7.4 billion in EDF funds in this region over the period 1995-2011. o European Union Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo (No. 18/2012) (see “A close-up of a performance audit”).

25 CLOSE-UP OF A PERFORMANCE AUDIT European Union rule of law assistance to Kosovo Kosovo police and EULEX patrolling the border in Kosovo © EULEX, 2011, photo by Enisa Kasemi As part of our audit of the EU's rule of law assistance to Kosovo, the Court identified for the first time a Common Security Mission and Defense Policy (CSDP) in the limelight.
Kosovo is the world's largest recipient of EU financial assistance per capita and is the site of the largest civilian crisis management operation ever launched by the Union (European Union Rule of Law Mission in Kosovo - EULEX).
The Court's Special Report No 18/2012 examined whether EU assistance to Kosovo in the area of the rule of law was effective.
The audit focused on the four sectors police, judiciary, customs and anti-corruption.
We also examined coordination with other donors and the implementation of EULEX.
Auditing such a complex area presented a challenge.
Four audit visits were carried out in Kosovo.
Officials from EULEX and the European Commission were interviewed, as well as local officials, representatives of the international donor community and civil society organisations.
The audit team examined Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and Instrument for Stability projects, as well as Monitoring, Guidance and Advice (MMA) activities implemented by EULEX.
Meetings were held in Brussels with the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Council Secretariat and NATO.
A panel of experts was also available to assist the Court.
The Court found that EU assistance was not sufficiently effective.
Although the EU has contributed to capacity building, particularly in the customs area, assistance to the police and judiciary has had limited success.
The level of organized crime and corruption in Kosovo remains high.
The judiciary continues to suffer from political interference, inefficiency and a lack of transparency and enforcement.
The limited ability to protect key witnesses within Kosovo and the difficulty in relocating witnesses abroad are significant shortcomings.
In the words of Gijs de Vries, the ECA Member responsible for the report, the Kosovo authorities do not give the rule of law enough priority and EU assistance should be more effective.
Francisco de Miguel Rodriguez, who heads the audit team, says there is no other place in the world like Kosovo where so many international donors could be found to provide capacity-building in such a small area.
The Court concluded that the EU's coordination mechanisms, including coordination with the international community, need improvement.
In contrast to the rest of the Western Balkans, in the case of Kosovo, the incentive of possible EU accession is jeopardized by the lack of a common EU position on its independence.
In terms of communication, this test broke new ground.
It was the ECA's most-cited report of 2012, with more than 130 articles appearing in print and electronic media.
A video summarizing the report was also published on the Court's website.
This was a first for the Court, reflecting its desire to reach a wider audience.
The European Commission and the European External Action Service have accepted the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The report was presented to the European Parliament and Council working groups.
Because of the importance of its findings, the UK House of Lords has decided to deal with the report in detail.
26 EU INSTITUTIONS, AGENCIES AND OTHER BODIES In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (salaries and pensions) as well as on buildings, equipment, energy , communication and information technology.
Total spending for 2007-2013 is €55.9 billion or 5.7% of the total EU budget. o Effectiveness of staff development policies at the European Commission (No 10/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission aligned the development of its staff to the needs of the organization, provided opportunities for development for its staff, created an environment that motivated staff to develop their skills and apply them in the workplace.
The Commission's annual budget for external trainers and teaching materials in 2010 was EUR 26.6 million. Annual investment in learning and development in 2010 also included 230 000 staff days to attend training and an equivalent of 310 staff to administer and deliver training and career development. o Have the procedures for producing reliable and credible European statistics been improved by the Commission and Eurostat?
(No 12/2012) - This special report assessed whether the procedures for producing reliable and credible statistics have been improved by the Commission and Eurostat.
Improvements are directly linked to compliance with the European Statistics Code of Practice, which sets the standards for the development, production and dissemination of statistics, and to the implementation of the European Statistical Programme.
An assessment of the reliability of specific statistical results did not take place.
The Court found that the Commission and Eurostat have not yet achieved full application of the European Statistics Code of Practice and that Eurostat had not designed the European Statistical Program 2008-2012 as an effective planning, monitoring and accountability tool.
Reliable and credible statistics are essential to carry out the tasks entrusted to the European Union.
Statistics are required in almost all areas in order to formulate, apply, monitor and evaluate the tasks and objectives foreseen in the Treaties. They are also used to collect and allocate EU funds.
European policy decisions are increasingly based directly on statistics, and statistical indicators are increasingly used as triggers for policy decisions or sanctions. o Management of conflicts of interest in selected EU agencies (No. 15/2012) - This special report assessed whether the selected agencies managed conflicts of interest adequately, whether there are adequate policies and procedures for handling conflicts of interest situations and whether the selected agencies have updated their policies and Have adequately implemented procedures for handling conflicts of interest situations.
The audit assessed the policies and procedures for handling conflict of interest situations in the case of four selected agencies that make influential decisions affecting consumer safety and health.
We concluded that the selected EU agencies did not adequately manage conflicts of interest.

The follow-up special reports related to three budget areas, namely agriculture, energy and external action.
The Court assessed the actions taken by the Commission on the Court's recommendations.
The audit showed that the recommendations had been taken into account: the Commission fully implemented 29% of the analyzed recommendations, 49% were mostly implemented, 20% were partially implemented and 2% were not implemented.

28 OPINIONS AND POSITION PAPERS ISSUED IN 2012 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legislation with a financial impact.
These opinions are issued at the request of the other EU institutions and are used by the legislative authorities - the European Parliament and the Council - in their work.

29 OPINION NO. 1/2012 ON THE COMMISSION'S LEGISLATIVE PROPOSALS FOR THE REFORM OF THE COMMON AGRICULTURAL POLICY FROM 2014 ONwards The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is to be reformed by 2013.
In October 2011, the Commission published a proposal containing the main elements of a legal framework for the CAP for the period 2014-2020.
In the new legal framework it was proposed to keep the current two-pillar structure of the CAP and thus the two existing European financial instruments of agricultural policy, namely the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). .
The Court acknowledged the efforts made by the Commission to simplify the provisions of the CAP (e.g. abandonment of the different implementation models in the current SPS, introduction of a simplified scheme for small farmers).
Through its proposals, the Commission has incorporated a number of comments from Parliament, the Council and the Court.
However, the fundamental principles of the legislative proposals remain focused on expenditure and its control, and thus, contrary to the stated intention, still provide compliance with legislation through performance.
The Court noted the Commission's aim to prioritize the payment of CAP support to 'active farmers' and its attempt to achieve a more balanced distribution of direct payments among beneficiaries.
However, the Court doubted that the proposed measures could be implemented effectively without imposing an excessive administrative burden on managing authorities and farmers.
In his view, the solution may lie in a combination of general principles laid down in the regulation and systematic monitoring and expert monitoring of its implementation by the Commission.
He noted that the so-called "capping" (cutting aid that exceeds a certain ceiling) will only have a limited impact on the redistribution of aid.
This opinion had a major impact on reflections on the future of the CAP.
Over 2,000 articles have been published in the media on this subject.
The Court has been invited by a number of NGOs, agricultural fair organizers and other industry forums to present the opinion to their respective audiences. The European Parliament invites representatives of the Court to participate in working groups on this topic.
Members of the European Parliament have incorporated most of the recommendations into their own proposals for legislative changes.
The legislative package will be voted upon adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework.
30 COOPERATION WITH OTHER SUPREME AUDITS INSTITUTIONS The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) mainly in the following bodies: o Contact Committee of the SAIs of the EU Member States; o Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; o International organizations of public sector audit bodies, in particular the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
EU Liaison Officers meeting in Rome, April 2012 INTOSAI Capacity Building Subcommittee meeting in Luxembourg, September 2011
CONTACT COMMITTEE OF SUPREME AUDIT INSTITUTIONS OF THE EU MEMBER STATES 31 In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies work together in a spirit of trust while respecting their independence.
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of the EU Member States through the Contact Committee.
The Contact Committee brings together the Presidents of the EU SAIs and the Court once a year.
Working groups and task forces have been set up to support the development of common positions and approaches.
In 2012, the Court assisted the Chair-in-Office of the Contact Committee (SAI of Portugal) in preparing and holding the 2012 Annual Meeting, held on 18 and 19 October 2012 in Estoril (Portugal).
The session had two main themes, namely the challenges for SAIs in preparing for the next EU financial framework (2014-2020) and recent developments in the response to the financial crisis and SAIs' experience with related audits.
At the meeting, the Contact Committee decided to set up a task force to analyze the tasks and role of SAIs, taking into account recent developments in the EU in building a new economic, budgetary and financial architecture and the possible impact on SAIs.
The Court is a member of this task force, which is due to report to the Contact Committee in 2013.
In addition, the Court continued to provide administrative support to the Contact Committee in 2012 and actively participated in the various working groups and networks.
In 2012, we also supported the euro area SAIs' initiative on adequate external public audit of the European Stability Mechanism.
A common position on a proposal for the Statute relating to Article 30 of the Treaty establishing the Mechanism was sent to the Secretary-General of the Council of the European Union in April 2012.
The final version of the Statutes is broadly in line with this common position as regards the Audit Committee.
32 NETWORK OF SUPREME AUDIT INSTITUTIONS OF CANDIDATE COUNTRIES AND POTENTIAL CANDIDATE COUNTRIES The Court works with the SAIs of candidate and potential candidate countries.
One of the main tools for cooperation is the Network of SAIs of Candidate and Potential Candidate Countries1, with its organizational structure similar to that of the Contact Committee.
This network includes regular meetings of SAI Presidents and liaison officers, as well as working groups, seminars, workshops and parallel audits.
In 2012, the Court supported the implementation of the work program that is part of the Istanbul Memorandum of Understanding adopted at the March 2011 meeting of the Network Presidents.
The President of the Court attended the 150th anniversary ceremony of the Turkish Court of Accounts and paid an official visit to the Croatian Court of Accounts.

34 OUR MANAGEMENT OUTLOOK: A STRATEGY FOR 2013-2017 In 2012 the Court adopted and published its strategy for 2013-2017.
The Court's aim for this period is to maximize the value of the Court's contribution to EU public accountability.
The key priorities to achieve this goal are: o Alignment of the Court's products to improve EU accountability; o Working with other stakeholders to increase the Court's contribution to EU accountability; o further development as a professional audit body; o making the best use of the Court's pool of knowledge, expertise and expertise; o Evidence of the Court's effectiveness and accountability.
The Court will use its unique powers and perspective, as well as the knowledge, expertise and partnerships it has built over its 35 years of existence, to o make a positive contribution to future governance, policy and of the financial management of the EU; o to support the other parties involved in the EU accountability process to identify the risks to EU accountability and to facilitate the use of the audit results; o Consolidate its professionalism by contributing to and applying new auditing standards and best practices; o further streamline the processes for preparing its reports and opinions; o improve its performance and accountability framework in line with its duties as an EU institution and as an SAI; o implement fiscal discipline measures, including necessary staffing plan reductions during the period of validity of this strategy, in line with the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020.
In 2013-2017, the Court will focus its reports, opinions and observations on: o strengthening public accountability and auditing arrangements; o Improving financial management and reporting on the implementation and impact of the EU budget; o Improved design of EU policies and spending programmes.
CHANGE IN THE COURT'S COLLEGE BOARD According to the contract, the term of office of the members of the Court is six years, renewable.
In 2012, five new members of the Court were appointed: Henrik Otbo (Denmark), Pietro Russo (Italy), Ville Itälä (Finland), Kevin Cardiff (Ireland) and Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain).
REVISED CODE OF CONDUCT FOR THE COURT'S MEMBERS In February 2012, the Court adopted a new code of conduct for its members, reflecting changes that have taken place since the previous code was adopted eight years ago.
In addition, the Court now publishes its members' declarations of interests on its website, which contributes significantly to transparency. 35
36 MEASURING THE COURT'S PERFORMANCE FINALIZATION OF THE 2009-2012 STRATEGY In 2008 the Court published its first strategy.
This strategy applied for the period 2009-2012 and aimed to maximize the impact of the Court's audits and to increase efficiency through the best use of resources.
Overall, the Court successfully implemented its 2009-2012 strategy.
The Court's recommendations were largely accepted: according to the Commission, around half of the recommendations made in 2011 have been implemented. The Court's main institutional stakeholders are satisfied with its annual and special reports, the quality of which is assessed as good and improving by external experts. In addition, through efficiency gains, the Court has increased the number of staff in the audit chambers by 60 (501 in 2008 compared to 564 in 2011) and reduced the number of staff in administration and translation by 40.
For the strategic period 2009-2012, the Court identified a set of key performance indicators with the purpose of: o informing management about the progress towards the objectives; o to support the decision-making process; o to provide the target group with performance-related information.
The key performance indicators are designed to measure core parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, with particular attention to the perspective of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
As 2012 was the last year of the strategy period 2009-2012, the results achieved on the key performance indicators are presented for all four years, where available.
The Court will update the KPIs applicable in the 2013-2017 strategy period to reflect its new or revised priorities and demonstrate its performance and accountability as a professional audit body.

The assessment was made using a five-point scale (1 - very bad, 2 - bad, 3 - fair, 4 - good, 5 - very good).

40 EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF RESOURCE USE The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources in terms of its ability to submit reports and audit findings in a timely manner, to fulfill its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and professional competence of its staff.
PREPARATION OF REPORTS The Court monitors the effectiveness of its reporting process by comparing the number of reports planned for the year with the number of reports adopted and checking that these reports have been adopted within the deadlines set for each.

PROFESSIONAL TRAINING The auditing profession requires constant training to keep up with new developments and acquire new skills.
In addition, due to the specific nature of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need a good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2012, the Court's staff (auditors and other staff) received an average of 8 days of professional development (9.3 days in 2011).
Language courses accounted for 52% of the total number of training days (compared to 54% in 2011).
Translation is an audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfill its mission and achieve its communication goals.
In 2012, the translation volume peaked at 158 861 pages, 11% more than in 2011.
More than 99% of translations were completed on time.
Information technology makes a crucial contribution to the Court's effectiveness and efficiency.
2012 was a successful year: o In the area of knowledge management, the first version of the Court's new audit support tool (ASSYST2) was set up and a pilot phase started in an audit unit.
In addition, a first knowledge network (community of practice) on the subject of the financial crisis was supported by providing information technology and content. In 2012, improvements were made to the content of the training measures and new courses were developed to meet the priorities in the examination area.
In addition, the establishment of a new paperless system and the development of e-learning enabled more efficient management of training activities.
TRANSLATION INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY The Court's Translation Directorate also provided language support to auditors during audits in the Member States and in the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
She also supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the Court's audit work. o The automation of administrative processes has been actively pursued through the introduction of ECAdemy to support the Court's training policy, through the decentralization of time recording, which has saved human resources, and through the full digitization of personnel files. o A major achievement was the relocation of the Court's data center to the new K3 building.
The commissioning of the new building also involved a new telephone system and a new data network. 47

54 35 YEARS OF MAKE THE EU WORK BETTER The European Court of Auditors has been the EU's external auditor for 35 years. It continuously adds value to the Union's financial management and ensures public accountability for the use of taxpayers' money.
The Court was established at a time when the European Community (the forerunner of the European Union) was becoming more democratic and accountable to its citizens.
Two particularly important steps were the extension of the European Parliament's budgetary control powers and the full financing of the European Community budget from its own resources.
The Community recognized that it needed an independent external auditor to assist Parliament and the Council in ensuring democratic scrutiny of finances.
Heinrich Aigner, Chairman of the European Parliament's Budgetary Control Committee, who had advocated an external audit body at Community level since 1973, launched the initiative that led to the creation of the European Court of Auditors by the Treaty of Brussels on 22 July 1975.
The Court started its activities in October 1977 with its headquarters in Luxembourg.
The then President of the Court of Justice, Hans Kutscher, praised the court as the financial conscience of the community.
The Court gained the status of a full European institution with the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty on 1 November 1993, guaranteeing its independence and authority as an equivalent institution.
The Maastricht Treaty also introduced what is now a core product of the Court, namely the declaration of assurance (DAS) on the EU's accounts and on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts.
The Court's role was enhanced with the entry into force of the Amsterdam Treaty on 1 May 1999, which strengthened the Court's independence and extended its audit powers to other policy areas.
The Nice Treaty of 1 February 2003 confirmed the principle that the Court should have one member from each Member State. In addition, the importance of the Court's cooperation with national audit bodies was stressed and the Court was given the opportunity to create a chamber structure.
Since its inception, the Court has consistently promoted cooperation with Member States' SAIs in auditing EU funds, notably through its participation in the Contact Committee of EU SAI Presidents.
In our capacity as SAI, the Court has also sought to help pioneer developments in public sector auditing by working with other SAIs in the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its regional group EUROSAI to set professional standards and best practices .
The Court made an early commitment to peer review as a tool for developing and disseminating best practice within the SAI community.
Throughout its 35 years of existence, the Court has strived to help improve EU financial management by producing high-quality products that reflect EU developments and the changing needs of its users.
Over the past 35 years, the EU has welcomed new Member States, acquired new powers and created new bodies at EU level – all of which the Court has had to take into account in our work.
As a result, the Court's output has increased significantly compared to the two opinions it produced in its first year of operation.
The Court's products today include Annual Reports, Special Reports, Statements of Assurance, Special Annual Reports, Opinions and Position Papers.
The number of outputs has increased to 87 publications in 2012.
For a number of years, the Court has given higher priority to examining the results achieved in the implementation of EU policies and providing advice on how to improve efficiency.
Like the EU, the Court has evolved.
Starting with nine members and 120 employees in 1977, the court now has 27 members and almost 900 employees.
Like the Union itself, the Court's success depends on close cooperation between members and staff from all over Europe.
The Court prides itself on having built a dedicated, professional and experienced staff since 1977 dedicated to protecting the financial interests of citizens.
In the coming years, the Court will work to help improve accountability to citizens for the funds used to meet the objectives.
55 The members of the first quorum of the Court, November 1977

In memory of our colleague Henrik Otbo, Member of the Court, who died unexpectedly on 1 February 2015 Henrik Otbo was born in 1949 and was a Danish national.
From 1995 to 2012 he was President of the Danish Court of Auditors and since March 1, 2012 he has been a member of the European Court of Auditors in the CEAD chamber ( “Coordination , Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development”) with particular responsibility for audit development and reporting .
His lifelong commitment to the service of public audit, in particular his leadership in the creation of International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions as Chair of INTOSAI 's Professional Standards Committee, has been of particular value to the Court, his former colleagues at the Danish National Audit Office, and the auditing sector as a whole .
01 European Court of Auditors 02 Mission The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the EU finances under the Treaty .
As the EU's external auditor, it helps improve EU financial management , promotes accountability and transparency and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
Mission Statement An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognized for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, offering valuable support to its constituency with a view to improving EU financial management.
Values Independence, integrity and impartiality Professionalism Added value Excellence and efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its staff.
Impartial scrutiny that takes into account the views of the Court 's stakeholders , but refuses any form of influence through outside direction or pressure.
Maintaining an exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work .
Active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU level and worldwide .
Produce relevant, timely, high-quality reports that are based on sound findings and evidence, address the needs of their audience , and contain important and meaningful statements .
to an effective improvement of EU financial management and contribute to strengthening the accountability of EU financial management .
Promoting team spirit through effective communication .

Foreword by the President 04 Dear Reader, 2014 was a year of profound change for the EU and its finances.
The EU gave the European Central Bank responsibility for supervising the large banks in the euro area .
was the first year of the new Multiannual Financial Framework that will govern the implementation of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020 .
The election of new members of the European Parliament and the replacement of top positions in the Council and the European Commission were also of particular importance. The European Court of Auditors (ECA) also welcomed six new members.
In 2014, our body produced 91 reports, opinions and other products – more than ever before.
They are the result of our financial , compliance and performance audits , which include those audits falling within the scope of our new responsibilities for financial and economic governance .
They contain a number of important findings, conclusions and recommendations to improve financial management and accountability of the EU in the 2014-2020 programming period .
Some of their core statements can be found in this annual activity report .
We also aim to provide our audience with the widest possible insight, based on our audit experience, into the main challenges the EU faces in financing and implementing its policies .
To this end - and as a contribution to this time of radical innovation - we introduced a new product in 2014, the so-called "Landscape Analysis ".
, we have published an overview of the results of our financial and compliance audits in the areas of agricultural and cohesion spending for the period 2009-2013 .
The Court is also committed to working with its stakeholders to ensure they get the most out of the results of its work.
Among other things, in 2014 the Court appointed a member responsible for institutional relations and a spokesperson.
He also organized several events to provide opportunities for exchanges with high-level EU and Member State stakeholders.
This conference brought together a wide range of people responsible for the management and control of EU funds, including members of the European Parliament, the European Commission, supreme audit institutions and academics.
The Vice President of the European Parliament and former EU Commissioner Olli Rehn gave an introductory speech .
Also of particular note was the visit of a delegation of members of the Court to Lithuania, where meetings were held with members of parliament , members of the government and representatives of the National Audit Office and the Central Bank of Lithuania.
Foreword by the President 05 Throughout the year, our 2013-2017 strategy has guided our work and the actions taken to reform our institution.
In 2014 we reduced the average time required for the preparation of our special reports and we reduced the number of our staff, as required by an interinstitutional agreement.
We also laid the foundations for future efficiency and effectiveness gains by launching an internal reform project .
This project coordinates the implementation of the recommendations of internal working groups as well as the recommendations from the independent, external peer review of our performance audit practice and from the European Parliament 's report on the future role of the Court.
The Court is based in Luxembourg, but our audit teams travel wherever EU funds are spent as part of their work to obtain audit evidence.
This activity report provides an overview of the audit visits and the reports we have prepared .
be on our audit of EU support for European airport infrastructure.
It is a vivid example of our performance audits - assessing the impact and added value of EU funding - and demonstrates the effort required on the part of the Court to fulfill its mandate.
This audit also demonstrates the commitment and professionalism of the Court 's staff , on whose expertise and dedication the Court and the citizens on whose behalf it acts can always count.

2014 at a glance 06 Our activities • Annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Funds for the financial year 2013. • 51 specific annual reports on the different ‐ Agencies, Decentralized Bodies and ‐ EU Joint Undertakings for the financial year ‐ 2013 as well two summary reports. • 24 special reports on specific budgetary areas or management issues , ranging from European banking supervision to EU - funded airport infrastructure . • Seven opinions and other pronouncements with contributions on financial management issues , from the reform of the EU 's own resources system to a study on the potential savings of bringing the European Parliament's activities together in a single place . • Two landscape analyses: one on the challenges of accountability and public audit in the EU and another on the risks to EU financial management . • Organization of a high - level conference on accountability and public audit in the EU. • Hosted the meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions - EU - Member States with a focus on strengthening cooperation between national SAIs and the Court.
Our Management • The Court welcomed six new members in 2014 : Alex Brenninkmeijer, Danièle Lamarque , Nikolaos Milionis, Phil Wynn Owen, Klaus - Heiner Lehne and Oskar Herics.
The College of Members - re -elected Vítor Caldeira as President of the Court for a third three -year term - and appointed Ville Itälä as Member responsible for institutional relations . • The Court 's strategy for the period 2013-2017 gave impetus to organizational change : the Court introduced an internal reform project aimed at streamlining the audit process and ensuring a more flexible organization of resources. • Further improvement of administrative efficiency, based on process simplifications and on the transfer of staff involved in support services to the audit area .
An action plan in the field of equal opportunities has also been implemented.
Court building in Luxembourg.
Our activities 07 Audit reports and other products The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: • Annual reports – containing the results of its financial and compliance audits – on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Funds (EDF) .
are also separately published special annual reports on the EU agencies , decentralized bodies and joint undertakings. • Special Reports – which may be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits on specific budget areas or management issues.
These are essentially performance audits . • Opinions – on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other analysis-based products, produced either at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
In 2014, the Court created more products than ever before and also presented new products.
be gleaned from the annual reports . They also provide a comprehensive account of the results of our annual financial and compliance reviews .
, there was an increased focus on performance audits , providing the EU budgetary authority with additional insights into the quality of implementation of the EU budget .
Complementing the annual reports, we published for the first time a summary of our audit findings in relation to shared management agriculture and cohesion expenditure over the period 2009-2013 to provide a multi-annual perspective.
The other important development was a new product called Landscape Analysis .
In Landscape - Analyzes - based on our expertise in the field of auditing - information and analysis is presented on key issues.
In 2014 we published two landscape reviews : the first focuses on the main challenges facing the EU in terms of accountability and public audit; in the second , the risks for EU financial management are in the foreground.

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2014 While most of the audit work takes place at our premises in Luxembourg, our auditors also carry out audit visits to Member States ' authorities , to other beneficiaries of EU funds ( including the headquarters of international organizations such as such as the World Health Organization in Switzerland) and the EU agencies and institutions.
The purpose of these visits is to obtain direct audit evidence from the entities involved in approving, managing and disbursing EU funds and from the respective final recipients.
Our review teams typically consist of two to three reviewers, and review visits can take anywhere from a few days to two weeks, depending on the nature of the review and the distance.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often conducted in coordination with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depends on the type of audit and the results of the sample selection .
The number and duration of audit visits can therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
In 2014, the Court's auditors spent 4 915 days on-site audits – in Member States and outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports and the selected audit tasks ( special reports).
They also spent considerable time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with the decentralized agencies and bodies across the EU.
In 2014, our auditors spent fewer days on on - site audits than in previous years.
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technology such as the use of video conferencing.
The EU auditors used EU auditors when inspecting sea freight transport facilities .

Our activities 10th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013 The Court devoted most of its financial and compliance audits during 2014 to the implementation of the EU budget for 2013 .
The 2013 Annual Report resulting from this work was published on November 5, 2014 and our audience, which includes the European Parliament and its Budgetary Control Committee, the Council of the EU (ECOFIN Council), national parliaments and governments, and presented to the media.
The aim of the annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and the citizens in assessing the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions .
( “DAS”) on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the transactions on which they are based .
That report contained even more information on the soundness of EU spending and the Commission's performance reporting.
Estimated error rate for the EU budget: 4.7% President Caldeira handing over the annual report on the financial year 2013 to the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz .
Our activities 11 Key messages from the 2013 annual report ο We gave an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the 2013 accounts of the European Union.
Revenue for 2013 was legal and regular overall; this also applies to the commitments. ο The payments for 2013 were affected by a material level of error.
Therefore, the Court issued a negative opinion on their legality and regularity.
This value is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%. ο The two most error-prone spending areas were regional policy, transport and energy, with an estimated error rate of 6.9%, and rural development, environment, fisheries and health, with an estimated error rate of 6.7%.
For shared management as a whole, the estimated error rate was 5.2%. ο Overall, the supervisory and control systems examined were partially effective in ensuring the regularity of payments , with significant divergences between Member States.
As in 2012, for a large proportion of the transactions affected by errors in shared management areas, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before claiming reimbursement from the Commission. ο Corrective actions and recoveries by Member State authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, the estimated overall error rate would have been 6.3 %. ο The use of EU funds in the 2007-2013 programming period focused on absorption ( use it or lose it) and compliance with the law rather than good performance .
This lack of focus on performance is a key weakness in the way much of the EU budget is structured .

Our activities 13 Agriculture and cohesion: overview of EU spending 2007 - 2013 In 2014, the Court published for the first time - in 23 official EU languages - a background document, alongside the annual reports , to provide a multiannual perspective on the festivals underlying the DAS . positions in the two main spending areas of agriculture and cohesion.
He drew lessons on EU financial management and control issues encountered in the past spending period , summarized audit findings and identified challenges related to the new spending period 2014-2020 .
This overview also responded to the European Parliament's request for country-specific information on shared management. Key messages: ο Except for direct aids and market support measures for farmers in agriculture, the pressure to take up the funds is a key aspect of risk in shared management spending . ο The main risks to the regularity of agricultural expenditure are that the land or animals or costs on which the aid payments are based are ineligible, the recipients of aid do not meet the eligibility criteria and the aid is not calculated correctly.
Violations of agri - environmental requirements, specific requirements for investment projects and procurement rules are important factors that increase risk in rural development spending. ο The main risk in cohesion spending is breaches of EU and /or national public procurement rules.
The second biggest risk is that expenditure (or projects) will not be eligible for EU funding . ο Although there is a significant need for improvement in the control systems, the main challenge is to take steps to simplify the administration of the programmes.
The Court finds errors in all EU Member States .
Many errors have occurred due to the complexity of the overall architecture for management and control. ο Despite improvements in the reporting of risks and errors by Member State authorities, it remains very difficult for the Commission to ensure the reliability of this information. ο The overall changes in the regulations for the new programming period may not have a significant impact on the level of risk.
Our Activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds 2013 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are funded by the EU Member States . They are governed by their own financial regulation and managed outside the general budget of the EU.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial implementation of the measures financed from EDF funds .
Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP ) States and the Overseas Countries and Territories (OCT) on the basis of the Cotonou Agreement of 2000 .
Expenditure is aimed at reducing and eventually eradicating poverty, in line with the goals of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP and OCT countries into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars, namely development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension .
The Court's 2013 annual report on the EDFs was published in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget on 5 November 2014 .
It contains the 20th Statement of Assurance on the EDFs .
The Court found that the 2013 accounts fairly present the assets and liabilities of the EDFs, the results of their operations and cash flows and changes in net assets overall.
The Court estimated the error rate in EDF expenditure transactions to be 3.4 % for the financial year 2013, which is an increase compared to 3.0 % in 2012 .
published 51 special annual reports covering the financial year 2013 .
The reports covered the 41 EU decentralized bodies, executive agencies and agencies, the seven EU research Joint Undertakings , the European Central Bank, the European Schools and the Sisnet communications infrastructure.
The Court also published two summaries summarizing the results of its annual audits for the financial year 2013 - one on the EU agencies and other bodies, the second on the Joint Undertakings active in the field of research .
These two summaries for analysis - and comparison - were presented to the President of the European Parliament , the Budgetary Control Committee of the Parliament, the General Affairs Council and the Budgets Committee of the Council.
( eca.europa.eu) together with the specific annual reports .
, Bodies and Joint Undertakings are set up on the basis of EU legal acts to carry out specific tasks . Their offices are located throughout the European Union.
They are active in many areas, such as security , health, research, finance, migration and travel.
They each have a mandate, board of directors, director, staff and budget.
Whilst the financial risk associated with the agencies, bodies and JUs is relatively low in relation to the total EU budget , the reputational risk for the Union is high as they are highly visible in the Member States and have a significant influence on policy making , decision-making and program implementation in areas of greatest concern to European citizens.

Our activities 15 The Court issued unqualified opinions on the reliability of the 2013 accounts to the 41 agencies and other bodies .
The transactions underlying these financial statements were legal and regular in all material respects for all but two agencies and other bodies . The Court issued qualified audit opinions for the EIT ( European Institute of Innovation and Technology) and Frontex (European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union).
, but the Court issued qualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying their accounts for three JUs: Artemis ( embedded ICT systems ), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and IMI (Innovative Medicines Initiative).
Concerning the European Schools, the Court was not able to come to a conclusion as to whether the consolidated accounts for 2013 were free from material misstatement as the Schools continued to have accounting and control weaknesses.
The Court examined the European Central Bank 's management of its carbon footprint and found that while the Bank has taken action to reduce the negative impact of its administrative activities on the environment, further efforts and action are needed .
Special reports adopted in 2014 In addition to our annual reports and annual special reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year, which give the results of its economy - ‐ and compliance ‐ checks on specific budget areas or management issues of his choice .
In selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court seeks to achieve maximum impact, thereby making the best use of its resources .
: • the risks of irregularity or poor efficiency in the spending or policy area; • the potential to add value in the course of an audit by the Court; • the political and public interest. 24 special reports in 2014
