Our activities 17 Smart and inclusive growth Smart and inclusive growth covers two areas: Competitiveness for growth and jobs includes funds for research and innovation, education and training, trans-European energy , transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, business development , etc. The EU funds earmarked for growth and jobs for the period 2014-2020 amount – in current prices – to €142 billion or 13% of the total EU budget .
's least developed countries and regions to catch up with the rest, is part of economic, social and territorial cohesion . The competitiveness of all regions should be strengthened and cooperation between them should be developed .
The EU funds earmarked for cohesion for the period 2014-2020 – in current prices – amount to €367 billion or 34% of the total EU budget .
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of EU funded projects in the field of public transport (No 1/2014) - In this special report, the Court assessed the implementation and effectiveness of EU Structural Funds co-funded public transport projects to determine whether the projects met users' needs and achieved their objectives.
The audit revealed that two thirds of the local transport projects co-financed with EU Structural Funds were underused.
This development was primarily caused by weaknesses in the project design and an inadequate mobility policy.
this underperformance was generally not followed up by project promoters or national authorities.
In general, infrastructure and rolling stock have been set up in accordance with the project specifications for most projects .
Significant delays and cost overruns were identified, but once completed almost all projects audited met user needs.
European cities need to improve mobility and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution through local mobility strategies .
Through the co-financed projects, the cities received support in setting up local transport systems such as subways , trams and buses.
Trams and buses are important means of public transport .
Our activities 18 • Has the cohesion policy funding to support renewable energy production achieved good results?
(6/2014) – In this special report, we examined whether the two main sources of funding to support renewable energy – the European Regional Development Fund ( ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF) – performed well were. To this end, it was assessed whether funds had been allocated during this period to appropriately prioritized, cost-effective and mature renewable energy production projects that pursued meaningful objectives and to what extent these funds had achieved good results that contribute to the achievement of the EU 2020 renewable energy targets .
The audit found that improvements are needed to ensure that EU funding contributes as much as possible to the achievement of the target .
The projects audited delivered the outputs as planned and most projects were sufficiently mature and operational at the time of their selection.
There were no significant cost overruns or major delays and the renewable energy generation capacity was installed and operational as planned.
However, results in terms of energy production have not always been achieved or properly measured.
Overall, the use of funds was limited, as cost-effectiveness was not the guiding principle in planning and implementing the projects and the spending had limited EU added value.
has set a binding EU target of 20% for the share of renewable energies in gross final energy consumption by 2020.
In the period 2007 - 2013 , around 4.7 billion euros were made available from the ERDF and the KF for renewable energies. • Has the ERDF been successful in supporting the development of business incubators?
(7/2014) – In this special report, we analyzed whether the incubators co‐funded by the ERDF had successfully supported start ‐ up companies with high growth potential.
The audit found that the EU has made a significant financial contribution to the creation of incubator infrastructure, particularly in Member States where this type of business support is relatively rare.
However, the performance of the audited incubators left a lot to be desired.
The provision of start - up related services was rather limited due to financial constraints and the small scale of start-up related activities .
This situation arose mainly due to a lack of expertise in start-up support procedures and poor administrative systems.
Business incubators aim to support new companies with the successful establishment and further development.
( SMEs) has therefore become an increasingly important policy priority over time.
In the period 2007-2013 , EU expenditure in this area amounted to 38 billion euros.
“Delta” building in the Technological Park in Wrocław , co-financed with ERDF funds .
Our activities 19 • Is the ERDF effective in funding projects directly promoting biodiversity under the EU ‐ Biodiversity Strategy 2020?
– In this special report, we examined whether the ERDF funding available for direct biodiversity support was used by the Member States.
The audit found that Member States lag behind in the absorption of ERDF funds to finance projects compared to other ERDF spending areas .
In order for the ERDF to continue to be useful in view of the implementation of the EU strategy to halt biodiversity loss by 2020, the Commission should provide more support to Member States in the implementation of specific protection and management plans for natural habitats and species .
were generally consistent with national and EU biodiversity priorities.
However, assessing the effectiveness of these projects was hampered by the fact that most Member States had neither result indicators nor monitoring systems to assess the evolution of natural habitats and species .
Protecting biodiversity is one of the EU's top priorities.
to meet the previous target of halting the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010, the Council approved a new strategy up to 2020. In the programming period 2007 - 2013 ERDF funds of 2 .8 billion euros allocated. • Has the support provided by the ERDF to e - commerce SMEs been effective?
20/2014 ) - In this special report, the Court assessed whether the operational programs formed a good basis for an efficient support of actions in the field of e - commerce for SMEs, whether the managing authorities correctly selected e - commerce projects and monitored and whether the ERDF co-financed e - commerce projects were successfully implemented and delivered measurable benefits .
The Court found that ERDF support for SMEs in e - commerce – buying and selling goods over the internet – helped increase the online availability of business services.
However, due to deficiencies in monitoring, it has been impossible to assess to what extent ERDF support has contributed to the achievement of Member State and EU IT objectives .
Inadequate selection procedures by the Member States mean that a good cost - benefit ratio is unlikely for many projects .
The program managers focused more on the use of funds (outputs) than on achieving results.
The Commission is promoting e ‐ commerce through its Digital Agenda for Europe . Within the framework of the ERDF budget , in the period 2007 - 2013 EU funds amounting to 3 billion euros were made available for the better use of ICT by SMEs . Court's video on special report 20/2014 "Is the ERDF effective in funding projects directly supporting biodiversity under the EU ‐ Biodiversity Strategy 2020?" - EUauditorsECA on Youtube.
Our activities 20 Close-up of a performance audit: EU - funded airport - infrastructures - an insufficient cost - benefit - relationship (No. 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura Airport.
Although EU air transport policy is aimed at overcoming capacity problems – by building additional infrastructure, making better use of existing structures , optimizing airport services and improving connections to other modes of transport – Europe will not be able to meet a large part of this demand because Runways and ground infrastructure are missing.
There are more than 500 commercial airports in Europe, which directly or indirectly employ a million people and which – together with the airlines – contribute more than 140 billion euros to European economic output.
Airport - related infrastructure projects are a significant spending area of the EU budget : the EU allocated around 4.5 billion euros to projects of this type in the programming periods 2000 – 2013, of which more than 2.8 billion euros were made available from the cohesion policy funds.
As part of its performance audit of this support, the Court examined whether the investments were demonstrated to be needed, whether the construction projects were on time and on budget and whether the newly built or upgraded infrastructure was fully utilised.
We assessed whether the investments resulted in increased passenger numbers and improved customer service, and whether the supported airports were financially viable.
The examiners carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014. The focus was on 20 EU - financed airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain.
more than 600 million euros have been made available for these airports in the period 2000-2013 EU .
The team undertook a desk review of the relevant legislation , air transport planning in the five Member States and publications from the main industry organisations .
In particular, the auditors visited the 20 airports to assess and obtain direct evidence of the outputs, uses, results and impacts achieved with the EU funds and the economic situation of the airports .
The Court concluded that EU - funded investments in airports did not represent a cost - benefit ratio .
Too many airports, often close to each other, received financial support for similar infrastructure and in many cases this infrastructure turned out to be oversized.
Only half of the audited airports managed to increase their passenger numbers.
Improvements in customer service or a regional socio - economic benefit such as B. the creation of additional jobs were either not measured or there was no evidence of this.
The audit also revealed that seven of the airports were not financially self-sustaining and will struggle to remain operational without further government support.
For most airports audited , the audit team found significant delays in construction and infrastructure deployment.
Almost half of the airports exceeded the costs, so that Member States had to contribute almost 100 million euros more from their national budgets than originally planned .
Our Activities 21 Funding was not well coordinated by Member States: in most States there was no strategic long ‐ term plan for airport development.
In addition, the funding was insufficiently monitored by the Commission . In general, the latter does not know which airports receive funding or what the amounts are.
As a result, it does not have a complete picture of all EU investments in airports and has limited ability to oversee and ensure policies are properly designed and implemented.
Based on these findings, the Court recommended that the Commission ensure, from the 2014-2020 programming period , that Member States only use EU funds for airport infrastructure that is financially viable and whose investment needs have been properly assessed and has been proven.
Another recommendation was that Member States should have coherent airport development plans at regional, national and supranational levels to avoid overcapacity, duplication and uncoordinated investments in airport infrastructure.
In its reply, the Commission assured that lessons were learned from these experiences.
As a result, it has ensured that a fundamentally different approach is applied in the relevant legislation for the 2014-2020 programming period .
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The publication of the report attracted a great deal of media interest.
The media reaction was greatest in Spain, but also included headlines in major international newspapers, television and social media coverage.
From left to right: Afonso de Castro Malheiro, Jasmine Mitterbuchner, Patrick Weldon, Mircea Radulescu, Pietro Puricella, Joël Costantzer, George Pufan (Member of the Court responsible for the report), Fernando Pascual Gil, Luc T'Joen, Tomasz Plebanowicz, Lorenzo Pirelli, Efstratios Varetidis, Jelena Magermane, Erki Must.
Our activities 22 Sustainable growth: natural resources The EU has high political responsibilities in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020 is – in current prices – €420 billion or 39% of the total EU budget.
Three-quarters of spending concerns direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the 'first pillar' of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
Another fifth of spending is on EU support for rural development , funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the 'second pillar' of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are managed jointly by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2014, we produced the following special reports in this area: • Integrating EU - water policy objectives into the CAP: a partial success (4/2014) - In this special report, we assessed whether the EU - water policy objectives were successful in integrated into the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
The audit revealed that the EU has only had partial success in integrating water policy objectives into the CAP.
The two instruments for integrating water-related concerns (cross ‐ compliance and rural development) show shortcomings and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive is marked by delays and weaknesses.
The CAP instruments have so far had a positive impact in supporting policy objectives of improving water quantity and quality .
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious goals of the CAP.
For example, neither of these two instruments allows for the full application of the polluter pays principle when disbursing CAP funds .
, there is insufficient knowledge at the level of the EU institutions and in the Member States to which pressures on water resources are exposed by agricultural activities and what developments these pressures are taking.
The EU gives high priority to the protection of Europe's water resources .
Agriculture, as one of the largest consumers and polluters of water resources, has a key role to play in sustainable water management.
Almost 40% of the EU budget is spent on the CAP ( over EUR 50 billion in 2014). Through the CAP, the EU is striving to influence agricultural practices that affect water resources.
Our activities 23 • Has the Commission effectively managed the integration of coupled support into the SPS ?
(8/2014) - In this special report, we assessed how well the Commission, following the 2008 Health Check of the CAP, is managing the integration of EU support linked to production levels (e.g. areas under cultivation or livestock numbers) into the SPS Has.
The audit found that during the period ‐ 2010 ‐ 2012 the Commission did not adequately monitor how Member States calculated farmers' entitlements to EU farm support payments under the Single Payment Scheme .
While most Member States had correctly used the farmers' reference data, there were serious shortcomings in the correct application of the calculation rules and principles .
The Commission did not exercise its mandate to ensure that the criteria for the allocation of the available support were always in line with EU principles, respected the principle of sound financial management and had no potential impact on market conditions .
The framework put in place by the Commission was not sufficiently clear about the controls Member States must carry out and the quality of the control systems in the Member States varied. The main objective of the SPS was to shift the focus of the CAP from market support to decoupled income support for farmers: farmers should be able to adapt their production to market demand and their income should be stabilised .
, the SPS accounts for 54% of the total EU budget for agriculture and rural development. • Is EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector well managed and are there documented results in terms of EU wine competitiveness ?
(9/2014) - In this special report, the Court assessed whether the investment - and promotion - measures were adequately designed. We also examined the available monitoring and evaluation data to assess whether the Commission and the Member States were efficiently achieving the intended results .
The audit found that the management of investment and promotion support in the wine sector was hampered by design and implementation weaknesses and impacts on the competitiveness of EU wines could not always be demonstrated .
The investment measure specific to the wine sector is not justified as support is already provided under the EU rural development policy .
EU support for the promotion of wine has often served to consolidate existing markets rather than opening up new markets or recapturing old ones.
The impact of the investment measure cannot be easily separated from the rural development investments.
The EU is the largest wine producer in the world.
EU support aims to improve competitiveness and ensure a better balance between supply and demand.
Member States spent 522 million euros on the promotion measure and 518 million euros on the investment measure in the period 2009 - 2013 EU .
For 2014-2018 , the funds allocated to Member States under this measure have increased significantly .
Our activities 24 • Effectiveness of support to aquaculture provided by the European Fisheries Fund ( EFF) (No 10/2014) – In this special report we assessed whether the measures to support aquaculture at EU level and in Member States were well designed and adequately implemented and whether the EFF delivered value for money and supported the sustainable development of aquaculture .
The audit found that measures to support aquaculture up to 2013 were not well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level , that the EFF did not deliver value for money and the sustainable development of aquaculture was not effective was supported.
The current framework was not suitable to concretely implement the EU's goals for the sustainable development of aquaculture and the results were not sufficient .
to support the sustainable development of aquaculture in Member States have not been well designed and implemented.
Member States ' National Strategic Plans and Operational Programs were not sufficiently clear and Member States did not have a coherent strategy for the sector.
The EFF funds were often not used in a sufficiently targeted manner for aquaculture projects, and the audit showed that these projects generally did not produce the planned results or a good cost - benefit ratio .
Around 1.3 million tonnes of fish are produced through aquaculture in the EU every year; the turnover amounts to 4 billion euros.
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy ( CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture.
been made available under the EFF to fund measures to encourage productive investment and environmental and health policies in the aquaculture sector. • Going thrifty: staying in control of the cost of EU - funded aid to rural development projects (n°22/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the approaches taken by the Commission and Member States ‐ the most effective in keeping rural development aid costs under control.
The audit showed that EU - Member States could achieve significant savings in rural development project grants while at the same time making more efficient use of funds.
The auditors identified workable and cost-effective approaches that could be used more widely in Member States' control of the cost of rural development support.
Member States' control systems were designed to control the prices of goods or works indicated in aid applications without giving equal attention to the question of whether the goods themselves were reasonable.
Some price controls were time consuming or provided little assurance that the approved costs were reasonable.
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance nor did it ensure the dissemination of good practice .
were effective before they approved large-scale aid.
Around half of the total €100 billion in rural development spending earmarked by the EU for the period 2007-2013 came in the form of grants towards the cost of investment projects and other projects run by farmers , agribusinesses , associations and local authorities.
Our activities 25 • Mistakes in rural development spending: what are the causes and what is being done to fix them?
(No 23/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined compliance with applicable laws and regulations in the implementation of rural development and described the main causes of the high level of error in this area.
The audit found that most errors in rural development policy stem from breaches of conditions set at Member State level .
Member States' control authorities could and should have detected and corrected most errors in rural development investment measures.
The Member State control systems are deficient as the controls are not comprehensive and based on insufficient information .
The average error rate for rural development spending over the past three years was 8.2%.
Errors in the context of investment measures accounted for two thirds of the error rate, area-related aid for one third.
Only 16% of the error rate resulted from non-compliance with provisions directly contained in EU regulations, while the largest share of the error rate – 84% – was due to breaches of conditions set at Member State level .
period 2007-2013 , the EU and the Member States provided over 150 billion euros for rural development policy, which was used almost equally for investment measures and area - related subsidies.
These outputs are particularly error-prone. • Is EU support for preventing and repairing forest damage caused by fire and natural disasters well managed?
(No 24/2014) – In this special report, we assessed whether the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) support measure for restoring forestry potential and introducing preventive actions (measure 226) was well managed and whether the Commission and Member States can demonstrate that the intended objectives of the aid have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
The audit found that EU funding for preventing forest fires and restoring forests damaged by natural disasters and fires was not well managed.
The Commission and the Member States are unable to demonstrate that the intended results of the funding have been achieved in a cost-effective manner.
During the last 30 years, an average of 480 000 ha of forest area has been destroyed by fire in the EU every year.
more than 80% of EU funding of €1.5 billion for the period 2007-2013 .
Our activities 26 Security and citizenship This policy area was established to ensure the free movement of people and to offer citizens a high level of protection.
It ranges from the management of the EU external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters and includes asylum and immigration policy , police cooperation and the fight against crime.
Expenditure in this area over the period 2014-2020 is expected to be €18 billion , or less than 2% of the total budget.
In 2014, we produced the following special reports in this area: • Lessons learned from the development of the second generation Schengen Information System ( SIS II) by the European Commission (3/2014) - In this special report we examined : why the Commission deployed the SIS II more than six years later than planned and incurred eight times the costs originally estimated.
It was verified that there was a viable business case for the SIS II throughout the project duration, taking into account major changes in terms of costs and expected benefits.
The audit found that the delays and excessive costs were due to weaknesses in the Commission's management.
The initial deadline was unrealistic and the Commission could not effectively manage the main contract for development before 2009.
The original cost estimates significantly underestimated the actual level of investment required.
The total cost of SIS II was EUR 189 million compared to an initial estimate of EUR 23 million.
The Commission did not fully demonstrate that the SIS II offered it the best value for money .
However, she has gained insights from her experiences during the first phase of the project and has already used some of these insights for other large IT projects .
The Schengen Information System is used by border guards , police , customs , visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengen area .
It contains information ( alerts) regarding persons who may have been involved in a serious crime or who do not have the right to enter or reside in the EU .
It also includes alerts relating to missing persons and lost or stolen property. • The EBF contributed to more financial solidarity, but there is a need to improve measurement of results and create additional EU - added value (15/2014) - In this special report, we assessed the effectiveness and EU - added value of the EBF and highlighted the Ask to what extent the goals of the co ‐ financed projects and programs have been achieved.
The audit found that the External Borders Fund has contributed to the protection of the EU's external borders and increased financial solidarity between Member States.
, its EU added value was limited and the overall results could not be measured due to weaknesses in monitoring by competent authorities and serious weaknesses in assessments at Commission and Member State level.
Member States' programs were not embedded in national strategies for border control and visa issues and did not contain SMART targets or measurable indicators .
The project selection procedures did not ensure that the real needs of the Member States were met.
Inadequate ‐ procurement practices in Member States pose a risk to sound financial management.
In the Member States primarily affected (Greece, Spain, Italy and in the first years of funding also Malta) there were serious weaknesses in the administration of the fund.
's main financial instrument to support the management of the external borders, the External Borders Fund had a budget of €1.9 billion for the period 2007-2013 .
Its overall objective was to support current and future Schengen States in ensuring uniform, effective and efficient controls at their common external borders .
Our activities 27 Global Europe The EU's external relations activities focus on enlargement, bringing stability, security and prosperity to its neighbourhood, actively supporting sustainable development internationally, promoting global political governance and security of strategic and civil security.
The EU has allocated €66 billion – in current prices – or 6% of its planned total spending to these objectives for the period 2014-2020 .
is managed by the Commission directly through its central services or its delegations.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • The establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (No 11/2014) - In this special report , the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS was adequately prepared, whether its resources have been efficiently prioritized, organized and allocated and whether it has effectively coordinated with the Commission and Member States.
The audit found that the EEAS should become more efficient and do more for the EU and its citizens.
The establishment of the EEAS was rushed and not sufficiently prepared.
, organization and resource allocation reduced its efficiency.
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective , mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and a rigid financial and administrative framework at delegation level .
Coordination with Member States can be further enhanced to exploit synergies in the area of information exchange or shared accommodation and to improve consular services, including the protection of EU citizens .
The EEAS is headquartered in Brussels and comprises a worldwide network of 140 delegations.
For 2014, the EEAS had a budget of €519 million divided between headquarters (41%) and the delegations (59%). • EU rehabilitation assistance after the earthquake in Haiti (13/2014) – In this special report we examined whether the EU rehabilitation assistance provided to the country was well designed and adequately implemented and whether the Commission ensured that the Provided emergency aid with rehabilitation and development measures .
The audit found that overall EU rehabilitation assistance after the 2010 earthquake in Haiti was well designed and targeted to the country's urgent needs, but the programs were not implemented effectively enough and relief , rehabilitation and development were not sufficiently linked were linked .
Most of the programs audited had their outputs on track or on track to deliver, although almost all programs experienced delays.
, it did not adequately address some key risks that jeopardized the implementation and achievement of the program objectives .
The programs were monitored but the Commission and the EEAS did not take timely action to increase the resources of the EU delegation in Haiti .
, 55 donors pledged US$5.4 billion for 2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and an additional US$3.0 billion for 2013 and beyond.
The EU was one of the most important donors with a commitment of an individual amount of 1.2 billion euros.
Our activities 28 • Effectiveness of blending grants ‐ from regional investment facilities with loans provided by financial institutions (blending) in support of the EU ‐ External Policy (No 16/2014) – In this special ‐ report we looked at the establishment and management of the investment facilities and examined whether the intended benefits were achieved with the blended financing.
The audit's judgment on blended finance, i.e. the combination of grants from regional investment facilities and loans provided by financial institutions in support of the EU's external policy, was positive in terms of structure and overall effectiveness, but the Court also reports draws attention to a number of key issues that urgently need to be addressed.
While the facilities were well constructed, the potential benefits of blending were not fully realized due to weaknesses in their management by the Commission .
For almost half of the projects examined, there was insufficient evidence that the grants were justified.
In some cases the investments would probably have been made without the EU contribution .
The Commission should ensure that the allocation of funds is based on a thorough, documented assessment of the added value in terms of achieving the objectives of the EU's development , neighborhood and enlargement policies.
Since 2007, the Commission has created eight regional investment facilities.
These combine grants from the EDFs and the general EU budget with loans primarily from European development finance institutions .
be financially viable but for which sufficient funds cannot be mobilized in financial markets. • Can the EU ‐ Centers of Excellence initiative contribute effectively to mitigating chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN ‐ ) risks originating outside the EU?
, we assessed whether the initiative was based on a sound analysis of the pre-2010 situation, whether the organizational structure of the initiative was appropriate to address the challenges identified and whether there was a adequate management system existed and whether this was applied.
a generally positive assessment of the contribution of the centers of excellence to mitigating CBRN risks .
The initiative is in line with the priorities set out in the European Security Strategy and the EU Strategy against Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction .
It provides for the involvement of all actors involved in the partner countries in order to improve the sustainability of the measures taken .
The organizational structure is generally adequate, but its complexity contributed to the delay in starting project activities.
The Centers of Excellence initiative aims to set up regional platforms in different regions of the world to counteract CBRN risks .
It forms the largest single measure of the long-term component of the Instrument for Stability and has a budget of EUR 100 million for the period 2010-2013 .
Our activities 29 • Systems put in place at EuropeAid for evaluation and results-oriented monitoring (ROM) (18/2014) - In this special report we examined whether these systems are reliable, whether their structure and their resource allocations are adequate and whether they ensure that relevant and meaningful determinations are made and maximum use is made of the determinations.
, the Court came to a critical assessment of the reliability of these systems.
The bodies responsible for evaluation and results - oriented monitoring are well organized, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources.
The systems do not provide enough information on the results achieved and they do not ensure that the best possible use is made of the findings.
The evaluations of projects and programs organized by the Commission Delegations and carried out in partner countries are not managed satisfactorily: the overall monitoring is not adequate , there is a lack of clarity about the amount of resources used and there is a lack of access to the results.
Two key elements of the accountability framework of the European Commission's Directorate-General for Development and Cooperation ( EuropeAid) are its evaluation and results - based monitoring systems.
The total annual costs of the systems are estimated at 34 to 38 million euros.
The annual development expenditure covered by these systems is estimated at around 8 billion euros. • EU pre-accession assistance to Serbia (19/2014) - In this special report we examined whether the Commission had effectively managed pre-accession assistance to Serbia over the period 2007-2013 , assessing its support to the key area of governance.
Along with other forms of support, funds made available from the Instrument for Pre- Accession Assistance (IPA) helped Serbia implement social and economic reforms and improve public financial management.
Based on its experience with other IPA beneficiary countries , the Commission is placing increasing emphasis on governance issues when planning financial and non-financial assistance to Serbia.
The Commission has effectively managed non - financial assistance to Serbia in the areas of governance and anti-corruption.
Serbia's preparations for decentralized management of EU funds, but only in the limited area of IPA management structures .
A quarter of the IPA budget for Serbia has gone to the area of governance, which the Commission says poses the greatest challenges for that country.
The EU complements IPA funding with a range of non - financial means to support Serbia in its preparation for EU membership .
Our activities 30 Administration The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (salaries and pensions), buildings, equipment, energy, communications and information technology .
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020 is – in current prices – €70 billion or 6% of the total EU budget .
, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • How do the EU institutions and bodies calculate, reduce and offset their greenhouse gas emissions ?
(14/2014) – In this special report, we assessed whether the EU institutions and bodies had policies in place to reduce the impact of their administrative activities on the environment and whether these policies were being implemented effectively.
In the report, the Court called on the EU institutions and bodies to develop a common policy to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions ( 'carbon footprint') .
is slow and the available information on the actual level of emissions is patchy.
Few institutions and bodies make systematic use of green procurement .
While the EU institutions and bodies have managed to reverse the trend of increasing greenhouse gas emissions associated with energy use in their buildings, the available data have not identified clear trends of reductions from other sources of emissions, such as business travel.
had not set any quantified targets for reducing their emissions.
The environmental policy of the EU aims for a high level of protection .
According to the Treaty (TFEU), environmental protection requirements must be integrated into the definition and implementation of Union policies and activities promoting sustainable development.
Our activities 31 Revenue/Own resources Own resources are the EU's revenue used to finance its expenditure.
There are three types of own resources : traditional own resources (customs duties levied on imports from outside the EU and production taxes on sugar), VAT-based own resources and GNI-derived own resources (the main source of revenue for the EU budget) .
, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • Are preferential trade arrangements adequately managed ?
(No. 2/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the Commission adequately assessed the economic impact of preferential trade arrangements and whether the controls are effective in ensuring that imports cannot be wrongly subject to preferential tariffs , with the consequence a loss of EU revenue .
The audit found that, while the Commission has improved the quality of its impact assessments over time, it still does not adequately analyze the economic impact of preferential trading schemes.
The EU is losing revenue due to weaknesses in Member States' customs controls: these controls do not prevent some imports from being incorrectly subject to preferential tariffs .
Through unilateral preferential trade arrangements, the EU grants developing countries preferences to give them duty-free access to the EU market , thereby helping to eradicate poverty and promote sustainable development.
In 2011, the value of goods imported into the EU under preferential trade arrangements was more than 242 billion euros; this corresponds to 14% of imports into the EU.
Our activities 32 Fiscal and economic governance The European Union's framework for economic governance aims to prevent or identify and correct problematic economic developments, such as excessive government deficits or debt levels, which hamper growth and reduce the sustainability of public finances can expose to risk.
In 2014 we adopted our first special report in this area: • European banking supervision taking shape - The EBA in a changing environment (5/2014) - In this special report we examined whether the Commission and the European Banking Authority ( EBA ) have satisfactorily exercised their responsibilities with regard to establishing new rules for the regulatory and supervisory system in the banking sector and how effectively these rules have functioned.
The audit found that the Commission-led reform of banking legislation and the establishment of the EBA were important first responses to the financial crisis.
The EBA laid the foundations for a new regulatory and supervisory system for the banking sector .
The weaknesses identified related to cross-border banking supervision, the assessment of the resilience of EU banks and the promotion of consumer protection.
In connection with the implementation of the 2011 stress test, which was carried out without financial backstop measures at EU level, the EBA only had a limited legal mandate and scarce human resources.
Although the 2011 stress test led to the recapitalization of numerous banks, it also highlighted that such stress tests are subject to limitations if they are not accompanied by an assessment of overall asset quality.
Questions remain about the future role of the EBA in banking supervision and the respective roles and responsibilities of the EBA and the ECB.
, the Commission launched banking sector stabilization measures aimed at strengthening the regulatory framework and banking supervision, in particular for banks operating cross - border.
The EBA was created in 2011 as part of the detailed proposals for changes in the area of regulation.
The EBA plays a role in overseeing European banking regulation and consumer protection.
Our activities 33 Opinions and other communications adopted in 2014 The Court contributes to improving EU financial management by providing opinions on proposals for new or amended legislation with a financial impact .
These opinions are issued at the request of the other EU institutions and are used by the legislative authorities - the European Parliament and the Council - in their work .
The Court may also issue position papers and analyzes on other issues on its own initiative .
At the Court's initiative, the position of the European Court of Auditors on the Commission's anti - corruption report was presented, while the study on possible savings in the EU budget by consolidating the activities of the European Parliament in a single place at the request of the European Parliament was created.

Our Activities 34 Landscape ‐ Analyzes The year 2014 was marked by far-reaching changes for the European Union.
Against the background of this change, the court conceived and created a new product: the landscape analysis .
Based on the results of the Court's work and its wealth of knowledge and experience , a broad range of topics is dealt with in each analysis.
The analyzes are intended to serve as a basis for consultation and dialogue with the Court's stakeholders and to help the Court to provide observations on important issues that are not normally subject to audit .

Our Activities 35 Gaps, Overlaps and Challenges: A Landscape ‐ Analysis of the EU ‐ Arrangements on Accountability and Public Audit is of the utmost importance and to give impetus to related considerations .
It describes the key features of an accountability framework, the role of public audit , the key elements for a robust chain of accountability and audit, and six key areas where accountability and public governance challenges are being addressed at EU level pass financial control. It also analyzes the accountability and auditing regimes in relation to the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments that have been developed in response to the financial crisis.
EU ‐ Making the Most of Funds: A Landscape ‐ Analysis of the Risks to EU ‐ Financial Management At a time when Member State governments and taxpayers want more value from the funds they contribute, we are in this Landscape Analysis summarizes the Court's observations on all aspects of EU financial management .
Based on the Court's 35 years of experience auditing EU revenue and expenditure, this landscape analysis provides an overview of EU financial management and a summary of the issues that need to be addressed to ensure that a better cost - benefit ratio is achieved with the EU budget .
This analysis is complemented by detailed fact sheets on the key characteristics and issues linked to the various revenue and expenditure areas , and suggestions for improvement are made.
Our activities 36 The analysis identifies a number of key issues that deserve particular attention: ο overly complex eligibility rules and other conditions for EU funding that make them difficult to understand , manage and control and lead to different interpretations; ο Public procurement rules and procedures that are not always respected – either intentionally or because they are not properly understood – and thus result in higher costs or delays in EU - funded projects; ο the insufficient capacity of national authorities to manage and disburse EU funds , which increases the risk of errors and low-quality spending; ο the poor coordination of the EU budget and national budgets, a lack of resources for co-financing by Member States and a greater emphasis on compliance than on achieving results; ο a high volume of commitments from the previous spending period that have yet to be funded from the EU budget .

Our activities 37 Relations with stakeholders The value of the Court's contribution to EU accountability depends to a large extent on the use of its work and products to its key partners in the accountability process .
These partners are the political bodies responsible for public oversight of the use of EU funds (ie European Parliament , Council of the EU and national parliaments).
's strategy for 2013-2017 requires it to put more effort into monitoring external developments and actively shaping relations with its partners.
The President and the Members of the Court maintain regular contacts with the committees of the European Parliament , in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control .
In 2014, President Caldeira attended two meetings of the Committee on Budgetary Control and a number of plenary sessions of the European Parliament.
This included the presentation of the annual work program and the annual reports.
One of the Court 's strategic objectives is to strengthen partnerships with its key stakeholders , including the various specialized committees of the European Parliament and the Council.
In April 2014, the Court delegated the newly created post of Institutional Relations Member to Ville Itälä. This helped to strategically strengthen our institution's relationships with other EU institutions and increase the chances of our work having a greater impact.
In 2014, other members of the Court answered questions on the Court 's annual and special reports 64 times in 17 meetings before the Budgetary Control Committee .
The ensuing discussions ‐ resulted in reports drafted by individual members of the Committee on Budgetary Control on the Court's special reports; this also includes a draft report on the special reports in connection with the 2013 discharge procedure .
In 2014, the Committee on Budgetary Control began to systematically invite the specialist committees to the presentation of our special reports at its meetings , thus contributing to the increased impact of our work.
In early 2014, the European Parliament adopted a report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors.
The Court welcomed the view expressed in this report that any reform needs to be seen in the broader context of the challenge of improving EU accountability .
This applies in particular to the Court's work, its relations with the addressees and its use of resources.
progress made on these issues was highlighted in the peer review report published in 2014 ( see “Key Events”).
Our activities 38 In many cases, as part of the implementation of our 2013-2017 strategy, the Court had already launched a number of improvement initiatives . This includes streamlining the audit and reporting process and making resources more flexible.
This resulted in more reports being written during the year and the average time taken to do so was reduced.
Further efficiency gains and increased effectiveness of the audit process are expected from the internal reform project initiated in 2014.
In a November 2013 resolution, the European Parliament asked the Court to provide a comprehensive analysis of the potential savings for the EU budget if the Parliament had a single seat. Savings due to less lost working time and greater efficiency should also be taken into account.
The Court presented the result of this work in July 2014 and concluded that significant savings could be achieved by moving from Strasbourg to Brussels, slightly increased by an additional move from Luxembourg to Brussels.
In 2014 the Court continued to work regularly with the Council in its various configurations and activities.
President Caldeira presented the annual reports to the ECOFIN Council in December 2014 and the Court was regularly asked to present special reports to the various committees and working groups of the Council.
Ensuring effective relations with national parliaments is another priority for the Court.
The committees responsible for European affairs and financial control in the national parliaments are regularly informed about the Court's activities.
During the year, delegations from several national parliaments visited the Court; this included a visit by a delegation from the French Senate in July 2014.
In addition, the Court invited key stakeholders to its Members ' annual seminar in December 2014 to present its perspective on the accountability challenges in the EU.
The Court works with the European Anti - Fraud Office ( OLAF) to fight fraud against the EU budget .

Our Activities 39 Cooperation with other Supreme Audit Institutions The Court mainly cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions ( SAIs) in the following bodies : • Contact Committee of SAIs of the EU - Member States ; • Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • International organizations of public audit bodies , in particular the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions ( INTOSAI ) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
In September 2014, we revised and updated our international cooperation strategy (see box).
EUROSAI ‐ Congress, The Hague, June 2014.
Court's international cooperation strategy The Court's cooperation strategy, in line with its overall strategy 2013-2017, aims to maximize the contribution to EU public accountability, in particular through enhanced bilateral and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners such as national supreme audit institutions and international audit organizations.
As the Court's audit duties extend to areas that have pan‐European (e.g. fiscal governance) and global (e.g. climate change) implications , our work in the field of international cooperation becomes even more relevant than in the past.
The Court's priorities in its cooperation strategy are: ο Cooperation at EU level - through the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the SAIs of the EU - Member States will remain the main priorities.
This may include participation in joint audits and joint work on accountability relevant to the EU budget and other EU policies . ο In the context of EU enlargement , the Court will continue to support the SAIs of candidate and potential candidate countries in their capacity - building activities. ο As a member of international auditing organizations such as INTOSAI, the Court will increase its involvement in collaborative activities on professional standard setting, given the importance of this organization for the development of expertise and for the exchange of knowledge in the public audit sector.
Through its cooperation strategy, in conjunction with other recent actions such as the newly launched high-level conferences and meetings, the Court will help raise awareness of EU - financial management and EU - accountability.
Our Activities 40 Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU - Member States In accordance with the EU - Treaty, the European Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies - while respecting their independence - work together in a spirit of trust .
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of the EU Member States through the Contact Committee . This includes an annual meeting and the various working groups, networks and task forces set up to address specific issues of common interest.
In October 2013, the Court chaired the Contact Committee for one year .
As Chair, we hosted the annual Contact Committee meeting, which took place in October 2014.
The main items on the agenda included a seminar on strengthening cooperation in particular in areas related to the Europe 2020 strategy and the Banking Union, reporting on the activities of the Contact Committee and its technical partners, and audits carried out by Contact Committee members with EU reference .
The Court also works with the SAIs of the EU Member States on a bilateral basis .
, Najwyższa Izba Kontroli, where the auditors from the Polish SAI actively participated in our audit work in Poland on animal disease eradication, control and surveillance.
In addition, the Court cooperates with the SAIs of Poland and Portugal on Europe 2020 in the context of the chapter on results - delivery of the FY2014 Annual Report.

Our Activities 41 Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of Candidate and Potential Candidate Countries Cooperation between the Court and the SAIs of the candidate and potential candidate countries occurs primarily through a network1 similar to the Contact Committee .
During 2014, the Court supported the network in conducting a parallel performance audit on energy efficiency , in particular by providing experts in the field and in the methodology of the performance audit .
International organizations of public audit bodies In 2014, the Court continued to be fully and actively involved in INTOSAI's activities and made important contributions to various committees and working groups: • as part of INTOSAI's Goal 1 as a member of the Committee on professional standards and as a member of the Financial Audit Subcommittee, the Legal Compliance Subcommittee and the Performance Audit Subcommittee ; • INTOSAI Goal 2 as a member of the Capacity Building Committee and the Subcommittee on Promotion of Best Practices and Quality Assurance through Voluntary Peer Reviews; • as part of INTOSAI's Goal 3 as a member of the Knowledge Sharing Committee and its Working Group on Environmental Auditing and the Working Group on Financial Modernization and Regulatory Reform. The court participated in the IX. EUROSAI ‐ Congress in June 2014. In this context he organized and hosted a workshop on “Measuring your performance”.
He also took part in the XLI . and the XLII. Meeting of the EUROSAI Governing Board , of which he has been a member since 2011. The Court continued to participate actively in the EUROSAI working bodies, in particular the IT and environmental auditing working groups, the monitoring committee for the establishment and operation of the electronic good practice database on audit quality , and the audit and ethics task force .
The Court also joined the newly established Disaster Assistance Audit Working Group .
Within the joint conferences of INTOSAI regional working groups, the Court actively participated in the II ASOSAI2 - EUROSAI Joint Conference , which focused on the lessons learned from the experience gained in relation to the adoption of the ISSAI3 and their implications for the future.

, the Court requested the SAIs of France, Germany and Sweden to carry out a peer review of its performance audit practice .
The peer review drew on the experiences of all three partners and was a very useful exercise for both the Court and the peer reviewers.
The methodology was based on generally accepted criteria for the work of SAIs and took into account the guidelines set out in international standards.
The peer review was published on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu) in 2014.
The peers concluded that the Court had made significant progress since the last peer review in 2008 .
The Court had examined the challenges posed by the EU's complex institutional framework and had taken a number of steps to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of its audits and the quality of its audit reports.
Conducting international peer reviews is encouraged in international auditing standards .
These allow Supreme Audit Institutions to receive a voluntary assessment of how they perform their duties, based on international standards.
In 2014, the Court led the peer review of the Supreme Audit Institution of Lithuania and was asked to assess the Federal Audit Office and participate in peer reviews of the SAIs of Spain and Latvia .
High Level Conference on Improving Accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, President Vítor Caldeira and EP - Vice-President Olli Rehn.
In October 2014, the Court organized a high-level conference bringing together a wide range of people responsible for ensuring that the European Union is accountable for the public funds used to achieve its objectives.
The theme of the conference was the gaps, overlaps and challenges at EU and Member State level identified in the Court 's landscape analysis of EU accountability and public audit arrangements (see page 35) .
The conference provided an opportunity for discussion among the participants, including members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court of Justice, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, national audit offices and academia . How these arrangements should be developed in response to developments in economic , fiscal and monetary integration was discussed .
with regard to central banks and supervisory authorities, crisis and post - crisis structures , increasing the leverage of EU funds through external participation and a stronger focus on EU service delivery.
The conference participants agreed that there is a need for greater cooperation between government agencies , parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level in order to give the public a better picture of how EU policies and programs are performing .
Our activities 43 Strengthening partnerships with national authorities in Lithuania A high-level ECA delegation visited Lithuania in September 2014 to strengthen partnerships with the country's parliament, government, central bank and SAI, and to improve the best use and scrutiny of the EU ‐ to promote spending there.
The Court and our partners in Lithuania shared priorities for ‐ improving EU ‐ accountability and how, by working together, they could best contribute to promoting the added value of EU spending and ‐ policy makers and the parliament in Lithuania at the best use of the Court's audit results.
During the visit, the Court's delegation actively participated in the Lithuanian Parliament's conference on the challenges of accountability and auditing in the public sector .
In addition, the delegation and its partners discussed issues of fiscal and economic governance and the benefits that Lithuania's entry into the euro area on 1 January 2015 will bring to the country.
was the first of a number of EU Member States that the Court intends to visit in the coming years in order to strengthen partnerships with the national authorities responsible for the management and control of EU funds .
Our management 44 The Court's College The Court's College consists of one member from each Member State.
According to the contract, the term of office of the members of the Court is six years, renewable.
The members are assigned to one of five chambers.
The chambers accept audit reports and opinions and make decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member is responsible for their own tasks, which are primarily audit-related tasks.
The underlying audit work is carried out by the Court's auditors and coordinated by the Member responsible, assisted by his cabinet.
The member then takes on the task of presenting the report for approval by the Chamber and/or the entire Court College and later presenting it to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media.
In 2014, the Council of the European Union appointed six new members of the European Court of Auditors, following proposals from their Member States and after consulting the European Parliament.
Four of these members – Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Danièle Lamarque (France), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Phil Wynn Owen (UK) – were welcomed by the Court on 1 January, as well as two others – Klaus - Heiner Lehne (Germany) and Oskar Herics (Austria) - were welcomed on March 1st, 2014.
On 23 January 2014, the 28 members of the Court re-elected Vítor Caldeira as President of the Court for a third triennium.
The President is responsible for overseeing the fulfillment of the Court's mission and represents the institution externally.
Members of the Court at the end of 2014.

Our management 46 Court's strategy 2013-2017 : progress made 2014 was the second year in which the Court implemented its strategy for the period 2013-2017.
, the aim is to maximize the value of the Court's contribution to EU public accountability .
In order to achieve this goal, the Court's main priorities are: ο targeting the Court's products to improve EU accountability; ο working with other stakeholders to enhance the Court's contribution to EU accountability; ο further development of the Court as a professional audit body; ο making the best use of the knowledge, expertise and expertise available to the Court; ο Demonstrate the Court's effectiveness and accountability.
In 2014, the strategy initiated a profound transformation of the Court's organizational structure.
Two internal working groups dealing with the strategy (“Streamlining of the audit process” and “Better definition of tasks and responsibilities”) presented their results.
This coincided with the European Parliament's report on the future role of the ECA and the results of the peer review process that the Court underwent .
The various recommendations were summarized in a far-reaching reform project, the implementation of which began at the end of 2014 and will last until mid-2016.
In the case of special reports, this means that they should be produced in a shorter time, in the case of the annual report, more focus and resource savings are sought.
Second ‐ the court is to be converted into a task-based organization.
This will enable him to better focus resources on those audits and analyzes that bring the most added value to EU citizens .
Our management 47 Measuring the Court's performance The Court has used key performance indicators (KPIs) since 2008 to inform management of progress towards its objectives, to support the decision-making process and to provide its stakeholders with information on performance to shake hands
The ALIs reflect the Court's priorities and provide insight into its performance and accountability as a professional audit body.
The indicators are designed to measure core parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, paying particular attention to the perspective of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
The ZLI were updated for the period covered by the strategy 2013 - 2017.
User judgments Relevantness of reports Likely impact of reports Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports through user judgments and peer reviews. Another evaluation criterion are the measures that are taken on the basis of his recommendations to improve EU financial management .
In addition, the Court measures its media presence.
Assess by users The Court has asked its key users – the Committees on Budgetary Control and Budgets of the European Parliament, the Budget Committee of the Council, the main auditees in the Commission and the EU Agencies and the Presidents of the EU – SAIs – to to rate the relevance and impact of its reports published in 2014 on a five-point scale from “very high” to “very low”.

The 2013-2017 strategy aims to achieve further improvements in this area and this strategy is expected to deliver measurable results in the coming years .

Support for audit activities Human resources Staff allocation In the wake of the difficult public finance situation in Europe , the Court continued the five-year ( 2013-2017 ) staff reduction of 1% per year, as set out in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Budgetary Discipline and the sound financial management of December 2013 .
As a result, in 2014 the staffing level was reduced from 891 to 882 officials and temporary agents (excluding members, contract agents, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the total posts, 561 are assigned to the examination chambers ( including 113 staff members in the Members' cabinets).
With a view to the goal of the best possible use of resources , in 2014 possibilities for increasing efficiency by simplifying processes were again identified and implemented in all activities.
The reallocation of staff from support to audit services also continued in 2014.
However, this has been offset by the reallocation of certain support services from Members' cabinets to an administrative pool and the transfer of the Communications and Institutional Relations Unit to the President's services .
51 Attitude The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both officials and temporary staff .
In 2014, an internal selection procedure for salary grade AST 1 and a selection procedure with a view to hiring a spokesman were carried out.
The Court also made internships available to 77 university graduates for periods of between three and five months throughout the year.
The Court recruited 78 staff in 2014, consisting of 31 officials, 29 temporary agents, 13 contract agents and five seconded national experts.
The number of vacancies has been close to 3% since 2011 (27 vacancies as of December 31, 2014).

Support for Audit Activities 55 Support Services Professional Development In order to develop the Court as a professional audit body and to make the best use of the knowledge, skills and expertise it has at its disposal, continuous training of staff is necessary to keep pace with professional developments and new ones to acquire skills.
In 2014, the Court's staff (auditors and other staff) received an average of eight days of professional development.
The share of language courses in vocational training continues to decline.
In 2014, this accounted for 43% of the total number of training days (compared to 46% in 2013).
In order to make the best possible use of the available resources and technologies, the farm has been offering its employees individually tailored e - learning courses and advanced training measures in the form of blended learning since 2014, in which the participants - before the face-to-face event - learn the general theory in complete an online training course .
, presentations by internal and external experts on developments in auditing and other relevant areas continued to be organized as part of the aim of sharing internal knowledge and updating the Court 's auditors on developments in public sector auditing .
Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfill its mission and communication objectives, which are to make the results it produces available in the languages of EU citizens .
In 2014, the total translation volume was 4% higher than in 2013.
More than 98% of translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate continued to increase the direct involvement of translators in the Court's audit and core business: translators provided linguistic support in 40 audit visits across the EU and in the drafting of audit reports .
, the Translation Directorate focused on quality assurance.
To this end, the first manual for quality assurance in the translation sector was approved and a system for customer feedback was developed .
Finally, in order to make the services more efficient, the translation process was reviewed and optimized. Automation of the process has started in cooperation with the Information Technologies Directorate.
Support for the audit activities 56 All processes related to the development and provision of instruments were carried out with the guarantee of safety and continuity of operation: For example, in 2014 after moving into the new K3 building , a comprehensive test was carried out for re - commissioning after a collapse of the IT systems ( disaster recovery) were carried out, and central IT components were also modernized (e.g. initiation of the migration of the Court 's e - mail system ).
Management and infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate ‐ is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfill its mission and strategic objectives and to ensure that the necessary funding ‐ , internal Controls and accounting mechanisms are in place to support all of the Court 's activities.
In 2014, the management continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economical.
system for the farm is currently being developed, in line with the principles of the Community Eco - Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS), with certification to be achieved by the end of 2016.
In 2014, several actions were successfully implemented, yielding tangible results and demonstrating the Court's commitment to the environment . These included: • Adopting an environmental policy; • Carrying out an environmental analysis and an audit of compliance with environmental law; • Increased the number of employee environmental awareness campaigns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014 ; • Obtaining BREEAM environmental certification ( the world 's leading method for the design and assessment of sustainable buildings) for the K3 building and retaining the certification mark for good waste management; • Promoting sustainable transport among employees by providing a new bicycle room with showers and changing areas for cyclists, by installing a charging station for electric cars and by reserving good parking spaces for carpooling .

The higher fill rate is primarily due to better estimation and planning of spend on Title 1, which achieved an average fill rate of 98.8%.
For Title 2, the average fill rate was 98.4%.

's internal audit The internal auditor advises the Court on risk control issues by providing opinions on the quality of the management and control systems and recommendations for improving the conditions under which transactions are carried out and promoting sound economics hand over housekeeping.
In addition, the internal auditor supports the work of the external auditor, whose mandate is to certify the annual accounts of the Court.
The internal auditor reported to the Court on the results of the audits carried out during 2014, the findings, the recommendations and the actions taken on those recommendations.
The Court reports annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit was certified as compliant with the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA) definition of internal audit, code of practice and standards.
This certification was the result of a comprehensive quality assessment of the Court's internal audit, carried out by an external evaluator - Deloitte SARL - at the request of the Internal Auditor and the Internal Audit Committee. It also complied with the IIA's international standards for the professional practice of internal auditing.
External audit of the Court The annual accounts of the Court are audited by an independent auditor .
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach of applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the entities it audits .
The auditor's report - Pricewaterhouse - Coopers SARL - on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013 was published on September 18, 2014.
's Opinions - Financial Year 2013 Concerning the financial statements: "In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2013, its results of operations and cash flows for the an year ending on that date in accordance with Regulation (EU, Eur ‐ atom) No. 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of the Commission of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation in all essential respects and taking into account the stated assessment criteria • the funds allocated to the Court have not been used for the ‐ intended purposes and • the control procedures put in place do not provide the necessary guarantee that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the rules and regulations in force. ”
