European Court of Auditors GUARDIANS OF THE EU ‐ FINANCES
European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors is the European Union's independent external audit body, based in Luxembourg.
It has 28 members – one from each EU Member State – and employs around 900 audit and administrative staff from all EU Member States.
Since its creation in 1977, the Court has worked to improve EU financial management and accounting.
The Court's tasks The Court checks that EU funds are correctly accounted for, raised and spent in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and that funds are used as efficiently as possible.
It warns of risks, provides reassurance and guides EU policy-makers on how to improve public finance management and ensure that European citizens know how their money is being spent.
Through its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and sustainability of the European Union.
Contents 03 Page 2 European Court of Auditors 4 Foreword by the President 5 2015 at a glance 5 Our activities 5 Our management 6-40 Our activities 6-9 Audits 10-13 Annual reports 14 Special annual reports 15-33 Special reports 34 Opinions 35-36 High-level events and conferences 37-38 Relations with stakeholders 39-40 Cooperation with SAIs 41-49 Our management 41-42 The Court’s College 43-45 The Court’s strategy for 2013-2017 46-49 Measuring performance 50-59 Supporting audit activities 50- 53 Human resources 53-55 Support services 56-57 Financial information 58-59 Audit and accountability 60 Declaration of the authorizing officer by delegation
Foreword by the President 04 Dear readers, In 2015, to which this activity report relates, the European Union once again faced major challenges. There have been significant developments in EU governance, policy and financial management, including the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the launch of the Single Resolution Mechanism for banks in the euro area.
These and other developments have resulted in new audit tasks for the Court.
In 2015 we continued to audit the activities of the EU institutions and other bodies, as well as all EU funds paid to Member States, countries outside the EU, international organizations and other recipients.
In accordance with our obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds, as well as specific annual reports on the accounts of over 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
In addition, we prepared 25 special reports on numerous topics, the results of which are summarized in this activity report.
We would like to draw your attention in particular to two special reports: our report on the emissions trading system, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial matters, and our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which is part of a series of new special reports on the financial and economic governance.
In addition, over the past year we have issued eight opinions on new or amended EU legislation with significant financial implications, including one on the EFSI regulation.
In order to make a difference with our work, we need to share the lessons learned with stakeholders at EU and national level.
During the year we continued to deepen our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union – our key partners in ensuring EU accountability.
We presented the results of our audits to an increasing number of technical committees of these bodies, and we took their concerns into account when planning future audits.
In addition, ECA members made high-level visits to Member States to strengthen partnerships with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015 we organized two notable conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of development aid in light of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals.
In addition, we prepared an extensive internal reform in order to be able to react better to the continuous developments within the European Union.
This report outlines some key changes we have made to our stakeholder relationships, our reviews and our resources.
You will also receive important information about our human resources, finance and performance and the results of our internal and external audits over the past year, as well as the most recent annual discharge process.
I hope that this report gives you a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015. Through these activities, we aim to fulfill our mission, which is to improve EU financial management, promote accountability and transparency, and protect the financial interests of EU citizens.
2015 at a glance 05 Our activities Our management • Annual reports on the general budget of the EU • and on the European development funds for the financial year 2014, which essentially contain the statements of assurance and the audit results. • 52 specific annual reports containing the Court's audit opinions on the accounts of each EU agency and other body, and two summary reports. We implemented an internal reform to streamline our audit and reporting processes and allow for greater flexibility in managing our resources. • 25 special reports on specific management • issues and budget areas, including the Emissions Trading Scheme, youth employment programs and financial crisis assistance. • • Eight opinions on new or amended EU legislation and other decisions affecting financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the amended regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our stakeholders, including two high-level conferences on EU accountability, one on security of energy supply and the other on the future of development aid.
We continued our equal opportunity policy in recruitment and human resource management. • We made significant progress in integrating information systems for audit management and audit documentation. We also made exam-related information accessible on mobile devices. The buildings of the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain, as they are used to hold those responsible for the EU's financial management to account, particularly during the annual discharge process.
These bodies are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
Member States also play an important role in areas of shared management, such as spending on agricultural and cohesion measures.
Our three main products are: • Annual reports, which mainly contain the results of financial and compliance audits on the European Union budget and the European Development Funds (EDFs), but also cover financial management and performance aspects.
There are also separately published specific annual reports on the EU agencies, decentralized bodies and JUs. • Special reports presenting the results of selected profitability or Compliance audits on specific spending or policy areas, or on budgetary or managerial issues are presented. • Opinions on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other analysis-based products, produced either at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative.
We aim to manage our resources to ensure an appropriate balance between our different activities. At the same time, the different areas of the EU budget should be well covered and solid results should be achieved.
In 2015, we dedicated a significant portion of our resources to the preparation of the annual Statements of Assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work underlying the Statement of Assurance covers the two aspects on which the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union requires us to express an annual opinion: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of underlying transactions.
In addition, where possible, we take into account the work of other auditors (see the section on auditing EU agencies on p. 14) and the management declarations in the form of the annual activity reports of the Commission's Directors-General.
In addition to the legally required audits, we select specific spending or policy areas at our discretion. This is based on criteria such as the risk of irregularities or inadequate performance, potential for improvement and public interest.
We select these topics completely independently, but take into account the points of view of our target group.
In 2015 we prepared 25 special reports, which are mainly the result of our performance audits.
The summaries of the special reports are presented in this activity report (pp. 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or amended rules and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we refer to our Opinion on EFSI to clarify both the subject matter and the implications of our Opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 Audit visits in 2015 While most of the audit work took place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also visited Member State authorities, other beneficiaries of EU funds inside and outside the European Union (such as organizations involved in the allocation of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and other EU institutions, agencies and bodies.
Through these visits, we obtained direct audit evidence from the entities involved in approving, managing, collecting and disbursing EU funds, as well as from the respective final recipients.
Our audit teams typically consist of two to three auditors and audit visits can last from a few days to several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depends on the type of audit and, where appropriate, the selection of the sample.
The number of inspection visits can therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in liaison with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days on-site – in Member States and outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
They also spent significant time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralized agencies and bodies across the EU.
The on-site inspections took fewer days than in 2014.
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as the secure exchange of data and documents and video conferencing.
Fraud Detection Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases in the course of our audit work where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activity.
The Court works with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to fight fraud against the EU budget.
Any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the EU that arises during our audit work is forwarded to OLAF.
These cases are then followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and cooperates with Member State authorities where necessary.
In 2015, we forwarded 27 such cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16 cases).

Our activities 10 annual reports on the financial year 2014 The majority of our financial and compliance audits in 2015 were devoted to the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2014.
The 2014 Annual Report resulting from this work was published on 10 November 2015 and is addressed to our audience, which includes the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (ECOFIN Council), national parliaments and governments, and the media presented.
The main aim of our annual report is to assist the European Parliament, the Council and the citizens in assessing the quality of EU financial management by providing findings and conclusions.
In the Annual Report 2014 we provide assurance on the use of EU funds in the financial year under review and highlight where the risk of EU funds being improperly spent was greatest.
In addition, we analyze why errors occurred and make useful and cost-effective recommendations for possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our 2014 Annual Report to make the report more reader-friendly.
The headings of the chapters now correspond to those of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The core element of the report is still the statement of assurance, in which we express our audit opinion on the reliability of the annual accounts of the EU and on compliance with the regulations for revenue and expenditure.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all major areas of EU activity and provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report also provides information on the performance of the EU budget and the Commission's performance reporting, in particular with regard to progress towards the Europe 2020 strategy targets.
President Vítor Caldeira presents the European Court of Auditors' 2014 annual report to the European Parliament. EU spending in 2014 amounted to 142.5 billion euros = just under 300 euros per citizen
Our activities 11 Key messages from the 2014 annual report The European Court of Auditors calls for a new approach to EU investment and spending. ƒ The reliability of the EU accounts for the year 2014 has been confirmed. ƒ Revenue was legal and regular in 2014. ƒ Payments in 2014 were affected by material errors.
Conclusions and recommendations ƒ The EU accounts for 2014 have been properly prepared in accordance with international standards and give a true and fair view.
We were therefore again able to issue an unqualified audit opinion on their reliability.
However, we issued a negative audit opinion on the regularity of the payments. ƒ The estimated level of error, which measures the magnitude of irregularities, is 4.4% for the 2014 payments. This value is close to the error rate for 2013 (4.5%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%. ƒ The estimated error rates we found were the same for expenditure under shared management with Member States and expenditure managed directly by the Commission (4.6%).
The highest levels of error were found in spending under the headings "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" (5.7%) and "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" (5.6%).
Administrative expenditure has the lowest estimated level of error (0.5%). ƒ There is a clear link between types of expenditure and error rates.
The estimated error rate for cost reimbursement schemes (5.5%) where the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities based on the cost claims prepared by beneficiaries is twice the estimated error rate for payment entitlement schemes (2.7%) , where costs are not reimbursed, but payment depends on the fulfillment of certain conditions. ƒ Corrective actions by Member State authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated level of error.
Without these actions, the estimated overall error rate would have been 5.5%.
The Commission still needs to improve on risk assessment and the impact of corrective actions. ƒ If the Commission, the Member State authorities and the independent auditors had used all the information available to them, they could have prevented or detected and corrected a significant part of the errors before they occurred. ƒ Amounts to be paid in the current and future years continue to be very high.
It is imperative for the Commission to take action to address this persistent problem.
The Europe 2020 targets are not sufficiently taken into account by the Member States in the partnership agreements and programmes.
These two aspects limit the ability of the Commission to monitor and report on the performance and contribution of the EU budget to Europe 2020. ƒ The forthcoming mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 is crucial for the management of EU spending.
It is important that the Commission analyze as soon as possible the areas with persistently high error rates, assess the possibilities to reduce these error rates and pay more attention to the performance of the expenditure.

Our activities 13 European Development Funds (EDFs) Annual Report 2014 ƒ Revenue was free from error. ƒ The payments were affected by material errors. Under the EDF, the European Union provides funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs).
Funded by the Member States, the EDFs are managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and, for some aid, by the European Investment Bank.
Their receipts were not affected by material error, while for payments there was an estimated error rate of 3.8%.
As in previous years, we found weaknesses in the ex ante controls.
Almost two-thirds of the estimated error rate is due to errors related to non-compliance with procurement rules and lack of supporting documents to justify expenditure.
Our annual report on the EDFs is published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Our Activities 14 Special Annual Reports on the Financial Year 2014 In total, around €4 billion was allocated to all EU agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings in 2014.
EU Agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings carry out specific tasks on behalf of the EU and are based in different EU Member States.
They operate in many areas, such as security, health, research, finance, migration and transport, and each has its own mandate, board of directors, director, staff and budget.
In 2015, we prepared 52 special annual reports for the 2014 financial year.
They related to 41 decentralized agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European research Joint Undertakings, the European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in liquidation and the communication infrastructure Sisnet.
In addition, we published two summaries giving an overview of the results of our audits in this area (one summary on the EU agencies and other bodies and the other on the JUs).
These reports were presented to the President of the European Parliament and the Parliament's Budgetary Control Committee, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Budget Committee.
In 2014, the individual annual accounts of the 33 decentralized agencies and other EU bodies were independently audited by a private auditing firm for the first time.
In forming our audit opinions on these financial statements, we considered that audit work and the actions taken by the audited entities based on the auditor's findings.
The financial statements of the remaining agencies and JUs have been fully audited by us.
We found the accounts of all agencies, other bodies and JUs to be reliable in 2014.
Operations were legal and regular except for Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (electronic components and systems).
In general, the agencies have continued to improve their procedures by taking corrective action based on our comments from previous years.
Our special annual reports as well as the two summaries of the results of our audits on the agencies, other bodies and JUs for 2014 are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
52 special annual reports on EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings based across Europe Europol Headquarters, The Hague, Netherlands.
Our Operations 15 Special Reports Prepared in 2015 In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports throughout the year containing the results of the performance and compliance reviews we perform on specific budget areas or management issues of our choice.
When selecting and designing these examination tasks, we are careful to achieve maximum effect and thus use our resources in the best possible way.
Our performance audits often cover multiple financial years and the subject matter is complex so it can take more than a year to complete these audits.
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on: the overall EU objective of creating value and growth, and the EU's response to global challenges such as fiscal sustainability, the environment and climate change.
The 25 special reports produced in 2015 are briefly presented under the respective headings corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework.

Our activities 16 100 80 60 40 20 0 Competitiveness for growth and jobs €143 billion 13% Smart and inclusive growth The 'Smart and inclusive growth' heading accounts for most of the EU budget's spending.
This area includes the two sub-headings "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" and "Economic, social and territorial cohesion".
The sub-heading "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" includes funding for trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, business development, research and innovation, education and training, social policy, etc. Spending in this area planned for 2014-2020 accounts for 13% of the EU -Total budget for the programming period, ie EUR 143 billion.
A budget of 15.7 billion euros was made available for 2015. • Inland waterway transport in Europe: no significant improvements in modal share and navigability conditions since 2001 (No. 1/2015) - This special report examines whether the projects co-financed by the EU budget are effective in increasing the modal share of freight transport by inland waterways and contributed to improving navigability and whether EU inland navigation policies were coherent and based on relevant and comprehensive analysis.
Projects co-funded by the EU have not been effectively implemented. Inland shipping was not able to establish itself as an alternative to road freight transport, nor was navigability improved.
Although the Commission has made inland waterways a priority, Member States have paid little attention to inland waterways.
There is no coherent overall strategy among Member States linked by the main shipping corridors and river maintenance, political and environmental considerations are not sufficiently taken into account in EU strategies.
Member States should give priority to those inland waterway projects that bring the greatest and most immediate benefits, and the Commission should focus its resources on those projects where plans for debottlenecking are advanced.
EU inland waterway transport projects received €1.3 billion in funding from the TEN-T programme, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund over the period 2007-2013.
Our activities 17 • Are the needs of micro-entrepreneurs adequately addressed by EU financial support?
(8/2015) - This special report analyzes whether the needs of micro-entrepreneurs are being met by the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Progress Microfinance Facility.
The auditors found weaknesses in the programming and design of ESF financial support and insufficient and reliable monitoring of service delivery.
Neither the Commission nor the Member States had comparative information on the administrative costs of each Member State and funding mechanism.
These circumstances could affect the effectiveness of EU financial support for micro-entrepreneurs.
Member States should conduct needs assessments when designing financial instruments and preparing operational programs that include EU financial support for micro-entrepreneurs.
The Commission should make the use of ESF financial instruments by Member States conditional on robust risk management systems being in place.
Microfinance usually involves loans of less than EUR 25,000, often less than EUR 10,000.
The total demand for financing of this magnitude in the EU Member States is estimated at more than 12 billion euros.
Examples given in the report include the allocation of EUR 5 000 to expand a city kiosk and EUR 9 500 to support the establishment of a playground and a clothing store. • Improving the security of energy supply through the development of the internal energy market: more effort needed (16/2015) - This special report looks at whether the implementation of internal energy market policies and EU spending on the energy infrastructure have contributed effectively to the achievement of energy security benefits.
The audit found that, in general, energy infrastructure in Europe is not yet geared towards fully integrated markets and therefore does not currently provide effective security of energy supply.
Therefore, the Commission should identify energy infrastructures in the EU that are not actively used and work with Member States to remove the obstacles that prevent their use for the purposes of the internal energy market.
In addition, the Commission should consider new ways of making energy from one Member State available to customers in another.
The internal energy market should enable the free movement and trade of natural gas and electricity throughout the EU.
Under the EU budget, EUR 3.7 billion has been allocated to finance energy infrastructure from 2007 to 2013, and a further EUR 7.4 billion is expected between 2014 and 2020.
However, the report notes that the EU's target of completing the internal energy market by 2014 has not been met.
Our activities 18 Economic, social and territorial cohesion Smart and inclusive growth The sub-heading 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' covers regional policies aimed at helping the EU's least developed countries and regions to catch up with the rest . The aim is to strengthen the competitiveness of all regions and promote cooperation between them.
Cohesion spending planned for 2014-2020 represents 34% of the EU budget for the whole programming period, ie €367 billion.
100 80 60 40 20 0 367 billion euro 34% • Efforts to solve public procurement problems in EU cohesion spending should be stepped up (n°10/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission and the Member States take appropriate and effective action to address public procurement errors in the area of cohesion policy.
The audit showed that there are still widespread problems in procurement by public authorities across the EU.
Although the Commission and Member States have started to tackle the issue, much remains to be done.
Serious mistakes meant that there was no fair competition and contracts were not awarded to the best bidders.
Systematic analysis is very limited and there is a lack of sufficiently accurate, reliable and consistent data on the nature and extent of errors.
If the situation does not improve by the end of 2016, it is recommended to suspend payments for the 2014-2020 period to the Member States concerned.
In the period 2007-2013, €349 billion was earmarked for regional policy spending, to be disbursed through the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Social Fund.
A significant part of these funds is spent through public procurement.
Errors were found in around 40 % of the projects we audited from a public procurement perspective for our annual reports for the financial years 2009-2013.
Our activities 19 • EU funding of urban waste water treatment plants in the Danube river basin: Member States need further support to achieve EU waste water policy objectives (No. 2/2015) - This special report assesses the effectiveness of Member States in the Danube river basin with funds from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund to achieve EU waste water policy objectives.
The audit found that while the EU spending programs have been a significant contributor to the progress made in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, there have been delays in all countries in complying with the rules and taking up the available EU -Gave funds.
Although wastewater treatment in these countries was generally adequate, treatment of sewage sludge and stormwater overflow was sometimes inadequate.
A third of the systems were oversized and potentially unsustainable in the long term.
Countries were slow to take up available EU funds and risked losing EU funding or needing additional funds from national budgets.
The Commission should tighten reporting requirements and Member States should legislate to ensure immediate connection to public sewers.
The Commission and Member States should establish criteria for all uses of sewage sludge and ensure reliable monitoring of pollutants.
The Danube catchment area is Europe's largest catchment area.
The EU contribution to waste water treatment projects in the four audited Member States was • €7.9 billion in the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods. Water quality in the Danube River Basin: Progress in the implementation of the Water Framework Directive, but further action needed (No. 23/2015) - This special report examines whether the implementation of the Water Framework Directive by the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia has led to better surface water quality in the Danube catchment area.
The audit found that there have been few improvements since 2004.
The main reason for the limited progress was that Member States' plans were not ambitious enough.
Targeted measures for water bodies with an insufficient quality status were lacking.
In addition, deficiencies in the monitoring systems led to a lack of data, both on the type of pollution and the sources of pollution, which led to negative assessments of the status of water bodies.
In addition, Member States exempted a significant number of water bodies from important deadlines without sufficient justification.
In the period 2007-2013, Member States in the Danube River Basin received €6.35 billion from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund for waste water treatment.
During the same period, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development provided €6.39 billion to compensate farmers for agri-environmental measures.
Our activities 20 • EU Youth Guarantee: a start has been made, but implementation risks are foreseeable (3/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission has adequately supported Member States in setting up the Youth Guarantee and whether possible risks related to the implementation passed.
The audit identified three risks that could hamper the effective implementation of the Youth Guarantee: the adequacy of the overall budget, the definition of a "quality" job and the way the Commission monitors the Youth Guarantee and reports on the results.
The auditors concluded that the Commission provided timely and appropriate support to Member States in implementing the Youth Guarantee.
However, the Commission has not carried out an impact assessment indicating the expected costs and benefits, although this is a standard procedure.
While the Commission had asked Member States to provide cost estimates when submitting their Youth Guarantee implementation plans, some did not provide the required information. No Member State provided the estimated cost of the necessary structural reforms.
The Youth Guarantee was established in June 2013 in response to the worsening situation of unemployed young people, exacerbated by the economic and financial crisis.
In the period 2014-2020, the Youth Guarantee will be co-financed – through the European Social Fund and a dedicated youth employment initiative – with a total of €12.7 billion from the EU budget. • Commission support to youth action teams: reallocation of ESF funds successful but insufficient focus on results (n°17/2015) - This special report examines whether youth action teams in 2012 made any proposals on how to use ESF funds faster and more effective results can be achieved for unemployed young people and whether these proposals have contributed to the reallocation of ESF funds.
The auditors found that while the youth action teams set up by the Commission were successful in reallocating funds to projects aimed at supporting young people, their proposals were limited.
The Commission provided advisory support to Member States but was limited by the amount and quality of information available.
While the initiative resulted in a reprogramming and reallocation of European Social Fund appropriations, the Commission's assessment of the changes to the operational programs focused mainly on their budgetary implications.
If there are any discrepancies between the promises made and the goals that the Commission can actually achieve, then expectations should not be raised too high with regard to such initiatives.
In 2012, the Commission set up youth action teams as part of its Youth Opportunities initiative.
The teams were composed of experts from the eight Member States with the highest youth unemployment rates, as well as experts from the Commission.
The initiative related to funds of almost 10 billion euros from the European Social Fund that were still available in the affected Member States.
Our activities 21 Natural resources EUR 417 billion Sustainable growth: natural resources This heading covers the EU's common agricultural and fisheries policies, rural development and environmental policies.
Three-quarters of spending concerns direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets.
The expenditure planned for 2014-2020 represents almost 39% of the total EU budget for this programming period, ie 417 billion euros.
For 2015, a budget of 56 billion euros was made available.
100 80 60 40 20 0 39% • Technical assistance: what contribution has it made to agriculture and rural development?
(4/2015) - This special report examines the use of technical assistance funding for agriculture and rural development in the 2007-2013 programming period.
The audit focused on the regularity, effectiveness and soundness of funding at Commission and Member State level.
The audit showed that neither the European Commission nor the Member States could demonstrate how well the use of technical assistance in the fields of agriculture and rural development contributed to the sound use of the budget and the objectives of the Common Agricultural Policy.
Rural networks, which aim to promote cooperation, knowledge sharing and innovation in the agricultural sector, are very good recipients of technical assistance.
In most cases, however, the funds earmarked for capacity building have been used to support general government budgets.
For rural development, the Commission should clarify the scope and use of technical assistance in Member States and closely monitor its implementation.
For the period 2007-2013, Member States had planned to use €1.5 billion of the EU budget for technical assistance. This was capped at 4% of each national budget available for rural development.
For the period 2014-2020, this amount increased to around 1.9 billion euros.
Our activities 22 • Are financial instruments in rural development a successful and promising tool?
(No 5/2015) - This special report examines whether the financial instruments used under rural development policy (loan and guarantee funds) were well designed and managed in the 2007-2013 programming period.
The check revealed that the financial instruments have not been successful so far.
This is mainly due to the fact that the financial instruments were over-capitalized and failed to realize their potential in terms of the desired leverage and revolving effect.
There were no clear arguments for introducing financial instruments in the 2007-2013 programming period.
There was also no reliable quantifiable information to justify the nature of the financial instruments put in place, to determine the demand for financial instruments in the agricultural sector and to demonstrate that the amount of capital earmarked for a fund was adequate.
Increased incentives should be created for Member States to set up financial instruments in the field of rural development and to increase demand from farmers or other beneficiaries. Adequate leverage and revolving effect standards and targets should also be set for the period 2014-2020.
By the end of 2013, the EU and its Member States had invested around €700 million in the rural development guarantee and loan funds.
The Commission wants Member States to commit to at least doubling the use of these tools over the period 2014-2020.
Close-up of a performance audit: integrity and implementation of the EU ETS (No. 6/2015) The European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) differs somewhat from other policies and programs we audit in that it does not have significant funding received from the EU budget.
However, it has a very large impact on the implementation of policies in the EU and on the quality of life of citizens.
The EU ETS was introduced in 2005 and is often cited as a reference model for the development of climate protection strategies and emissions trading systems elsewhere in the world.
Therefore, an appropriate framework would be expected to ensure market regulation and supervision, legal certainty and systems for managing essential information.
The basic structures of the implementation systems should also be sufficiently solid.
At the end of 2013, our auditors examined the framework for protecting the integrity of the EU ETS and the systems for the actual implementation of the program at the Commission and in the Member States up to phase II (end 2012).
The audit was carried out because of the risks involved in creating a viable market to implement EU climate change policies and the difficulty of controlling an activity that is intangible ('How to measure hot air?').
Our auditors examined whether the EU ETS was adequately managed.
To do this, they not only carried out desk reviews and interviews with the officials involved in managing the EU ETS at the European Commission in Brussels, but also provided competent authorities in five Member States (Germany, France, Italy, Poland and the UK ) pay a visit.
In addition, documents were checked and experts consulted in two other countries (Greece and Spain).
The auditors obtained further evidence by examining national authorities' files on 150 installations selected in these seven Member States. In addition, data from the EU transaction log
Our activities 23 analyzed. The auditors could not inspect the installations on the spot as they do not receive any EU funding related to the Emissions Trading System and the Court does not have the necessary access rights to carry out the audit.
The evidence obtained by our auditors indicated a lack of oversight of the emissions market and insufficient cooperation between regulators.
For example, our auditors found that the legal definition of allowances should be clarified and that the procedures for opening ETS accounts in the Union Registry and for monitoring transactions were not adequate to ensure sufficient controls against abuse.
However, the initial situation was difficult: Member States could not monitor cross-border transactions effectively because they did not have direct access to the central database, and the Commission, in turn, could not monitor transactions because there was no legal basis for doing so.
In addition, our auditors found that the systems for monitoring and reporting emissions were not harmonized and there were weaknesses in control. In addition, the support from the Commission and the reporting by the Commission and the Member States were inadequate.
From their findings, the auditors concluded that the framework for protecting market integrity is not sufficiently robust and that there were clear weaknesses in implementation in the last phase, some of which require further measures at the current phase.
However, it is also clear from our report that this innovative system has been continuously improved.
At the time the report was published, the debate on possible reforms to the EU ETS, focusing on the effectiveness of the system and how to deal with excess allowances, was ongoing.
In our report, however, we point out that the fundamental issues of market integrity and implementation also need to be addressed so that the EU can be confident that this core instrument is adequate to meet expectations for emission reductions and low-carbon technologies.
We made some practical recommendations to the Commission and Member State authorities to improve market integrity and system implementation to make the EU ETS a more powerful tool to achieve climate targets by 2020 and beyond.
The Commission agreed with the report's recommendation that key remaining issues related to the regulation and supervision of the emissions market should be addressed in order to improve market integrity where appropriate. She also assured that for phase III (2013-2020) numerous improvements have already been made, taking our comments into account in particular.
The report generated a lot of media interest and was presented by EU-accredited journalists at a press conference in Brussels.
In the EU and globally, the press reported that the EU ETS needed more oversight to improve the carbon market. In addition, the system must be better protected against market abuse, including the still great risk of VAT fraud.
As is usual with all special reports, the Member responsible for the report - in this case Kevin Cardiff - presented the report to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and, moreover, to the Environment Committees of the Parliament and the Council to share with them the Court's findings, which served as a basis can be used for future decisions on relevant rules and regulations.
Parliament and Council welcomed our comments and recommendations and will take future proposals into account when it comes to improving the integrity and implementation of the system.
Audit team (from left to right): Stefan Den Engelsen, Emese Fésűs, Kevin Cardiff and Colm Friel.
Our activities 24 • Are the fisheries partnership agreements well managed by the Commission?
(No 11/2015) - This special report examines whether the agreements are well managed.
The auditors assessed the negotiation and implementation of the agreements, the Commission's monitoring of catches and the selection and control of the actions financed.
The audit found that while the agreements were generally well managed, the quantities negotiated were often higher than the catches reported for previous periods.
This regularly leads to incomplete utilization.
Since the EU makes payments in full regardless of the de facto catch, the actual cost has often been higher than the negotiated price.
There was also a lack of reliable, consistent and complete data on the actual catches of the EU fleet.
The Commission should, when negotiating new schemes, take into account previous exploitation rates that tie payments more closely to actual catches and ensure that the new catch database is fully used by flag Member States and contains reliable catch data that can be monitored and kept up to date.
The agreements aim to ensure the sustainability of the fisheries concerned by only allowing EU vessels to catch the partner countries' surplus resources.
However, the auditors doubt that the so-called "surplus" can be reliably calculated due to the lack of reliable information. • The EU priority of promoting a knowledge-based economy in rural areas has been hampered by poor management of knowledge transfer and extension measures (12/2015) - This special report examines in particular whether there are management and control systems in place to ensure knowledge transfer and effective implementation of advisory measures in the field of rural development.
The audit found that running EU-funded training and counseling programs in rural areas is too expensive, often duplicating existing programs and favoring incumbent training providers.
The auditors found poor administrative practices in Member States and insufficient oversight by the European Commission.
Member States relied too much on the trainers' suggestions and considered any type of training as 'good' and eligible for public funding.
The lack of fair and transparent selection meant that long-established and established providers were repeatedly selected and received the bulk of the funding.
Member States should select training projects that respond to skill needs identified through a periodic analysis and avoid supplier-driven selection procedures.
The EU supports training and advisory projects in rural areas with funds from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
For the period 2007-2013, 1.3 billion euros have been made available for these projects.
Together with the co-financing from the Member States, public funding totaled 2.2 billion euros.
In the period 2014-2020, the corresponding amount could be more than 4 billion euros.
Our activities 25 • The cost-effectiveness of EU rural development support for non-productive agricultural investments (n°20/2015) - This special report specifically assesses whether non-productive agricultural investments (NPIs) are cost-effective and make a contribution contribute to the achievement of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development's objective of sustainable farming in the 2007-2013 programming period.
The auditors concluded that while NPI grants contributed to the achievement of the objectives, they did not do so in a cost-effective manner, with 75% of the projects visited having unreasonably high costs.
Many of these projects were funded entirely with public funds, despite having obvious profitable features. The auditors visited four Member States that together spent 80% of the total EU budget on NPIs: Portugal, Denmark, the United Kingdom (England) and Italy (Puglia).
Only five of the 28 projects audited proved to be cost-effective.
The report warns that cost-efficiency inefficiencies may not be limited to the sample, as the problems identified were due to weaknesses in Member States' management and control systems.
Non-productive investments are investments that do not generate significant returns or revenues, nor significantly add value to the beneficiary's holding, but have a positive impact on the environment. • EU support for infrastructure in rural areas: Funds could be used much more efficiently (25/2015) - This special report examines whether the European Commission and Member States are involved in funding roads, water supply systems, schools and other facilities through development programmes have achieved good value for money for rural areas.
The audit found that while some infrastructure projects have made a positive contribution to rural areas, Member States and the Commission have received insufficient value for money under shared management.
Much more could have been achieved with the resources available. The need for EU rural development funds has not always been clearly justified by Member States.
The risk of supporting projects that would have been carried out without EU funding has not been managed effectively.
According to the report, since 2012 the Commission has taken a more proactive and coordinated approach.
If properly implemented, this should lead to better financial management in the period 2014-2020.
Rural development programs provided €13 billion of EU funding for rural infrastructure between 2007 and 2013.
Our activities 26 100 80 60 40 20 0 Foreign policy 65 billion euros 6% Global Europe The Global Europe section covers the EU's external relations (the "External Policy"), including enlargement matters, as well as the development and humanitarian aid of the EU off.
For the 2014-2020 programming period, the EU has earmarked 6% of its total planned spending, ie €65 billion, for these objectives.
The budget for 2015 was 7.5 billion euros.
Additional funds are made available through the European Development Fund, which is not part of the EU budget and therefore not covered by the Multiannual Financial Framework. • EU Police Mission in Afghanistan: mixed results (7/2015) - This special report assesses whether the EU Police Mission (EUPOL) was well planned and coordinated, whether it received adequate operational support and appropriate guidance, whether she has contributed to progress in the Afghan National Police and whether her exit was prepared in an appropriate manner.
The audit concluded that EUPOL has partially achieved the objective of contributing to the development of a sustainable and effective Afghan-owned civilian police force.
In an environment marked by the lack of a trained, fully functioning Afghan police force, high illiteracy rates and widespread corruption within the Afghan police and judicial systems, EUPOL has managed to contribute to the reform of the Interior Ministry and the professionalization of the National Police.
However, given the continuing systemic weaknesses in the police and judicial sectors in Afghanistan, there is a risk that the results achieved by EUPOL and in the Afghan police sector in general will not last after the end of the mission at the end of 2016.
The total cost of EUPOL over the period May 2007 to December 2014 was almost €400 million, with security-related costs accounting for almost a third of this amount.
At the end of 2014, the EU had deployed a total of 32 Common Security and Defense Policy missions, of which 16 have been completed and wound up and 16 are still ongoing.
Our activities 27 • EU support to combating torture and the abolition of the death penalty (9/2015) - This special report assesses whether the prevention of torture, the rehabilitation of victims of torture and the abolition of the death penalty are within the scope of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights are effectively promoted.
The audit showed that although the projects funded by the EU have had an impact, the projects are often not targeted enough and have a limited scope of action, since the funds are distributed according to the scattering can principle.
While the allocation of funds has generally been adequate, the Commission has not sufficiently taken into account individual country human rights priorities.
Projects were often not well coordinated with other EU policies such as development aid and political dialogue.
They were generally carried out by committed and competent organisations.
The auditors' recommendations related to the targeting of financial resources, better coordination with other EU actions, selection and improvement of project proposals, performance measurement and sustainability of the beneficiary organisations.
The European Union acts through diplomatic channels and provides grants to non-governmental organizations through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.
In the period 2007-2013, around 180 grants totaling more than 100 million euros were awarded to projects to combat torture and abolish the death penalty. • EU support to timber producing countries under the FLEGT Action Plan (No. 13/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission has managed well the support provided under the EU's FLEGT Action Plan to combat the illegal logging is provided.
The auditors found that while the action plan is a welcome initiative, the overall results are meager.
Aid was not granted to timber producing countries on the basis of clear criteria and its impact was diluted due to the large number of countries competing for aid.
Progress in the countries concerned varied greatly.
The lack of progress is mainly due to a lack of adequate planning by the Commission and a lack of clear priorities in the allocation of funds to timber producing countries.
The auditors recommended that the Commission set clear goals and identify the means to achieve them.
Four member states have yet to fully implement the EU Timber Regulation, which was put in place to prevent the import of illegal timber into the EU market.
In the period 2003-2013, 35 countries received €300 million under the Action Plan.
Two of these countries, Indonesia and Ghana, made good progress towards a full licensing system for their timber.
In general, however, progress has been slow and many countries have struggled to overcome the barriers to good governance.
In the 12 years since the Commission launched the Action Plan, no partner country has managed to set up a fully recognized permitting system.
Our activities 28 • The ACP Investment Facility: does it add value?
(14/2015) - This special report assesses whether the Investment Facility has added value to the EU's development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries.
The audit found that the Investment Facility does indeed add value to EU development cooperation with ACP countries and fits well with EU policy objectives.
At the end of 2014, lines of credit represented 28% of the Facility's portfolio, compared to 14% at the end of 2010.
The increased proportion reflects the continued importance of the long-term funding offered by the Facility.
The facility also acted as a catalyst in a positive sense by mobilizing additional funds.
However, the auditors found that the contractual obligation to inform final beneficiaries about European Investment Bank (EIB)/Investment Facility financing is not always respected and that technical assistance is not always targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises.
They made recommendations to fix these issues.
Established in 2003, the ACP Investment Facility is funded by the European Development Fund and managed by the EIB.
Development projects worth EUR 5.7 billion have been approved under the facility over the past ten years.
The Facility provides medium to long-term financing with the aim of delivering sustainable economic, social and environmental benefits. • Promoting renewable energy in East Africa from the ACP-EU Energy Facility (No. 15/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission has successfully used the Energy Facility to improve poor people's access to renewable energy in East Africa.
The audit found that some notable achievements have been made, but that the facility still needs better monitoring.
While the Commission made a good selection from the proposed projects, it did not monitor the progress of the projects closely enough.
The project managers' reports were of variable quality and the Commission made no effort to enforce compliance with reporting requirements.
For projects known to be affected by serious problems, Commission officials undertook too few on-the-spot visits and monitoring verifications to complete the information provided by those responsible.
The report made recommendations for more rigorous selection, monitoring and improved sustainability of future projects.
A total of EUR 268 million had been approved by mid-2014, including EUR 106 million for projects in East Africa, which had by far the least access to electricity in Africa.
Our activities 29 • Analysis of the risks associated with a results-based approach to EU action in the field of development and cooperation (21/2015) - The special report has been prepared in response to the renewed interest that has recently been focused on the focus of the To shift EU policy on development and cooperation away from activities and towards results.
The auditors identified nine key risk areas: inconsistent outcome-related terminology or no logical chain between actions, outputs, outcomes and impacts; increased complexity due to the consideration of cross-cutting issues in EU programmes; the lack of harmonization of aid delivery instruments, results frameworks and accountability structures of development partners; weaknesses in evaluation and reporting of results; a lack of consolidated reports or an overview of the results achieved through EU assistance; a lack of sufficient, relevant, reliable and timely data; a focus on budget outcome as a target; Changes in the context of measures.
The audit found that these risk areas have been correctly identified by the Commission in a wide variety of documents.
However, further action is needed to realize the full potential of the Commission's initiatives and to improve the EU's development and cooperation performance.
Against this background, a number of recommendations were formulated which the Commission should take into account.
Our activities 30 100 80 60 40 20 0 Fiscal and economic governance The EU framework for economic governance aims to address problematic financial and economic trends, such as excessive government deficits or debt, that can dampen growth and threaten the sustainability of public finances .
Part of this framework is the establishment of the EU Banking Union.
Following the report on the European Banking Authority in 2014, this special report is the second we have published on the subject.
In 2008, Europe faced a financial crisis that escalated into a sovereign debt crisis.
The sovereign debt crisis was a consequence of various factors. These included weak banking supervision, inadequate fiscal policies and the difficulties in which large financial institutions had run into (and the consequent cost of bailing them out, which was borne by the general public).
The crisis hit the EU member states in two waves. It first hit the countries outside the euro area in 2008-2009 and later spread to the euro area itself.
Our auditors examined how the European Commission managed the financial assistance provided under the Balance of Payments Facility and the European Financial Stabilization Mechanism during the crisis, for which the Commission borrowed on the capital markets, using the EU budget as a guarantee.
The audit related to the financial assistance granted to Hungary, Latvia, Romania, Ireland and Portugal. Particular attention was paid to the role of the Commission in these programmes.
In addition, our auditors analyzed the Commission's cooperation with its partners – the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington.
They obtained audit evidence through in-depth document reviews and analysis, as well as interviews with officials from the Commission, national authorities, the ECB and the IMF.
The partners and the decisions taken at EU political level were not the subject of the audit.
The audit found that the European Commission was unprepared for the first requests for financial assistance during the 2008 financial crisis as warning signs were overlooked. This explains to a large extent the initially obvious weaknesses in their administrative processes.
The auditors identified four main problem areas in the Commission's crisis management: different approaches, limited quality control, insufficient monitoring and deficiencies in documentation.
They found several examples where countries in comparable situations were not treated equally. In some programmes, the overall conditions for assistance were less stringent and therefore easier to meet.
They also found that the Commission's teams had insufficiently reviewed key documents, the underlying calculations were not verified by anyone outside the team, the work of the experts was not closely monitored and the verification process was not adequately documented.
Our activities 31 However, despite the lack of experience, the auditors consider that the Commission has managed to carry out its new administrative tasks and to launch the financial assistance programs crucial to the reform process, which is a success given the time constraints.
The auditors also found that as the crisis progressed, the Commission increasingly built internal expertise and engaged with a wide range of stakeholders in the affected countries. Later reforms also introduced improved macroeconomic surveillance.
For example, the targets of the programs were met, the adjusted deficit targets were broadly met, structural deficits improved and Member States met most of the conditions of their programs, albeit with some delays.
In most cases, countries continued with the reforms mandated by the program conditions, and in four of the five countries the current account adjustment was faster than expected.
Our auditors indicated that a number of weaknesses remain and that the Commission needs to improve its procedures for managing financial assistance.
We have made a number of recommendations to the European Commission to ensure that financial assistance is managed more soundly in the future when Member States that are struggling ask for support.
The report received wide coverage, particularly in the European media, but also in the United States and Australia.
Like our other special reports, it will be presented to the European Parliament and Council by our reporter, Baudilio Tomé Muguruza.
Audit team (from left to right): Didier Lebrun, Ignacio García de Parada, Kristian Sniter, Josef Jindra, Giuseppe Diana, Baudilio Tomé Muguruza, Adrian Savin, Daniela Hristova, Zacharias Kolias, Marco Fians and Daniel Costa de Magalhães.
Our activities 32 • EU supervision of credit rating agencies is well established but not yet fully effective (22/2015) - This special report examines whether the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is in the successfully established the EU as supervisor of the rating agencies.
As a result of the financial crisis in 2008, the rating agencies and their influence on the financial markets have increasingly come to the fore.
At that time, rating agencies in Europe were hardly regulated.
The audit found that while ESMA has laid a good foundation, its rules and guidance are not complete and significant risks remain to be addressed.
The auditors found that ESMA has reduced the average length of the registration process, but the process remains complex.
Although rating methodologies should be rigorous, systematic, consistent and subject to validation, the main focus of ESMA's work is whether the methodologies are rigorous.
The current framework for credit assessments in the Eurosystem does not guarantee that all rating agencies registered with ESMA act on an equal footing. This creates a two-tier market structure that puts small rating agencies in an unfavorable position.
The auditors made some recommendations to ESMA in relation to the registration process, traceability of the risk identification process, supervisory processes and IT systems. • Technical assistance to Greece: Improved delivery needs a stronger focus on results (n°19/2015) - This special report examines whether the Task Force for Greece has fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance to Greece has effectively contributed to the reform process .
The task force was set up by the Commission in 2011 to support Greece's economic adjustment with numerous technical assistance measures.
The auditors examined whether the task force fulfilled its mandate and whether the technical assistance contributed effectively to the reform.
They obtained evidence from the Commission, service providers, Greek ministries and other stakeholders.
The audit found that technical assistance was provided to the Greek authorities in accordance with the mandate, but this did not always sufficiently advance the reforms.
Due to the urgency of the situation, the task force was set up in a very short time and without a full analysis of other options or a dedicated budget.
The task force did not have a single, comprehensive strategy document to deliver the technical assistance or set priorities.
The assistance provided was relevant and broadly in line with program requirements, and the task force developed a flexible and diversified delivery system. However, there were weaknesses at the project level.
Greek Parliament Building, Athens, Greece.
Our activities 33 Other 8.2% 100 80 60 40 20 0 VAT 12.8% TOR 13.3% GNI 65.7% Revenue The EU budget is mainly financed by revenue from three types of own resources.
These include own resources based on gross national income (GNI) and value added tax (VAT), as well as traditional own resources (TOR), in particular customs duties on products imported into the EU and sugar levies.
The EU also receives taxes levied on EU officials' salaries, contributions from third countries to certain EU programs and fines from companies that breach EU rules and regulations.
EU expenditure must be fully covered by revenue.
In 2015, revenue was 141.3 billion euros. • Tackling intra-community VAT fraud: further action needed (n°24/2015) - This special report examines whether the EU is effectively tackling intra-community VAT fraud.
Organized crime costs the European Union between €40 billion and €60 billion in VAT revenue every year.
Since there is no VAT on exporting goods and services from one EU country to another, criminals can fraudulently evade taxes in both countries.
This means that both the countries concerned and the EU are losing revenue.
Significant weaknesses were identified during the audit, which indicate that the current system is not effective enough.
The EU has a wide range of tools to combat intra-Community VAT fraud, but some of these tools need to be improved or applied more uniformly.
In most Member States visited there are no effective cross-checks between customs and tax data; Member States' tax authorities exchange VAT information, but there are problems with the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the data; there is a lack of cooperation and overlapping competences between administrative, judicial and law enforcement authorities.
Measures must be taken by the Member States, the European Parliament and the European Commission to improve the system.
Our activities 34 opinions in 2015 We also contribute to improving EU financial management with our opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications.
These opinions are issued at the request of the other EU institutions and are used by the legislative authorities - Parliament and Council - in their work.
We may also issue position papers and analyzes on other issues on our own initiative.
In 2015 we published eight opinions covering a number of important areas: • Opinion No. 1/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Financial Regulation Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union; • Opinion No. 2/2015 on a proposal for an amendment of the Financial Regulation of the CPVO; • Opinion No. 3/2015 on a proposal for the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Board; • Opinion No. 4/2015 on the Proposal for a Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) (see box for more details); • Opinion No. 5/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Regulation of the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market; • Opinion No. 6/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Board; • Opinion No. 7/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the traditional, VAT and GNI own resource regulation and measures to provide the necessary treasury resources; • Opinion No. 8/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Financial Regulation for the 11th European Development Fund.
In focus: statement on the EFSI In November 2014, as a reaction to the decline in investment since 2007, the Commission launched an "Investment Plan for Europe".
The investment plan is based on the intervention logic that there are high investment needs in Europe and numerous economically viable projects for which sources of financing are sought.
The challenge is to use savings and financial liquidity productively to support sustainable employment and growth in Europe.
The investment offensive should be implemented without burdening national budgets and new debt.
The Commission expects this investment plan to create between 1 million and 1.3 million new jobs and mobilize additional (mainly long-term) investment funds of at least €315 billion over the period 2015-2017 until it is fully implemented. High expectations are placed on the Commission's initiative.
In order to contribute to the success of this initiative, in our statement we drew attention to issues related to the governance and legal framework, accountability and external audit arrangements, and financial liabilities for public budgets.
We also pointed out that instruments where the EU works with the private sector need to ensure an appropriate level of transparency and accountability for public funds.
The performance of these instruments should also be measured by the extent to which the funded activities achieve the objectives pursued.
We drew attention to the fact that the arrangements between the Commission and the European Investment Bank are not clearly described in the proposal.
Our opinion has been taken into account by the legislators in Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 on the EFSI.
Our activities 35 Contributing to EU accountability through high-level events and conferences We hold conferences on issues where we have identified risks and where our audit expertise can contribute to EU accountability. In doing so, we raise awareness of the importance of sound financial management and control of EU finances.
In 2015, we organized the two conferences described below, in line with our strategic objective to work with our partners in the EU accountability process.
During the year we also hosted seminars at our premises with internal and external experts to share knowledge on the latest developments in EU policies and to inform the planning and conduct of our audits.
For example, a seminar was held in October which focused on the progress made in reforming the common agricultural policy. The seminar was also attended by representatives of the Commission's Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
ECA Conference on Energy Security in the EU On 5 May 2015 in Brussels, we held a conference on Energy Security in the EU to provide a neutral and independent platform for stakeholders from EU institutions, Member States, the energy industry and academia where they can discuss the challenges facing the EU in the field of energy security.
Our President Vítor Caldeira opened the conference and Maroš Šefčovič, one of the Vice-Presidents of the Commission, gave an introductory speech.
Our members Szabolcs Fazakas and Phil Wynn Owen From left to right: Szabolcs Fazakas, Maroš Šefčovič, Vítor Caldeira and Phil Wynn Owen. chaired the conference, which included panel discussions on two main themes: obstacles to the completion of the internal energy market and Ukraine's important contribution to Europe's energy supply as a major transit country.
We organized this conference because the EU faces a number of major challenges in this area, which are interrelated.
These include creating an internal energy market to improve the competitiveness of the European economy, combating climate change and increasing the security of energy supply.
In our audits, we are increasingly focusing on energy and climate issues.
We have already produced special reports on topics such as the internal energy market and security of energy supply, energy efficiency and renewable energies.
Further reports are also planned in this area, including on EU support for Ukraine and EU spending on climate protection measures, as well as a landscape analysis on energy and climate issues in the EU.
Our goal is to add value to EU energy policy. With this conference we have shown that we also want to support a democratic debate on these issues.
Our activities 36 Court conference on the future of development assistance On 20-21 October 2015, we held an international conference on European development assistance after the European Year for Development, the adoption of the new UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Luxembourg Presidency in Luxembourg on 20-21 October 2015 year 2015.
At the start of the two-day conference, chaired by our member Danièle Lamarque, our President Vítor Caldeira took the floor, followed by the Luxembourg Minister for Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Affairs, Romain Schneider, on behalf of the EU Presidency, by the Chair of the Development Committee of the European Parliament, Linda McAvan, the EU Commissioner for Development Neven Mimica and UN Under-Secretary-General Grete Faremo.
The conclusions of the conference were summarized by Marc Angel, Chairman of the Committee on Foreign and European Affairs and Defense of the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies.
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and works with many public and private partners, including international organisations, foundations, non-governmental organizations and states.
It is becoming increasingly important to ensure the effectiveness of aid, which can be achieved by paying close attention to the criteria for its allocation and evaluation.
In this context, the court plays an important role.
The new United Nations Sustainable Development Goals for 2015-2030 are more ambitious than the previous Millennium Development Goals and encourage them to “think and act differently”.
Participants agreed that development aid needs to be aligned with environmental, energy, migration and other policy areas and involve new stakeholders.
In addition, development agencies need to adapt to the increasing diversification of finance and financial instruments: innovative financial instruments contribute to greater leverage and closer proximity to market conditions, but at the same time make it more difficult to take financial decisions and determine the added value of aid.
The European Commission gave a presentation on what a results-based budget should look like, with a clearer definition of how EU funds are spent and what results are achieved.
The Court also participates in the joint interinstitutional working group set up for this purpose.
Our activities 37 Relations with stakeholders The European Parliament and the Council of the European Union The value of our contribution to EU accountability depends to a large extent on the use made of our work and products by our key partners in the law-making and accountability process.
These partners are the political bodies responsible for public oversight of the use of EU funds: the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and national parliaments.
In line with our strategy for the period 2013-2017, we have paid particular attention to improving our working relationship with Parliament and the Council.
The President and the Members of the Court maintain regular contacts with the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), which is our main partner.
In 2015, President Vítor Caldeira presented our annual work program and annual reports at two CONT meetings. He also presented the annual reports in two plenary sessions of Parliament and took part in the discharge debate.
At the initiative of Ville Itälä, our Member responsible for Institutional Relations, President Caldeira also presented our 2015 work program to the Conference of Committee Chairs and was informed of their priority areas in order to plan our 2016 work programme.
In October 2015, CONT paid a working visit to the Court, continuing the practice of annual bilateral meetings at the Court's premises in Luxembourg. In addition, our representatives took part in visits to Member States (Greece) and recipient countries (Serbia) organized by CONT.
In 2015, our members represented the Court at 29 CONT meetings to discuss our annual and special reports.
In addition, our members presented nine special reports to the relevant committees.
We also organized a joint meeting with Parliament's Agriculture and Environment Committees to discuss issues of common interest and began working with Parliament's Research Service to promote more efficient knowledge sharing between our Examination Chambers and the Service.
We also began to work more closely with the Council to develop and improve relations with the Council and its respective Presidencies.
In November, President Caldeira and Pierre Gramegna, Luxembourg Minister of Finance and Chair of the Ecofin Council, met during the Luxembourg Presidency to discuss the follow-up to our 2014 Annual Report as part of the 2014 discharge process.
We presented our work program for 2015 and 15 special reports to various working groups of the Council.
In addition, we presented the different chapters of the annual report to the Council's budget committee as a basis for the discharge procedure.

Our Activities 39 Cooperation with Supreme Audit Institutions The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs). This cooperation mainly takes place through • the Contact Committee of the SAIs of the EU Member States; • the network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • International organizations of public sector audit bodies, in particular the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its European regional group (EUROSAI).
Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court and the national audit bodies work together in a spirit of trust, while respecting their independence.
Cooperation with the SAIs of the EU Member States takes place actively within the framework of the Contact Committee. This includes an annual meeting and various working groups, networks and task forces addressing specific issues of common interest.
In 2015 the Contact Committee met in Riga.
During their meeting, the members of the Contact Committee discussed the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), preventing and fighting irregularities and fraud, and the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.
Questions about the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) were also discussed.
The Contact Committee adopted a statement on the accountability and auditing arrangements of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, addressed to national parliaments and governments and to the EU institutions and bodies concerned.
In addition, the Contact Committee agreed to the proposal to carry out parallel audits on the deployment of the SSM, as well as on the contribution of the Structural Funds to the Europe 2020 strategy and the underlying risks to the sustainability of public finances.
In November 2015, we hosted a kick-off meeting of the Structural Funds VII Working Group to set out a work plan for a new multilateral parallel audit to identify how EU funding in the areas of education and employment was making an effective contribution to the strategy achieve Europe 2020.
Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of Candidate and Potential Candidate Countries Cooperation between the Court and the SAIs of candidate and potential candidate countries takes place primarily through a network1, comparable to the Contact Committee.
In the course of 2015, we continued to support the network in conducting a parallel energy efficiency audit.
The last workshop on this project took place in May 2015 at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
The Court is involved in the preparation of new projects, due to start in 2016, which focus on performance and financial audits.
In May 2015, ECA representatives attended an event celebrating the 90th anniversary of the founding of the SAI of Albania.
On this occasion, President Caldeira and the President of the Republic of Albania Bujar Nishani met.
Eight auditors from the SAI's network participated in our 2015 internship program.
