Since November 2013, Kosovo* has participated in the network as an observer. * This designation is without prejudice to positions on status and is in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1244/99 and the International Court of Justice Opinion on Kosovo's Declaration of Independence.
Our activities 40 Multilateral (INTOSAI – EUROSAI) and bilateral cooperation In 2015, we continued our active involvement and participation in the activities of INTOSAI and EUROSAI, particularly in their respective working bodies.
In November, the Court was appointed Vice-Chair of INTOSAI's Professional Standards Committee, effective from the International Congress of Supreme Audit Institutions (INCOSAI) in late 2016.
We also accepted the request of the SAI of Ukraine, which chairs the Audit of Disaster Relief Working Group, to host the first meeting of this working group.
The Court is also an active member of the EUROSAI Audit and Ethics Task Force, which seeks to promote ethics and integrity in SAIs and public institutions.
The main objective of the task force is to create a framework for promoting ethical behavior and to strengthen it by providing SAIs with appropriate practical guides and tools to support their day-to-day audit work.
We took part in the 5th EUROSAI-ARABOSAI joint conference, which covered the oversight of government bailout plans, and the 2nd Young EUROSAI conference, which gave young auditors the opportunity to discuss questions on topical issues .
We also attended the SAI's Global World Leadership Forum, which focused on the role of public sector auditors in 2030.
The Court has good bilateral relations with other SAIs.
For example, in 2015 our delegation took part in an international seminar organized by the SAI of Poland for auditors from Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in Warsaw.
The delegation members shared their experiences of advancement and capacity building in preparation for EU accession with the SAIs of the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and the Slovak Republic and provided training on our compliance and performance auditing methods.
Cooperation with SAIs in international peer reviews Peer reviews (expert opinions) are a common method of supporting good practice and promoting quality assurance.
The INTOSAI Peer Reviews Subcommittee is responsible for keeping the peer review guide ISSAI 5600 (ISSAI stands for International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions) up to date.
In 2015, we were instrumental in the revision of this guide, which will be presented to the 2016 INCOSAI Congress for adoption.
In addition, we took a leading role in the international peer reviews of the SAIs of Latvia, Spain and Switzerland.
The expert review of the SAI of Latvia was very comprehensive, covering accounting, compliance and performance audit methods and procedures, and the efficiency of support functions.
The expert review of the SAI of Spain, led by the SAI of Portugal, also covered many aspects of the functioning of that body.
We were the sole assessor in the expert assessment of the SAI of Switzerland.
The review assessed the appropriateness of this SAI's strategy, as well as its planning and quality control processes.
Our management 41 The Court's College The Court's College consists of one member from each Member State.
Members are appointed by the Council, after consultation of the European Parliament, on the basis of proposals from each Member State for a six-year term.
In accordance with the Treaty, the members carry out their activities with full independence and in the general interest of the European Union.
The President is elected by the members from among themselves for a period of three years.
The terms of office of the President and members are renewable.
Most members are assigned to one of the five chambers. The chambers adopt audit reports, opinions and position papers and make decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member is responsible for their own tasks, primarily in the field of auditing.
The member coordinates the respective audit teams with the support of his/her cabinet.
It then takes on the task of presenting the reports, opinions or position papers for approval by the Chamber and/or the entire Court College and then in Parliament, the Council and other relevant addressees, including the media.
In selected cases and at the initiative of the members, a report can also be presented to the authorities of the Member States concerned.
One of the members - Ville Itälä - is responsible for institutional relations.
The Council of the European Union appointed Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) as a Member of the ECA in 2015, on a proposal from the Member State and after consulting the European Parliament.
The mandate runs from 1 September 2015 to 28 February 2018, ie for the remainder of the term of office of the previous Danish member, Henrik Otbo, who died suddenly in February 2015.
The Court's College as at 31 December 2015.

Our management 43 Our strategy for 2013-2017: continuous progress Our five-year strategy aims to maximize the value of our contribution to EU public accountability.
Our key priorities to achieve this goal are shown in the figure below: Many of the initiatives launched under the strategy have already been implemented.
We have increased the range of outputs, deepened and broadened our relationships with our stakeholders, accelerated our review processes and improved the way we measure our own performance.
In 2015, the Court decided to reform its organizational structure.
In this way, we will take account of the European Parliament's recommendations on the Court's future role, as well as the results of the international peer review process carried out on our performance audits in 2014.

Our management 45 Reacting flexibly in a rapidly changing environment We have developed a new work planning process that allows us to plan our work based on farm-wide priorities and a comprehensive risk assessment.
We now systematically consider the viewpoints of our audience when planning our work to ensure that our reports are as relevant as possible.
With the support of our Member responsible for Institutional Relations, our President and Members work with EU stakeholders, which include the committees of the European Parliament.
Flexible allocation of resources to audit priority tasks We have organized our staff into flexible teams around specific tasks rather than units to facilitate the allocation of priority tasks.
This means that we can now “put the right person in the right job” and thereby fully utilize their skills and potential.
The reform also led to a more streamlined administration of the Court: Heads of Units became Senior Managers, sharing managerial responsibilities under the direction of the relevant Director, and contributing their expertise in the areas of quality and oversight.
We are also strengthening our expertise in audit areas and introducing knowledge transfer tools to further improve our knowledge management processes.
Timely Delivery of Products We have streamlined our review procedures and simplified our task management to enable us to deliver products in a timely manner.
In recent years we have steadily reduced the average time it takes to produce our special reports, and the reform will allow for a further reduction.
This is particularly important in the context of the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation.
Better communication about our role and our work We have revised our annual report to refer to the headings of the multiannual financial framework, making it easier to use and more reader-friendly.
In the Annual Report, we now report on the top spending areas as well as performance on a multi-year basis.
We have also strengthened the communication and stakeholder relations functions and hired a spokesperson.
Our management 46 Measuring performance Since 2008, we have used Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management of progress towards our goals, to support the decision-making process and to provide our stakeholders with information about performance.
They reflect our priorities and provide insight into our performance and accountability as a professional auditing body.
The indicators are used to measure core parameters for the quality and impact of our work, with special consideration of the point of view of important addressees as well as the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources.
The ZLI have been updated for the period covered by the 2013-2017 strategy.
Quality and impact of our work We assess the quality and impact of our reports through user judgments and peer reviews.
We also measure our presence in the media.
Assessed by stakeholders We asked our key stakeholders – the Budgetary Control and Budgetary Control Committees of the European Parliament, the Budget Committee of the Council, the main auditees at the Commission and the EU Agencies, and the Presidents of the EU SAIs – to assess the relevance and impact of our 2015 published reports using a five-point scale from "very low" to "very high".
Responses show that 90% of our key stakeholders rate the value of our reports as relevant to their work (up from 94% in 2014). 92% believe our work is having an impact (91% in 2014).

Our management 47 Expert reviews Each year, independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of our reports to assess quality. In 2015, the reviewers assessed four special reports and the annual reports for the financial year 2014.
They rated the quality of various aspects of the reports using a four-point scale from “seriously impaired” (1) to “high” (4).
Expert ratings in 2015 were higher than at any time in the last four years, with an overall average of 3.3 across both types of reports.
Follow-up to recommendations The main way we help improve EU financial management is by making recommendations in our reports to the Commission and other auditees.
Some recommendations can be implemented quickly, while others require more time due to their complexity.
We regularly check to what extent our recommendations have been implemented by the audited bodies.
By the end of 2015, 73% of over 600 recommendations that we formulated in 2012-2015 had been implemented.
This represents an increase on the 69% implementation rate recorded in 2014 for the recommendations made in 2011-2014.

It concerns the strategic objective of raising awareness of the Court, its products and its audit findings and conclusions.
In 2015 we identified around 3 400 online articles related to our special reports, annual reports and the Court in general.
54% of these related to our audit reports; the remaining articles referred to the court and its work in general.
In 2015, our annual reports received almost twice as much media coverage as in 2014.
On the other hand, media coverage of our special reports has decreased compared to 2014, largely due to interest in one particular report from that year (EU-funded airport infrastructure (n°21/2014), on which over 800 articles have been published).
Efficiency and Effectiveness of Resource Use We evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of our resource use based on our ability to execute our work program, conduct audits in a timely manner and ensure the professional competence of our employees.
Implementation of the work program We plan our audit and other tasks against the annual work program and monitor progress throughout the year.
In 2015, we implemented 88% of our work program.
Whilst the work on the annual reports and special annual reports was on track, on special reports this was 69% true compared to our very ambitious plan.
The completion of the remainder of the special reports, which has been delayed due to outstanding audit evidence or unexpected complexity, has been pushed over to early 2016.
These special reports mainly concern new or innovative tests, which by their very nature may take longer to complete.
The Court's reform project, assessed under the heading 'Other tasks', progressed as planned.

Our management 49 Preparation of the special reports For our special reports to be effective, they must be submitted in a timely manner.
In recent years we have managed to shorten the time required for exams. This was largely based on initiatives stemming from the strategy for 2013-2017.
In 2015, we prepared our 25 special reports within an average period of 17 months (19 months in 2014), i.e. in less than 18 months for the first time.
We will continue our efforts to reduce the time it takes to produce our special reports, in particular in response to the new principle introduced in the revised Financial Regulation.
Professional Development In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we aim to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional development (excluding language courses).
The target for the professional development of auditors was again exceeded, demonstrating the great importance we place on staff development.
If the language courses are taken into account in 2015, one examiner had an average of 9.4 training days.

Support for the 50 audit activities Human resources Staff allocation In 2015 we continued the five-year (2013-2017) reduction in staff of 1% per year, as set out in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Budgetary Discipline and Sound Financial Management of December 2013.
As a result, the staffing level was reduced from 882 officials and temporary agents to 872 in 2015 (excluding members, contract agents, seconded national experts and trainees).
The audit staff included 562 staff, including 113 staff in Members' private offices.
Recruitment The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds and the quality of their work and commitment is reflected in the Court's output.
Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and employment conditions of the EU institutions. The staff consists of civil servants as well as temporary employees.
In 2015 we recruited 63 staff: 30 officials, 17 temporary agents, 11 contract agents, four seconded national experts and one adviser.
We also provided internships for 74 university graduates for periods of three to five months.
On 31 December 2015, the Court had only 15 vacant posts (1.7% of the total number of posts).

Supporting audit activities 51 Gender balance Like the other EU institutions, we have an equal opportunities policy in human resources management and recruitment.
For several years we have been able to maintain a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees.
The chart shows the proportion of men and women by level of responsibility as of December 31, 2015. These proportions have hardly changed in recent years.
With our action plan in the area of equal opportunities, a balanced proportion of men and women should be achieved at all levels.
After the latest waves of recruitment, 50% of staff in grades AD 5 to AD 8 are women (an increase from 48% in 2014).
Due to the renewal in the upper and middle management levels and the growing proportion of women in the function group AD, it is to be expected that the proportion of women in management positions will increase in the future.

Support for audit activities 53 Age profile Age group 20-24 25-29 30-34 35-39 40-44 45-49 50-54 55-59 60-64 65+ 0% 0.3% 3.0% 8.0% 13 .7% 9.6% 20.3% 20.9% 19.6% 20% 25% 4.1% 0.6% 5% 10% 15% The age profile of the personnel in active service as of December 31, 2015 indicates that 52% of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
Thirty-two of the 69 directors and senior managers (46%) are aged 55 or over.
As a result, over the next five to ten years, as these employees retire, there will be renewal in senior management positions.
Support services Continuing professional development The auditing profession requires ongoing training to keep up with developments in the profession and to acquire new skills.
In 2015, our employees completed an average of 7.3 days of professional development.
The share of language courses in the total number of training days continues to decline.
Language courses accounted for 35% of the total number of training days in 2015 (compared to 43% in 2014).
Our main activities related to professional development concern the modernization of our professional development programs and closer cooperation with learning opportunities inside and outside the EU institutions and bodies.
We created a collaboration with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France) to offer a postgraduate course in Audit of public organizations and policies and a Masters course in Management of public organizations (Management public organizations) to be able to offer.
Cooperation has continued with the European Commission, which offers language courses for our staff, and with the European Administrative Academy, which has supported us in organizing the soft skills training and the ECA training day.
We have also further expanded our range of courses with individually tailored e-learning courses and training courses in the form of integrated learning (blended learning).
In addition, we continued our successful series of presentations given by internal and external experts on audit developments and other issues affecting our auditors' work.
Finally, we introduced a framework for 'Performance Recognition Awards', designed to recognize the performance of non-managerial staff with dedicated off-court training.
Audit support 54 Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables us to fulfill our mission and achieve our communication goals.
In 2015, the total translation volume was higher than ever: almost 200,000 pages, an increase of almost 3% compared to 2014.
Around 99% of translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, our translators provided language support on 26 audit visits across the EU and interpretation at internal events and meetings.
They also provided assistance in the drafting of preliminary observations and special reports, thereby increasing their involvement in the Court's core audit processes.
In 2015, as a result of the translation workflow review and the Court's reform, the Translation Directorate streamlined its structures by introducing pools of assistants.
A major management project, GroupShare, will bring significant improvements by further streamlining the work of the assistant pools to make room for efficiencies and automation. It also unifies the procedures of all language teams.
Information Technology In 2015, the Information Technologies Directorate focused its efforts on adapting our administrative information systems to support a successful implementation of the Court's reform, as well as preparing developments in the field of knowledge management to support the Court's new organizational structure.
In addition, all functions of the full version of the audit documentation system Assyst2 for work related to the declaration of assurance, performance audits and related reports have been introduced. This completes this major project.
Our new Audit Management System (AMS) went live: more than 300 plans were created in the system and 180 audit tasks were defined and monitored with the tool.
Building on the technical bases for mobility introduced in recent years (deployment of the WiFi network in all premises of the Court, equipment of all staff with laptops), the Directorate is currently focusing on global mobility, ie access to all content any place, any time and on any device.
The project to develop a solution that ensures employees can access our information on any device will help keep the farm running and increase efficiency and effectiveness.
Business operations were maintained during the development and provision of IT solutions, so critical systems were 99.82% available.
Supporting audit activities 55 Management and infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfill its mission and achieve its strategic objectives.
The Directorate also ensures that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are in place to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2015, the management continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economical.
Due to the extraordinary situation after the terrorist attacks in Paris in November and the subsequent crisis situation in Belgium, we tightened our security measures and acquired the necessary security equipment as part of public procurement procedures.
Information on public procurement is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Buildings The Court currently owns three buildings ('K1', 'K2' and 'K3') and rents small spaces for its IT center for data recovery and a meeting room.
He also rents three offices in Brussels and one office in Strasbourg from the European Parliament.
In order to ensure the cost-effectiveness of our building policy, we consider three factors: purchase or rental, follow-up costs and inter-institutional cooperation.
In developing and implementing our facilities policy, as in everything we do, we strive to maintain and meet the highest standards of transparency and accountability.
Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) The Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) is a management tool developed by the European Commission for companies and other organizations to assess, report and improve their environmental performance.
We started in 2014 to develop an environmental management system2 in line with the principles of the European EMAS standard provided for in the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and Council3.
Our goal is EMAS certification by the end of 2016.
In 2015, the EMAS project achieved the planned progress.
2 The EMAS project at the farm started in July 2013.
3 Regulation (EC) No. 1221/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 25, 2009 on the voluntary participation of organizations in a Community system for environmental management and auditing (EMAS).
Support for audit activities 56 Financial information The Court is funded from the general budget of the European Union.
Our budget accounts for around 0.087% of total EU expenditure and 1.51% of total administrative expenditure.
In 2015, the implementation rate of the total available budget was 98.68%.

Supporting the audit activities 58 Audit and accountability Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2015, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General for the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2013, meaning that our 2013 accounts were finally approved.
We have carefully analyzed the issues raised during the discharge process regarding our audit and management responsibilities and have also taken appropriate action as part of our reform.
We reported on our follow-up to the European Parliament.
Internal and external audit The Court's internal audit The internal audit service advises the Court on risk control issues, providing opinions on the quality of the management and internal control systems and recommendations for improving the management of our operations and promoting sound financial management.
The service also supports the work of the external auditor, whose mandate is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
Finally, the Internal Audit service provides information on significant risks and corporate governance issues.
The work of the Internal Audit Service is overseen by an Internal Audit Committee composed of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee regularly reviews the progress of the various tasks set out in the Internal Audit Service's work programme.
The committee also ensures the independence of the internal audit service.
In 2015, the Internal Audit Service prepared specific reports on strategic issues such as changes in our annual report, mid-term review of the implementation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017, and follow-up on the implementation of the peer review and European Parliament recommendations.
Taking into account the 2014 recommendations of the Internal Audit Service to strengthen the internal control cycle, we updated our IT security system and formalized the existing risk management framework and policies.
The Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of the new guidelines and ensured that their recommendations were taken into account.
We report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit.
The Court's external audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach of applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the entities it audits.
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à rl - on our financial statements for the financial year 2014 was published on September 15, 2015.
Supporting the audit activities 59 Opinions of the Independent Auditor - Financial Year 2014 Concerning the financial statements: "In our opinion the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2014, and of its results of operations and cash flows for the year ended year-ending in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application for the Financial Regulation." Regarding the use of resources and the control procedures: "In the work steps described in this report, we have not come across any facts from which we would have to conclude that in all material respects and taking into account the right nth assessment criteria • the funds allocated to the Court have not been used for the intended purposes and • the control procedures put in place do not offer the necessary guarantee that the financial transactions have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."
Declaration of the 60 Authorizing Officer by Delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, in his capacity as Authorizing Officer by Delegation, hereby declare • that the information contained in this report is correct and accurate, and • certifies with reasonable assurance that — the appropriations earmarked for the activities described in this report have been provided, used for their intended purposes and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, — the control procedures put in place provide the necessary assurances as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and that allegations of fraud or suspected fraud are dealt with appropriately , — the costs and benefits of the controls are reasonable.
This security is based on the undersigned's assessment and the information available to him, e.g. B. the reports and declarations of the authorizing officers by sub-delegation, the reports of the internal auditor and the opinions of the independent auditor for previous financial years.

European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the EU's external auditor and one of the seven institutions of the Union.
The Court's College has 28 members, one from each EU Member State.
The Court employs around 900 staff of all EU nationalities, made up of auditors and administrative staff.
It was established in 1977 and is based in Luxembourg.
The Court's tasks The Court checks that the EU keeps its accounts properly, ensures that its financial rules are correctly followed and that EU policies and programs deliver value for money.
Through our audit work, the Court helps improve the EU's financial management and promotes accountability and transparency.
It warns of risks, provides assurance, highlights weaknesses and successes, and provides guidance to EU policymakers and legislators.
The Court submits its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national parliaments and the general public.
The European Court of Auditors buildings on the Kirchberg plateau in Luxembourg, 2017

Foreword by the President 04 Dear readers!
The European Court of Auditors started its work in 1977 - 40 years later we can look back on many successful contributions we have made to public accountability and EU financial management.
An official ceremony was held in October 2017 to mark the court's anniversary, at which Their Royal Highnesses the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, the President of the Republic of Estonia Kersti Kaljulaid, the President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani and the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker were present.
Your participation in the event is a great testament to the importance of the Court as the 'financial conscience' of the European Union.
However, as the year progressed, we also looked ahead.
So we discussed and agreed a strategy for the remaining three years of the current Multiannual Financial Framework until the end of 2020.
Our citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that they do not lose confidence in the EU and its institutions.
People need to be able to see that the EU is acting with integrity, upholding the rule of law, using public funds wisely, pursuing clear political goals and delivering the results it promised.
As the Union's external auditor, we are well placed to review and report on these aspects.
Throughout the year we have issued special reports on a wide range of EU policies and programmes, as well as analysis-based publications such as landscape analyzes and quick analyses.
We have also prepared several opinions on legislative proposals and, as every year, we have produced our annual reports on the EU general budget and the European Development Funds, as well as on the EU agencies and many other Union bodies.
This activity report provides a comprehensive overview of our activities in 2017 and contains key information about the Court, its budget and its staff.
Klaus Heiner Lehne President
2017 at a glance 05 Our activities Our management • 28 special reports examining the effectiveness and • added value of EU policies and programs in areas such as youth unemployment, environment, migration and banking union; • a landscape analysis on EU action in the fields of energy and climate change and a rapid analysis on staff reductions in the EU institutions; • • five opinions on new or amended EU legislation with significant implications for financial management, including one opinion on the Financial Regulation for the • EU budget and one opinion on the funding of European political parties; • Annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget as well as on the activities of the European Development Funds with the associated synopsis report "2016 - Summary of the EU audit"; • • 55 specific annual reports covering the annual accounts of each EU agency, body and Joint Undertaking located in different Member States, including two summary reports; • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our institutional stakeholders and peers, such as the meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States and conferences on youth unemployment and energy, climate change and impact assessment.
We welcomed two new members: Juhan Parts (Estonia) on January 1, 2017 and Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary) on September 1, 2017. • We issued a new multi-year strategy to guide our work and management in 2018 -2020 serves. We also revised our work planning to ensure a more strategic, coherent and Court-wide approach to planning our audit priorities. We also reviewed our risk management policy and strengthened our financial processes. • We continued the downsizing agreed among the EU institutions, while implementing policies of equal opportunities in recruitment and human resource management.
What we do 06 Audits We carry out different types of audits in the different budget areas of the EU: • Performance audits - looking at the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes.
These best use reviews focus on specific management or budget issues, which we select based on criteria such as public interest, room for improvement, risk of underperformance or irregularities; • Financial and compliance audits - looking at the reliability of the financial statements and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions (particularly in relation to the Statement of Assurance) as well as assessments of whether the systems or transactions in specific budget areas comply with the relevant rules and regulations to match.
Based on the evidence collected during our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved and on the state of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
This information helps us make recommendations that are useful and cost-effective.
Audit visits in 2017 Most of the audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors also carried out numerous audit visits to the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and EU delegations, to national, regional and local authorities in the Member States and to international organizations such as the United Nations, throughout 2017 involved in the allocation of EU funds.
We also carry out on-site inspections of recipients of EU funds inside and outside the European Union.
Through these controls, we obtain direct audit evidence from the entities involved in the management of EU policies and programs and the collection and payment of EU funds, as well as from the respective beneficiaries.
Audits are our core activity The frequency and intensity of our audit work in each Member State and recipient country depends on the type of audits we conduct.
In 2017, our auditors spent 3 670 days on-site in Member States and outside the EU (2016: 4 246 days).
Within the EU, our on-the-spot checks are often carried out in liaison with the Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) of the Member States visited.
3 670 days of on-site inspections in Member States and outside the EU in 2017 Our auditors also spent 2 300 days (2016: 2 510 days) at the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg and at decentralized agencies and bodies across the EU EU, international organizations such as the United Nations or the OECD as well as auditing companies.
We are making increasing use of video conferencing and other information technologies (such as the secure exchange of data and documents) to obtain and validate audit evidence.

Our activities 08 Fraud detection We work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to fight fraud against the EU budget.
These cases are then followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and cooperates with Member State authorities where necessary.
In 2017, we referred 13 suspected fraud cases identified during our audits to OLAF. Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally come across cases in our audit work where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activity.
In 2017, we forwarded 13 such cases (2016: 11) suspected of fraud to OLAF. The suspicion of fraud arose as part of our audit work for the statements of assurance for the financial years 2016 and 2017 as well as other audit tasks.
Publications Our publications: special reports, annual reports, opinions and analysis-based publications Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain, as they are used to hold those responsible for the EU's budgetary management to account, particularly during the annual discharge process to pull.
In areas of shared management, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role, as in the case of spending on agricultural and cohesion measures. Around 80% of the EU budget is implemented in this way.
Our range of publications includes • Special reports presenting the results of selected audits on specific policy or spending areas, or on budgetary or managerial issues; • Annual reports covering mainly the results of financial and compliance audits of the European Union budget and the European Development Funds, but also covering budgetary and performance aspects; • Separately published specific annual reports on the EU Agencies, Decentralized Bodies and Joint Undertakings; • Opinions on new or amended legal acts with significant implications for financial management, prepared either at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative;
What we do 09 • Analysis-based publications: • Landscape analyzes are descriptive and analytical documents on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, in which we present our experience and accumulated knowledge on the chosen topic, often from a cross-cutting perspective; • Issue papers are similar to landscape reviews in that they are also descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management, but their topics are more limited; • in the rapid case reviews, facts are compiled and presented that relate to very clearly defined specific issues or problems.
All publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
In addition, all special reports, opinions and analysis-based publications from 2017 are listed at the end of this report.

Our activities 10 annual reports Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016 In our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016, we examined how EU funds had been spent in the financial year under review and identified in which areas the risk of EU funds being misused was greatest.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all major areas of the EU budget - based on the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 - and provided information on budgetary and financial management as well as performance-related information.
We also analyzed why errors had occurred and made recommendations for possible improvements.
Audit of around 1 000 payments to beneficiaries made from the EU budget in 2016 Our auditors examined around 1 000 payments to beneficiaries made across the different spending areas of the EU budget.
This means that we analyzed around 1 000 different cases where EU funds had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research organisations, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.
The discharge procedure begins with the presentation of our annual report for the 2016 financial year The publication of our annual report marks the beginning of the discharge procedure carried out by the European Parliament for the implementation of the EU budget.
On 28 September we presented our annual report to the Budgetary Control Committee (CONT) of the European Parliament and subsequently also to the plenary of the European Parliament, as well as to the ECOFIN Council and the national parliaments of the Member States.
Our activities 11 EU annual accounts give a true and fair view; The proportion of irregular expenditure continued to decrease in 2016 Main conclusions ƒ The 2016 accounts have been prepared in accordance with international standards and, in all material respects, give a true and fair view of EU finances. ƒ Revenues in 2016 were free from material error. ƒ In recent years, the estimated level of error in payments made from the EU budget has continuously improved: 2016: 3.1%, 2015: 3.8% and 2014: 4.4%.
In 2016, a significant part of the expenditure audited – entitlement-based payments (as opposed to reimbursement-based payments) – was not affected by material error. ƒ The Commission's reporting on regularity is broadly consistent with our findings in most areas.
However, the Commission should simplify performance measurement, for example by reducing the number of objectives and indicators. ƒ Corrective actions by Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Without these measures, our estimated total error rate would have been 1.2 percentage points higher.
However, sufficient information was available to prevent or detect and correct a significant proportion of errors. ƒ The total amount of payments committed by the EU under future budgets was at an all-time high and is expected to continue to rise.

Our activities 13 Our institutional users also need information on EU spending results “This year's qualified opinion shows significant improvements in EU finances.
In the future, we will reconsider how we audit the EU budget: − We will pay more attention to the internal controls carried out at European Commission and Member State level, so that we can promote accountability even better and further improve EU financial management to enhance. − We will also focus more on performance aspects to ensure that EU citizens' funds are used in the best possible way.' The importance of focusing on the performance of EU spending and the results achieved was also emphasized by Joachim Zeller, Member of the European Parliament and rapporteur for the 2016 discharge: Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors, presenting the annual report at the plenary session of the European Parliament on 4 October 2017 in Strasbourg " Information such as error rates or, for example, information on whether Structural Funds have been used correctly is important, but we should also look at what has been achieved with these funds.” Joachim Zeller, Member of the European Parliament, rapporteur for the 2016 discharge
Our activities 14 Annual report on the European Development Funds The European Development Funds (EDFs) provide financial assistance to African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and overseas countries and territories.
Funded by the Member States, the EDFs are managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and, for some aid, by the European Investment Bank (EIB).
Around a third of the overall error rate in the EDFs is due to non-compliance with procurement rules.
Other important types of error include expenditure that is either not actually incurred or is ineligible.
Our annual report on the EDFs is published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Special annual reports The EU agencies and other bodies, as well as the European Joint Undertakings, are based in different EU Member States. They carry out specific tasks in areas of greatest concern to EU citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice, and research.
In 2017, we checked whether the agencies' accounts were reliable and whether the transactions underlying them were compliant.
In forming our opinions on the agencies' financial statements, we consider audit work performed by public accounting firms, where available.
We also examined the Sisnet communications infrastructure, the European Schools, the contingent liabilities of the Single Resolution Board and the liquidation of the Galileo Joint Undertaking.
We have been working to consolidate the results and expect to issue a single report to the agencies in 2018. i Key data Budget of the EDFs 2016 3.4 billion euro Audited amount 2.8 billion euro Accounting Reliable Revenue Non-errant Payments Significantly errored (estimated error rate of 3.3%) i Key data Audited by the Court 45 agencies and others EU bodies, 8 Joint Undertakings Total 2016 budget €5.2 billion Total 2016 staff Around 11 000 staff The Court publishes 55 specific annual reports, including two summary reports
Our activities 15 agencies (budget of 3.4 billion euros, 10 364 staff) Our audit shows that the annual accounts of all 41 agencies give a true and fair view.
The financial transactions underlying the accounts were legal and regular for all agencies except for the European Asylum Support Office, for which we gave a qualified opinion for non-compliance with public procurement principles.
Joint Undertakings (budget of €1.8 billion, 633 employees) The financial statements of all eight Joint Undertakings were reliable.
They presented the assets and financial position of the Joint Undertakings and the results of their operations and cash flows for 2016 in all material respects as a whole and appropriately.
In addition, the transactions underlying the accounts of seven JUs were in compliance with the relevant legal requirements, except for the ECSEL JU, for which we gave a qualified audit opinion as we could not obtain reasonable assurance on the reliability of its internal controls over FP7 grant payments .
All the specific annual reports, as well as the two summary reports, are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Special reports In 2017, we published 28 special reports.
In these reports, we examined in particular whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programs were being met, whether the results were being achieved in an effective and economical manner, and whether added value was being created with EU funds.
We also made recommendations for improvements in terms of financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or achieving the desired policy goals more cost-effectively.
In particular, the special reports examine the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes. Our special reports focused on issues reflecting issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, generating growth and promoting inclusion, challenges related to migration and global development, the internal market and banking union, and ensuring the accountability and efficiency of the European Union.
Here we will take a closer look at two of those 28 special reports: a special report on food waste, which examined whether EU policies were adequate to tackle this problem along the entire food supply chain, and a special report on the Greek financial crisis, in which it was examined how the EU reacted with the economic adjustment programs to the financial and debt crisis in one of its member states.

Our activities 17 Special report: Tackling food waste: an opportunity for the EU to improve resource efficiency in the food supply chain Food waste is a global problem Food waste is a global problem that has increasingly become the focus of public and political debate in recent years especially given the need to feed the growing world population.
According to current estimates, around a third of the food produced for human consumption worldwide is wasted or lost, resulting in high economic and environmental costs.
The EU auditors examined the role the EU can play in tackling food waste. In particular, the Court's auditors looked at the actions taken so far and how the various EU policy instruments are working to reduce food waste.
The focus was on preventing food waste and facilitating food donation, as these two aspects are given the highest priority in the fight against food waste.
Our auditors interviewed Commission staff responsible for the policy in question, carried out desk checks and audit visits to five Member States: Italy (Lazio), the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Finland.
They visited the ministries concerned and carried out on-site visits.
They also consulted relevant stakeholders in food production, retail, research and charities. "The EU can and should do more to tackle food waste effectively," say the EU auditors The auditors concluded that while food waste could be tackled through a range of EU policies, this potential is not being realised .
Action to date remains fragmented and incoherent, and there is a lack of coordination at Commission level.
Our report identified a number of untapped opportunities and potential improvements that would not require new legislation or additional public funding. The auditors also recommended better adjusting existing policies and setting a clear policy target of reducing food waste.
The report was presented to the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, as well as the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU and a number of national parliaments across the EU.
Both the European Parliament and the Council welcomed the report and endorsed the conclusions it contained.
The report also received significant media coverage, particularly social media.
Our activities 18 Special report: The Commission's role in the Greek financial crisis Greece needed support to ensure its financial stability The 2008 financial crisis was followed by an economic downturn and a debt crisis in Europe, exposing the vulnerabilities of the Greek economy.
In April 2010, Greece was no longer able to sustainably finance itself on the financial markets and therefore requested financial assistance from the euro area Member States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
Since then, Greece has participated in three economic adjustment programs administered by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the IMF – the so-called “troika”.
The European Stability Mechanism (ESM) was also involved in the third programme.
The support, totaling €368.6 billion, was subject to political conditionality agreed jointly by the Greek authorities and the lenders.
These programs aimed to bring about a stabilization of the economic situation in Greece by covering the financial needs of the Greek economy. This should prevent the crisis from spreading to the rest of the euro area.
In return, Greece undertook to implement far-reaching structural reforms.
The EU auditors examined whether the Commission had managed the economic adjustment programs adequately. This audit is part of a series of performance audits we have carried out in recent years of the measures and reforms introduced in response to the 2008 financial crisis.
Our auditors assessed how the Commission had handled the first two programs for Greece and how the third program had been designed.
They reviewed EU financial assistance program documents, analyzed program conditions and interviewed Commission officials, staff from national authorities (such as line ministries), the Bank of Greece, business associations and business stakeholders, as well as staff from the IMF, ESM and the EU OECD. 'Economic adjustment programs for Greece: despite weaknesses, progress in reform process' say EU auditors Our auditors concluded that the economic adjustment programs for Greece had provided short-term financial stability and enabled progress in the reform process.
However, the programs in Greece resulted in only a limited recovery.
In addition, the auditors found that the Commission had no experience in managing such a process, that the terms of the programs were not sufficiently prioritized by importance nor embedded in a broader strategy for Greece, and that the macroeconomic assumptions of the programs were shaky .
This special report was presented to the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament and institutional stakeholders in Greece.
The report was the subject of extensive media coverage and received the widest media coverage of any special report we published in 2017.

Our activities 20 Court of Justice conference on youth employment - Tackling challenges and finding solutions 10 May 2017, European Parliament, Brussels This conference followed the publication of our special report on the Youth Guarantee which, like other reports, assessed the effectiveness of the EU policies in tackling the problem of youth unemployment in the EU Member States.
During the conference, Iliana Ivanova, the rapporteur, and the auditors discussed with high-level representatives from EU institutions, employment services and young people whether EU policies are delivering results and how best to proceed in the future.

The Court's conference provided a platform for stakeholders and key players in this area, from both the public and private sectors, to discuss the challenges ahead.
It was organized jointly by the Court and the European Parliamentary Research Service.

The conference was attended by representatives of Member States, EU institutions, Supreme Audit Institutions, NGOs and think tanks, as well as Members of the European Parliament (MEPs), academics and our auditors.

Our Activities 24 Working with Supreme Audit Institutions Contact Committee of EU Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions In 2017, we hosted and chaired the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) of the 28 EU Member States.
The main topic of discussion was the role of SAIs in restoring EU citizens' trust in national and supranational state institutions.
In addition, the Court participated or contributed to the activities of the working groups on the following topics: European Banking Union, Structural Funds, Europe 2020 Strategy, Fiscal Policy Audit, VAT, Public Sector Accounting Standards in EU Member States (EPSAS) and Prevention and Combating irregularities and fraud.
Network of SAIs of candidate and potential candidate countries We also support the SAIs of candidate and potential candidate countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Kosovo*, Montenegro, Serbia and Turkey). This support is primarily provided through a network comparable to the Contact Committee.
In 2017, nine auditors from SAIs in the network participated in our internship program.
We also actively contributed to several meetings and activities of this network. This included addressing issues such as combating fraud and corruption, as well as hosting workshops on financial and compliance audits.
We also participated in a parallel public procurement performance audit led by the SAI of Sweden.
The purpose of this meeting was to adopt a work program for 2018 and beyond. * This designation is without prejudice to positions on status and is in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1244/99 and the International Court of Justice Opinion on Kosovo's Declaration of Independence.

Our management 26 The College of ECA Members The tenure of ECA Members is six years; Reappointment is permitted.
The members carry out their activities in full independence for the general good of the EU.
When they take office, they take a corresponding oath before the Court of Justice of the European Union.
The College has 28 members, one from each Member State.
The individual members are appointed by the Council of the EU after consultation of the European Parliament according to the proposals of the respective national government.
In 2017, the Council appointed two new members: • Juhan Parts (Estonia), who took office on 1 January 2017; • Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary), who took office on 1 September 2017.
President The members elect a President from among themselves for a period of three years; Re-election is permitted.
The President's role is that of primus inter pares ("first among equals").
In addition to his other responsibilities, the President oversees the performance of the Court's work and represents it externally.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) was elected President.
Audit Chambers and Committees Members are assigned to one of the Court's five Audit Chambers. The chambers accept audit reports, opinions and other analysis-based publications.
The chambers are governed by a dean who is elected by the members from among themselves.
Each member is responsible for their specific auditing tasks.
The members are supported by their cabinet.
As of December 2017, the five Audit Chambers were led by the following Dean: Phil Wynn Owen (UK), Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria), Karel Pinxten (Belgium), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain) and Lazaros S. Lazarou (Cyprus).
Danièle Lamarque (France) chaired the Audit Quality Control Committee.
Rimantas Šadžius (Lithuania) was responsible for coordinating the Court's interinstitutional relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues are taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President.
The members of the Court of Auditors held 21 college meetings in 2017.
Photo: 7 September 2017 quorum meeting

Our Management 28 Strategy The next three years will be a crucial period for the European Union, in which essential decisions will have to be made.
We recognize that EU citizens need access to clear and reliable information in order for the EU to be successful in tackling the challenges it faces.
Citizens must be able to see that the EU acts with integrity, upholds the rule of law, uses taxpayers' money wisely, has clear goals and delivers the results it promised.
As the EU's external auditor, we can make a contribution to this.
Our strategy for 2018-2020: building trust through external audit In July 2017, we published our strategy for the period 2018-2020, in which we set out four strategic objectives: • Communicate clearly to our stakeholders; • more focus on the performance aspects of EU action; • Improving the added value of the Statement of Assurance; • Alignment of our overall organization to our products.
Because at the end of the day, the EU isn't about numbers, it's about people. By exercising external financial control, the Court can show what works and what doesn't about the EU's spending and activities, it can help EU citizens answer the question whether the EU institutions provide them with results and support them, thereby helping to increase trust in the EU.
In this sense, the Court's audits must also address what worries European citizens, its ultimate ultimate target group.
The strategy for 2018-2020 identifies five priority areas for the Court's work in the coming years.
Sustainable management of natural resources and combating climate change Investing for cohesion, growth and inclusion Challenges related to migration, security and global sustainable development A functioning internal market and a stable monetary union Financing and managing the Union in an accountable and efficient manner
Our management 29 In the course of developing our strategy, we placed great emphasis on internal and external consultation.
We discussed the strategy with our staff and reached out to MEPs, EU Member State representatives, the European Commission, other Supreme Audit Institutions and non-institutional stakeholders such as academics, think tanks, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and private sector auditors.
The Court's strategy for 2018-2020 is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Work Planning In January 2017, we decided to introduce new work planning procedures, which we applied for the first time to our 2018 Annual Work Program published in October last year.
The main changes in terms of our work planning: • Developing a list of audit tasks for the whole Court; • centralized process for the selection of test ideas, possible test tasks and final test proposals; • more flexible allocation of resources to and distribution of resources between the individual examination chambers, taking into account the workload; • Extension of the product range to include examination tasks, which result in analysis-based publications; • Identifying high-priority audit tasks for which shorter deadlines apply.
We have also agreed with the European Parliament's Conference of Committee Chairs a procedure under which all Parliament's standing committees can propose potential audit topics to the Court.
The Court's work program for 2018 is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Performance measurement During the period 2013-2017, we used seven Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management about the progress made towards our goals, to support the decision-making process and to provide our stakeholders with information about our performance give.
The indicators served to measure key parameters relating to the quality and impact of our work, with particular consideration being given to the point of view of important addressees and the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources.
A revised set of performance indicators will be introduced in 2018, valid for the period 2018-2020.
Quality and impact of our work We assessed the quality and impact of our reports through user judgments and peer reviews. Another evaluation criterion was the follow-up to our recommendations to improve EU financial management.
Our management 30 Stakeholders' assessment We asked our key institutional stakeholders and peers – the European Parliament's Budgetary Control and Budgetary Control Committees, the Council's Budget Committee, the main auditees at the Commission and the European Agencies, and the Presidents of the EU SAIs – to express our evaluate reports.
Similar to previous years, the vast majority of respondents rated the relevance and impact of our reports in 2017 as “high” or “very high”.
Expert reviews Each year, independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of our reports to assess their quality.
In 2017, the Reviewers assessed six special reports* and the annual reports for the financial year 2016.
They rated the quality of various aspects of the reports using a four-point scale from “seriously impaired” (1) to “high” (4).
The results have changed only slightly in recent years, with the quality of our reports being rated as "satisfactory". * In 2017, the reviewers assessed our special reports 3/2017, 4/2017, 5/2017, 10/2017, 14/2017 and 17/2017.

Our management 32 140 120 100 80 60 40 20 ECA special reports - average number of online articles per special report 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 The increase in media coverage of our special reports in 2017 is in line with a trend observed for several years.
While fewer than 1,500 articles were published online in 2013, this number rose to almost 7,000 in 2017. The average number of articles written per special report has increased from an average of less than 30 in 2013 to almost 130 in 2017.
The greatest media coverage was our special report on the Greek financial crisis, which covered over 2,000 online and social media articles to ensure the professional competence of our employees.
Audit duration In 2017, the average time from the start of an audit task to the acceptance of a special report was 14.6 months.
This is the shortest processing time since the beginning of the 2013-2017 period.
It took us less than 13 months to produce eight reports (29%) published during the year.
It took an average of 16 months for the reports to be published, around two months less than in 2016.
This positive trend indicates that the actions taken to reach the 13-month target set in the Financial Regulation are bearing fruit.

Our management 33 Release of reports In 2017, 65% of our special reports were released according to the original plan.
The remaining reports have been postponed and will be published in 2018.
In addition, our annual reports and all special annual reports were published as planned.
Professional Development In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we aim to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional development per year.
In 2017, we again exceeded this target with 6.7 training days per examiner.
If the language courses required for the efficient work of our auditors in all EU Member States are also taken into account, an auditor spent an average of 8.3 training days in 2017.
For the other employees, we aim to provide an average of 16 hours (two days) of professional development (excluding language courses).
In 2017, this target was met with an average of 2.3 training days.

Our people 34 Staff allocation In 2017 we completed the 5% staff reduction over a five-year period (2013-2017) as set out in the December 2013 Interinstitutional Agreement on Budgetary Discipline and Sound Financial Management.
At the end of 2017, 853 officials and temporary staff were working at the Court. 548 of them worked in the examination chambers, including 118 staff in the members' cabinets.
Recruitment The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds.
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and employment conditions of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels.
The staff includes both civil servants and employees on temporary contracts.
Open competitions are usually organized by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
In 2017, the Court recruited 72 staff: 29 officials, 13 temporary agents, 24 contract agents (seven of whom left the Court by the end of the year) and six seconded national experts.
We also provided 71 university graduates with internships for periods of three to five months.

Our People 35 Age Profile The age profile of active staff as of December 31, 2017 indicates that almost half of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
Of the Court's 68 Directors and Senior Managers, 31 (46%) are aged 55 or over.
As a result, over the next five to ten years, as these employees retire, there will be renewal in senior management positions.
Balance between men and women The Court follows an equal opportunities policy, which applies to all stages of the career of its staff.
Overall, we have achieved a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees; 43% of our auditors and directors are women.
In recent years, we have succeeded in increasing the proportion of women in management positions in our examination chambers from 7% in 2015 to almost 20% in 2017.
We remain committed to achieving a gender balance at all management levels.
In addition, our equal opportunities policy for the period 2018-2020 addresses issues related to age and disabilities.
More detailed information on the nationality and gender of executives is given in the table below.

In 2017, we further expanded our range of training courses; among other things, the number of courses in the areas of e-learning and blended learning was increased.
We continued our successful series of presentations given by internal and external experts on audit developments and other issues affecting our auditors' work.
We also organized several training sessions and events where experts from other SAIs shared knowledge and best practices related to performance and financial audits.
A good example of this is the annual "Training Day" that we organized in November 2017 in cooperation with the University of Luxembourg and which was attended by over 300 employees.
We work closely with the European Commission, the European Institute of Public Administration (EIPA) and the European School of Public Administration (EUSA) to offer our staff a wide range of training courses, including both specialized courses in auditing and courses to develop personal skills, as well as work-related language courses.
We also support our staff to obtain or maintain professional qualifications and degrees in areas relevant to the Court's role and work.
In particular, we continued our cooperation with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France), which offers the postgraduate course “Audit of public organizations and policies” and the master's course “Management of public organisations”.
We also signed a cooperation agreement with the European University Institute (EHI) in Florence (Italy).
In 2017 we established a partnership with the University of Pisa (Italy) and the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) to organize a summer course in the field of public auditing and accountability.
Last year, we recognized the best submission with the Court's 2016 Public Sector Audit Research Award.
37 We continued our Performance Recognition Awards program, which allows non-managerial employees to participate in specific external training.
Translation The Court's Translation, Language Services and Publishing Directorate translated and revised over 211 000 pages.
We continued our efforts to streamline translation processes and reduce associated costs.
For example, all of our translation teams now use a collaborative work platform to increase efficiency.
We strive to increasingly involve our translators in our core activities and create further synergies with our reviewers.
In particular, in 2017 the translators increasingly assisted the auditors with the linguistic preparation of the special reports and the annual report.
They also provided language support to our auditors during 38 audit visits.
Information Technology Our Directorate responsible for IT makes a key contribution to our audit processes, optimizing the flow of information using modern and secure technologies.
We made further progress in document management and were able to fully digitize the production, acceptance and publication processes.
We introduced a simplified tool to facilitate remote access via mobile devices.
We also carried out a system upgrade (installation of Windows 10 and SharePoint 2013).
In order to make even better use of interinstitutional synergies, we introduced new systems to manage audit visits, missions and training, which are currently used by other EU institutions.
Support for audit activities 38 buildings The Court currently owns three buildings ('K1', 'K2' and 'K3') and rents office space for its data recovery center in Luxembourg.
K1 The K1 building, which opened in 1988, has office space for up to 310 employees and boardrooms.
The basement floors house parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities.
The K1 building was modernized in 2008 to bring it in line with national health, safety and environmental requirements.
Wherever possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adjusted to be compatible with the K2 and K3 buildings.
As a result, the three buildings form a single integrated technical unit.
K2 The K2 building opened in 2003.
Parking spaces, technical systems, storage rooms and the fitness center are located in the basement.
The entire top floor is used for technical systems.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also house boardrooms, a conference room with interpreter booths, videoconference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area.
The Court commissioned a study to assess the feasibility of establishing activity-based workspaces and upgrading the technical facilities of K2.
According to the study, the layout of the work areas could be improved and some technical installations need to be modernized.
A detailed study on this project will be carried out in 2018; work is expected to start in 2019.
As approved by the Council and the European Parliament in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds from the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation.

Safety at work project In 2017, the project to improve safety at the farm and its employees continued according to plan.
The new security control center, external accreditation center and access control center for employees and visitors will be operational in 2018.
Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, we consider it our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all our activities and we strive to continuously reduce the farm's environmental impact.
In 2017 we received the Eco Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) certificate.
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of the ISO standard 14001:2015.
Our goal is to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions.
In 2017, for the third year in a row, we analyzed the greenhouse gas emissions (ie our carbon footprint) caused by our operations.
The results of this study are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Accountability of the Court 40 Financial information The Court is funded from the general budget of the European Union, its budget falling under administrative expenditure.
In 2017, the Court's budget was around €141 million.
This corresponds to less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure, or around 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.
The proportion of appropriations used in the 2017 budget was 98%.

Accountability of the Court 42 Risk management During the year, as required by the Financial Regulation, we reviewed the risk assessments prepared for each Directorate.
The results of these checks feed into the annual declaration of the authorizing officer by delegation included in the annual activity report and are used for the following year's risk assessments.
Where necessary, we prepared action plans for ex-ante and ex-post controls.
In September 2017, following the completion of these reviews, we strengthened internal controls and financial processes related to travel expenses and company vehicle management.
Internal and external audit Internal audit The internal audit service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It issues opinions on the quality of the management and internal control systems and reports to an Internal Audit Committee composed of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee regularly monitors the progress of the various tasks set out in the Internal Audit Service's annual work program and ensures the independence of the Service.
In 2017, the service examined the implementation of the Court's 2013-2017 strategy, the operational structure of the Presidential Services Directorate and the management of our software licenses and products.
It also audited the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and monitored the implementation of its recommendations to ensure action plans are taking shape.
The Internal Auditor considers that in 2017 the overall governance, risk management and internal control processes in place provide reasonable assurance that the Court's objectives will be achieved.
We report annually to Parliament and the Council on the results of internal auditing activities.
External audit Our annual financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach of applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the entities it audits.
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à rl - on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2016 was published on 31 October 2017.
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2017, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General for the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2015.
This means that our financial statements for 2015 have been finally approved.
As every year, we carefully analyzed the issues raised during the discharge process regarding our audit and management responsibilities, took appropriate action and reported to the European Parliament on our follow-up.

European Court of Auditors 4 About the Court The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the European Union.
Established in 1977, it is one of the seven institutions of the EU.
The Court is based in Luxembourg and employs around 900 staff of all EU nationalities, made up of auditors and horizontal and administrative staff.
The Court's college consists of one member from each EU Member State.
The Court's tasks The Court checks that the EU keeps its accounts accurate, applies its financial rules correctly and that its policies and programs are delivering on their intended objectives and getting the best value for money.
Through our audit work, the Court helps improve the EU's financial management and promotes accountability and transparency.
The Court submits its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national governments and parliaments, and the general public.
Foreword by the President 5 Dear readers!
We have increased our focus on assessing the performance of EU action, communicating our messages clearly to the Court's audience and increasing the value of our work for our stakeholders.
In this activity report, we provide an overview of our work in 2018, in which we published the highest number of special reports, analyzes and opinions to date.
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances.
Our reports provide an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programs and the quality of EU financial management, both inside and outside the European Union.
We check that EU spending is compliant and that Union policies and programs ensure best use of funds.
It will be our pleasure to work with the newly elected European Parliament and European Commission to further improve EU financial management and ensure the EU delivers results.
This report reflects our determination to continue to adapt the Court's organization to "fit for the future" and continue to help pioneer developments in public sector auditing.

Our activities Strategy 2018 is the first year of our current strategy, which covers the period up to and including 2020.
Our strategic objectives for this three-year period are to: o improve the added value of the Statement of Assurance in view of current EU financial management, o increase focus on the performance aspects of EU action, o convey clear messages to our constituency.
In addition, we have agreed to align our overall organization even better with our products.
To implement our strategy, we have agreed an action plan for these goals to remain at the forefront of developments in public sector auditing.
At the end of 2018, all these measures were underway.
At the same time, we have already commissioned an independent peer review process to implement our strategy. The peer review is expected to be completed by the end of 2019 - see the chapter on the Court's accountability for more information.
Progress towards achieving our strategic goals 7
In focus – the communication activity relating to our products Conveying clear statements to our target group Communication is crucial if we want to achieve our strategic goal of conveying clear statements to our target group. This consists of the political bodies of the EU and the Member States responsible for the control and administration of the policies and programs of the Union, from the other supreme audit institutions, from companies and industrial organisations, from academics and last but not least from the general public – our most important stakeholder.
In 2018 we experienced how great the interest of the media is in our work.
Our special reports, in particular, met with great interest in the media and were also increasingly discussed in national and EU-oriented media channels - more information on this in the chapter on media presence.
In 2018, we published 12 Exam Previews (previously referred to as "Background Papers"). These are intended to provide a source of information for anyone interested in specific policy areas or programs for which reviews are in progress.
The information presented therein is based on the preparatory work prior to the start of an ongoing exam task.
Audit previews have contributed to the stable and balanced output of the Court's publications throughout the year: 2018 was the first year in which there was not a single month without an ECA publication.
We will continue to release these types of communication products in 2019. 8th
