Now each issue is devoted to a different overarching theme.
In 2018, the Hofjournal targeted a range of topics such as EU pre-accession assistance, Parliamentary funding and scrutiny, and EU financial and economic governance, as well as our special reports, our work programme, our international cooperation and our forward-looking actions with the EU The aim is to "prepare the farm for the future".

Audits More focus on performance We carry out different types of audits across the different areas of the EU budget: o Performance audits - looking at the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes. These best use reviews focus on specific management or budget issues.
In selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court weighs up the risks to performance or compliance, the level of revenue or expenditure involved, and the political and public interest; o Financial and compliance audits - looking at the reliability of the financial statements and the legality and regularity of the underlying financial transactions - particularly in relation to the Statement of Assurance - as well as assessments of whether systems are compliant in specific budget areas.
Our random sampling process ensures the same probability of an audit for every dollar spent.
Our audits focus on issues reflecting issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, challenges related to migration and global development, the internal market and banking union, and ensuring accountability and Economics of the European Union.
Based on the evidence gathered during our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved and on the state of the Union's budgetary and financial management.
Our audits are in line with internationally recognized auditing standards for the public sector.
The examination work is divided into the following phases: 10
PLAN Determination of the advisability and feasibility of a proposed test.
ON-SITE AUDIT WORK Multidisciplinary teams collect audit evidence on-site at the Commission's headquarters, as well as in Member States and beneficiary countries.
DRAFT 03 04 05 06 11 01 02 Clear, structured presentation of the main findings and conclusions.
CLARIFICATION Confirmation of the facts and findings by the audited entity.
ACCEPTANCE Acceptance of the report by the Audit Chamber or the Court College as a whole.
PUBLICATION Publication of the Special Report in 23 official languages together with the auditee's reply.
Work planning Audit priorities are aligned with key EU concerns Our work program is decided annually by the Court's members.
In January 2018, President Lehne presented the 2018 work program to the European Parliament's Conference of Committee Chairs and asked all Parliament's committees to propose potential audit topics for the 2019 work program as part of the annual stakeholder consultations.
12 In October 2018 we published the first work program prepared under the new strategy. In this 2019 work program, we detailed our audit priorities and the 36 reports and analytics-based products we plan to release this year.
These tasks covered, at least in part, 29 of the 69 proposals put forward by Parliament (42%) (2017: 32%).
Our audits will continue to look at key issues such as the sustainable use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, migration, security and global development, the single market and the EU's accountability and economy to determine whether the EU achieves what it promised.
On-site audits 3 761 days of audit work – inside and outside the EU Most of our audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg.
At the same time, our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission, the main body audited by the Court; this also applies to the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and the EU delegations, the national, regional and local authorities in the Member States and the international organizations to which EU funds flow.
We also carry out on-the-spot audits of recipients of EU funds, inside and outside the European Union.
These audits enable us to understand the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the entities involved in the management of Union policies and programs and the collection or payment of EU funds, and also from the relevant beneficiaries. 13
The frequency and depth of our audit work in each Member State and recipient country depends on the type of audits we conduct.
In 2018, our auditors spent 3 761 days (2017: 3 670 days) on-site inspections in Member States and outside the EU.
Within the EU, our on-site audits are often conducted in liaison with the SAIs of the Member States visited.
In addition, our auditors spent 2,723 days (2017: 2,300 days) with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralized agencies and bodies across the EU, international organizations such as the United Nations or the OECD, and auditing firms.
To obtain and validate audit evidence, we increasingly use video conferencing and other information technologies, such as the secure exchange of data and documents. 14

Fighting fraud against the EU budget Nine cases of suspected fraud We work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to fight fraud against the EU budget.
These cases are then followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and cooperates with Member State authorities where necessary.
While our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally come across instances where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activity.
In 2018, we forwarded nine such cases (2017: 13 cases) suspected of fraud to OLAF.
Additional information on the nature of suspected fraud cases sent to OLAF and related recoveries recommended by OLAF can be found in our annual reports on the general budget of the EU. 16
Publications New record: highest number of publications in 2018 Our audit reports, analysis and opinions are an important link in the EU accountability chain.
They help the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to monitor and verify that the EU is meeting its policy objectives, and to hold those responsible for the EU's budgetary management to account, particularly in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
This is primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
National, regional and local authorities in Member States also play an important role in areas of shared management, where most of the EU budget is spent; these include agricultural and cohesion measures.

Among our publications: Special and annual reports o Special reports presenting the results of selected audits on specific policy or spending areas, or on budgetary or managerial issues; o Annual reports, covering mainly the results of financial and compliance audits of the European Union budget and the European Development Funds, but also covering budgetary and performance aspects; o Separately published specific annual reports on the EU Agencies, Decentralized Bodies and Joint Undertakings.
Opinions and analysis-based publications o Opinions on new or amended legal acts with a significant impact on financial management, which are either mandatory under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or drawn up at the request of another institution or on the Court's own initiative; o Issue papers are descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management that focus on specific issues; o Landscape reviews are similar to issue papers, but focus on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, often from a cross-cutting perspective; o Rapid Case Reviews, which gather facts related to very well-defined specific issues or problems. If necessary, they contain an evaluation that enables a better understanding of these facts.
Finally, we present background information on future or current exam tasks in the form of exam previews - more information in the chapter on communication activity around our products.
All of the Court's publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu) and are listed at the end of this report. 18

Special reports We assess the performance of EU action in our special reports In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we are increasingly focusing on assessing the performance of EU action to ensure that EU citizens' funds are well served be used optimally.
In 2018 we published 35 special reports (2017: 28 special reports) on the different areas of EU spending, where we addressed the challenges facing the EU, such as air pollution, the high-speed rail network, the Facility for refugees in Turkey, banking supervision and financing of non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
In these special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programs have been met, whether the results have been achieved in an effective and cost-effective manner, and whether EU funds have added value – ie whether they have achieved more than is only possible through action at national level.
We also make recommendations for financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or more cost-effectively achieving desired policy goals.
Here we will take a closer look at two of our special reports from 2018: one on high-speed rail in the EU and one on the Facility for Refugees in Turkey.
In line with the EU Financial Regulation, we aim to produce our special reports within 13 months. 20

Special Report in Focus European high-speed rail network: not a reality but an ineffective patchwork High-speed rail transport has numerous benefits for passengers.
It is a comfortable, safe, flexible and ecologically sustainable mode of transport.
Improved connections between regions in the EU also make them more competitive and contribute to European integration by bringing people closer together.
In this way we analyzed the different connections, travel times and prices for business and private travelers.
We also examined whether the co-financed high-speed rail investments were cost-effective and effective, and well thought out and planned.
The Court concluded that the European high-speed rail network is just an inefficient patchwork of routes across Member States that are poorly connected.
There is no realistic long-term plan for connecting the different parts of the EU's existing network; High-speed lines crossing national borders are not among the priorities of individual Member States and the European Commission does not have the power to force Member States to do so.
In such circumstances, EU co-financing for high-speed rail will bring little added value.
However, there is also good news: the number of passengers using high-speed rail transport in Europe is steadily growing. There has been an increase from around 15 billion passenger kilometers in 1990 to over 124 billion in 2016.
Both institutions welcomed the report and agreed with our conclusions.
We also presented it to numerous national authorities and SAIs, as well as to researchers, industry stakeholders and the media.
The report was widely covered by media across the EU, particularly EU-oriented media and financial media, particularly in Spain and Germany.
DE – Die Zeit: Railway lines: expansion of fast train routes in the EU too expensive and too slow IT – La Repubblica: Alta velocità nell'Ue, la Corte dei Conti europea boccia la rete UK – Financial Times: Bloc criticized over high-speed rail strategy ES – El cinco days: Los auditores de la UE critican la incoherencia de los trazados del AVE
Special Report In Focus The Facility for Refugees in Turkey: Support Helpful, but Better Use of Funds Cannot Be Achieved Turkey, with almost 4 million people, has taken in more refugees than any other country in the world.
Around 3.5 million of these refugees are Syrians, most of whom live outside refugee camps.
Support under the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, worth a total of €6 billion from the EU and its Member States, covers humanitarian and non-humanitarian activities for refugees and host communities.
As part of the political agreement, Turkey was obliged to end irregular migration from Turkey to the EU.
Humanitarian projects have been able to meet the basic needs of refugees, but in some cases they have not achieved the expected best use of funds or the Facility's objective of effectively coordinating this support.
The humanitarian projects audited provided helpful support to the refugees.
For example, the Emergency Social Safety Net helped 1.3 million refugees with cash assistance.
However, half of the projects have not yet achieved the expected impacts – a lasting positive impact that can be sustained without further financial support – and nine out of ten projects had to have their duration extended.
The timely implementation of the projects managed by NGOs was hampered primarily by the difficult working environment.
to track. This was due to the Turkish authorities' refusal to provide access to the data of the eligible beneficiaries of the two cash assistance projects in our sample, totaling €1.1 billion.
We presented our report at a joint meeting attended by the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, and subsequently also the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.
He was also introduced to the EU Council's Enlargement and Accession Countries Group and to the press.
This report attracted a lot of media interest in Germany in particular, but also in Denmark, Austria, the Benelux countries and the Mediterranean countries, as well as in the EU-oriented media.

Annual reports Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017 Signed-off accounts, unqualified opinion on revenue, qualified opinion on expenditure Each year we audit the revenue and expenditure of the EU budget and examine whether the accounts are reliable and the revenue and expenditure operations are in line with financial regulations at EU and Member State level.
In addition, we assess all major areas of the EU budget specifically - based on the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020 - and provide information on budgetary and financial management as well as performance-related information.
We also analyze why errors occurred, make recommendations for possible improvements and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice.
As part of our latest annual report on the EU budget covering the financial year 2017, our auditors examined a sample of around 700 payments to beneficiaries, made across the different spending areas of the EU budget, totaling €100 billion.
This means that we analyzed around 700 different cases where EU funds had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research organisations, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.

Estimated error rates continue downward trend This extensive work forms the basis of our Statement of Assurance, which we are required to present to the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with our mandate as set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
As in previous years, the Court gave an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts and on the EU's revenue.
In addition, for the second year in a row, we were able to provide a qualified (and no bad) opinion on EU spending.
A significant part of the expenditure audited in 2017 was free from a material level of error.
In addition, the estimated error rate for 2017 payments was 2.4%, down from 3.1% in 2016 and 3.8% in 2015.
Launch of the discharge procedure by Parliament The publication of our annual report marks the start of the discharge procedure carried out by the European Parliament, in which the EU's legislative and budgetary authority decides - on the recommendation of the Council - whether the EU budget should be managed by the Commission and other facilities was done satisfactorily.
We presented our annual report to the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament on 4 October, coinciding with its publication, and subsequently to the plenary of the European Parliament and the ECOFIN Council, as well as the national parliaments and authorities of 14 Member States.
Mr Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors, and Mr Lazarou, Member of the Court, presenting our annual report to the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on November 28, 2018
For cohesion spending, we assessed the 2014-2020 control and assurance framework and the reliability of the information provided by the Commission to demonstrate regularity.
This represented a first step towards the potential design of the statement of assurance as an attestation-oriented test.
In general, with the changed approach and the move to an attestation-oriented audit, we intend to take greater account of the different levels of internal control at the European Commission and the Member State authorities responsible for managing EU spending.
This will show more clearly where weaknesses remain, both in the European Commission and in the Member States, allowing us to help promote accountability and further improve EU financial management.
This approach is only ever applied when the relevant requirements set out in international auditing standards are met. 29

Joint Undertakings Unqualified opinion on all European Research Joint Undertakings except one Joint Undertakings are the EU's public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States that play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is the public sector member of the Joint Undertakings and represents the EU.
The private members include various partners from industry and research.
One of the main objectives of the JUs is to attract contributions from members in the private industry and research sectors; that is their added value.
33 Main Conclusions Overall, our audit of the agencies for the year ended 31 December 2017 confirmed the positive results of previous years.
We issued o unqualified audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts for all agencies; o unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts of all agencies; o unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the accounts of all agencies, with the exception of a negative opinion for the European Asylum Support Office, which identified a number of issues.
Main conclusions o We have signed off the accounts of all EU JUs for the financial year 2017 and confirmed their reliability. o Seven JUs received unqualified audit opinions on their revenue and payment operations; the 'Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership' JU received a qualified audit opinion as the auditors identified problems which in some cases hampered effective internal control.
Opinions We also help improve EU fiscal governance by publishing opinions on Commission proposals for new or amended legislation.
If these are legal acts with a significant financial impact, EU law requires the Court's opinions.
These are primarily used by the legislative authority – the European Parliament and the Council – in their work.
Opinions can also be launched at the request of other institutions or on the Court's own initiative.
In 2018 we published ten opinions – the highest number ever – on different areas of EU governance.
On the one hand, these mainly concerned the Commission's legislative proposals for the new MFF, such as the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its cooperation with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO), on the other hand the linkage of EU funding with respect for the rule of law and protection of whistleblowers.
In Focus - Opinion on CAP reform Greener and more strictly performance-based CAP, more accountable, needed When the European Commission published its legislative proposal for the new CAP post-2020, it highlighted that environmental and climate targets are a very would be given high priority.
However, in our opinion on the reform of the CAP, we pointed out that many of the proposed policy options differed only slightly from the current CAP regime.
In particular, most of the budget will continue to be direct payments to farmers based on the number of hectares owned or used.
We also found that this instrument is not the most economical way to support a decent income and that it fails to address many environmental concerns.
Furthermore, the Commission's assessment of the contribution of the CAP to the EU's climate protection goals seemed unrealistic to us; therefore, the Court recommends more environmentally friendly and consistently performance-based plans for the next CAP, which should also put a stronger focus on accountability. 34
In accordance with the procedure we use in our reports, this opinion has been presented to the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council, stakeholders from the environment and agriculture sectors and the press. 35
Analysis-based publications: Landscape reviews, issue papers and rapid case reviews Analytical overview of publicly available information and the Court's own work Landscape reviews In 2018 we produced two landscape reviews.
In the first, we looked at the application of Union law in practice and set out to strengthen the Commission's oversight of the application of Union law by the Member States.
In the second landscape analysis, we dealt with mobility and transport and rated them as cornerstones of European integration.
However, we raised concerns about the investment backlog, as the modernization of the EU transport network is slowed down by falling investments in transport infrastructure.
Issue papers We published a total of six issue papers in 2018: five on the Commission's proposals for the future MFF and one on the integration of migrants in the EU.
In particular, the Court's observations on the MFF focused on the proposed mechanism for prioritizing EU spending, the flexibility of the EU budget, the focus on performance and administrative simplification, and the arrangements for accountability and audit.
While welcoming the Commission's efforts to modernize the EU budget for post-2020, we identified several potential risks, identified a number of weaknesses and proposed concrete improvements.
We pointed out that effective parliamentary scrutiny requires robust accountability arrangements and that the Court should, in principle, be designated as the external auditor for all bodies created by the EU.
Rapid case reviews In the only rapid case review we presented on Cohesion in 2018, we found that value added tax (VAT) reimbursement is prone to errors and does not always represent an optimal use of EU funds.
We considered that VAT refunds to public authorities on EU co-financed spending should no longer be possible in the post-2020 period. 36

Member State governments and parliaments ECA President meets senior government officials in five Member States During the year, President Lehne visited and met senior government officials in a number of EU Member States – Austria, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Ireland and Romania.
These visits were often combined with attendance at an official state event or high-level conference.
Our members also presented the 2017 annual report to the national parliaments and/or other national authorities of 14 Member States.
In addition, we took the additional opportunity to present some of our special reports to the relevant parliamentary committees of national parliaments.
Delegations of representatives from national parliaments occasionally visit the Court and we continue to explore ways to further deepen our cooperation with national parliaments.
Mr Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors, and George Pufan, Member of the Court, during a meeting with Klaus Iohannis, President of Romania, in Bucharest, October 2018 43
Cooperation with Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) SAIs of the EU Member States Actively collaborating with the SAIs of the EU: joint call to address weaknesses in the accountability and audit arrangements for EU banking supervision Our cooperation with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU -Member States takes place primarily within the framework of the Contact Committee of Presidents of EU SAIs.
In October 2018, we actively participated in the annual meeting of the Contact Committee hosted by the SAI of Croatia under its own chairmanship.
Discussions focused on interacting with EU citizens and making SAIs accessible to the public.
Court President Klaus-Heiner Lehne addresses the Presidents of the EU SAIs at the annual Contact Committee meeting in Dubrovnik, Croatia, October 2018. Together with the Presidents of the SAIs of the 28 Member States, we appealed to the national governments and parliaments as well as to the European Parliament , the Council and the Commission to address a number of weaknesses in the accountability and audit arrangements for EU banking supervision.
We have also been involved and participated in the activities of several Contact Committee working bodies, including the VAT Working Group, the Fiscal Policy Audit Network, the Europe 2020 Strategy Audit Network and the European Banking Union Task Force, and other activities in the areas of public sector financial reporting and public procurement auditing.
We also coordinated the production of the Contact Committee's first audit compendium (Youth Unemployment and Vocational Integration of Young People), based on audit reports prepared by 14 EU SAIs between 2013 and 2017.
With the publication of the Examination Compendium, the Contact Committee is introducing a new product 44
INTOSAI/EUROSAI In 2018, we continued our active participation and contribution to the activities of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI), particularly in our capacity as Vice-Chair of the Committee on Professional Standards (since December 2016) and as a member of the Subcommittee on Financial and Accounting Audit, Compliance Audit Subcommittee and Performance Audit Subcommittee.
We also actively participated in the activities of other INTOSAI working bodies, notably the Subcommittee on Peer Reviews, the Working Group on Environmental Auditing, the Working Group on Financial Modernization and Regulatory Reform, and the Taskforce on Professionalizing Auditors.
We also actively participated in the activities of the European Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI), the European regional group of INTOSAI, especially in the working group "Environmental Audit", the working group "IT Audit", the task force "Audit & Ethics" as well as at several workshops and seminars.
The SAIs of the candidate and potential candidate countries of the EU We also support the SAIs of the candidate and potential candidate countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo1, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia and Turkey). This support is primarily provided through a network similar to the Contact Committee and through our sponsorship of activities coordinated by the OECD.
In 2018, seven auditors from SAIs in the network participated in our internship program.
We also actively contributed to the meetings and activities of this network. This included addressing issues such as financial and IT audits.
Our Management The College of Members of the Court The term of office of the Members of the Court is six years, renewable.
The college consists of one member from each Member State.
The ECA has no role in the nomination and appointment of members.
In 2018 the Council appointed four new Court members: o Eva Lindström (Sweden), Tony Murphy (Ireland) and Hannu Takkula (Finland) on 1 March 2018 and Annemie Turtelboom (Belgium) on 1 May 2018.
In addition, the terms of office of five incumbent members have been extended by the Council: o Pietro Russo (Italy), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain), Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) and João Figueiredo (Portugal) until 29 February 2024 and Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria) until December 31, 2024.
In 2018, the College of ECA Members met 18 times (2017: 21).
46 Meeting of the ECA's College of Members on 28 February 2019 in Luxembourg
The President's role is that of Primus inter Pares.
His responsibilities include the board's strategy, planning and performance management, communications and media relations, legal affairs and internal audit.
He also represents the Court in all of its external relations.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President.
Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the ECA, addressing the annual meeting of the College of ECA Members and the College of Commissioners in Luxembourg in February 2018 47
The President and Members 48
Audit Chambers and Committees Members are assigned to one of the Court's five Audit Chambers.
They are under the direction of a Dean or Dean, elected by the members from among themselves.
Each member is responsible for its specific tasks and is supported by its cabinet.
The examination work is carried out by professional examiners who work for the directorates of the examination chambers.
As of December 2018, the five Examination Chambers were led by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Neven Mates and Lazaros S. Lazarou.
Danièle Lamarque chaired the Quality Control Committee, Oscar Herics chaired our Ethics Committee and Samo Jereb our Audit Committee, while Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues are taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President.
The European Court of Auditors has ten Directorates for all its areas of work, five of which are attached to the Audit Chambers, one to Audit Quality Control, another to the President and three to the Secretary General.

Performance measurement Our new KPIs as part of the 2018-2020 Strategy Since 2008, we have been using Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management of progress towards our goals, to support the decision-making process and to inform our stakeholders about our performance.
Not only have we set our strategy for 2018-2020, we have also adjusted our KPIs for this period.
Thus, 2018 is the first year in which we can report on these indicators.
These five KPIs provide a high-level view of how we as an organization do our work in terms of dissemination, impact and perception. o KPI 1 - Implementation of our recommendations o KPI 2 - Stakeholders" feedback on our work o KPI 3 - Our appearances in the European Parliament, Council and national parliaments ( Court appearances in the European Parliament, Council and national parliaments) o KPI 4 - Number of special reports (and similar products) published o KPI 5 - Our presence in the media court) 50

In addition to the selected audits foreseen in our work programme, we issued ten opinions.

In addition, most members of the Court present our annual reports to the national parliament of their Member State.

ECA appearances in 2018: European Parliament, Council and national Parliaments 52 European Parliament 91 Council of the EU 47 133 65 50 National Parliaments 19 2017 2018 Media exposure Number of online articles and social media posts almost tripled We have been in closer contact since 2018 to the media and non-institutional stakeholders and are much more active on social media.
We issued o 76 press releases in 23 EU languages (2017: 57) and o held 20 press briefings in Brussels (2017: 16), including press briefings for the annual report, including both sector and Member State briefings .
We also received journalists from Brussels and Member States and offered several briefings on selected reports to industry stakeholders, NGOs and think tanks.
53 Visits to Luxembourg by journalists from Member States in November 2018 We monitor media coverage of our work and our institution, which can vary significantly depending on the topic and complexity of a report.
At the same time, we have to take into account that external factors can strongly influence media interest in our publications.
For example, if the date of publication coincides with an important event or political development, public interest in the topic in question can increase significantly.
The total number of media reports, including those on social media, has almost tripled: while there were around 15,500 online articles and social media posts in 2017, in 2018 the number increased to more than 44,000.
Social media posts made by the Court's official accounts in relation to our publications were viewed around 11 million times in 2018, almost 18 times more than in 2017.
Special reports are clearly our flagship product in terms of media coverage. When it comes to communication and media coverage, special reports have clearly become our flagship product. Twelve of the Court's top 15 publications in 2018 were special reports.
There were more than 11,000 online articles related to our special reports that year, more than doubling the number from 2017.
This compares to a total of 1,500 online articles in 2013, the year we started tracking media coverage.
At the same time, compared to 2017, there was a 60% increase in the average number of media reports per special report.
This means that our media presence has increased not only due to a higher number of reports, but also due to a greater interest in our publications.

Impact and perception of our work Our reports – appropriate and effective We evaluate the impact and perception of our work based on user reviews. Another evaluation criterion is the follow-up to our recommendations to improve EU financial management.
In early 2018, we started asking our stakeholders (from the European Parliament, Council and Commission, EU agencies, Member State permanent representations, Member State public bodies, national SAIs, NGOs, academia, media, etc.) for feedback to ask about the usefulness and likely impact of our reports.
This feedback concerns selected special reports and analyzes as well as the Court's annual reports and is collected through anonymous electronic surveys from those who have previously received a copy of these reports.
Through this survey, stakeholders can also provide qualitative feedback on reports and make general suggestions about the Court's work.
Overall, 87% of respondents said our reports were useful for their work and 78% said they were effective.

Follow-up to our recommendations Most of our recommendations have been implemented Since 2018, we have used a follow-up by our auditors as the basis for this indicator, instead of the European Commission's management statement.
For 2018, we analyzed the recommendations made in our special reports published in 2014 and the annual report of the same year.
This analysis shows that 74% of the recommendations we made in our 2014 annual report and 94% of the recommendations in our special reports published in 2014 have been fully, largely or partially implemented.

Our staff Staff allocation At the end of 2018, the European Court of Auditors employed 834 officials and temporary agents.
The Court's establishment plan included 853 permanent and temporary posts – including 541 in the audit chambers – including 112 posts in Members' cabinets.
Areas of activity of our staff: Audit Services, Translation, Administration and Presidential Services 58 Audit Services 541 Translation Administration Presidential Services 135 Total 853 129 48 In addition, 76 contract staff and 15 seconded national experts were employed at the Court at the end of the year.
Recruitment The Court's staff come from a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds.
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and employment conditions of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels.
In 2018, the Court recruited 79 staff: 15 officials, 32 temporary agents, 22 contract agents and 10 seconded national experts.
We also provided 60 university graduates with internships for periods of three to five months.
Age Profile The age profile of employees on active duty as of December 31, 2018 indicates that almost half of our employees are 44 years old or younger.
Thirty of the Court's 64 directors and senior managers (47%) are aged 55 or over.

Audit support Professional development Education: how we prepare our staff and the Court for the future In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we aim to give each auditor an average of 40 hours (five days) per year to provide professional training.
In 2018, we again exceeded this target with 6.9 training days per examiner.
We have continued to expand the range of training we offer to employees both in and outside of the audit space and to support auditors in achieving various certifications.
We continued our successful series of presentations given by internal and external experts on audit developments and other issues affecting our auditors' work.
We continued our Performance Recognition Awards program, which allows non-managerial employees to participate in specific external training.
Average number of training days per year 7.0 6.7 6.9 Target ≥ 2 days 2016 2017 Per examiner 2018 4.0 2016 2.3 3.1 2017 2018 Target ≥ 5 days Per non-examiner 62 days
Successful cooperation with educational institutions We have signed a partnership agreement with the College of Europe (Bruges, Belgium) for cooperation in a number of areas , including training, internships and the drafting of reports.
We have also entered into cooperation agreements with the European Institute of Public Administration and other organizations, which enable our employees to attend training courses organized by these institutions.
We continued and expanded our cooperation with the University of Lorraine: we again offered the postgraduate course "Audit of public organizations and policies" (auditing of public organizations and policies) and the master's course "Management of public organisations" (management of public organisations). ) on. In addition, we have designed a new postgraduate program called "Fundamentals of statistics applied to audit".
Finally, auditors from other SAIs participated in our internal training. Some of them shared their experience of illustrating reports at the Court's annual Training Day, which was attended by more than 450 people.
Interactive public online courses We opened our online performance auditing training course to the public and held two interactive seminars with a capacity of more than 150 participants from around the world.
Translation The Court's Translation, Language Services and Publishing Directorate translated and revised over 251 000 pages in 2018. This represents an increase of more than 18% compared to 2017.
This increase also led to a higher rate of outsourcing.
In addition, all of our translation teams now use harmonized working methods.
Translators were increasingly involved in the Court's audit activities, providing linguistic support during audit visits and in the preparation of most reports.
This enabled us to create further synergies with our auditors.
The team responsible for the publication is now an integral part of the management.
Review of originals for translation and finally for publication, integrated into a single, streamlined workflow.
Information, Work Environment and Innovation Our Information, Work Environment and Innovation Directorate supports our employees in the effective and efficient use of information technologies by promoting innovation and knowledge management.
Information Management We have launched a new initiative called tECAway, which gives our employees access to the network on the go.
As a result, they can now access the farm's digital resources and services on any device, anywhere, anytime.
The Court has created a new harmonized document management system and introduced multifunction devices for printing, photocopying and scanning.
We expect that these devices will have a beneficial impact on information security and paper consumption.
We have also introduced a new cybersecurity governance model and are currently working on the implementation of the cybersecurity plan.
was duly considered in all IT projects and IT solutions . This ensured the unrestricted availability of critical systems.
Innovation We have also established the ECAlab, an interdisciplinary innovation laboratory that focuses on the digitization of the testing field through the use of data and technology.
The ECAlab tests the use of technologies such as artificial intelligence, natural language processing and text mining on real exam tasks.
This support has already benefited several tasks and publications.
, we conducted a pilot project on the application of blockchain technologies for the notarization of audit evidence and publications.
The resulting prototype, the "ECA registry", was selected by the European Blockchain Partnership - set up by EU Member States and the Commission - to be part of the European Blockchain Infrastructure for Services to be developed from 2019 onwards .
Knowledge Management July 2018 saw the launch of our first annual public audit summer course, co-organized with the University of Pisa and the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA).
45 people from SAIs, EU institutions and universities attended the summer course, which focused on data analysis for audits.
We also held a Blockchain-themed conference, where we explored the possibilities offered by this technology and its practical applications for controlling EU spending.
This conference was primarily aimed at participants from other EU institutions.
Buildings The Court currently has three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") forming a single integrated technical unit.
The Court also rents office space for its data recovery center in Luxembourg.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also house boardrooms, a conference room with interpreter booths, videoconference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area.
A detailed study on this project will be carried out in 2019; work is expected to start at the end of this year.
As approved by the European Parliament and Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds from the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernization.
K3 The K3 building opened in 2012.
The K3 building was rated "very good" by the world's leading method for assessing and certifying the sustainability of buildings (Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method, BREEAM).
A new security control center and an external accreditation and access control center for staff and visitors became operational in September 2018.
The ECA main building "K1" and the new security control center at Rue Alcide De Gasperi, Luxembourg Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all our activities.
We are therefore striving to constantly reduce the environmental impact of the farm.
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
As part of our goal of consistently and systematically reducing our CO2 emissions, we regularly analyze the greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities.
Our greenhouse gas emissions in 2017 totaled 10,451 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), a 3% reduction from 2016.
2018 was the fourth consecutive year for which we analyzed our carbon footprint.
67 Accountability of the Court Financial information The Court is funded from the general budget of the European Union, with its budget falling under administrative expenditure.
In 2018, the Court's budget was around €146 million.
This corresponds to less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure, or around 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.
The proportion of appropriations used in the 2018 budget was 96%.

Internal and external audit Internal audit The internal audit service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective assurance and advice designed to add value and improve the Court's activities.
This service also reports to the Internal Audit Committee, which is made up of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee regularly monitors the progress of the various tasks set out in the Internal Audit Service's annual work program and ensures the independence of the Service.
In 2018, she carried out an audit of the Court's cybersecurity systems and construction work related to its perimeter protection.
The service also examined the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and the annual declarations made by the authorizing officers by delegation.
It also oversaw the implementation of its previous recommendations to ensure that the agreed action plans took shape.
In 2018, the service's audits did not reveal any deficiencies that, by their nature or magnitude, would seriously call into question the overall reliability of the internal control systems; these control systems were put in place by the authorizing officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations.
We report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of our internal audit activities.
External control Our financial statements are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach of applying to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the entities it audits.
The auditor's report — PricewaterhouseCoopers Sàrl. — the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2017 was published on 17 May 2018. 70
Opinions of the independent auditor - Financial year 2017 71 Concerning the annual accounts of the Court: "In our opinion, the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and financial position of the European Court of Auditors (hereafter "Court") as at 31 December 2017 and of the results of its transactions , its cash flows and changes in net assets for the year then ended in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No. 1605/2002 (OJ
L 298 of 26.10.2012, p. 1) and its subsequent amendments, hereinafter referred to as "Financial Regulation", as well as Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No. 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the provisions for the application of the Financial Regulation and its subsequent amendments changes."
Regarding the use of resources and the Court's control procedures: "During the work steps described in this report, we did not come across any facts from which we would have to conclude that in all material respects and taking into account the assessment criteria mentioned, the funds allocated to the Court were not for the intended purposes and the established control procedures do not offer the necessary guarantee that the financial transactions were carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In April 2018, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General for the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2016.
As every year, we carefully analyzed the issues raised during the discharge process regarding our audit and management responsibilities, took appropriate action and reported extensively to the European Parliament on our follow-up.
On March 26, 2019, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary General for the financial year 2017.
This means that our financial statements for 2017 have been finally approved.
Peer Reviews Peer reviews mean independent and transparent professional assessments of a particular SAI's capabilities by other SAIs.
Each SAI involved in the peer review will continue to respect the independence of the other SAIs during the conduct.
In 2018, we asked the SAIs of Estonia (lead SAI), Denmark, the Netherlands and the United States to assess whether the Court is on track to achieve its strategic goals at the midpoint of the 2018-2020 period, and whether it is likely that the actions we have taken to implement the strategy to date will have the desired impact.
The peer review report is expected to be published in early 2019.
At the same time, together with the SAIs of Poland and the UK, we started preparing the peer review of the SAI of Lithuania.
The main objective of this expert review will be to assess whether the auditing approach of the SAI of Lithuania is consistent with international norms.
We also commissioned an external and independent review of the Court's ethical framework during the year.
This peer review is carried out by the Courts of Audit of Croatia and Poland.
The audit report is expected to be available in 2019. 72
