European Court of Auditors 5 Who we are o external auditor of the European Union; o established in 1975 by the Brussels Treaty; Assumed office in October 1977; fully-fledged EU institution since the Maastricht Treaty of 1993; o Head office in Luxembourg; o one member per EU Member State, appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament; o Around 900 employees of all EU nationalities.
Our role o We ensure that the EU keeps its accounts accurate, applies its financial rules correctly and that its policies and programs achieve their intended objectives and get the best use of funds. o We contribute to improving EU financial management and promoting accountability and transparency. o We warn of risks, provide assurance, highlight weaknesses and successes, and provide guidance to Union policymakers and legislators. o We submit our comments and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, national governments and parliaments and the general public. Foreword by the President Dear readers!
2019 was a year of many changes for the Union: elections to the European Parliament were held and a new European Commission took office.
The strategic priorities were redefined and important packages of measures such as the "European Green Deal" or the "Digital Future of Europe" (early 2020) were launched.
Towards the end of the year it also became clear that we would now be a Union of 27 Member States.
At the same time, the EU is at a significant crossroads in terms of its finances.
We are on the verge of concluding negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the outcome of which will determine the Union's financing capacity over the next seven years.
All EU institutions must now build on past efforts to further improve the Union's financial management and ensure that the EU delivers.
As an external auditor, we provide an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programs and of the quality of EU financial management, both inside and outside the Union.
We check that EU spending is compliant and that Union policies and programs ensure optimal use of funds.
This activity report provides an overview of our work in 2019, in which we published a large number of highly topical special reports, analyzes and statements.
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances.
We hope you find this information useful.
We are publishing this year's Annual Activity Report at a time when public health in the EU and its Member States is facing an unprecedented challenge due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Our institution has reacted quickly to this situation, in accordance with the health and safety instructions of the Luxembourg government.
I would like to thank all colleagues for their good work and their willingness to adapt flexibly to the current situation.
We must stand together now and do everything we can to continue fulfilling our role as the EU's external auditor in these difficult times.
Klaus Heiner Lehne President 6
7 2019 at a glance
8 What we do Strategy To remain at the forefront of government audit developments, we use multi-year strategies to set long-term audit direction and drive organizational change initiatives for continuous improvement.
At the end of 2019 we had completed the second year of our current strategy for 2018-2020.
During this three-year period, we have set ourselves the following strategic objectives: improve the added value of the Statement of Assurance; more focus on the performance aspects of EU action; Communicating clear statements for our target group.
To put our strategy into practice, we have agreed on an action plan that covers these goals.
In the last two years we have made good progress in implementing our strategic goals.
A number of initiatives and projects have been launched in relation to all the areas targeted, sometimes even going beyond what is set out in the Action Plan, in particular: o A pilot phase of the attestation-based approach to the preparation of the Statement of Assurance, which has led to useful lessons learned ; o A significant increase in the number of performance audits and analytical products and a more diverse range of topics, encompassing both EU spending and regulatory action; o Better liaison with the European Parliament and greater visibility on traditional and social media.
During the year a group of four SAIs (Estonia, Netherlands, Denmark and United States) conducted a peer review of our strategy.
Our peers' report was published in March 2020, just in time to provide valuable impetus for our next strategy from 2021 onwards.
Good progress in implementing our Strategy 9
Auditing the efficiency and regularity of EU actions Performance, financial and compliance audits Our performance audits look at the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes.
The focus here is on issues reflecting issues relevant to the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, challenges related to migration and global development, the internal market and banking union, and ensuring the accountability and efficiency of the European Union Union.
These audits aim to help the EU better achieve its policy goals.
Our financial and compliance audits result in our statement of reliability and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We may also carry out selected compliance audits to examine the budgetary and financial management of the Union or to assess whether the management and control systems put in place for the collection and use of EU funds comply with applicable EU and national regulations.
Our audits are in line with internationally recognized auditing standards for the public sector. 10
Strategic Foresight work program In 2019, we continued to embed the Strategic Foresight into our audit work to better address key future challenges for the EU through a forward-looking approach.
To this end, we have set up a Strategy and Foresight Advisory Committee.
One of the current tasks of this five-member committee is to oversee the development of the post-2020 strategy.
Audit priorities in view of the issues relevant to the future of the EU Our work program was published in October 2019. It details our audit priorities for the coming years and the 41 reports and analyzes scheduled for release in 2020.
With our audits planned for 2020 and beyond, we will continue to provide Union citizens and policy makers with independent reports on issues relevant to the future of the EU.
We create the work program for our exams independently, but not in total isolation from our environment.
It is therefore of the utmost importance for us that we work together with our institutional stakeholders, in particular the European Parliament.
As usual, in early 2019 we asked all parliamentary committees to propose possible audit topics for our work programme. 11
On-site audit work Most of our audit work takes place at our offices in Luxembourg.
Our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission – our main auditee; this also applies to the other EU institutions and EU agencies and bodies, the national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, the EU delegations in third countries and the international organizations to which EU funds flow.
We also carry out on-the-spot audits of beneficiaries of EU funds, inside and outside the EU.
These audits enable us to understand the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the entities involved in the management of Union policies and programs and the collection or payment of EU funds, as well as from the recipients of such funds.
In line with the target set in the EU Financial Regulation, we aim to complete our selected audits within 13 months. 12
3 605 days of on-site audit work – inside and outside the EU Our audit teams typically consist of two to three auditors and audit visits can last from a few days to several weeks.
Within the EU, our on-site audits are generally co-ordinated with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States concerned.
13 The frequency and depth of our audit work in each Member State and recipient country depends on the type of audits we conduct.
In 2019, our auditors spent 3 605 days (2018: 3 671 days) on-site inspections – in Member States and outside the EU.
In addition, our auditors spent 2,504 days (2018: 2,723 days) with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralized agencies and bodies across the EU, international organizations such as the United Nations or the OECD, and auditing firms.
In order to interact with our auditees, we are making increasing use of video conferencing and other information technologies, such as the secure exchange of data and documents. 14
Audit reports, analyzes and opinions Our audit reports, analyzes and opinions form an important link in the EU accountability chain.
They help the European Parliament and the Council to monitor and verify that the EU is meeting its policy objectives and to hold those responsible for managing the EU's budget to account, particularly in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
Special reports and analytical products In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we have increased our focus in recent years on assessing the performance of EU policies.
In 2019 we published 36 special reports and analyzes addressing many of the challenges the Union faces in different EU spending areas such as food safety, renewable energy, e-commerce, border controls, fiscal governance and ethical frameworks in selected EU countries. organs, just to name a few. 15
16 In our special reports we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programs have been met, whether results have been achieved in an effective and cost-effective manner, and whether EU action has added value – that is, whether it has achieved more, than would be possible through action at national level alone.
We also make recommendations for financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or more effectively achieving desired policy goals.
Our analyzes aim to provide introductory descriptions and analytical considerations, often from a cross-sectional perspective and based on previous audits or other publicly available information.
They may also be used by us to present our analysis of areas or issues that have not yet been examined, or to compile facts on specific topics or problems.
Unlike exams, they neither deal with evaluation questions nor do they offer a guarantee of reliability.
17 Sustainable Use of Natural Resources Analysis No. 01/2019: The EU's Response to the "Diesel Scandal" In 2015, deviations between the emission values achieved on the test bench and on the road were found in diesel engines.
Studies revealed that so-called "defeat devices" were used, which in official tests caused lower emissions than in normal driving.
The type-approval authorities of some member states reacted to the emissions scandal by re-testing diesel cars.
These tests showed that on-road exhaust emissions from almost all Euro 5 and Euro 6 light commercial diesel vehicles significantly exceeded the legal NOx limits, in some cases by more than 10 times.
We looked at the actions taken by both the EU and Member States in response to the "diesel scandal".
We also considered the changes made to the exhaust emissions measurement system after September 2015.
We noticed that numerous legal changes to the EU system of vehicle type-approval and emission testing were accelerated.
The Commission is now empowered to review the work of national type approval authorities. It can also have vehicles tested and revoke or suspend type approvals.
Affected third parties can now also carry out emission tests.
The Commission also launched infringement procedures against certain Member States.
We also found that in several Member States there has been an increased willingness to restrict motor vehicle traffic in order to improve air quality. In addition, low-emission zones have been created in several European cities, where car traffic is restricted or banned.
We presented our work results in the form of an analysis, since the changes made to the legislation will not have a measurable impact in the near future.
Our analyzes do not contain any recommendations.
18 Investing for Cohesion, Growth and Inclusion Special Report No 08/2019: Wind and solar power for electricity generation: significant efforts needed to reach EU targets Electricity can come from either non-renewable energy sources such as fossil fuels, non-recyclable waste as well as Nuclear fuels in conventional reactors, or obtained from renewable energy sources such as hydroelectric power, wind and solar power, biomass etc.
Renewable energies are also used to generate heat and cold and to obtain fuel for the transport sector.
Currently, 79% of the EU's total greenhouse gas emissions are due to the use of fossil fuels for energy production.
A higher share of renewable energies in electricity generation will contribute to the EU target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Member States determine how best to use their energy resources and how to structure their energy supply.
The EU can support Member States' actions by providing additional funds for investments in renewable energy projects.
We assessed progress made by the EU and Member States towards renewable energy targets to reach the overall EU target of 20% by 2020 and 32% by 2030.
In Germany, Greece, Spain and Poland, we checked on site whether the promotion of electricity generation from wind energy and photovoltaics was effective.
We found that significant progress had been made in terms of the share of renewable energy in the energy mix from 2005, but that this trend slowed down after 2014.
The share of renewable energies in electricity generation in the EU has increased from around 15% (in 2015) to almost 31% (in 2017) and has thus doubled.
Wind and solar power were the technologies that made the biggest contribution to this increase.
However, reaching the targets will be a major challenge for around half of the Member States.
We recommended that the Commission encourage Member States to support further expansion by conducting auctions to allocate additional renewable energy capacity, encouraging greater citizen participation, simplifying administrative procedures and addressing grid inefficiencies.
In addition, we recommended that the Commission review the legal requirements for Member States to improve the timeliness of statistical data.
19 External Policies, Security and Justice Special Report No 24/2019: Asylum, resettlement and return of migrants: time to step up action to close the gap between goals and results In 2015, the European Union experienced an unprecedented influx of migrants, followed by an increase in asylum applications.
In recent years, immigration numbers have fallen back to pre-crisis levels.
We conducted interviews with officials at the European Commission, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (commonly referred to as "Frontex").
Audit visits were made to national authorities, international organizations and non-governmental organizations implementing EU-funded projects. In addition, 20 EU support measures in Greece and Italy were examined.
Both Member States are particularly affected by these migration flows.
We assessed whether the objectives of the EU-funded assistance were being met and whether asylum and return procedures were being managed efficiently and expeditiously.
We also examined whether the targets and objectives of the temporary emergency relocation schemes were met.
We found that enrollment and fingerprinting rates had improved significantly in the hotspots.
Despite this, large numbers of migrants continue to move to other EU Member States and apply for asylum without their fingerprints being recorded in the Eurodac database.
In both Member States, the implementation of asylum procedures is still characterized by long processing times and bottlenecks.
A high proportion of applicants were actually relocated (80% in Greece and 89% in Italy).
However, since February 2018, the relocation process in the countries receiving migrants has not been monitored by the Commission.
As in the other EU countries, the return rates from Greece and Italy are low.
We recommended that the next Commission should take appropriate action to improve the management of emergency aid.
In addition, the Commission should draw on past experience when designing future voluntary relocation mechanisms.
Finally, EASO's support for asylum procedures should be improved and Frontex's support for return operations should be adjusted.
20 Market Regulation and Competitive Economy Special Report No 10/2019: EU-wide bank stress tests: more information on banks than ever before, but more coordination and risk focus needed The EU-wide bank stress test aims to assess the potential impact that a common shock on the financial situation and viability of large European banks could have.
It is the task of the European Banking Authority (EBA), in cooperation with the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB), to initiate and coordinate the implementation of EU-wide bank stress tests.
Stress tests have been carried out in the EU since 2011, all of them bottom-up. The banks provided the results of the shock scenario based on the methodology approved by the EBA.
We assessed the implementation of the EU-wide bank stress test under the mandate given to the EBA.
We found that at the outset of the process, the EBA did not specify the risks or the level of severity that it considered relevant to the stress testing process.
The ESRB, which developed the stress scenario, received significant input from the ECB as well as from the national central banks and authorities.
As a result, the EBA lacked control over key phases of the procedure.
In the United States, regulators rely on a top-down approach, giving them a much greater degree of control over the results achieved by banks.
Conversely, the role of the EBA in the EU is limited to initiating stress tests, providing the methodology and largely coordinating stress tests.
The EBA stress test assessed the vulnerability of the system and banks to an economic downturn rather than a severe financial shock affecting the system.
Although the EBA aimed for broad coverage, certain risky banks were excluded from the stress test.
The EBA's bottom-up approach led to limited reliability and comparability of the results achieved by banks.
We recommended that the EBA should increase its scrutiny over the stress testing process and develop a top-down approach to complement the current bottom-up approach.
Furthermore, in order to fulfill their purpose of assessing resilience to adverse market developments, future stress tests should take due account of the risks arising within the EU financial system, ensure a minimum level of stress and provide clear indications of banks' resilience.
After all, the selection of banks for the stress test should not only be based on size, but also on risk.
21 Funding and governance of the Union Special Report No 14/2019: "Have your say!"
The Commission's public consultations involve citizens but lack public outreach 'Better regulation' is about ensuring that policy decisions are prepared in an open and transparent manner, are based on the best available evidence and are read by citizens Citizens and other stakeholders, such as civil society organizations and representative associations, are fully involved.
The Commission has an obligation to consult citizens and representative associations on all areas of Union action.
The Better Regulation Guidelines define stakeholder consultation and include citizens as "stakeholders".
Stakeholder consultations, in particular public consultations, collect information and views from citizens and other stakeholders when the Commission is preparing a policy initiative or evaluating ongoing interventions.
The Commission carries out on average more than 100 public consultations per year.
We assessed whether the Commission's public consultations have been effective in reaching out to citizens and stakeholders and capitalizing on their input.
We examined the design of the Commission's framework, the manner in which the Commission prepared and conducted a selection of public consultations, and the manner in which it provided information on the consultation activities and used the consultation work.
We reviewed a sample of 26 Commission public consultations conducted by five DGs over the period 2016-2018 and conducted an opinion poll to determine how satisfied respondents to public consultations actually were.
We found the Commission's framework for public consultation to be of a high standard.
In addition, the sample of public consultations carried out by the Commission was overall positive and the participants' perception of them was generally satisfactory.
Inadequacies were identified in public relations and feedback. For example, the full range of communication channels was not always used, there were no clear criteria to justify why a questionnaire was not available in all official EU languages, and some questionnaires were long and complex.
We recommended that public promotion of the consultations should be larger and more targeted to increase visibility and enable more people to participate.
We also suggested that the Commission better report on the follow-up to the public consultation.
Finally, there is room for improvement in citizen participation when it comes to launching legislative proposals within the framework of the European Citizens' Initiative.
Audit Previews Audit previews provide information on ongoing audit tasks (in the field of performance auditing).
They are based on the preparatory work carried out before an audit begins and are intended to provide a source of information for all those interested in the specific policy area and/or program which is the subject of an ongoing audit.
In 2019, we issued 18 exam previews (2018: 12).
Annual reports and special annual reports The annual reports essentially contain the results of our Statement of Assurance on the European Union budget and the European Development Funds (EDFs).
The special annual reports contain the results of our annual audit of the accounts of the EU Agencies, Decentralized Bodies and Joint Undertakings and the European Schools.
We also publish a report on the contingent liabilities arising from the Single Resolution Board (SRB) carrying out its duties. 22
Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2018 Every year we audit the EU's revenue and expenditure to examine the reliability of the accounts and the underlying revenue and expenditure transactions with the relevant EU and national legislation Member States are in line.
In addition, we present specific assessments on all major areas of the EU budget - based on the (sub)headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020.
We also analyze why and where errors occurred, make recommendations for improvements and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice.
Finally, we provide information on housekeeping and financial management, as well as performance-related information.
This extensive work forms the basis of our Statement of Assurance, which we are required to present to the European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with our mandate as set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
EU general budget: unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts and revenue; qualified audit opinion on expenditure In 2018, EU expenditure amounted to 156.7 billion euros; this corresponds to 2.2% of the total government expenditure of the EU Member States and 1% of the gross national income of the Union.
Our auditors examined a sample of 728 payments to beneficiaries, made across all spending areas of the EU budget, from an audited population of around €120 billion.
This means that we assessed different cases where EU funds had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research organisations, farmers and students in EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.
For the financial year 2018 we gave an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and on the EU revenue.
In addition, we were able to provide a qualified audit opinion on EU spending for the third year in a row. 23
Around half of the expenditure audited is free of material error As in previous years, we found that errors in EU spending were not pervasive and, with the exception of high-risk expenditure (mainly reimbursed, subject to complex regulations expenses) the payments were legal and regular.
24 Overall, with an error rate of 2.6%, the Commission and the Member States have maintained the progress recorded over the previous two years (2017 financial year: 2.4%; 2016 financial year: 3.1%).
We see this as an encouraging sign.
Error - what does it mean?
An error or irregular payment is the amount of funds that should not have been paid from the EU budget because they were not used in accordance with EU or national rules and therefore not what Council and Parliament have agreed to with the correspond to the objectives pursued by the relevant EU legal acts or are contrary to specific national rules in the Member States.
We estimate the level of error using statistical methods, based on quantifiable (ie measurable in monetary terms) errors that we have identified by testing a sample of transactions across the entire audited population of expenditure.
most error-prone MFF (sub-)heading was "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" , followed by "Natural resources" and "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" . 25
Annual Report on the European Development Funds EDFs: unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and revenue; Qualified Opinion on Expenditure 26 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are the EU's main aid instruments in the context of development cooperation.
The EDFs aim to eradicate poverty and promote sustainable development and the integration of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States and Overseas Countries and Territories into the world economy.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States of the Union and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB).
As in previous years, for the financial year 2018 we issued an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the EDF accounts and revenue and a qualified audit opinion on EDF expenditure.
Specific annual reports on the EU Agencies and the JUs The EU Agencies are separate bodies with legal personality created to carry out specific technical, scientific and managerial tasks, thereby helping to shape the policies of the EU institutions and carry out.
There are 43 agencies in total.
Joint Undertakings are public-private partnerships between the EU and industry, research groups and Member States that play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy.
The European Commission is the public sector member of the Joint Undertakings and represents the EU.
There are eight Joint Undertakings in total.
27 Note: The United Kingdom left the European Union on January 31, 2020.
Unqualified opinion for all but one agency; unqualified audit opinion for all JUs In the 2018 financial year, a total of EUR 4.2 billion was allocated to all agencies (excluding the SRB), which is 20% more than in 2017 (EUR 3.5 billion). This corresponds to approximately 2.9% of the EU general budget for 2018 (2017: 2.7%).
Overall, our audit of the agencies' accounts for the financial year 2018 confirmed the positive results demonstrated in previous years.
We gave unqualified audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts, revenue and payments underlying the agencies' accounts; this does not apply to EASO, which received a qualified audit opinion on the payments.
We also issued unqualified audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts, revenue and expenditure to all JUs.
Parliament launches the discharge process The publication of our annual reports marks the start of the discharge process, during which the European Parliament – on a recommendation from the Council – decides whether the Commission and other bodies have managed the EU budget satisfactorily.
In October 2019, we presented our annual reports on the EU general budget and the EDFs to the Budgetary Control Committee of the European Parliament and subsequently to the plenary of the European Parliament, the ECOFIN Council and the parliaments and national authorities of 21 Member States .
28 Other annual reports: on contingent liabilities and the European Schools We are required to report annually on all contingent liabilities incurred by the Single Resolution Board, the Council and the Commission in connection with the performance of their bank resolution responsibilities.
In our 2018 report, we concluded that the Committee has improved the presentation of its accounts but that better reporting of contingent liabilities is needed from a national level.
We also publish an annual report on the annual accounts of the European Schools.
Our review of the 2018 accounts revealed a material level of error for one of the 13 European Schools.
Towards Digital Audit Digital is about harnessing the potential of technology to provide more and better information for the accountability process.
Digital change is also of great importance for our audit work and our organization.
We have set up a five-member Digitization Steering Committee to steer this transition process over the coming years.
As the first major audit initiative, in 2019 we launched a pilot to automate the audit of executive agencies' accounts.
In this pilot, we will use traditional and digital tools at the same time. 29
Opinions Opinions: contributing to Better Regulation One way for us to strengthen the Commission's approach to Better Regulation is to publish Opinions on Commission proposals for new or amended legislation.
When it comes to legislative proposals with significant financial implications, EU law requires the Court's opinions.
Other bodies may also ask us to issue opinions on specific issues.
Our opinions are presented to the European Parliament and the Council.
In 2019 we published three opinions: on the proposal for the European Union Intellectual Property Office, on a proposal for the financial regulation of the Single Resolution Board (SRB) and on the proposal for the financial regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office.
Our observations on the new MFF In early 2019, we also published our summary of the ECA's observations on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.
This briefing focused on the proposed process for prioritizing EU spending, flexibility of the EU budget, performance orientation and administrative simplification, and arrangements for accountability and audit.
This analysis was based mainly on a number of opinions we issued on the Commission's proposals over the course of 2018, but also on our most recent briefing papers and other reports on EU finances.
Balanced number of publications throughout the year We achieved a relatively balanced number of publications throughout the year, peaking in October when we issued our annual reports.
31 32 Fighting fraud against the EU's financial interests Administrative Arrangement signed with OLAF The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is at the forefront of fighting fraud against the EU's financial interests.
We have adopted detailed guidance on how to manage fraud risk for our auditors.
We refer to OLAF any suspicion of fraud or any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the EU arising from our audit work or reported to us.
These cases are then processed by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and, where necessary, cooperates with Member State authorities.
In 2019 we also signed an Administrative Arrangement setting out the operational arrangements for our cooperation with OLAF, including the coordination of training, workshops and staff exchanges.
10 cases of suspected fraud referred to OLAF We are the EU's external auditor.
Our checks are not specifically designed to detect fraud.
Nonetheless, our auditors regularly identify a number of cases where they suspect fraudulent activity.
In 2019, we sent 10 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2018: 9 cases), of which 8 came to our attention in the course of our audits and 2 cases arose from tips received from third parties.
Additional information on the nature of these suspected frauds and the resulting recoveries recommended by OLAF can be found in our annual report on the general budget of the EU.
In 2019 we also published two special reports closely related to the fight against fraud in EU spending: Special Report 01/2019 "Fighting fraud in EU spending: action is needed" and the Special Report No 06/2019 "Tackling fraud in EU cohesion spending: managing authorities need to step up detection, response and coordination".
33 Finally, we dedicated a special issue of the ECA Journal to fighting fraud and corruption and protecting the EU's financial interests.
Focus on sustainability UN Sustainable Development Goals at the heart of our audit work In recent years, in which we have focused on environmental and climate issues, sustainability issues have been audit topics of paramount importance.
In 2019, our work in the area of sustainability was supplemented by the analysis of sustainability reporting.
This analysis provided an overview of how the EU institutions publish sustainability information and how they contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
We also hosted a conference – the ECA Sustainability Reporting Forum – to raise awareness and bring key stakeholders together.
In July, we attended a meeting of SAI Presidents and stakeholders on “SAIs Making Things Happen: Auditing the Implementation of the SDGs” at the UN High Level Political Forum on the 2030 Agenda.
Finally, we published a special issue of the ECA Journal on the SDGs.
Audit team: Analysis "Sustainability reporting: taking stock of the EU institutions, bodies and agencies".
Institutional relations Steady increase in presentations to the European Parliament, Council and national parliaments We work closely with the European Parliament (EP), Council and national parliaments in the Member States as the impact of our work depends to a large extent on how these institutions benefit from our audit results and recommendations.
Our audit reports are presented to the relevant committees of the European Parliament and the working groups of the Council.
We also present our annual reports, but also our special reports and analyzes to the national parliaments.
In 2019, the presentations of our reports to these institutional audiences continued to increase, mainly due to a significant increase in presentations to national parliaments.
At the same time, due to the parliamentary break from mid-April to September 2019, fewer presentations were made to the EP. 34
Meeting with the newly elected Presidents of the EU institutions 2019 was a year of change at the helm of many EU institutions: after their election, our President met with the Presidents of the European Parliament, the Presidents of the European Commission and the Presidents of the European Council.
35 ECA President Lehne with EP President David Sassoli, Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and Council President Charles Michel.
European Parliament Our members and audit teams are regularly invited by the committees and bodies of the European Parliament, and in particular by the Committee on Budgetary Control.
In 2019, special circumstances prevailed due to the elections to the European Parliament in May 2019, in that the meetings of the parliamentary committees were paused in mid-April and then resumed in September.
We presented 31 special reports and 10 analyzes to 14 committees (2018: 39 reports and 14 committees).
Following the elections, we launched an awareness campaign to inform MEPs about our work as the EU's external auditor.
We also organized a series of workshops for EP staff.
Finally, in October 2019, we launched a publication portal that allows more user-friendly access to our reports not only for members of the EP, but also for the general public. 36
Council of the European Union In 2019, our audit teams presented 26 special reports to 22 Council working groups and two committees (2018: 40 reports and 27 working groups).
We also presented two analyses: one to the Budgets Committee during an informal Council meeting in Romania and another to the Working Group on the 2030 Agenda.
We also exchanged views with the Financial Services Committee on the agreement with the European Central Bank, with the Budgets Committee on our 2020 draft budget and presented our 2020 work program in December 2019.
In October 2019, the President of the Eurogroup paid us a visit to discuss the current status and future reforms of the Economic and Monetary Union and our potential contribution in the area of fiscal and economic governance in the EU.
In addition, the Chair of the Eurogroup Working Group met with our members in May 2019.
Member State governments and national parliaments More appearances in national parliaments Our members regularly visit national parliaments and governments.
In 2019 we made 90 presentations in 21 Member States (2018: 50 presentations in 14 Member States).
This represents the highest number to date. 37
European Commission Exchanging views with our auditees at the highest level For years it has been standard practice for our members to hold an annual meeting with their counterparts in the Commission.
These meetings provide an opportunity to take stock and reflect on how our cooperation can be further improved.
European Central Bank In June 2019, this tradition continued when President Jean-Claude Juncker invited our members to exchange views with the College of Commissioners in Brussels.
In October 2019, we signed an agreement with the European Central Bank that sets out the practical modalities for the exchange of information on the European Central Bank's supervisory activities for our auditors.
Cooperation with Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) Contact Committee of EU SAIs Annual Meeting 2019 in Poland Our cooperation with EU SAIs takes place primarily within the framework of the Contact Committee of EU SAI Presidents.
This network of EU SAIs enables us to promote independent external audit activities in the EU and its Member States.
In June 2019, we attended the annual meeting hosted by the SAI of Poland, which also chaired it.
Discussions centered around the challenges and opportunities that Digital Europe brings to EU SAIs.
At this meeting we chaired the Contact Committee, as we do every three years.
Contact Committee meeting, Warsaw, June 2019. 39
Online portal "Public audit in the EU" In January 2019 we launched an online portal on financial control in the European Union.
This online portal provides information on the mandate, status, organizational structure, activities and outputs of the supreme audit institutions of the EU and its Member States.
Audit compendium on public health in the EU In December 2019, on behalf of the Contact Committee, we published a second audit compendium that provides information on the public health audits carried out across the European Union.
The compendium provides background information on public health, its legal basis, its main objectives and related responsibilities at Member State and EU level. It also illustrates the main challenges facing the EU and its Member States in this regard.
It is based on recent audit findings from the European Court of Auditors and SAIs from 23 EU Member States.
In 2019 we started preparatory work for a third exam compendium, to be published in 2020, which will deal with the topic of cybersecurity. 40
INTOSAI In 2019, the ECA continued its active involvement in the activities of the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI), notably in its capacity as Vice-Chair of the Professional Standards Committee (since December 2016) and as a member of the Subcommittee for the Audit of the Accounting and Accounting, the Compliance Audit Subcommittee and the Performance Audit Subcommittee.
We also participated in the activities and projects of other INTOSAI working bodies, primarily in the areas of environmental auditing, big data, financial modernization and regulatory reform, and assessment of public policies and programs.
We have also been involved in the INTOSAI task force on professionalizing auditors, the INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) and the ISSAI 200 revision project under the aegis of the Financial Audit and Accounting Subcommittee.
INTOSAI Congress (INCOSAI) in September 2019 in Moscow.
Two main themes were discussed in detail at the conference: information technology for the development of public administration and SAI's contribution to national priorities and goals.
EUROSAI We also actively participated in the activities of the European Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI), the European regional group of INTOSAI, notably in their Working Groups on Environmental Auditing, IT Auditing and Auditing of Disaster Relief, and in their Task Force on Auditing and Ethics.
We also participated in several workshops and seminars and contributed to the publication of a joint report on air quality with 14 other European SAIs. In October 2019 we hosted the seventeenth annual meeting of the EUROSAI Working Group on Environmental Auditing and a joint conference on biodiversity. Finally, we attended the Third EUROSAI-ASOSAI Joint Conference on “Emerging Issues and Emergencies” in March 2019 in Israel, as well as the First EUROSAI-AFROSAI Joint Seminar in November 2019 in Lisbon, hosted by the Portuguese SAI .
41 Annual Meeting of the EUROSAI Working Group on Environmental Auditing, October 2019.
42 The SAIs of the EU candidate and potential candidate countries We also support the SAIs of the candidate and potential candidate countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo*, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia and Turkey). This support is primarily provided through a network similar to the Contact Committee and through our sponsorship of activities coordinated by the OECD.
In 2019, 10 auditors from SAIs of the network participated in our internship program.
We also actively contributed to the meetings and activities of the network. This included addressing topics such as higher impact accounting methods and digital auditing.
Peer reviews of other EU SAIs A peer review is an external independent review of one or more elements of the organization and/or functioning of an SAI by a team of peers from one or more SAIs.
It is not an examination, but an assessment and advice from specialist colleagues on a voluntary basis.
In 2019, a peer review team led by our Secretary General conducted a peer review of the SAI of Lithuania together with the SAIs of Poland and the UK.
The main objective was to assess whether the auditing practices of the Lithuanian SAI were in line with international auditing standards.
In December 2019, the final report was submitted to the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas). * This designation is without prejudice to positions on status and is in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) and the International Court of Justice Opinion on Kosovo's Declaration of Independence.
Our Management The Members The ECA acts as a collegiate body of Members, with one Member per Member State.
Each member is appointed by the Council, after consultation of the European Parliament, following their nomination by their respective national governments.
We are not granted any role in the nomination and appointment of members.
They will make a solemn undertaking to that effect before the Court of Justice of the European Union when they take office.
43 Meeting of the College of Members of the ECA on 18 July 2019 in Luxembourg.
In 2019, the Council appointed four new Court members: Viorel Ștefan (Romania) from July 1, 2019 and Ivana Maletić (Croatia) from July 15, 2019, and Joëlle Elvinger (Luxembourg) and François-Roger Cazala (France) from July 1, 2019 January 2020.
In addition, the Council extended the terms of office of three incumbent members: Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany).
Phil Wynn Owen (UK) was a member until January 31, 2020.
As of March 2020, following the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as Member of the European Commission in December 2019, a Polish Member has yet to be nominated and appointed.
In 2019, the College of Members of the ECA met 21 times (2018: 18 times).
President The President's responsibilities include the board's strategy, planning and performance management, communications and media relations, the relationship with the other boards, legal matters and internal audit.
The President also represents the Court in all of its external relations.
The members elect the President from among themselves for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election.
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President; he was re-elected in September 2019.
The President and Members 44 Note: as of March 2020.
Examination Chambers and Committees The members are assigned to one of our five examination chambers. The majority of our audit reports, analyzes and statements are prepared and accepted in the chambers.
The Chambers are governed by a Dean or Dean elected by the members of the Chamber from among themselves.
As of December 2019, the five Examination Chambers were led by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Alex Brenninkmeijer and Lazaros S. Lazarou.
Danièle Lamarque was the Member responsible for Audit Quality Control (until her term expired in December 2019).
She chaired the Audit Quality Control Committee.
The chambers divide their areas of responsibility among the members.
Each member is accountable to the Chamber and the Court for its own audit work.
The members are supported by a cabinet.
In addition to their role in the Audit Chambers, some members have also taken on other responsibilities: Oscar Herics chaired the Ethics Committee, Samo Jereb chaired the Audit Committee, Eva Lindström chaired the Digitalization Steering Committee and João Figueiredo chaired the Strategy and Foresight Advisory Committee.
Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations.
Decisions on broader strategic and administrative issues are taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President. 45
46 Our senior management consists of the Secretary General and the Directors.
There are 10 Directorates in total: five of these are attached to the Audit Chambers, one to the Audit Quality Control Committee, another to the President and three to the Secretary General.
Our senior management Note: as of March 2020.
Performance Measurement We use Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform our management on progress towards our strategic objectives, to support the decision-making process and to inform our institutional stakeholders about our performance.
These KPIs provide a high-level view of how we as an organization are doing our work in terms of dissemination, impact and perception.
36 reports released as planned in 2019 We monitor the number and timing of reports released throughout the year.
In 2019 we published 36 reports: 25 special reports and 11 analyses.
This corresponds to the number of publications planned in the work programme.
Number of special reports and analyzes published 47 We also issued six annual reports, three opinions, 18 audit previews and four other publications.
In total, we produced 67 publications during the year. 48
Media exposure Continued increase in social media coverage We monitor media coverage of our work and our body, which can vary significantly depending on the subject matter and complexity of a report.
At the same time, external factors can strongly influence media interest in our publications.
This may be the case, for example, when the date of publication of a report coincides with an important event or political development, which may significantly increase public interest in the subject in question.
In total, more than 50,000 free online articles and social media posts were noted in 2019.
49 For 2019, we saw a significant increase in our social media posts, also due to more active use of these communication channels throughout the year.
Increased contacts with the press In 2019, we intensified our contacts with the press and the media.
We did this by: o issuing 61 press releases in 23 EU languages (2018: 76), as well as numerous short releases and notices for the media in specific languages; o Held 25 press briefings (2018: 20), including sector and country press briefings related to the annual report.
These press briefings usually take place in Brussels.
We also received on-site visits from journalists based in Brussels and Member States and organized several briefings on selected reports for industry stakeholders, NGOs and think tanks.
Visit of journalists from Member States to Luxembourg in November 2019. 50
One million visitors to our website In 2019, the number of visits to our website exceeded one million for the first time.
In total, we recorded around 511,000 individual visitors.
Increased Followers on Social Media Throughout the year, we saw an increase in our presence and engagement on social media – particularly Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn – which has now become an essential part of our communication activities and allows us to engage directly exchange with citizens.
At the end of 2019, our three social media accounts had around 29,500 followers (2018: around 22,500). 51
Impact and perception of our work 88% of stakeholders surveyed find our audit reports useful We assess the likely impact and usefulness of our audit work based on feedback from our stakeholders from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, EU agencies, the permanent representations of the Member States, Member State public bodies and SAIs, NGOs, academia, the media and other parties.
Since 2018, we have been seeking feedback from our stakeholders on a selection of special reports and analyses, as well as on the Annual Report, through anonymous electronic surveys.
Through these surveys, stakeholders can also provide feedback on the quality of the reports and make general suggestions about the Court's work.
Overall, in 2019, 88% of respondents said our reports were useful for their work and 81% said they were effective.
52 Follow-up to our recommendations Almost all of our recommendations implemented We determine the status of the implementation of our recommendations based on the follow-up performed by our auditors.
For 2019, we analyzed the recommendations made in our special reports published in 2015 and the annual report of the same year.
This analysis shows that 96% of the recommendations we made in our 2015 annual report and 94% of the recommendations in our special reports published in 2015 have been fully, largely or (at least) partially implemented. 53
Our staff Allocation At the end of 2019, our institution had 853 permanent and temporary posts (2018: 853 permanent posts), of which 534 were in the audit chambers, including 118 permanent posts in the Members' cabinets.
54 In addition, at the end of the year we had 75 contract agents and 16 seconded national experts (2018: 76 and 15 respectively).
Recruitment Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions. Our employees have a wide range of academic and professional backgrounds.
In 2019, the Court recruited 77 staff (2018: 79 staff): 17 officials, 33 temporary agents, 21 contract agents and six seconded national experts.
We also provided 55 internship positions (2018: 60) for university graduates for periods of three to five months.
Age profile Almost three quarters (74%) of the staff on active duty at the end of 2019 are aged between 40 and 59.
55 More than half of our directors and senior managers are 50 years of age or older.
As a result, over the next five to 10 years, as these employees retire, there will be renewal in leadership positions.
Equal opportunities The Court provides equal professional opportunities for its staff at all levels of the organisation.
Overall, we have a balanced proportion of women and men among our employees.
In 2019, approximately one-third of our directors and senior managers are women.
57 Support for audit activities Professional development Record number of training activities In 2019, we continued to diversify and expand the training offer for our staff.
We organized a record number of training courses, conferences, presentations and workshops on a wide variety of topics.
We continued to provide financial support to employees to participate in externally hosted courses and programs to acquire or maintain professional qualifications and degrees.
We also launched a leadership development program consisting of courses, coaching and mentoring for employees who want to improve their leadership skills.
We supported HR operations by training newly created pools of career advisors, mentors and internal facilitators.
Training days target exceeded We again exceeded the professional training days target (5 days of non-language training per year) set in accordance with the recommendations of the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC).
Our examiners completed an average of 7.5 training days; our employees who do not work as auditors accounted for an average of 3.6 training days.
Collaboration in the field of training In July 2019, the second Summer School on Public Audit and Accountability took place at the University of Pisa on the theme "Digitalization of Audit".
We also continued our cooperation with the University of Lorraine, within which we offered the fifth edition of the postgraduate course "Audit of public organizations and policies" leading to the master's degree "Management of public organisations".
In addition, we started a new postgraduate program on "Fundamentals of statistics applied to audit".
These programs are now also open to European Commission staff.
Finally, we intensified our cooperation with NATO's International Audit Committee (IBAN) in the field of training.
In May 2019, a workshop on "Audit of the Union's security and defense policy" was held in the Court, bringing together auditors dealing with security and defense policy issues from the Commission, NATO, the European Defense Agency, the Joint Organization for Armaments Cooperation (OCCAR ), the Athena Mechanism and several EU Supreme Audit Institutions.
Launch of ECAdemy We also launched ECAdemy, a tool that allows us to share course material, publish conference recordings and organize webinars with anyone interested in public audit in the EU and its Member States.
This e-learning platform is open to the general public free of charge at https://ecademy.eca.europa.eu.
58 Sabine Chaupain-Guillot, Vice-Chair of the Education Committee of the University of Lorraine, Lazaros S. Lazarou, ECA Member (February 2019).
Translation In 2019 we translated and revised more than 223,000 pages including outsourced work (2018: 251,000).
We translate our publications into all EU official languages.
We also translate our correspondence with Member State authorities into their national language, as required by law.
Our translators are also often involved in our audit activities, providing linguistic support during audit visits and the preparation of reports.
Information Technology, Work Environment and Innovation Transition to cloud-based services An important milestone is the transition to cloud-based services, which has generally provided an easy-to-use system for various end-user requests (IT, human resources, office equipment, security, etc.). .
A new IT security action plan has achieved many of its goals, such as remediating software vulnerabilities more effectively and regularly, preventing unauthorized access to cloud services, reviewing information security governance, and enhancing our security monitoring capabilities.
Finally, in 2019 an ambitious technical program was implemented to provide equipment and systems that allow all employees to work more flexibly, e.g. B. Home office, teleconferencing and mobile work.
New open data policy In 2019, we also adopted a new open data policy.
The re-use of documents and the process of providing our data are determined in cooperation with the Publications Office. 59
ECALab ECALab, our interdisciplinary innovation lab team, has continued to research technologies such as text mining, artificial intelligence and process mining.
In 2019, ECALab also started supporting a number of exam tasks.
Network for Technology and Innovation in Auditing In November 2019, at the "Big and open data" conference held at our premises in Luxembourg, we also presented the EU SAIs' Network for Technology and Innovation in Auditing (Technology and Innovation for Audit, TINA) founded.
Conference on "Big and open data", November 2019, Luxembourg.
To accompany the development of the European blockchain services infrastructure by the European Commission and Member States based on our "proof of concept", another network of EU SAIs on blockchain technology in the audit area has been set up. 60
Buildings The Court currently has three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") forming a single integrated technical unit.
K1 The K1 building, which opened in 1988, has office space for up to 310 employees and boardrooms.
The basement floors house parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities.
The K1 building was modernized in 2008 to bring it in line with national health, safety and environmental requirements.
Wherever possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adjusted to be compatible with the K2 and K3 buildings.
Parking spaces, technical systems, storage rooms and the fitness center are located in the basement.
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also house boardrooms, a conference room with translation booths, videoconference rooms, a cafeteria and basic kitchen areas.
We are currently modernizing the K2 building to optimize the organization of its workspaces and to update certain technical systems.
A detailed study of this project was carried out in 2019 and work started at the end of the year.
As approved by the European Parliament and the Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining budget of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernization. 61
In the basement there are parking lots, technical facilities, storage rooms, unloading areas, waste storage facilities, the printing shop, kitchens and archives.
There are also offices for 503 employees, boardrooms and an IT room in this building.
Based on the world's leading method for assessing and certifying the sustainability of buildings (Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method, BREEAM), the K3 building was rated "very good". 62
Further increasing our security measures In 2019, we took a number of measures to increase security in our buildings in Luxembourg.
This included setting up a team of armed security guards.
An agreement has been reached with the Luxembourg police allowing us to use their national training centres.
We have also agreed with the European External Action Service to support our auditors in their visits to high-risk countries.
63 Eduardo Ruiz García, ECA Secretary General and Helga Schmid, EEAS Secretary General.
Environmental management As an EU institution, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all our activities.
We strive to continue to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions and regularly analyze the greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities.
Our greenhouse gas emissions in 2018 totaled 10,178 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), a 3% reduction from 2017.
We are proud of our EMAS certification for environmental management and environmental audit: We successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015.
An external EMAS audit was carried out in the last quarter of 2019, resulting in our EMAS certification being renewed for the 2020-2022 period.
New initiatives such as the "plastic-free ECA" initiative are progressing according to plan.
In 2019, we also placed four beehives in our gardens in collaboration with the Luxembourg Ministry of Agriculture.
The bees are cared for by volunteers.
We anticipate that this will have a positive impact on the sustainability of pollinators in our area. 64
Accountability of the Court Financial information The Court is funded from the general budget of the European Union, its budget falling under administrative expenditure.
For 2019, our budget was around €147 million, 98% of which was used during the year.
This corresponds to less than 0.1% of total EU expenditure, or around 1.5% of total EU administrative expenditure.

Internal and external audit Internal audit The internal audit service advises the Court on risk management issues.
It provides independent and objective assurance and advice designed to add value and improve the Court's activities.
This service also reports to the Internal Audit Committee, which is made up of three members of the Court and one external expert.
The Committee regularly monitors the progress of the various tasks set out in the Internal Audit Service's annual work program and ensures the independence of the Service.
During 2019, the Internal Audit Service carried out three selected tasks: "Risks and challenges of the Audit Quality Control Committee", "Travel expenses of Members and senior officials, expenses for Members' representation and use of the Court's vehicle fleet" and " professional training activities of the Court".
Our risk management strategy and three annual declarations by authorizing officers by sub-delegation were also examined.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations, ensuring that agreed action plans were being implemented and providing advice on the Court's new internal control framework.
Our internal auditor did not identify any deficiencies that, by their nature or magnitude, would seriously call into question the overall reliability of the internal control systems; these control systems had been put in place by the Authorizing Officer by Delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019.
External audit Our annual financial statements are audited by an independent external auditor.
We attach great importance to this audit as it demonstrates that we apply the same principles of transparency and accountability to ourselves as to the entities we audit.
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.à.rl - on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2018 was published on 4 April 2019. 67
Opinions of our independent auditor - Financial year 2018 68 On the Court's accounts: "In our opinion, the accounts give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2018, and of the results of its operations, cash flows and changes of net assets for the year then ended in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Regulation (EC , Euratom) Council No. 1605/2002 (OJ
L 298 of October 26, 2012, p. 1) and subsequent amendments thereto, hereinafter referred to as the "Financial Regulation", as well as Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No. 1268/2012 of October 29, 2012 (OJ
L 362 of 31.12.2012, p. 1) on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation and subsequent amendments."
Regarding the use of resources and the Court's control procedures: "During the work steps described in this report, we did not come across any facts from which we would have to conclude that in all material respects and taking into account the assessment criteria mentioned o the funds allocated to the Court are not for the intended purposes and o the established control procedures do not offer the necessary guarantee that the financial transactions were carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."
Discharge for the financial year 2017 Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure.
In March 2019, the European Parliament granted discharge to our Secretary-General for the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2017.
As every year, we carefully analyzed all issues raised during the discharge process regarding our audit and management responsibilities, took appropriate action and reported extensively to the European Parliament on our follow-up.
Peer review of our ethics framework Finally, in 2019, our ethics framework underwent external peer review by the SAIs of Poland and Croatia.
The corresponding report was completed in January 2020. 69
Declaration of the authorizing officer by delegation Pursuant to Article 74(9) of the Financial Regulation Declaration of the authorizing officer by delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares, in his capacity as authorizing officer by delegation, o that the information contained in this report, as well as the additional internal information, is necessary for the fulfillment of my duties , which contains financial and management information, including the results of controls, is true and accurate, and o confirms with reasonable assurance that — the funds allocated to the activities described in this report are used for their intended purposes and in accordance with the principles sound financial management have been used, — the control procedures put in place provide the necessary assurance that the underlying transactions are legal and regular and that the transactions involved are dealt with appropriately allegations or suspicions of fraud, — the costs and benefits of the controls are proportionate.

DE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 © European Union, 2014 Reproduction is authorized provided the source is acknowledged.
EN 2013 Brief information on the EU audit Presentation of the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013
Foreword by the President 02 Every November, the European Court of Auditors reports on the results of its annual audit of the EU's financial management over the previous financial year .
Based on the audit evidence obtained , the Court provides assurance on the use of EU funds and highlights where the risk of EU funds not being used properly was greatest .
The reports also contain recommendations for possible improvements in EU financial management .
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in scrutinizing EU spending and helps ensure that accountability to EU citizens is effectively exercised .
” the most important findings in our annual reports 2013 on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European development funds are summarized and explained .
, the reports provide an insight into the extent to which the EU and national stakeholders responsible for EU financial management report accurately on the management of funds, ensuring the application of EU financial rules and the principles of economy, economy and effectiveness.
are publishing our annual reports on this budget year at an important transition period for the EU and its finances.
, in the 2014-2020 programming period now underway , a new European Parliament and Commission face both long-standing and new challenges to financial management and accountability.
The continuing pressure on EU and national finances requires careful management and control of EU funds and better forecasting of long - term funding needs.
In particular, we highlight in our reports that the Commission and Member State authorities, in their EU financial management , need to pay more attention to the fact that EU funds are used to achieve results that cannot be achieved by other means as efficiently or effectively could.
At the same time, the Court's audit results show that more can and should be done to ensure that EU spending is compliant.
The Court will welcome the opportunity to assist the new European Parliament and Commission in resolving these and other financial management and accountability issues at EU level .
To this end, based on our audit experience, we have also produced two landscape analyzes that identify the main challenges facing the EU in the areas of accountability , audit and financial management.
Vítor Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

This value is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%. ο Overall, the supervisory and control systems examined were partially effective in ensuring the regularity of payments, with significant divergences between Member States . ο The two most error-prone spending areas were regional policy, transport and energy, with an error rate of 6.9%, and rural development, environment, fisheries and health, with an error rate of 6.7%.
For shared management as a whole, ie including agriculture: market support and direct payments and employment and social affairs, the estimated error rate was 5.2%. ο Corrective actions and recoveries by Member State authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate.
Overall results 05 Correct use of EU funds The EU funds for 2013 Each year the Court examines the EU's revenue and expenditure and gives its opinion on the ‐ the reliability of the accounts and the revenue ‐ and expenditure transactions with the relevant ‐ Rules and legislation are consistent.
, expenditure from the EU budget totaled 148.5 billion euros, or around 290 euros per citizen.
This expenditure corresponds to about one percent of the gross national income of the EU and accounts for about two percent of the total public expenditure of the EU Member States .
The EU budget is approved annually by the European Parliament and the Council, based on a seven-year financial framework.
Ensuring that the budget is properly spent is primarily the responsibility of the Commission.
Member States for around 80% of expenditure – particularly in the areas of agriculture and cohesion .
Where are the funds coming from?
The EU budget is financed from various sources .
The largest share relates to payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110.0 billion).
Other sources include payments by Member States based on the VAT they collect ( €14.5 billion) and customs and agricultural duties (€15.4 billion).
The annual EU budget is spent on a wide range of policy areas (see Figure 1).
The payments made serve to promote activities as diverse as research projects , training for the unemployed or agricultural production.

Overall results 09 Errors, waste and fraud The Court's estimated error rate is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste.
is an estimate of funds that should not have been paid out because they were not used in accordance with applicable legislation .
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenses or for purchases where procurement rules have not been properly applied.
Fraud is a deliberate act of deception with the aim of gaining an advantage.
The Court forwards cases encountered during our audits where we suspect fraud to OLAF (the European Union's anti - fraud office), which is responsible for conducting any further investigations in cooperation with the authorities in the Member States is responsible.
A comparison of the error rates estimated for the different spending areas is shown in Figure 5.
Higher rates in research and other internal policies and administrative and related expenditure were offset by lower rates in rural development, environment, fisheries and health, and external relations, external aid and enlargement.
As in 2012, the two most error-prone spending areas were regional policy, transport and energy, and rural development, environment, fisheries and health.
These two areas together with the other two areas of shared management (agriculture: market support and direct payments and employment and social affairs) have an estimated error rate of 5.2%.
For all other operational expenditure (most of which is managed directly by the Commission), the estimated level of error was 3.7%.
We also found an estimated level of error of 1.0 % for administrative expenditure.

Overall results 12 The Court analyzes the contribution of the different types of error, as well as each area of expenditure, to the overall estimated error rate ( see Figure 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be claimed under EU - funded projects accounted for the largest proportion of the estimated total error rate (inclusion of ineligible costs in the cost statements: 39% or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate - te).
In second place were projects where either the funded object/activity or the beneficiary should not have been funded under the applicable rules (ineligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22% or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
( 44% or 2.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
The area of agriculture: market support and direct payments, where the volume of expenditure was almost as high, contributes about half as much to the estimated total error rate.
Corrective action has a positive impact on the error rate Member States and the Commission apply corrective action to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure .
If such corrective action had not been taken for the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6.3 % instead of 4.7 %.
However, the estimated level of error could still be further reduced to a significant extent through better application of the existing control systems and corrective actions.
The Court found that for a large proportion of the transactions affected by errors in the areas of shared management, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before claiming reimbursement from the Commission.
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in the area of regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in the area of rural development, environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0% and in the area of employment and social from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information The reporting of the above corrective adjustments does not clearly distinguish between the main types of corrective adjustments. In addition, the information is largely provided outside the accounting system.
This makes further analysis difficult and reduces the accuracy of the figures presented in the accounts and related financial reports.
Another development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investment in potentially economically viable projects, in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Because of their complex structure, financial instruments require particular care in their valuation and recognition in accordance with internationally accepted public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Steady increase in amounts to be financed from future budgets Key features of EU budgetary and financial management in 2013 include: ο a sharp increase in the volume of payments the Commission was allowed to make through amending budgets : 9.6% the initial budget; ο a sustained increase in commitments giving rise to future payments (by 2.6%), despite the high volume of payments; ο an unchanged long period (more than two years on average) between the date of the initial commitment and the date when the declarations of expenditure are accepted by the Commission; ο only 37% of the funds allocated to financial instruments had been paid to final beneficiaries by the end of 2012; ο Repayments, interest and dividends of €259 million accumulated since 2008 were not recognized as income.
What are commitments and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements : commitments (amounts to be paid in the current or future years) and payments (covering funds disbursed in the current year).
Payments can only be made against valid funds commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitments and payments are set in the multiannual financial frameworks agreed by Council and Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes , particularly the long time between commitment and payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013 and this trend will continue similarly in future budgets.
Overall results 14 How can budgetary and financial management In the Court's view, the Commission should ο publish more relevant information on the functioning of the correction mechanisms ( timing ‐ ‐ origin and nature) and the accuracy of the corresponding figures by recording the information ‐ within the traditional accounting systems raise; ο record and value all financial instruments and financing instruments in accordance with internationally accepted public sector accounting principles , in particular through reliable methods for determining and recognizing impairments; ο provide information on treasury funds held pending payment to final beneficiaries; ο prepare and publish a long-term cash flow forecast , updated annually; this would make it easier for stakeholders to identify future payment needs and budget priorities. be improved?
