The full information on the main audit findings can be found in Chapter 1 “Statement of Assurance and related information” of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Overall results 15 EU funds and delivery of results EU funds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (economy, efficiency and effectiveness).
Against this background, achieving good performance requires inputs (financial, human, material, organizational or regulatory resources required for program implementation ) , outputs (what the program aims to achieve), results ( immediate caused changes in those directly involved or direct beneficiaries) and impacts (longer-term societal changes at least partly attributable to the EU action) .
The Court assesses these aspects in its performance audits.
Not enough emphasis on performance The use of EU funds - in the 2007 - 2013 programming period - was focused on absorption (use it or lose it) and compliance with the law rather than good performance.
When selecting the projects for EU funding , for example , the need to use the available EU funds was the top priority. Second came the need for compliance, and only third, and only to a limited extent, was the achievement of outcomes and impact.
This lack of focus on performance is a key weakness in the way much of the EU budget is structured .
According to the Commission, in the 2014-2020 programming period the focus is more on performance , with performance reserves being the main incentive.
Through these reserves, the Commission will hold back 6% of the funds allocated to individual Member States until performance is found to be satisfactory.
In practice, however, input and output indicators will continue to largely determine the release of funds .
The Commission will only use result indicators in a few areas.
Whether the performance reserves work more effectively will depend on the success of the Commission in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and in obtaining accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States to determine whether the targets were reached.
The reporting framework is not appropriate for the desired performance culture Performance reporting is split into several general reports at the general budget level.
do not provide information on progress towards the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives nor a comprehensive overview of the results in terms of EU added value .
, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction in that it attempts to establish a link between the main financial programs and the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of the individual Directorates-General of the Commission, performance targets are set for the policy areas in their respective areas of responsibility in the management plans. Thereafter, it will be reported in the Annual Activity Reports.
The Court's analysis of the Management Plans and Annual Activity Reports of the Commission's Directorates-General shows that assurance is limited to regularity and internal control aspects and does not address performance-related aspects.
In addition , the objectives were too general to be used for management purposes and the indicators selected are not always suitable for measuring performance.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU spending is not always demonstrated In the 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013, performance audits cover a wide range of issues and assess whether EU intervention is – in line with the principles of sound financial management (economy, efficiency and effectiveness).
to be learned from our special reports adopted in 2013 for the preparation of the new programs and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and found that : ο EU added value could not always be ensured. ο In several cases there was potential deadweight, ie the beneficiaries would have carried out the activity even without EU funding.
Example: European Globalization Adjustment Fund The European Globalization Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by mass redundancies.
We found that a third of the funding was used for measures that would have been paid by Member States anyway (Special Report No 7/2013 “Does the European Globalization Adjustment Fund have EU added value in the reintegration of redundant workers - accomplished?").
Example: Risk-Sharing Finance Facility The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that the EU funds made available under the Risk - Sharing Finance Facility (instrument designed to facilitate access to third-party finance in the field of research) would lead to increased investment than the beneficiaries would do without public money (Special Report No. 2/2013 "Did the Commission ensure efficient implementation of the Seventh Research Framework Programme?").
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The Court's follow-up to recommendations resulting from performance audits is a key part of the accountability cycle and can support the Commission's effective implementation of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court analyzed how the Commission ‐ followed up on recommendations from eight special reports adopted between 2007 and 2010 and found that the Commission had either fully or largely implemented 79 % of the recommendations .
The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should streamline its performance reporting framework in the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report includes an executive summary containing all available information on progress towards the Europe 2020 targets. ο The Commission should further strengthen its performance management and reporting system to take accountability for sound financial management and the contribution of the EU budget to policy achievements. on the basis of Member States ' Gross National Income (GNI) and VAT collected by Member States accounted for 74% and 10% of revenues in 2013, respectively.
Import duties and the production levy on sugar , collected by the authorities in the Member States on behalf of the EU, accounted for 10% of EU revenues. The remaining 6% comes from other income.
Explanation of EU revenue audit EU revenue , which is based on GNI and VAT, is calculated based on macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States.
audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions carried out by the Court relates to the processing of this data by the Commission, but not to the original collection of this data by the authorities in the Member States.
Consequently, the Court's audit conclusion concerns the impact that any errors made by the Commission have on the total amount of revenue.
established entitlements submitted by the Member States .
These data are not sufficiently harmonized among Member States.
A reservation is a tool to keep open the possibility of rectification for a disputed element in GNI data transmitted by a Member State .
There is a general caveat regarding the Greek GNI data for the years 2008 and 2009 as the data are still based on preliminary estimates.
This aspect is part of a problem affecting Greece's national accounts .
A closer look at revenue and expenditure areas 19 Member States' customs authorities carry out controls to verify importers' compliance with customs and import regulations.
The Court found that the quality of these checks varied greatly between the Member States visited .
This can lead to importers deciding to declare goods in a Member State other than that in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of an inspection and make it more difficult to collect the duties due.
An example where this practice seems to apply is the case of an importer who unloaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg (Germany), transported them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation, and then transported them to Poland for final sale to spend.
Our recommendations We recommend that the Commission: ο The Commission should encourage Member States to harmonize their methodologies for calculating data on unobserved economic activity. ο The Commission should draw up a detailed action plan with clear milestones and closely monitor its implementation to address the problems in the preparation of the national accounts of Greece . ο The Commission should set minimum standards for controls by Member States' customs authorities to allow better targeting of high-risk importers. 20 This spending area includes the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's Common Agricultural Policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture , to ensure a fair standard of living for the agricultural community, to stabilize the markets, to ensure supplies and to ensure that supplies are made to consumers at reasonable prices.
Expenditure is under shared management with Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate : 3.6% (2012: 3.8%) Control systems examined: Partially effective Most of the expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in beneficiaries' claims, the most common being over-declarations of area (see example).
- claiming aid for ineligible land In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas declared as permanent grassland and paid for, were in fact fully or partially covered with ineligible vegetation ( dense bushes or trees).
No EU aid should have been paid for these ineligible areas .
In Greece, this error occurred because such areas were classified as eligible grassland and registered as such in the agricultural parcel identification system. * Note on the use of Member States in the examples: the sampling approach used by the Court means that transactions are not audited in every Member State, beneficiary country and/or region every year.
The error examples are intended to illustrate the most common types of errors.
They do not form the basis for any conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
In all EAGF direct aid schemes, recipients of EU aid are legally obliged to comply with "cross-compliance" relating to environmental protection, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare and land conservation in good agricultural and environmental condition.
If farmers do not comply with these obligations, their subsidies will be reduced.
The Court's audits found non-compliance in 25% of the transactions related to these commitments.
In a significant number of transactions affected by error, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting reimbursement from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before declaring the expenditure to the Commission, the estimated level of error in this area would have been 2.5%.

Overall, despite the weaknesses revealed by the audit, IACS makes a significant contribution to preventing errors in the expenditure covered by this system.
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetable sector can receive EU subsidies .
In order to be recognized as a producer group, certain conditions regarding the number and relative size of member producers must be met.
The Court found that nine of the 40 audited producer groups in Poland did not meet these conditions.
In its Annual Activity Report for 2013, the Commission reported that it had reserved an amount at risk of 25% of the total expenditure under the measure concerned in Poland.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ο The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the full potential of IACS is realised. To do this, they should ensure, for example, that eligibility and the size of agricultural parcels are correctly assessed and recorded. ο The Commission should monitor the remedial actions related to the shortcomings in EU subsidies in favor of producer groups in Poland. In particular, this concerned the following conditions: agri - environmental commitments (see example), special requirements for investment projects and procurement regulations.
Example: non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) was compensated for not using environmentally harmful pesticides when growing artichokes.
During its on -the - spot inspection , the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products 12 times during the period audited.
Therefore, the payment for a subsidy was not eligible.
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments were also uncovered in the Piedmont region (Italy), Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.

The Court found that several serious errors had occurred in the procurement of the IT system and the subsequent maintenance of the data.

Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations for rural development: ο Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by using all relevant information available to paying agencies.
In this way, the majority of errors could be detected and corrected. ο Member States should ensure that the action plans to address the high estimated error rate in rural development cover all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they are consistent with the Commission's audit findings and the Court into account. A closer look at the revenue and expenditure areas of regional policy, transport and energy €45.5 billion Subject of our audit 24 This audit covered regional policy (accounting for 96% of payments in this area of expenditure), funded mainly by the European Regional Development Fund ( ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF) is financed .
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the development gap between the various regions.
Expenditure on regional policies is under shared management between the Commission and Member States , with projects co-financed under approved spending programmes.
The remaining 4% of this audited spending area is in the transport and energy policy areas.
The aim of transport and energy policy is to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services .
This expenditure is managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated most likely error rate: 6.9 % (2012: 6.8 %) Control systems examined: Partially effective The Court found serious errors in the area of public procurement, accounting for 39 % of the Court's estimated error rate .
The cumulative order value of the 122 audited procurement procedures is estimated at 4.2 billion euros.
Example: Unjustified Private Contracts Contracts for additional construction work at the passenger terminal of an airport in Germany were awarded private contracts to the original contractor.
This additional work was necessary because of poor preparation , planning and execution of the project and not because of unforeseen circumstances .
In such cases, direct award is not permitted, which is why the additional work should have been put out to tender.
Similar cases of unjustified direct award taking place have been found in projects in Belgium , the Czech Republic, elsewhere in Germany, and in Spain, Italy and Sweden.
's auditors also check compliance with EU state aid rules.
Unlawful state aid gives the beneficiary an unfair advantage and therefore affects the internal market.
Errors related to State aid accounted for 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
Example: State aid for a viable project A small or medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) in Slovenia was granted aid for research and development activities in the automotive industry.
However, the SME was fully owned by large companies and carried out its research activities exclusively for them.
Due to stricter rules on public funding for large companies, the company was not entitled to all the funding.
Similar cases have been identified in Bulgaria and Hungary.
In a significant number of transactions affected by errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before requesting reimbursement from the Commission .
If this information had been used to correct errors before declaring the expenditure to the Commission, the estimated level of error in this area would have been 3.9%.
The Court's auditors also found that in 2013 financial instruments continued to show low rates of disbursement to final recipients .
The funds in question support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees.
The funds are endowed with funds when their legal structure is in place and then use these funds to support projects.
A total of 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States, which are endowed with around 12.6 billion euros.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should require Member States to explicitly confirm in their management declarations: ‐ the effectiveness of the primary controls carried out by the managing authority and the certifying authority. ο The Commission should, as required by the Financial Regulation , carry out a thorough assessment of the ongoing problem related to the primary controls carried out by authorities in the Member States during the programming period 2007-2013 . ο The Commission should analyze the reasons behind the frequency of breaches of EU State aid rules . ο The Commission should reduce the persistent delays in disbursing EU funds through financial instruments . A closer look at the employment and social affairs revenue and expenditure area EUR 16.2 billion Subject of our audit 26 The audit covered the employment and social affairs expenditure area, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy.
The main objectives of spending in this area are the fight against unemployment , the development of human resources and the promotion of labor market integration.
Employment and social policies are mainly implemented through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98% of the payments made in 2013 in this spending area came from this fund.
The ESF supports investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures.
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the headmaster was charged to the EU project, although he also had other duties to perform .
In addition, the upper limit for the co-financing of salaries was not observed.
The Court made similar findings for projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
In a significant number of transactions affected by error, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting a refund from the Commission .
If this information had been used to correct errors before declaring the expenditure to the Commission, the estimated level of error in this area would have been 1.8%.
A closer look at the revenue and expenditure areas 27 In 2009, on the Court's recommendation and with the aim of reducing the likelihood of error and the administrative burden for project promoters, the use of lump sums and flat rates was extended instead of the reimbursement of 'actual costs'.
The Court's 2013 audit did not find any quantifiable errors specifically related to the application of lump sums and flat rates.
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less error prone.
Our recommendations We recommend that the Commission: ο The Commission should ask Member States to strengthen controls on procurement rules, costs not related to the project or projects with no EU added value . ο The Commission should ensure that Member States address the issue that EU projects claim higher rates of staff costs than nationally funded projects. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States have taken into account all the possibilities for simplification provided for in the regulations for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020 . Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU spending in the area of employment and social affairs can be found in Chapter 6 of the Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013 .
28 This spending area includes spending on external relations, development and humanitarian aid, and on actions in favor of candidate and acceding countries.
Development projects are spread across more than 150 countries worldwide and implementing organizations vary significantly in terms of size and experience .
Funding of projects from EU funds is subject to compliance with conditions laid down in specific funding agreements, as well as compliance with other regulations , such as those relating to tendering and contracting procedures.
Expenditure is managed either directly by the Commission's Directorates-General – through the Commission's central services in Brussels or the EU Delegations in the beneficiary countries – or jointly with international organisations.
Yes Estimated error rate: 2.6% (2012: 3.3%) Control systems examined: Partially effective Most errors concerned ineligible expenditure incurred at final beneficiary level such as ‐ expenditure incurred outside the eligibility period, inclusion of ineligible expenditure in project costs ‐ Claims (e.g. VAT, unjustified staff costs or overheads) and expenses not supported by adequate supporting documents.
The Commission validated pre-accession expenditure totaling €150 million, although there was no documentary evidence that the expenditure had been incurred and was eligible.
The amounts validated were based on the Commission 's own estimates rather than on incurred, paid and accepted costs supported by supporting evidence .
After the Court discovered this systematic error, the Commission corrected the relevant transactions in the accounts.
Example: unspent expenditure The Commission signed a €9.5 million agreement with the United Nations Development Program to promote social development in Moldova.
In 2013, the Commission accepted for reimbursement €1.8 million worth of contracts for which no underlying expenditure had yet been incurred.
- General EuropeAid manages the bulk of EU expenditure in the area of external action , which is funded from the budget.
The systems examined by EuropeAid are rated as partially effective.
In May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main shortcomings identified .
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should ensure that instructions to staff reflect that the final settlement of expenditure is based only on actual expenditure and should not be based on own estimates.
The Commission has already agreed to amend its procedure for clearing expenditure accordingly. Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure in the area of external relations, external assistance and enlargement can be found in Chapter 7 of the Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013 .
30 The most important component of this expenditure area are research and innovation projects , which accounted for 7.7 billion euros in payments in 2013.
The other internal policies concern expenditure on a range of policy objectives, including education and culture, security, migration and measures to deal with the consequences of the financial crisis.
Most of the expenditure is managed directly by the Commission .
, the Commission reimburses costs declared by beneficiaries in project cost statements.
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs that are not detected by the control systems before reimbursement by the Commission .
35% of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible staff costs.
Among other things, the estimated and not the actual personnel costs as well as working hours that were not used for the project are claimed.
Apart from non-compliance with spending rules, reimbursement of ineligible costs also hinders the successful achievement of policy objectives and consequently limits the added value of EU funding (see example).
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU - added value The EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at the EU - external borders.
The Court examined a project in Spain consisting in the purchase of four helicopters, 75% of which would be used for external border surveillance and control.
However, the Court found that only 25 % of the helicopters' operating hours were devoted to this purpose.
As a result, the EU should only have paid 25% of the cost of the helicopters, not the 75% actually covered.
A Closer Look at Revenue and Expenditure Areas 31 As part of the research expenditure control system, the Commission checks progress reports and cost statements on funded projects before payments are made.
The Court found that the Commission does not always apply the procedures consistently, which can hamper the efficiency of the programs and increase the administrative burden for beneficiaries.
Our recommendations We recommend that the Commission: ο For the new 2014-2020 programs in the field of research (Horizon 2020) and other internal policies, the Commission should provide beneficiaries and Member State authorities with up- to-date, consistent and clear guidance on : provide the eligibility rules and control provisions. ο The Commission should make its control activities more risk-based, by focusing audits on high-risk beneficiaries (e.g. entities less experienced with EU funding ) and reducing the burden of controls on lower-risk beneficiaries.
Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU spending on research and other internal policies can be found in Chapter 8 of the Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013 .

's audits of the agencies and other decentralized bodies of the European Union are covered in specific annual reports, which are published separately, including an executive summary .

Closer examination of the revenue and expenditure areas European Development Fund (EDF) EUR 2.6 billion Subject of our audit 33 Within the framework of the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific Ocean (ACP - countries ) and the Overseas Countries and Territories ( OCT).
, sustainable development and the integration of the ACP states and OCTs into the world economy are to be promoted.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States. They are governed by their own financial regulation and managed by the European Commission outside the general budget of the EU.
The environment in which the external assistance financed by the EDFs is implemented is fraught with risk, in particular due to the geographically dispersed activities and the lack of institutional and administrative capacity in partner countries.

Example: non-compliance by the beneficiary with procurement rules The Court examined a tender for IT equipment for a business information centre; funding came from a micro and small business support programme .
The examination showed that the contract was not awarded to the bidder with the lowest price offer, although the lowest price was the award criterion .
The error was not detected by the auditor who carried out an accounting audit of the program in accordance with the relevant framework contract with the Commission.
A Closer Look at Revenue and Expenditure Areas 34 The EDF also grants budget support, where payments go directly to a developing country's budget if specific conditions are met.
The Court found errors in transactions related to budget support where the eligibility had been incorrectly assessed and the wrong exchange rate used to convert the payment into local currency.
The Commission's Directorate-General for EuropeAid not only manages the majority of expenditure from the EU budget related to external assistance , but also almost all expenditure made under the European Development Funds ( EDFs).
The systems examined by EuropeAid are rated as partially effective.

Background information 35 The audit approach at a glance The Court's opinions in the Statement of Assurance are based on objective evidence obtained in particular through audit procedures carried out in accordance with international auditing standards .
The EU budget is complex.
The Commission Directorates-General initiate hundreds of thousands of accounting entries each year , based on information from many different sources (including Member States).
The Court checks that the accounting procedures are working properly and that the resulting accounting data is complete, correctly recorded and properly presented. ο Assessment of the accounting system to determine whether it provides a sound basis for reliable (complete and accurate) data. ο Review of key accounting procedures to determine whether they are working correctly. ο Analytical checks of accounting data to determine whether they are presented consistently and appear reasonable. ο Direct examination of a sample of accounting entries to determine whether the underlying transactions actually exist and are correctly recorded . ο Auditing the financial statements to determine whether they fairly present the financial position. Background information 36 Regularity of transactions Are the revenue transactions underlying the EU accounts and the payment transactions1 recorded as expenditure in compliance with the relevant rules? ο Transactions are sampled from all parts of the EU budget using statistical methods , which the Court's auditors use as a basis for detailed audits. ο The transactions sampled are thoroughly checked, usually on-site at the final recipients ( e.g. a farmer, a research institute, a company carrying out public works or services) in order to obtain direct evidence to ensure that the transaction is caused by an event, is properly recorded and complies with the regulations governing the relevant payments . ο Errors are analyzed and classified as quantifiable or non-quantifiable. ο By extrapolating the quantifiable errors, the effects of the errors are calculated in the form of a " most likely " error rate (estimated error rate). ο For the purpose of formulating the Court's opinion, the estimated level of error is related to a materiality threshold of 2%. ο A number of control systems are assessed to determine whether they are effective in ensuring the legality and regularity of the transactions under them. ο Other relevant information such as annual activity reports and reports from other auditors are taken into account. ο All audit findings are discussed with both Member State authorities and the Commission to ensure that the facts are correct. ο The Court expresses its opinions on the basis of the procedures performed and the results obtained.
1 Payments recorded as expenditure are interim payments, final payments and cleared advances.
The implementation of the EU budget makes millions of payments to beneficiaries within the EU and around the world.
Most of this expenditure is managed by the Member States.
out direct audits of revenue and payments recorded as expenditure and assesses the systems by which the payments are processed and controlled.
For more information on the process of auditing the Statement of Assurance , see ‐ Annex 1.1 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the independent auditing body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It employs around 900 staff of all EU nationalities , made up of auditors and staff in horizontal services.
, it has raised awareness of the importance of EU financial management and contributed to its improvement.
The Court's audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
Our results are used to hold accountable those responsible for the management of the EU budget , particularly in the context of the discharge process.
This is mainly the Commission, but the other EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies are also affected.
Member States also play an important role in shared management.
Our main tasks: ο Financial and compliance audits, mainly in relation to the Statement of Assurance; ο performance audits on topics selected to ensure that we achieve the greatest possible impact with our work ; ο Opinions on legislation related to budgetary management and other important issues.
We aim to use our resources to strike the right balance between our different areas of activity in order to achieve sound results and appropriate coverage of the different areas of the EU budget .
Background information 38 Our results We present the following results: ο annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds; the annual reports mainly include the opinions and findings of the Statement of Assurance and are published in November of each year ; ο specific annual reports containing the audit opinions on the accounts of each agency and other EU body; 53 reports to be published in 2014; ο special reports on selected audit topics, published throughout the year; these are mainly performance audits; about 25 reports to be published in 2014; ο Opinions used by the European Parliament and the Council when adopting EU legislation that has a significant impact on financial management; six opinions to be published in 2014; ο Landscape analyzes on selected EU policies - analyzing the major challenges and long-term trends; two such analyzes are to be published in 2014; ο the annual activity report , which contains information and explanations about our activities in the relevant year.
With our work we contribute to raising awareness and transparency about EU financial management by providing assurance on the state of financial management and making recommendations for further improvements.
This is in the interest of the citizens of the European Union.
Information on the Court's audits of the agencies and other decentralized bodies of the European Union can be found in their respective specific annual reports for the financial year 2013, which are available on the Court 's website.
The European Court of Auditors is the EU's independent external audit body - guardian of EU finances In its annual reports on the EU budget and the European Development Funds, the Court issues an audit opinion (statement of assurance) on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the accounts on which they are based processes.
This brief information provides an overview of the most important findings and conclusions.
The full text of the reports is available on the Court's website and is published in the Official Journal of the European Union.
2 INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereafter "the Agency") based in Ljubljana was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council1.
The main task of the agency is to support the national regulatory authorities in fulfilling the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and - where necessary - to coordinate the actions of these authorities.
As part of the Regulation on the Integrity and Transparency of the Wholesale Energy Market (REMIT Regulation)2, the agency, together with the national regulatory authorities, is given additional tasks with regard to the monitoring of the European wholesale energy market3.
With regard to the financial year 2011, the period from 8 March to 31 December 2011 was therefore examined.

Auditor's responsibility 6. Responsibility of the Court, on the basis of its audit, to provide the European Parliament and the Council10 with a statement of reliability as to the reliability of the Agency's accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
7. The Court conducted its audit in accordance with the IFAC International Standards on Auditing and Codes of Conduct and the INTOSAI International Standards of Supreme Audit Institutions.
Those standards require the Court to plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance that the Agency's accounts are free from material misstatement and that the transactions underlying them are legal and regular.
8. An audit includes the performance of audit procedures to obtain audit evidence for the amounts and other disclosures contained in the annual financial statements and for the legality and regularity of the transactions on which they are based.
The choice of audit procedures is at the discretion of the auditor. This includes assessing the risks of material misstatement, whether intentional or unintentional, in the financial statements and of material non-compliance with European Union law in the underlying transactions, whether intentional or unintentional.
In assessing those risks, the auditor considers the internal control system relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements and the supervisory and control systems put in place to ensure the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions 5 in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances are.
An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the financial statements.
9. The Court is of the opinion that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as a basis for the audit opinions below.
Opinion on the reliability of the accounts 10.In the Court's opinion, the annual accounts of the Agency11 present its financial position as at 31 December 2011 and the results of its operations and cash flows for the financial year then ended in accordance with its financial regulation and those of the Accounting Officer of the accounting rules12 adopted by the Commission in all material respects as a whole appropriately.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Areas of competence of the Union under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) Areas of competence of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713 /2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Regulation (EU) No. 838/2010 of the Commission; Regulation (EU) No. 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Powers and activities The European Parliament and the Council shall adopt in accordance with the ordinary Legislative procedures and, after consultation of the Economic and Social Committee, measures to approximate the laws and regulations of the Member States which have as their object the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy shall, in a spirit of solidarity between Member States in the context of the completion or functioning of the internal market and taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment, aim to: (a) ensure the functioning of the energy market; b) ensuring security of energy supply in the Union; c) promoting energy efficiency and energy savings and developing new and renewable energy sources; and d) promoting the interconnection of energy networks.
The European Parliament and the Council, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, adopt the measures necessary to achieve the objectives.
These measures are adopted after consultation of the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
Objectives The purpose of the Agency is to support the national regulatory authorities in fulfilling the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and - where necessary - to coordinate their actions.
Tasks - Supplementing and coordinating the work of the national regulatory authorities, - Participation in the development of regulations for European networks, - Under certain conditions, making binding individual decisions on the modalities for access and the operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - Advising the European institutions on energy-related issues, - Monitoring of the developments in the energy markets and corresponding reporting, - Preparation of a proposal to the EU Commission for the annual compensation amount for cross-border infrastructures within the framework of the ITC mechanism, - Cooperation with the national regulatory authorities, the ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and where appropriate, national competition authorities to monitor wholesale energy markets, - assess the functioning and transparency of different categories of marketplaces and different hands lsarten, - Making recommendations to the Commission on market rules, transaction records, trade orders, standards and procedures that could improve market integrity and the functioning of the internal market.
Management Board Composition: The Management Board consists of two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member has a deputy.
Responsibilities: The Management Board adopts the Agency's annual work programme, adopts its budget and oversees implementation.

ACER - Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators ACER - Agence de coopération des régulateurs de l'énergie THE AGENCY'S REPLIES 13. During its first year of operation, ACER had to recruit a large part of its staff, which caused problems and resulted in vacancies were occupied late; this was clearly reflected in the implementation rate of the Agency's budget.
This also affected the estimated procurement needs and resulted in procurement processes being concentrated towards the end of the year; thus, large carry-overs became necessary to meet the legal and budgetary commitments made.
With most posts filled at the beginning of 2012, ACER is now in a significantly better position to carry out its assigned responsibilities and associated budget.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY MANAGEMENT 11.The Agency carried over 1.9 million euro or 56% of the total amount committed under Title II (Agency buildings and associated costs). These transfers of appropriations are mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT regulation.
This is an operational, multiannual activity which should have been discontinued under Title III of the budget.
12. In addition, the Agency transferred EUR 3.1 million or 91% of the total amount committed under Title III, also related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
The extraordinarily high carry-over rate for Title III is mainly due to an additional appropriation increase of around 3 million euros through an amending budget approved on 31 October 2013.

1 FOLLOW-UP TO PREVIOUS YEARS' OBSERVATIONS ANNEX I Year Court's observation Status of corrective action (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a) 2011 The high levels of unspent appropriations and carry-overs made and the low payment rate indicate weaknesses in the planning and implementation of the budget and constitute a violation of the budgetary principle of annuality.
Completed 2011 The transparency of recruitment procedures needs improvement.
In addition, the questions for the written and oral tests and their respective weightings were not prepared before the applications were examined.
Completed 2012 To cover higher school fees, the agency grants a special allowance to staff whose children attend primary or secondary school, in addition to the education allowance provided for in the Staff Regulations1.
In 2012, the special allowances totaled around 23,000 euros.
They are not covered by the Staff Regulations and are therefore illegal.

These transfers of appropriations are mainly related to the ongoing implementation of the REMIT regulation.
As these implementation measures are part of the Agency's operational activities, they should have been budgeted under Title III.

Governance on the incentives and on a common method for assessing the higher risks involved in investments in electricity and gas transmission infrastructure.
Management Board Composition The Management Board consists of two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Tasks The Management Board adopts the Agency's annual work program and adopts its budget.
He ensures that the Agency fulfills its mission and carries out the tasks assigned to it in accordance with the Agency Regulation.
Director The Director is appointed by the Management Board, after a favorable opinion of the Board of Regulators, on the basis of a list of candidates proposed by the Commission.
Board of Regulators Composition The Board of Regulators consists of a senior representative of the regulatory authorities of each Member State and a non-voting representative of the Commission.
Each member has an alternate appointed by each Member State's national regulatory authority.
Tasks − The Board of Regulators submits opinions to the Director on opinions, recommendations and decisions that are under consideration for adoption. − He guides the Director in carrying out his duties. − He gives an opinion to the Management Board on the candidate to be appointed Director. − He approves the work program of the agency.

C 449/20 Official Journal of the European Union 1.12.2016 EN Court's observation The Agency carried over 1.57 million euro or 62 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2013: 3.1 million euro or .91%).
These transfers of appropriations were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT regulation, a complex multi-year operational activity for which the implementing regulation was only adopted on 17 December 2014 (1).
In addition, the Agency carried over 0.98 million euros or 41% (2013: 1.9 million euros or 56%) of the appropriations committed under Title II (Administrative Expenditure) to the following financial year. These transfers mainly concerned studies for the implementation of the REMIT regulation and annual contracts that were extended towards the end of the year.
In October 2013, the agency received an additional 3 million euros for the implementation of the REMIT regulation via an amending budget, which it carried over to 2014.
However, according to the implementing regulation, the REMIT framework will not apply until October 2015.
Some of the funds were used in 2014 to prepare for the implementation of the REMIT regulation.
At the end of 2014, the Agency made two pre-financing payments of EUR 1.56 million for contracts for REMIT-related services to be provided in 2015-2017. In this way, an automatic repayment to the Commission of unused appropriations was avoided(2).
Although this allows the Agency to fund its future REMIT-related activities, this practice is in conflict with the budgetary principle of annuality.
According to the headquarters agreement between the agency and the Slovenian government, a European school is to be established in Slovenia, but this has still not happened more than four years after the signing of the agreement.

EN 6.12.2017 Official Journal of the European Union C 417/27 Auditor's responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements and underlying transactions 11. Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements of the Agency are free from material misstatement and that the transactions underlying them are legal and regular and to provide the European Parliament and the Council or other relevant discharge authority with a statement, based on our audit, on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
Misstatements and errors may be intentional or unintentional and are considered material if individually or collectively they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.
12. An audit involves performing procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and other disclosures in the financial statements and the legality and regularity of the transactions on which they are based. The choice of audit procedures is at the discretion of the auditor. This includes assessing the risks of material - intentional or unintentional - misstatement in the financial statements and material - intentional or unintentional - violations of European Union law in the underlying transactions.
In assessing these risks, the auditor considers all internal controls relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements and the legality and regularity of underlying transactions in order to design audit procedures that are reasonable in the circumstances, but not with with the aim of issuing an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used, the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall presentation of the financial statements.
13. With regard to revenue, we review the subsidy the Agency has received from the Commission and assess its procedures for collecting fees and other revenue where relevant.
14. For expenses, we examine payment transactions after expenses are made, recorded, and accepted.
Prepayments will be checked after the beneficiary has proven their proper use and the agency has accepted the proof by clearing the prepayment Ń in the same year or later Ń.
15. In accordance with Article 208(4) of the EU Financial Regulation (6), in preparing this report and the statement of assurance, we have taken into account the work of the independent external auditor on the Agency's accounts.
16. The following observations do not call into question the Court's opinion.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the urgent need to clarify roles and responsibilities and to analyze the contracting authority's workload in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that there is a need for significant improvement in procurement planning and monitoring.
The Agency and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan.
OBSERVATIONS ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 18. The Agency carried over 4.9 million euros or 86% of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: 1.4 million euros or 59%).
As in previous years, these transfers of funds were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market(7) and amounted to EUR 4.7 million in 2016 (2015: EUR 1.1 million). . Euro).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency carried over EUR 1 million or 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million or 35%).
19. The increase in carry-overs is a concern and contradicts the budgetary principle of annuality.
The higher transmission rate is directly linked to the fact that procurement procedures and contracts are largely completed or signed towards the end of the year, which leads to a deferral of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 contracts were signed in November and December (EUR 5,976,122.47 or 40% of the total value of contracts concluded in 2016).
The Agency may consider introducing differentiated budget appropriations to better reflect the multiannual nature of activities and unavoidable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.

EN C 417/30 Official Journal of the European Union 6.12.2017 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 18. The Agency has successfully implemented the actions as agreed with the IAS.

2. The Court has audited the financial statements of the European Center for the Development of Vocational Training for the year ended 31 December 1995.
Pursuant to Article 18(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1416/76 (OJ
OJ L 181, 23.7.1993, p. 15), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
According to Articles 65, 61 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1416/76 as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1948/93, the latter is also responsible for preparing the financial statements in accordance with the financial regulations create and submit.
The Court of Auditors is required to audit these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
4. The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki.
In order to facilitate this move, certain changes were made to staff employment conditions, some of which were inconsistent with the regulations in force.
The exact circumstances are explained in paragraphs 46-66.
In addition, a number of other cases were uncovered where payments were not fully in line with the applicable regulations.
5. The Court's audit provides it with reasonable assurance that the financial statements for the financial year ended 31 December 1995 are reliable in that they accurately present 1995 revenue and expenditure and the financial position at the year end .
With the exception of the important exception in the area of expenditure mentioned in the previous paragraph, the underlying transactions were, on the whole, legal and regular.
AUDIT OBSERVATIONS General comments Background 6. The European Center for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 {l) as a satellite body of the European Community to promote vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop started its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
7. As defined in the said regulation, the role of the Center is “to support the Commission in order to promote vocational training and continuing education! to promote and further develop at community level", to make a contribution "to the implementation of a common vocational training policy" and in particular to promote the "exchange of information and experience".
In the field of vocational training, the center has the specific task of "creating documentation, contributing to the development and coordination of research, ensuring the dissemination of relevant documentation and information, promoting and supporting initiatives leading to a coordinated solution (particularly in the harmonization of training levels and mutual recognition of diplomas) and to provide a meeting place for the parties involved". 8. The Center is governed by a Management Board of 48 members (a cost of 334 000 ECU) The i1) Council Regulation (EEC) No. 337/75, published on 13 February 1975, OJ.
The board of directors elects a chairman and three deputy chairmen from among its members for a period of one year.
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Management Board was chaired by the Director-General of DG XXII — Education, Training and Youth.
The Director of the Center is appointed by the Commission from a list of candidates submitted by the Management Board.
9. According to the Basic Regulation, the Director is responsible for the day-to-day management of the Center while the Management Board has overall responsibility.
The Board of Directors takes decisions, adopts the work program and the annual report, draws up the statement of income and expenditure for the previous year and the estimate of income and expenditure for the coming year.
10. According to the Basic Regulation, the Commission's role, performed by representatives of DG XXI I, is not only to represent the interests of the Commission within the Management Board, but also to adopt the Work Programme, the Annual Report and the Revenue and Expenditure Plan to examine and forward the statement of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament.
In accordance with Article 23 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of June 1, 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 * of June 30, 1993, all commitments and payments made by the Centre before actual payment a) a reasonable cost-benefit ratio of budgetary expenditure in support of Cedefop; b) efficient use of human and other resources; c) high-quality products that meet the needs of Cedefop's customers; d) a clear and coherent role in European Community policy on vocational training.
Financial figures 14. For the financial year 1995 the Center had a budget of ECU 16.50 million.
The commitments made resulted in payments of 10.11 MECU and carry-overs to 1996 of 4.67 MECU, with the balance of 1.72 MECU being cancelled.
Of appropriations carried over from the previous year, ECU 2.16 million was paid and ECU 0.29 million cancelled.
Annex 1 to this report contains an analysis of the use of appropriations for the financial year and appropriations carried over from the 1994 financial year.
Appendix 2 gives an overview of the budget accounts for the financial year 1995 and the overview of assets and liabilities as of December 31, 1995.
Observations on implementation of the budget Separation of activities 15. After the move to Thessaloniki, the Center had not yet put in place adequate procedures to separate the activities of authorizing officer, accounting officer and imprest administrator by the time of the audit (May 1996).
For example, it was observed that the accounting officer also took on the duties of the imprest administrator.
Paying Agency 16. The proportion of payments made without the Financial Controller's approval remains high (60% in 1995 excluding salaries').
The heavy use of the imprest system is not in the spirit of the financial regulations.
A more acceptable practice would be to use the imprest account only for current and small-scale expenditure, where the risk of irregularities is comparatively low.
Transfers within the budget 17. Transfers between different budget lines totaled 922 000 ECU in 1995, ie 5.6% of the initial budget against 10.9% in 1994.
No. C 81/4 | EN | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Carry-overs (570 000 ECU) were made in the last two months of 1995, while in 1994 this figure was 33%.
18. In 1995 the Center made no transfers between titles.
Thus, observation (2) made by the Court last year has been addressed.
Carryovers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of carrying over large amounts of appropriations (3), already observed in previous years, increased in 1995.
In 1995 only 61% of the final available funds were disbursed compared to 73% in 1994.
The proportion of commitments carried over to 1996 was 28% (compared to 23% in 1994).
The proportion of funds forfeited was 10% compared to 5% in 1994.
Table 1 shows, by title, the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use.
20. Carry-overs in the area of operational expenditure amounted to 53% of the initial appropriations compared to 40% in 1994.
As 8% of appropriations for operational expenditure was cancelled, this means that in 1995 the Center paid out only 39% of its 1995 operational budget.
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34% of the 1995 funds carried over within Title 3 had been disbursed.
21. The high number of budget carry-overs and cancellations, as well as the high level of carry-overs to the next financial year, suggest that the work program was not implemented as planned and the principles of sound financial management were jeopardized.
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 to 45) will have a serious impact on the implementation of the 1996 budget.
Observations on the accounts and the balance sheet Revenue (subsidy from the Commission) 22. The subsidy charged to the general budget of the Communities for the financial year 1995 was paid by the Commission in several tranches. The first tranche of 2 300 000 ECU was paid on 6 February 1995, followed by further tranches of 2 400 000 ECU on 20 April 1995 and 2 500 000 ECU on 28 June 1995 2 800 000 ECU on 5 October 1995, 5 875 000 ECU on 22 November 1995 and 525 000 ECU on 1 December 1995.
As in previous years (4), this payment rhythm is not consistent (2) Court's 1994 annual report.
(3) Annual reports of the Court for the financial years 1992, 1993 with Article 26 of the Financial Regulations for the Center according to which payments are to be made in the first half of each quarter and are to be adjusted to actual needs.
Expenditure 23. Following the decision to move the Center to Thessaloniki, a new Deputy Director was appointed in 1994, who was then living and working in Thessaloniki.
Servant moved to Berlin and received an installation allowance of twice his basic salary. Less than a year later, ie after the center had moved to Thessaloniki, the same staff member again received an installation allowance of twice his basic salary.
Since the transfer of the center was rapid, the official's stay in Berlin was short-lived (11 months); in addition, he spent part of this time in Thessaloniki, also receiving full daily allowances (including weekends). The Court ^ considers that these decisions are contrary to the principle of sound financial management and to Cedefop's interests.
24. The contract of another deputy director, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995', was terminated by the Administrative Board with effect from 3 1 .
This official subsequently received a payment of ECU 71 030.
The Court considers that the Management Board's decision is not in accordance with the principles of sound financial management.
25. Pursuant to Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, contracts may be awarded by private treaty , if the contract value does not exceed 12 000 ECU.
In at least 12 cases contracts were awarded for an amount in excess of ECU 12 000 without following the procurement procedure described in Article 45 of the said Regulation.
26. Almost 40% of the commitments on the 'Pilot Studies and Projects' budget line for the financial year 1995 (ECU 300 000) were made in the last two months of 1995.
An amount of ECU 150 572 was committed from the budget line 'Exchanges of officials and experts' to cover the remuneration of one expert who started working at Cedefop on 1 February 1996 and another expert whose contract ended on 22 December was signed in 1995.
These funds were committed hastily so as not to let the funds expire.
27. Cedefop's temporary premises rent for January. 1996 (ECU 22 750) has already been included in the 1995 accounts.
Since this expenditure relates to the 1996 financial year, it should also have been charged to 1996. and 1994.
The Court urges the Center to draw up an up-to-date inventory as soon as possible, as required by Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948 /93 of the Council of June 30, 1993.
29. The balance sheet shows an outstanding amount of ECU 3 134 for an invoice issued in 1991, among the outstanding debts from the previous financial year.
The Court's observation (5) made last year has not been taken into account, although the Center had given an undertaking in its reply.
The Court recommends that the Center write off this amount unless there is reason to believe that this amount will be recovered.
30. At the end of the year the Center had treasury balances of ECU 5.9 million.
The Center thus bears responsibility for managing large amounts of treasury, although it has little expertise in this area.
The Court reiterates the observation made last year (6) that this situation should be avoided by the Center making the quarterly calls for funds from the Commission more in line with its real cash needs. - At the same time, the Commission should ensure that it receives a realistic liquidity forecast from the Center before making its payments.
Relocation of the Center to Thessaloniki General comments ^B 31. The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki in Greece (7).
32. The actual transfer to Thessaloniki took place in August 1995 and in September 1995 the Center started operations in Greece.
According to the Court's calculations, the 1995 accounts include approximately ECU 3 300 000 for relocation-related expenses.
33. Since 1 September 1995 the center has been housed in a building belonging to the Thessaloniki Institute of Agriculture and Industry.
No later than September 1, 1999, the Greek State will provide the center with a building for permanent accommodation.
The Center has signed four agreements (i) Court's 1994 annual report.
(6) Annual Report of the Court for the financial year 1994.
(7) Council Decision 93/C 323/01 of October 29, 1993, OJ C 323 of November 30, 1993, p relate to accommodation.
The basic agreement between Cedefop and the Greek State was signed on 22 June 1995 in Thessaloniki.
The three other agreements, including an agreement between the Greek State and the organization responsible for the overall construction, are part of this basic agreement.
Temporary accommodation 34. The Centre's temporary building has an annual rent of ECU 273 000, payable direct to the owner.
35. Pursuant to Article 1 of the agreement between the Greek State and the Center, the Greek State is making the building with the temporary premises and all associated installations available to Cedefop from 1 September 1995.
The Greek authorities are responsible for the electrical and electronic cable connections as well as for the telephone connections.
36. When the building was handed over, the Center did not raise any written objections.
However, during the first four months in Thessaloniki (September to December 1995) the Center had to invest ECU 120 000 to make the building containing the temporary premises operational.
Among other things, electronic and electrical cable connections as well as telephone connections had to be laid.
37. These investments were fully borne by the Center and the corresponding costs were included in the 1995 budget accounts.
The agreements do not contain a clear statement as to who is responsible for these investments.
Permanent housing 38. The Greek State is obliged to make a building available to the Center for permanent housing by 1 September 1999 at the latest.
For the construction of the building, Cedefop will pay the Greek State a total of 6 879 750 ECU, to be paid in four equal tranches of 1 719 937 ECU each.
Payment dates for the first three tranches were September 1, 1995, September 1, 1996 and September 1, 1997.
The final installment will be paid upon final handover of the building.
39. The Center has not ensured that these payments are linked to the actual progress of the works.
The center will have already paid an amount of ECU 5 159 811 more than two years before the handover of the building.
40. The Court recommends that the Center ensure that the interest on the first tranche is used for the benefit of the project.
No. C 81/6 | EN | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 41. The Center should ensure that the Employee Accommodation Organization (OEK) responsible for the overall implementation of the work represents Cedefop's interests.
Staff: general comments 42. The 1995 establishment plan foresees 79 posts, of which 24À,11LA,15B,26C and 3D. At the time of the audit (May 1996) 37 people actually worked for Cedefop (14A, 7B, 14C and 2D) , 11 people had been taken on by other EU institutions, 14 people had left the center before moving to Thessaloniki and 17 people had decided to stay in Berlin.
In 1995 and 1996 a large number of new employees had to be hired and this trend will continue in 1996.
43. The 17 people remaining in Berlin are free to work for public and private bodies or other EU institutions, while continuing to receive their salary for a maximum period of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each year of service corresponds to one month's salary , the minimum period of service must be 6 months).
After this period, those affected can either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution.
One of the consequences of this situation is that Cedefop is unable to fill these 17 posts (May 1996) as they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled as those concerned may decide at a later date to move to Thessaloniki after all.
44. It is unclear what will happen to those from this group of 17 who do not wish to move to Thessaloniki after the specified length of stay in Berlin.
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides as follows: 'An official shall reside at the place where he is employed or at a sufficient distance from that place as is compatible with the proper performance of his duties'.
Separately, three cases involving staff who refused to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought before the EU's Court of Justice.
45. This situation, with 17 key budgeted posts being blocked by staff not currently working for Cedefop, had a major impact on Cedefop's work already in 1995 and will continue to do so in 1996-1997.
Personnel: change of status 46. I n Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 337/75 of February 10, 1975 as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No. 251/95 of February 6, 1995 means es: 'The staff of the Center are subject to the rules and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Center shall exercise the powers conferred on the Appointing Authority in relation to its staff.
The Centre's Management Board, in consultation with the Commission, will adopt the relevant implementing rules."
Council Regulation (EC) No. 251/95 also repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No. 1859/76 of June 29, 1976 laying down the conditions of employment for the staff of the European Promotion Centre of vocational training.
The change was necessary in order to 'make the management of the staff of each decentralized body (...) consistent at Community level' (8).
However, while the staff of the Center have been appointed officials, the staff of the other decentralized bodies are made up of temporary staff.
47. The Court has examined the changes to the conditions of employment and other agreements between the Management Board and staff and found a number of irregularities. The most serious irregularities from the Court's point of view are described in paragraphs 49 to 66.
48. The Management Board did not submit these agreements to the Financial Controller for his approval.
Nevertheless, all commitments resulting from these agreements were processed through the imprest procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's approval.
Appointment of staff as officials 49. In connection with the move to Thessaloniki, the Center has taken the following measures to adjust the situation of its staff: — As a first step, on 1 March 1995 all staff members were appointed as temporary staff (Articles 2 b of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities), in the same grade and step as contractual servants. — In a second step, these officials were recruited as EU officials from 1 April 1995, following an internal competition "arranged" solely on the basis of qualifications.
Breach of the Staff Regulations in relation to the step in the initial appointment of Cedefop's former contract agents as temporary agents η 50. On the initial appointment of Cedefop's contract agents as temporary agents on 1 March 1995, would have none of the staff may be classified at a higher step than step 3 (or at step 4 for grades A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No. 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending the Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 establishing Cedefop, fourth recital.
13. 3. 97 |~EN~1 Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/7 to A 4, LA 3 and LA 4) (see Article 32 of the Staff Regulations applicable to temporary staff pursuant to Article 15 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants is applicable).
51. Nonetheless, 33 of Cedefop's 59 temporary staff were placed at a seniority higher than level 3.
Abuse of powers in the organization of the internal competition for the appointment of former Cedefop contract staff to officials 52. On 1 March 1995 the Center published 15 linked vacancy notices and announcements of internal competitions.
F ollowing these competitions, all former Cedefop employees were promoted to civil servants. ^w' 53. According to the Staff Regulations, the purpose of a competition is to organize a competition between several candidates with a view to filling the vacancy with the most qualified candidate (Article 27(1) of the Staff Regulations).
A selection procedure is therefore, by definition, associated with a competitive situation and the risk of failure. made (10).
As a result, appointment decisions following a selection procedure in which there has been a misuse of powers are to be regarded as unlawful ( n ) .
56. The Commission's Legal Service came to the same conclusion, as confirmed by its note of 4 January 1995, paragraph (c) (12).
57. Since the objective of the competitions in question was different from that set out in the Staff Regulations, it must be assumed that the competitions organized by Cedefop involved a misuse of powers and must therefore be regarded as unlawful.
Violation of the Staff Regulations in relation to the classification in the appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff to officials 58. According to Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, Cedefop staff members should have been appointed officials from 1 April 1995 as follows: — Officials in category A or Language Service (LA): in the starting grade of their category or career (ie A 7 or LA 7) (Article 31(1)); — Officials of the other categories: in the starting grade corresponding to the post to which they were recruited (ie Β 1, Β 3 or Β 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4 ) (Article 31, paragraph 2); — up to half of the appointments, exceptional staff members may be appointed to the next higher grade; this applies to every six posts to be filled within each salary group (Article 31, paragraph 2 b).
59. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff were appointed to a grade higher than the starting grade of their career (13).
(10) Judgment of 29.9.1976, Case 105/75 GI UFFRI DA v COUNCIL, ECR p. 1395. (n) Judgment in GI UFFRI DA case, see above.
(12)A selection procedure involves, by definition, a risk of failure and there are obvious legal reasons why this margin of risk should remain.
(13)Out of 17 staff appointed to A grade, 13 were appointed to a grade higher than A7 (the Staff Regulations limit appointments to six); all five LA staff were appointed to a higher grade than LA 7 (the Staff Regulations do not provide for this possibility); out of 18 staff in category C, 12 were appointed to a higher grade than the starting grade of their career (the Staff Regulations limit appointments to six); two out of three staff members in category D were appointed to a higher grade than the starting grade of their career (the Staff Regulations do not provide for this possibility). ^ ^ 54. The 15 competitions organized by Cedefop, on the other hand, had a completely different purpose, as they dealt with the situation of staff after moving to Thessaloniki.
No C 81/8 EN Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Failure to comply with the obligations relating to the probationary period 60. Before a staff member can be established as an official, he must successfully complete a probationary period (Article 34 of the Staff Regulations). The probationary period must therefore be followed by an objective retrospective assessment of the probationer.
61. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, the probationers were informed beforehand that their appointment would be permanent. The probationary period was clearly described in advance as a necessary "legal formality" which was not really to be regarded as a probationary test (paragraph 4.1 of the "framework agreement"; letter of 7 February 1995 to the probationers, subparagraph 2 and paragraph 1 f of the Annex: The probationary period is a legal formality which as such must be completed by every probationer). ·» Unlawful secondment of officials during the probationary period 62. According to Article 38 of the Staff Regulations, only permanent officials can be seconded to other institutions, ie officials who have already successfully completed the probationary period.
65. This means that a system has been put in place whereby up to 50% of staff salaries are transferred in a currency to which a higher weighting applies (namely the weighting applicable to Germany of 111.4%) than Thessaloniki (for Greece a weighting of 80.2% applies) .
Unequal treatment vis-à-vis other civil servants through the introduction of special mobility provisions 66. The Commission has given a commitment to the Center to introduce specific regulation provisions on mobility.
These provisions contradict the principle of equal treatment for all civil servants.
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants are applicable to the Centre's staff.
This means that all the provisions contained therein apply to the staff of the Centre, including Article 29(1)(c) which concerns the transfer of officials to other institutions.
Thus there is no justification for special treatment in relation to mobility. Summary | 67. The Court's audit revealed that the Center's work program was not being carried out as planned due to serious staff shortages.
This led to large-scale transfers and cancellations of funds.
The audit also revealed that no functioning administrative and accounting procedures have yet been put in place.
68. Two Deputy Directors received remuneration equal to four months' base salary. These payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in accordance with sound financial management and the interests of the Centre.
69. At the time of the Court's audit there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 people were actually working at the Centre.
17 staff members had been appointed as EU officials', although they did not want to move to Thessaloniki, nor had they been transferred to another Community institution.
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that, in the context of the move to Thessaloniki, efforts were made to retain staff in the EU institutions and to reduce the complicated problems associated with the move.
The problem, however, is that the regulatory framework "within which the move had to be carried out, even after the changes to the conditions of employment, was not consistent with fair treatment of senior staff and did not allow Cedefop to move smoothly without disrupting its activities .
This report was approved by the Court of Auditors at its meeting of 21 November 1996 in Luxembourg.
