The Management Board will follow the structure of the Court's observations and conclusions.
3. The Governing Body has a reasonable expectation that all institutions and decentralized bodies will be treated in an equal manner and on the basis of the same professional standards and practices that ensure equal treatment.
4. The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention essential facts which could be summarized as follows: — The European Council decision of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the implications of such a transfer.
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to move by 1 September 1995, a timetable which CEDEFOP respected despite the problems caused by the Centre's relocation. — The chairman of the board of directors sent a letter to the responsible commissioners, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti.
On 18 November 1994, the President and Vice-Presidents of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were received by the members of the Commission.
The Chairman urgently appealed to the Commission to develop social support measures, particularly for those officials who were unable to leave Berlin.
In view of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were ready to examine the specific problems of some staff members in a positive and pragmatic spirit.
They also expected the same from the other institutions of the community (European Parliament, Council etc.) December 1994 unable to decide when to move as it did not seem acceptable to simply dismiss staff who could not move to Thessaloniki without a modern social plan.
At the same meeting, the Board instructed the Director to prepare a Board resolution (to be taken at an extraordinary meeting on January 27, 1995) providing for a socially acceptable relocation of the Center as of September 1st. "— In the second half of December 1994, the Council began examining the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the regulation applicable to CEDEFOP, which provided that the staff of the Center should comply with the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants in the European Communities subject to regulations.
The director took this change as a basis for formulating the framework agreement on the social accompanying measures related to the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki.
On January 23, 1995, the framework agreement was signed with the staff.
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved very helpful throughout the transition period (1994-1996). — The Management Board decided to accept the framework agreement and to move the center to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995.
3/13/97 | P Ë Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13 able to move to Thessaloniki.
According to the framework agreement, officials unable to leave Berlin chose to make themselves available to other EU institutions or public/private organizations and to receive a salary from the Center for at least six months, with one month's salary for each commenced year of service was paid.
The principle of paying a monthly salary for each year of service largely corresponds to the social plans and usual procedures in Germany and neighboring countries. — Early retirement was considered in 1995 for 17 staff (over 55 with 10 years of service and over 50 with 15 years of service).
These measures were not part of the framework agreement and were ultimately not proposed by the Commission due to the decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the "redundancy" of officials in connection with the accession of new Member States only for officials of the European Parliament.
The Governing Body will reply in more detail in its comments on paragraphs 46-66.
In general, it should be emphasized that the political aspects are to be taken seriously and subsequent criticism is to be avoided.
The relocation of an entire community facility within the restrictive framework of a large number of different ordinances and in the face of a considerable range of social and individual problems is indeed unique in the history of the community.
5. The Directors will come back to the exception mentioned in the last sentence later in this reply.
8. The cost of Governing Body meetings in 1995 is due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the relocation.
In addition, the December 1995 meeting incurred higher costs due to the official start of operations in Greece.
Only two meetings are planned for 1996.
13. The Management Board regrets that the Court has not reacted to the European Parliament's decision to postpone the discharge for the 1994 budget.
This raises serious questions as: — the discharge for 1994 should be seen in the context of the Court of Auditors' report for 1994 and the Council's recommendation to grant discharge and should follow normal rules and practice; — The European Parliament's appraisal of the 1995 financial year, without a report from the Court of Auditors for 1995 on which the Management Board could have commented, leads to a mixture of very different situations; — the center was transferred to Greece in 1995.
The installation went smoothly and under acceptable conditions.
This transfer requires a transitional period which cannot be completed until 1997 because of the disruption to which staff have been subjected.
15. There has been a noticeable improvement in this regard.
In the initial phase in Thessaloniki, the officials helped each other to get the work done.
16. As already pointed out last year, the increased use of the imprest procedure was at the request of the Financial Controller, who justified this with the cost-benefit ratio. The previous system caused high express delivery costs and caused delays.
It also meant that the financial controller had to work more frequently.
The use of the imprest procedure for all expenditure that might require provisional commitments limited administrative costs and avoided delays.
The situation is made even more difficult by the payment arrangements in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by check).
Invoices showing bank details are rare; the contractors collect their claims themselves.
The geographical distance to the financial controller and the lack of reliability of mail delivery also have to be taken into account.
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (Bfrs 3,000 per shipment).
An amendment to the decision establishing the imprest system will shortly be submitted to the Management Board to better accommodate the Court of Auditors' wishes.
17. The transfers of appropriations in the last two months are explained by the need to make the best use of the budget (of which 2 000 000 ECU had been set aside and only released just before the center moved to Thessaloniki) and by the decision of the Management Board (7 /8.12.1995) to hire seconded national experts according to the specifications of the Commission (also to promote the work of the Centre).
19. The Governing Body recognized that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal.
A certain drop in productivity is inevitable in this international transfer, which the Board of Directors considers to have been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner.
The center is still facing problems related to the transition period.
20. As the center was relocated with a greatly reduced number of staff, the work of the administration and all other services slowed down.
For this reason, a non-automatic transfer of funds has been requested and approved.
No. C 81/14 | EN Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 22. The Management Board notes that the Commission is making every effort to comply with the provisions of Article 26 of the Financial Regulations for the Center and to adjust the grant according to actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter to be paid out.
In 1995 compared to 1994 there was an improvement here.
However, due to the lengthy internal procedures (involving the authorizing authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer) and the length of the bank's transfer procedure, an overall delay in the processing time (12 days on average in 1995) cannot be totally avoided.
However, in 1995, three payments came close to complying with the provisions of Article 26, arriving at the Center less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter.
If the processing time for all payments (which varied between 9 and 22 days) had been the average time of 12 days, then all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Regulations.
The first payment did not comply with the regulations, but this payment must be preceded by the commitment, which takes time.
23. The Deputy Director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because of uncertainty about the actual date of the Centre's transfer.
At the time of the appointment (October 1, 1994) no decision had been taken on the date of the move (which could have been further postponed).
It was hoped that his stay would be brief, but its ultimate duration was then unknown.
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of status.
Per diem allowances for missions were granted according to the same procedure as for other staff.
As for the second installation grant, the deputy director returned this sum to the center after the audit, although he should have been entitled in full.
24. At its June 1995 meeting, the Management Board terminated his contract with effect from 31 December 1995 and instructed the Director to implement this decision and arrange for the statutory payments to be made.
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was willing to assist in the implementation of the 1995 work program and to assist the Center in its relaunch in Thessaloniki.
The indemnity (the payment of one-third of his basic salary from the time his duties ended until the end of his contract) was in accordance with his contract and Article 47 CEOS.
25. Given the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Center was not able to carry out the usual tendering procedures in each individual case.
Tendering procedures are ongoing or planned for 1996 for longer-term contracts.
In addition, to ensure balanced budget management throughout the year, the Management Board will frontload the adoption of the work program to allow the services the necessary time to call for tenders, make commitments and conclude the relevant contracts in the early months of the financial year.
26. The 40% of the commitments in favor of the "Pilot Studies and Projects" budget line (ECU 300 000) were made in the last months of the year, reflecting the late release by the budgetary authority of the appropriations set aside in the 1995 budget and the relocation of the Center to Thessaloniki was due.
The Center had to act consistently and consistently, having no choice but to meet its financial commitments under Titles I and II first and could only commit further under Title III once the deferred funds had been released.
The possibility of seconding national experts was recognized by the Management Board at its December 1995 meeting and could only be funded from the appropriations set aside.
The Director had to act quickly and within a short space of time to prevent funds (which became available only very late) from lapsed.
The (Austrian) expert's application (which was officially approved by the government) was already available at the beginning of 1995.
27. The reason for recording January 1996 rent in the 1995 financial statements was purely practical.
According to the contract, the rent has to be paid in advance in two installments on January 1st and July 1st.
Since the first payment was not made until October 1995 and it would have been difficult to pay again immediately on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months including January 1996.
28. Inventory update is in progress.
29. This will be complied with.
30. The Center ensures that it provides the Commission with a realistic forecast of cash flows.
The last payment of the year should be the largest, as it must also cover the first few months of the following year, when larger payments are usually made.
31. See comments on paragraph 4. 32. The administration of the Center is making an assessment of the costs of the transfer and an assessment of developments in order to have a full picture of the costs and benefits of the transfer to Greece.
13. 3. 97 I EN 1 ^ Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/15 36-37.
Since the center was expected to resume operations immediately after the move, some additional investment and changes were required.
It was noted that the agreements are not clear on this because the center needed more power outlets and heavier computer cables than the existing ones.
Other investments related to additional security requirements and communication facilities, such as "Europe by Satellite" to be able to receive broadcasts directly from the institutions.
However, the Center has placed issues relating to the temporary building on the agenda of the steering committee, which is dealing with the new and (if necessary) the temporary building.
The Board is aware of the fact that the content of the agreement on the new building placed a great deal of responsibility on the Greek government, which is currently fulfilling the agreement.
Two points are of particular concern: — ensuring the delivery of a quality building at a reasonable price; — ensuring the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998).
The fact that substantial payments were made in advance (half of the building is already paid for even though the construction work has not yet started) may also have a positive impact as the actual construction work (after the selection of the construction plan and construction company in October/November 1996) could proceed rapidly given the immediate availability of the necessary funds.
In general, the Management Board fully understands the concerns of the Court, which were also shared by Members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Center on 1-2. or on 14./15. visited in May.
The Management Board stands ready to act on this issue in accordance with the Commission's recommendations.
42. The staffing situation was very complicated due to the various accompanying social measures, but all the people on CEDEFOP's payroll who were not made available to other organizations or seconded to Berlin were working for CEDEFOP and its work programme.
43. The Management Board took the decision on the social measures accompanying the transfer (framework agreement) in order to "take appropriate measures as soon as possible" (see the statements contained in the minutes of the Council).
The evaluation of the measures must therefore take into account their political background.
The center is located in Thessaloniki and the board of directors and the director decide on the organization of the work.
Certainly some items are blocked while the accompanying social measures are effective.
However, by the end of 1996 almost all measures will come to an end and Cedefop will then be able to work at full capacity on the basis of the medium-term priorities (to be decided by the Management Act in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which is also based on these priorities.
From 1997, CEDEFOP will therefore move forward with a revitalized and new approach.
44. Those persons who, for social or personal reasons, cannot leave Berlin when the specified length of their stay in Berlin ends have three alternatives.
In this regard, the President of the Court of First Instance issued three orders dismissing the motions for interim proceedings.
These people have to move, leave the service of the center or find other solutions according to the statute.
45. The impact in 1996 is of course severe, but after the first few months of 1997 it will be minimal.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, if you compare it to a similar move at national level, such as that of CEREQ (Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 staff moved with the centre), then there have been differences would not result in an excessively negative impact on CEDEFOP given an international deployment over a distance of almost 2 000 km.
Cautious cost estimates suggest that cost neutrality will be achieved by the year 2000 and that work will be even more cost effective thereafter (mainly due to lower labor costs in Greece). 46th-66th
The points raised require some general comments first: a) As the Court points out in its conclusion (71.), it is understandable that efforts have been made to support the staff in order to encourage them to continue working for the EU institutions and to alleviate the difficult problems of laying. b) However, it is not the fault of the Management Board "that the regulatory framework within which the move took place [...] was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff and did not allow for a smooth transfer of CEDEFOP". c ) Following the decision of the Management Board of January 27, 1995, the Council on February 6, 1995 (Regulation (EC) No. 251/95) amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No. 337/75 so that “the staff of the Center is subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities".
Despite the absence of transitional provisions, as was the case when Council Regulation (EEC, Eur: torn, EGSC) No. 269/68 was adopted (see Article 102 of the status of officials of the European
No. C 81/16 | D Ë | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 and Article 99 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities) was the case, account should have been taken of the fact that the officials of CEDEFOP could very well be regarded as 'officials of the European Communities', although they were subject to an ad hoc Council regulation d) In the absence of any transitional measures provided for by Community legislation, the Management Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDE-FOP officials e ) It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95, which changed CEDEFOP's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki, meant a sudden change in the place of work listed in the employment contracts: Berlin had been the for 20 years only seat of CEDEFOP and at no time since 10 February 1975 has there been the slightest indication of it, i.e ate that seat could be moved, let alone to another Member State far away.
On this basis, CEDEFOP employees entered into an employment relationship and based their private decisions (employment of the spouses, education of the children) accordingly. (f) In view of these circumstances, the Governing Body had the duty: — to provide staff with a high degree of security as regards their job (appointment as permanent officials), — to ensure the maintenance of their category, grade and step, and — to staff to help those who wish to find another job. g) The Management Board would also like to point out that the posts granted to Cedefop by the Budgetary Authority were permanent posts.
According to Articles 2 and 8 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the EC, these posts can only be filled by officials or temporary staff. h) In addition, the wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 ("The staff of the Center shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities") clearly provides for the employment of civil servants.
Given the permanent nature of the positions held by the staff, the choice of civil servant status over temporary contracts was appropriate and justified.
The Governing Body would also like to comment on the specific points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Governing Body had the choice to either appoint the staff to permanent status or to offer them two-year contracts (see opinion under point g) above).
It was considered unacceptable to require staff to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract.
48. Although it is true that the Management Board did not officially submit the agreements to the Financial Controller for approval, the latter was informed of the decisions taken.
At the time the agreement was signed, it was not clear what the exact financial impact of the agreement would be due to the pending individual decisions of the staff.
It provided a framework that provided the basis for individual decisions and received the full endorsement of the Financial Controller during his visit to Berlin.
50-51.
In view of the argument listed under e) above, the decision taken (see comment, second indent) was the only possible one.
It was also in line with the Commission's unequivocal statement (see last sentence of the statement for the Council minutes attached) "that there must be no deterioration in the employment conditions for Cedefop staff".
The considerations of the Commission's Legal Service, only partially quoted in paragraph 56, leave sufficient scope for such a decision.
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations authorizes the appointing authority to hold internal competitions for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (point lb).
The selection procedures were carried out in full compliance with Annex III of the Staff Regulations.
55. The Governing Body had the aim and duty of ensuring that as many CEDEFOP officials as possible agreed to move to Thessaloniki.
It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the rules applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of the same year.
The Management Board's action was based on the following considerations: — it was unthinkable to require staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (comment under g) and paragraph 46 above); — there was not enough time to organize an open competition before moving to Thessaloniki and again it would not have been realistic to expect staff to move without a secure job offer.
13. 3. 97 I EN | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/17 56-59/ The Management Board has already explained (see above, comment under e)) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change of place of work, which inevitably caused social problems and for affects productivity for a period of time.
Requiring staff to move after being assigned a lower grade or step would have made their situation even worse.
The note of the Legal Service of the Commission, which is mentioned in paragraph 56, provides under subparagraph d) sufficient arguments to justify the position taken by the Centre. 60th-61st
All staff applying for permanent appointment served the probationary period required by Article 34 of the Status.
62. According to note f), 3rd indent above, the Governing Body considered it its duty to assist the staff in an acceptable manner.
This was also the view of the Commission's Legal Service.
65. The provisions governing the transfer modalities of part of the salary allow this percentage to be increased from 35% to 50% in individual cases where there are legitimate reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation.
The framework agreement made it possible to transfer a higher percentage (> 35%' according to the Statute, but < 50% ) .
The application of these rules is completely different in the case of CEDEFOP and affects only a limited number of people with high liabilities in Berlin.
66. The Management Board thanks the Commission for the assistance it has given in a number of cases in finding alternative employment opportunities for staff who have not been able to relocate to Thessaloniki and for any other assistance they have given to the Centre almost daily during the move.
68. See comments of the Governing Body to paragraphs 23 and 24. 69.-70.
See in particular the general comments at paragraphs 46-66.
71. The Management Board regrets that the legislator has not introduced any transitional legal arrangements in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 to solve the difficult staffing problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki.
Given the lack of suitable instruments, the Governing Board was all the more obliged to support CEDEFOP's staff to the best of its ability.
The Directors believe they have acted in the only acceptable manner in the given and truly unprecedented circumstances.
Ultimately, it was obvious that he had to make such an effort (as the Court recognizes) since it is his duty as an employer to promote international . of a complete institution in a socially responsible manner.
The Board of Directors, Director and staff acted in this positive spirit, possibly taking some risks but not abusing power or acting illegally.

The Court of Auditors is required to audit these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
3. The Court has conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards as far as these are applicable in the Community context. Accordingly, it carried out financial controls and applied other audit procedures which it considered necessary in this context. 4. In the Court's opinion, the financial statements for the year ended 3 1 .
Established for the financial year ending December 1995, its mission is "to contribute to the design and creation of better living and working conditions through an action to promote and disseminate knowledge capable of supporting this development".
The Dublin Foundation began operations in 1976.
Scope of audit 6. The Court of Auditors has audited the Dublin Foundation's 1995 annual accounts and budget, in accordance with the relevant regulations (2).
Financial figures 7. For the financial year 1995 the Foundation had funds of ECU 12.5 million at its disposal.
The commitments made resulted in payments of 9.3 MECU and carry-overs to 1996 of 3 MECU, with the balance of 0.2 MECU being cancelled.
Of the appropriations carried over from the previous year, ECU 1.9 million was paid and ECU 0.2 million cancelled.
Annex 3 to this report contains an analysis by title of the use of appropriations for the year and of appropriations carried over from 1994.
Follow-up to previous observations Separation of duties 8. The Court reiterates its observation made in previous years that the duties of the authorizing officer and the accounting officer are not sufficiently separated.
This is contrary to Article 15 of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1417/76, according to which the principle of "separation of authorizing officer and accounting" applies and the "activities of the authorizing officer , the financial controller and the accounting officer [...] are incompatible with each other."
Paying Agency 9. A large proportion (1995: 5 9% , excluding salaries) of payments continue to be made without prior approval by a financial controller.
The extent to which the imprest account is used is not within the meaning of the financial regulations.
It would be more acceptable if only (2) Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 of 26 May . 1975 on the founding of the foundation (OJ
L 139 of May 30, 1975), amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1947/93 of June 30, 1993 (OJ

The Foundation, in consultation with the Financial Controller, should define in writing what is meant by current and minor expenses.
Title-to-title transfers 10. The Foundation continued to make title-to-title transfers in 1995 (see paragraph 16).
This is contrary to Article 21 of Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 494 000 ECU (11.9% of the appropriations entered in the budget), compared to 756 000 ECU (6.5%) in 1994.
16. Transfers of appropriations amounting to ECU 500 000 from Title 1 (Staff) to Title 3 (Operating expenditure) allowed the Foundation to carry forward to the following financial year commitments which would otherwise have been committed in accordance with Article 6(1) of Regulation (EEC) No 1949/ 93 of the Council amending Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1417/76 should have been cancelled.
As stated in paragraph 10, the Court considers that such transfers from title to title are contrary to the financial regulation.

Income 18. The EU grant to the Foundation in 1995 was ECU 12.5 million.

The difference of ECU 2.4 million corresponded to unneeded treasury funds not called from the Commission, following the Court's recommendation last year.
As in previous years, this funding pattern is not compatible with Article 26 of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1417/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1949/93, according to which the subsidy is paid in the first half of each quarter is paid.
Expenditure 19. Pursuant to Article 63 of Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1949/93 of June 30, 1993 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No. 1417/76 of June 1, 1976, orders with a value of more than 12 000 ECU to be awarded following a call for tenders.

13. 3. 97 I EN | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/25 ANSWER 8. The Foundation has introduced a number of measures to separate the duties of the authorizing officer and the accounting officer.
The Court of Auditors has noted these initiatives in previous reports.
The only remaining problem in practice is the procedure by which the authorizing officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system.
This problem will be solved once the Foundation has purchased a new accounting system.
Following consultations in 1995, in 1996 the Foundation took part in a joint tender with other EU agencies to purchase a suitable accounting system.
However, the result was that none of the candidates fully met the institutions' requirements.
Following extensive contacts with the Commission services, the Foundation is expected to purchase an appropriate accounting system from the Commission during 1997, having recently completed work on a corresponding system which will meet the Agencies' technical and legal requirements.
9. The Foundation has contacted the Commission services with a view to finding solutions to the problem identified.
The Foundation has since been informed that this issue is being discussed between the Commission and the European Parliament as part of the ongoing dialogue on the agencies' financial regulations.
10. Following the last report of the Court of Auditors, the Foundation asked the Commission services for clarification of the Financial Regulation of the Foundation in relation to the transfers concerned.
The Foundation is now informed by the Directorate-General from DG XIX that the transfers have been made in accordance with the Foundation's Financial Regulations (see also paragraph 16).
11. All missions within the Foundation were documented and authorized by the Authorizing Officer after ensuring that they were in line with the Foundation's work program or administrative requirements.
The Foundation will review its procedures for recording and locating the necessary documentation related to missions.
The regulation establishing the foundation stipulates that the European bodies are to be consulted and that the social partners are to be involved in their work.
Although exchanges between THE FOUNDATION and the relevant EU bodies in Brussels have intensified in recent years, the number of business trips to Brussels has not increased.
No business trips will be made if other means of communication can be used.
Telephone, internet, e-mail and other electronic means are used as far as possible. A videoconferencing pilot project was also launched in November 1995.
Likewise, experiments with computer conferences have also been carried out.
14. Lawyers are currently preparing a revised lease agreement on the basis of a proposal submitted by the Irish authorities.
16. As indicated in paragraph 10 above, the Foundation has been informed by the Commission that the transfers concerned are fully in line with the Financial Regulation. With their help , the Foundation has been able to make the most efficient use of the funds made available to it by the decisions of the budgetary authorities.
However, the Foundation appreciates the position of the Court of Auditors and Parliament and endeavors to make such transfers only in urgent cases.
These contracts mainly related to studies with implementation periods of 12 months or more.
18. The Foundation will again remind the Commission services that grant payments must be made by the 15th of each quarter.
19. In the case of the contract to carry out a European study on working conditions, the relevant file shows that this contract was concluded under the framework contract for the "Eurobaromètre-Standard" drawn up as a result of an open tendering procedure between the European Commission and INRA (Europe). was.
The direct award of contracts was fully in line with the procedure and criteria to be respected in Article 46 of the Foundation's Financial Regulation. These will be followed. Article 46 paragraph d) was applied to the supply of computers.
Only one supplier had the required software and dedicated multilingual keyboards and provided local support: the other two contracts relate to research proposals.
The Management Board of the Foundation, at its meeting of 25 March 1994, approved the introduction of new procedures, which should be fully operational during 1995, for the award of contracts based on calls for expressions of interest published in the Official Journal and of tenders.
The two contracts were entered into during the transition period determined by the Board of Directors.
20. The Foundation operates a decentralized ordering system.
The two invoices were part of a series of orders placed by an operational entity whose total orders exceeded committed funds.
Appropriate measures will be taken to ensure that this does not happen again.
The deployment of a new accounting system should ensure the automatic implementation of the necessary controls.
21. The implementation of the study contracts is monitored monthly at the program management meeting.
22. The appointment was made on 11 October 1994 for the services concerned.
Changing the date on the invoice itself did not affect the carryovers in any way.
Nevertheless, the officer in question was reprimanded.
Any necessary corrections to be made by hand will be signed and dated in the future.

The Court found that this system allows entries to be changed subsequently without this being apparent.

Until August 1995 the Agency processed all payments through a paying agency.
This additional use of the imprest procedure is contrary to Article 45 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, which only provides for this procedure for certain types of expenditure. 1.8.
Moreover, the agency only started to account for this expenditure in September 1995.
At the end of the financial year on 31 December 1995 some ECU 937 000 remained to be cleared.
General invoice 1.9.
Because of the processing via the paying agency, the entries in the accounts and against the budget only took place in September and December 1995.
This violates accounting practice.

The commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the particularities of the Community's financial regulations.
For this reason, in 1995 the agencies published a call for tenders for a system that suited their needs.
Until the introduction of the new system, the agency will work with a spreadsheet system.
It is true that subsequent changes to the postings can be made with this system without these having to be reproduced in the accounting of the budget transactions.
However, these changes can be found in the general accounts.
In the matter, all budget processes are documented.
During the start-up period, until the Financial Controller was appointed, an in-house imprest account was essential for the Agency to function properly.
This was the only way that the Member States' decision to set up the agency could be implemented quickly.
With the appointment of the Financial Controller, the imprest account was used less and was closed at the end of July 1995. On 3 1 .
By December 1995, 75% of the advances processed through the imprest account had been cleared.
Even if a large amount could not be cleared until 1996, the agency achieved a satisfactory end result and did its best under difficult circumstances.

In view of the future provision of its final seat, the Office should clarify the need for housing its services.

No C 81/36 p 5 Ë Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 REPLIES OF THE OFFICE Subsidy from the Commission 1.5.
Neither the Commission nor OHIM were aware of the need for a recovery order.
OHIM has taken note of the Court of Auditors' observation and has arranged for an immediate recovery order to be issued for the entire subsidy less the provisions for the 1996 financial year.
Accounting for budgetary transactions 1.6. It is true that the accounting system currently used by the OHIM allows subsequent changes to the entries.
For the period up to the introduction of the Sincom2 system developed by the Commission, the OHIM has taken organizational precautions for additional security guarantees when using the current system.
Until then, OHIM has no choice but to await the Commission's accounting system, which should be available before the end of the year, as the development of such a system involves a large financial burden that one office alone cannot bear.
In 1995 the Office's budget had been adopted, taking into account a provision of ECU 2 million requested by Parliament, out of a total budget of MECU 10.1.
The provision was released in two stages: — ECU 1 million in October 1995, — the balance in November 1995.
The temporary blocking of appropriations has of course had an impact on their use, particularly those under Title I (Staff) as there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would actually be lifted.
The OHIM could not under any circumstances agree to recruit staff as long as the payment of salaries was not guaranteed by the end of the financial year.
Once the provisions had been released, measures were taken to use the released appropriations, on budget lines where it was still possible due to the deadlines in the commitment procedures and where there was also a real need.
For this reason, the Office has requested a transfer of funds from Title I to Title II, mainly to purchase computer equipment, which was particularly urgently needed during the start-up phase of the Office.
It must be remembered that OHIM started its work on April 1, 1996 and that since then over 30,000 trade mark applications have been received, while the workload for the whole financial year had been estimated at 15,000 applications.
Inventory 1.8. At the time of the Court's audit, OHIM had just received from the Commission the software for the computerized management of the inventory; it was just installed at the time.
Segregation of Duties 1.9.
A query made to the Court of Auditors made it clear that this point concerns the sequence of signatures that must be observed in the commitment and payment procedures.
There is therefore no confusion as to the duties of the authorizing officer, the accounting officer and the financial controller.
Rather, the comment related to the fact that the transaction was signed off first by the accounting officer and then by the authorizing officer. · This approach had the advantage of ensuring that funds were available before a transaction was signed off by the authorizing officer during the start-up phase of the Office, when there was no manager yet. Now that OHIM has a budget manager, the order of signatures on the various budget documents can be respected as follows: 1st budget manager, 2nd authorizing officer, 3rd financial controller, 4th accounting officer.
Property, plant and equipment 1.10.
There is an agreement (see copy attached) between the Minister of Industry of the Spanish Government

Balance sheet accounting - The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
He also played a key role in introducing a system for managing the budget and accounts that was common to all departments.
Discussions are currently being held with the responsible departments of the Commission which will make it possible to overcome all the concerns expressed by the Court of Auditors through the introduction of a new budget management system, which will come into force on 1 January 1997.

1.6. Management of Advances It must be stressed that advances were not used for all equipment purchases, nor for participation in the real estate which formed a significant part of the budget.

Conclusion of contracts On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, which are closely linked to the activities and projects belonging to the work program of the foundation, represent an extremely small part of the foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.
On the other hand, it is true that the involvement of competitors that led to these contracts was informal.
This procedure was chosen at the time mainly because of the urgency.
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organizing conferences and seminars in the name and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control.
The associated budget was divided into two parts: the fixed remuneration part (less than 12 000 ECU) and the operational part, which was pre-determined by the Foundation and reimbursed on the basis of supporting documents.
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual amount of the contract would not exceed 12,000 ECU.
When it became clear at the beginning of 1996 that the Court of Auditors did not share this opinion, this system was abandoned.

The tables appended to this report present these financial statements in condensed form. Commission subsidy used (budget: ECU 12 million — appropriations collected: ECU 6.2 million).
The Court considers that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the 1995 financial year for the outstanding balance (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (ECU 7 million in total). . Overrun 1.6.
Several overruns totaling around ECU 0.4 million were recorded under Titles I (Expenditure on staff) and II (Expenditure on materials) of the budget.
This amount, which could not be charged to the 1995 budget, is shown on the assets side of the balance sheet in a holding account and must be charged to the 1996 budget (infringement of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Financial Regulation for the agency).
Paying agent 1.7.
Almost all payments charged to Titles I and II of the budget were made through a imprest account.
The use of this imprest account is not compatible with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the Agency, since the imprest administrator at the time was both the accounting officer and the manager of some budget lines.
Furthermore, the deadlines for submitting supporting documents were not met and the availability of the funds committed for payments was not checked.
This appears to be the main reason for the above budget overruns.
Transfers of funds 1.8.
As at the end of the 1994 financial year, a very high proportion of the appropriations available were carried over at the end of 1995 (ECU 7 million — 57.2% of the total budget).
Most of the carry-overs concerned Title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6.4 million — 90.3% of the appropriations entered in this title).
A large part (ECU 1.8 million) of the appropriations carried over from 1994 to 1995 amounting to ECU 8.5 million had to be canceled (21% of the appropriations carried over).

Several commitment requests amounting to ECU 0.5 million were subsequently submitted to the Financial Controller.
In these cases, the financial controller withheld his approval, which the Board of Directors overrode.
The Court underlines the obligation to respect the financial regulation, according to which 'any action likely to result in expenditure against the budget' (Article 27 of the Agency's financial regulation) must be subject to a proper prior commitment request. Segregation of duties 1.10.
Segregation of duties was not respected in the administrative department of the agency.
Due to the lack of staff in the accounting/financial area, the same person was simultaneously accounting officer, imprest administrator and appropriations manager/authorizing officer of some budget lines.
Accounting systems 1.11.
Two independent, unconnected systems are used for the budgetary accounts and for the general accounts.
In addition, the budgetary accounting system does not provide for any blocking in the event of overruns of available or committed appropriations.
Financial controller 1.12.
The Management Board has appointed the Financial Controller of the Commission as Financial Controller.

• The European Environment Agency was set up in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was approved on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on the location of the Agency had been delayed, work had to be done particularly quickly when the Environment Agency began its work.
Thanks to a great deal of work, projects were identified and commitments made before the end of the year, but for obvious reasons the implementation of the commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994.
Thus in 1995 the Agency faced the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the Agency's regular staff had taken up their duties.
The vacancies in the agency were advertised in November 1994 and after a lengthy selection process with over 7,000 applications, the first selected candidates began work in the summer of 1995.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work program and practically two budgets to implement, but had a very limited number of staff to do the job.
Nevertheless, work progressed and in 1995 major projects such as the Dobris Status Report and the revision of the 5th Environmental Action Plan were completed.
Five European topic-specific contact centers have been set up and the establishment of the EIONET has progressed.
The Agency's regular staff increased from 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary agents such as national experts and support staff) and reached 22 regular agents on 31 December 1995, with 10 temporary agents remaining stood aside.
The Agency's administrative machinery was gradually expanded as the same open recruitment procedure was followed.
Nonetheless, in 1995 the Agency was clearly understaffed to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
As far as the financial side is concerned, only one person was available in the first half of the year to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme.
In June 1995, the head of the administration department took up his post, and it was not until early 1996 that the remaining financial and contractual staff were added.
The Agency has performed its task, but in the area of finance and budget some mistakes have been made in relation to the prescribed procedures.
Overruns Some budget lines have been overrun.
This was partly because the agency's budgetary control system was not functioning satisfactorily and partly because some payments made were not accounted for as the agency's finance department was clearly understaffed.
Consequently, when the accounts were closed, there was a discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made, which appeared as an overrun on certain budget lines.
Since after 1 January there will be no more transfers between different budget lines, these amounts must be included in the 1996 accounts, ie financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996 the expenditure and the appropriations available under Titles I and II (ie the problems of 1995) were carefully controlled to avoid overspending.
Non-compliance with procedures (ex-post referral to the Financial Controller) A work program was drawn up during the establishment phase of the Agency and its implementation started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and an appropriate management structure was in place to monitor compliance with the procedures.
In some cases this has resulted in work being commissioned and carried out in violation of certain procedural rules.
In particular, work was commissioned without first obtaining the approval of the Financial Controller in Brussels, which is a prerequisite for this type of operational expenditure.
The error was purely procedural, because work had to be done but the necessary administrative structures to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels were not yet in place.
There is a clear delegation of authorizing powers and staff are aware of the procedural rules.
Separation of duties As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial nature should also remain separate at the Environment Agency.
One of the basic principles is that commitments and disbursements should not be made by the same person.
However, when the agency was being set up in Copenhagen, the number of staff was so low that this principle could not be adhered to.
The Court of Auditors rightly criticizes this fact.
In the case of the Environment Agency, the Financial Controller of the Agency and that of the Commission are one and the same person based in Brussels.
The Agency's work would be significantly hampered as a result.
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency.
In principle, it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts transacted through it are quite significant.
Instead of obtaining the prior approval of the Financial Control, the Agency orders the disbursement and once a month sends the statement of transactions made by the Paying Agency to the Financial Control for the subsequent approval.
On the one hand this facilitates the work of the paying agency, but on the other hand it is also a double-edged sword as the internal control of the agency and the finance department need to be able to cope with this additional responsibility.
In this respect, the complaint of the Court of Auditors is perfectly understandable, but as long as the financial controller is based in Brussels, the agency sees no alternative to making extensive use of the paying agency. · For this reason, the Agency has noted with great interest the Court of Auditors' recommendation that the Commission appoint a financial controller to the Agency. The Environment Agency would welcome such a move.
Computerized accounting system The Court of Auditors stresses the need for the Agency to introduce a modern accounting system covering both general accounting and budgetary control.
Such a computerized system is indispensable for the complicated financial system of the EU, if one wants to avoid that large resources are tied up in financial and budgetary work.
The Environment Agency wholeheartedly supports the Court of Auditors' conclusions.
Since the beginning of 1995, the agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem.
It turns out. Incidentally, in the same form for the other EU agencies.
In 1996 the agencies issued a joint tender, but this was unsuccessful, ie no satisfactory system was found.
That is why the agency is currently investigating the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budget control system.
It is planned to be installed and operational in time to implement the 1997 budget.
But there will still be one software for budgetary control and another for general accounts.
The payment offices will also not be integrated into the software. The Agency will continue to look for an appropriate solution to these problems and will endeavor to coordinate this work with the other Agencies.

3/13/97 | ΡΕ ~ | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/53 The following comments concern the main observations made by the Court of Auditors on the implementation of the EMCDDA budget for the financial years 1994 and 1995 (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court's observations).
The EMCDDA shares the Court's view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all appropriations entered in the balance sheet as Commission subsidy and this was done for the 1996 financial year. b) Subsidy from the Portuguese government (point 1.6 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA has acted in accordance with the instructions of the Financial Controller of the Commission (who is also the Financial Controller of the EMCDDA). within the meaning of Article 54 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities and Article 82 of the implementing rules for the same (in accordance with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities), the EMCDDA has initially for the purposes referred to in Article 54 of the above The paying agency procedure is used for the expenditure shown in the implementation regulations.
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a temporary system (based on Excel files) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system.
In this context, the decentralized agencies (including the EMCDDA), coordinated by the European Training Foundation in Turin, published a call for tenders at the end of December 1995 with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated computerized system for general and budgetary accounting .
No. C 81/54 | EN | Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3. 97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA is implementing a plan for programming and monitoring the implementation of the budget and its work program with the aim of improving the use of the appropriations allocated and, in particular, limiting carry-overs to exceptional cases only. f) Segregation of duties (point 1.10 of the Court's observations) C Due to its very limited staff in 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA could not fully ensure compliance with the principle of segregation of duties, as pointed out by the Court of Auditors.
The separation of duties of authorizing officer, financial controller and accounting officer required by Article 16 of the OEDT Financial Regulations for the duties of the authorizing officer has been fully respected.
The EMCDDA is already making efforts to ensure segregation of duties in carrying out the various tasks in question.
In this context, it takes into account, as far as possible, the requirements communicated by the Court of Auditors when defining its short-term staffing needs, in order to ensure that the administrative tasks mentioned by the Court (imprest administration, accounting, administration of staff and contracts) are carried out by different people.
Appropriate proposals will be submitted to the EMCDDA Management Board. g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the Court's observations) When adopting the EMCDDA Financial Regulations in June, the Management Board of the EMCDDA took a negative decision regarding the delegation of the tasks of Financial Controller to an EMCDDA staff member (particularly following the objection of the European Commission).
Furthermore, since the financial controller of the European Commission is also the financial controller of the EMCDDA, it would be up to the Commission to check on the spot the feasibility of appointing a financial controller, taking into account how this matter is regulated in the other decentralized agencies.

EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 1 of 5 Avis juridique important 31997Y0313(06) Report on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies Official Journal C 081 , 13/03 /1997 P. 0043 - 0048 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 81/06) (For the period from 1 September 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1 .
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in accordance with Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Court of Auditors examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in accordance with the requirements of Article 13 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. His responsibilities include the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in accordance with the internal financial provisions set out in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts.
This report constitutes the first audit of the Agency.
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the Community context.
The court carried out checks on the accounts and records and also applied such additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context.
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are presented in the second part of this report.
The financial statements for the financial years 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the underlying operations were carried out, on the whole, in accordance with the rules concerning legality and regularity.
Main observations concerning the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 The Commission subsidy 1.5.
During the financial year 1995 the Agency used only part of the Commission subsidy provided for in the general budget (ECU 12 million, of which ECU 6.2 million was drawn down).
It is the Court's opinion that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the financial year 1995 for the balance remaining due (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments that were carried over to the financial year 1996 (totaling ECU 7 million).
Spending in excess of available appropriations 1.6.
Several cases of expenditure in excess of available appropriations, amounting to approximately ECU 0.4 million altogether, were found under titles I (staff expenditure) and II (administrative expenditure) of the budget.
This http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 2 of 5 amount, which could not be charged to the budget for 1995, which entered on the assets side of the balance sheet in a suspense account, and had to be charged to the budget for the financial year 1996 (contravention of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Imprest account 1.7.
Almost all payments charged to the budget under titles I and II were made via an imprest account.
The utilization of this account was not in accordance with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the administrator of the imprest accounts was, at the time, both the Accounting and the Authorizing Officer for certain budget headings.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents were not met and the availability of appropriations committed was not verified before payments were made.
This situation seems to be the principal cause of the cases of spending in excess of available appropriations pointed out above.
Appropriations carried forward 1.8.
At the end of the financial year 1995, as was already the case at the end of the financial year 1994, the percentage of appropriations carried forward was very high in relation to the appropriations available (ECU 7 million - 57.2% of the total budget).
The majority of these carryovers concern title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6.4 million, representing 90.3% of the appropriations under this title).
A large share (ECU 1.8 million) of the appropriations carried over from 1994 to 1995, totaling ECU 8.5 million, had to be canceled (21% of the appropriations carried over).
A posteriori referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
Several proposals for the commitment of funds totaling ECU 0.5 million were submitted, a posteriori, to the Financial Controller for his approval.
In these cases, the Financial Controller withheld his approval, but this refusal was overruled by the Management Board.
The Court wishes to emphasize the obligation to respect the Financial Regulation and to submit proposals for commitments in due form prior to 'any measure of a kind which might lead to expenditure from the budget` (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Separation of duties 1.10.
The separation of duties within the administration of the Agency has not been observed.
Due to a shortage of staff in the financial accounting department, the same person was, at one and the same time, Accounting Officer, administrator of the imprest accounts and Authorizing Officer for certain budget headings.
Accounting systems 1.11.
The budgetary accounting and general accounting are carried out on two independent and unconnected computer systems.
The budgetary accounting system is, moreover, not programmed to refuse entries in the event of appropriations available, or appropriations committed, being exceeded.
The Financial Controller 1.12.
The Management Board appointed the Commission's Financial Controller as their own Financial Controller.
The Court considers it would be advisable, in respect of the Agency's present mode of operation, to appoint a full-time Financial Controller for the Agency.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg at the Court meeting of 28 October 1996. http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 3 of 5 For the Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President >TABLE> >TABLE> >TABLE> (1) OJ No L 120, 11. 5. 1990, p. 4.
(2) Contrary to the requirements of Article 13 (3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Agency in respect of the financial year 1995 were not prepared until 20 June 1996, the date on which the accounts were signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and sent to the Commission, to the Board of Management and to the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court on 28 June 1996.
The abridged version of these financial statements is presented in the tables annexed to this report.
THE AGENCY'S REPLIES The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was already adopted on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on where to locate the Agency had been delayed a fast start was needed.
Through a significant effort, projects could be identified and the budget committed before the end of the year, but for obvious reasons the execution of the commitments could barely start before the end of 1994.
Thus, in 1995 the Agency faced the daunting task of executing, not only the budget from 1994 but also a new budget for 1995 of ECU 10.5 million, and this before the regular staff of the Agency had taken up duty.
The vacant posts in the Agency were published in November 1994 and the selected candidates started coming on board in summer 1995 after a long selection procedure involving more than 7,000 applications.
In short, the agency had an ambitious work program and virtually two budgets to execute, but very limited staff for the task.
Despite this, work went ahead and in 1995 the Agency finalized major projects, like the Dobris assessment, the review of the fifth environmental action plan.
Five European topic centers were established and the build-up of the EIONET advanced.
The build-up of the Agency progressed with regular staff increasing from 1 on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, for example national experts and auxiliary staff) to 22 on 31 December 1995, still supported by 10 temporary staff.
The Agency's administration has progressively developed since the same open procedure to recruitment was applied.
Nevertheless, it was clearly too understaffed in 1995 to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
On the finance side only one person was available to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work program during the first half of the year.
In June 1995 the Head of Administration took up duty, and only in the beginning of 1996 did the rest of the finance and contract staff come on board.
The Agency rose to the challenge, but some mistakes of a procedural nature were made in the areas of finance and budget.
Overspending There was overspending on some budget lines.
The reason was, on the one http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 4 of 5 hand, that the Agency's budgetary monitoring system did not function in a satisfactory way and on the other hand some executed payments were not introduced due to the fact that the Agency was seriously understaffed in the finance department.
As a consequence, when the accounts were closed, the discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made showed up as overspending on some budget lines.
Since no adjustment between budget lines can be made after 1 January, this has to be booked on the 1996 accounts, ie be financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996 the expenditures and the availability of appropriations in titles I and II, which was where the problems occurred in 1995, were carefully monitored in order to avoid overspending.
Procedures overlooked (Saisine a posteriori) During the build-up of the Agency, a work program was established and started being executed before administrative procedures had been well established and an administration in place to monitor that procedures were followed.
In some cases this led to work being ordered and carried out without all the procedures being observed.
In particular, work was contracted without the Financial Controller in Brussels having given his visa which is a prerequisite for this kind of operational expenditure.
It was not a question of finances being wasted or that the finances were not there.
The mistake was procedural and reflected that work had to be done and the procedures to assure that this was done according to Community rules were not yet in place.
Procedures are now in place to avoid similar problems.
A clear delegation of authorizing powers have been established and staff informed of the rules.
Separation of functions In the financial framework of the Agency, as is the case in all public institutions, certain functions should be kept separate.
A basic principle is that the same person should not commit money and order payment.
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen the number of staff in the Agency was so small that it was not possible to observe this principle.
This is rightly criticized by the Court of Auditors.
However, once the staffing of the Agency started to increase this was corrected and these functions have been rigorously separated in the Agency since autumn 1995.
Extensive use of imrest accounts The normal procedure for committing and ordering payments in the EU system is to have prior approval by the Financial Controller in practically all cases.
In the case of the Agency, the Agency Financial Controller is the same as the Commission's and located in Brussels.
To send all financial transactions to Brussels for approval before they could actually be executed would be an excessively tiresome procedure.
It would seriously obstruct the working of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is the impregnable account.
It works in principle as a petty-cash reserve although the amounts involved are important.
Instead of seeking prior approval from Financial Control, the Agency executes the payment and once a month the imprest account is sent to the Financial Controller to have the ex post approval of the payments which have been made.
On the one hand this facilitates the functioning of the Agency, but, on the other hand, it is a double-edged sword since the Agency's internal controls and the financial department must have the capacity to handle this additional responsibility.
Thus, the criticism by the Court of Auditors is understandable, but as long as http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 5 of 5 the Financial Controller is located in Brussels there is, in the Agency's view no alternative to an extensive use of the imprest account.
It is therefore with great interest that the Agency has noted the recommendation by the Court of Auditors that the Financial Controller of the Commission should place a Financial Controller in the Agency.
The Agency would welcome this step.
Computerized financial system The Court of Auditors underlines the need for the Agency to find an up-to-date computerized financial system which can integrate the accounting side with the budget monitoring side.
In the complicated financial system of the European Union such a computerized system is crucial to avoid having to tie down a lot of resources in financial and budgetary work.
The Agency wholeheartedly supports the conclusion by the Court of Auditors.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has tried again and again to find a solution to this problem.
It is a problem which the European Environment Agency shares with the other EU Agencies.
In 1996, the Agencies launched a joint call for tenders to find a solution but this call for tenders has not been successful, ie no satisfactory system has been found.
Thus, the agency is at present pursuing the possibility of using the new budget monitoring system Sincom 2. The plan is to have it installed and operational in time to execute the 1997 budget on the basis of this system.
There will still be one software for the budget monitoring system and another for the general ledger.
Nor will the imrest accounts be integrated in the software the agency will continue to look for an efficient way of solving these problems and will endeavor to coordinate this work with the other agencies.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/25 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Environment Agency (hereinafter ăthe AgencyŇ) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Agency's mission is to set up an environmental monitoring network that will provide the Commission, Member States and the general public with reliable information on the state of the environment.
This information is intended in particular to enable the European Union and the Member States to take environmental protection measures and to evaluate the effectiveness of these measures.
2. Table 1 summarizes the Agency's responsibilities and activities.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 contain, for information purposes, key information from the Agency's annual accounts for the financial year 2006.
STATEMENT OF ASSURANCE 3. This Statement of Assurance is submitted to the European Parliament and the Council in accordance with Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (2). It is based on an audit of the Agency's accounts, which the Court is required to carry out under Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
4. The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (3) were prepared by its Executive Director in accordance with Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 and sent to the Court, which issued a statement of reliability of the accounts as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying processes.
5. The Court conducted its audit in accordance with the INTOSAI Auditing Standards and Code of Ethics and the IFAC International Code of Ethics, where applicable in the Community context.
The audit was planned and performed to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements are reliable and the underlying transactions are legal and regular.
6. The Court has a reasonable basis for the statement of assurance below. Reliability of the annual accounts The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 are reliable in all material respects.
The following comments do not call into question the Court's statement of assurance.
OBSERVATIONS 7. Over 30% of the year's commitments had to be carried over.
For operational expenditure (Title III and assigned revenue), more than half of the appropriations were carried over.
Some of these carry-overs were not justified: in the last two months of 2006 the Agency made commitments of 1.3 million euro but carried over the corresponding payment appropriations to 2007.
A random examination (4) of these transfers showed that they all related to activities to be carried out in 2007.
The budgetary principle of annuality was therefore not strictly applied.
8. The authorizing officer by sub-delegation not only performed ex ante controls but also managed the access rights to the electronic accounting system, in breach of the principle of segregation of duties.
This report was approved by the Court of Auditors at its meeting of September 27, 2007 in Luxembourg.

C 309/28 EN Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 AGENCY'S RESPONSE The higher level of carryovers in 2007 is mainly due to exceptional events in 2006 which caused us to defer interim payments to theme centers pending satisfactory delivery of services .
The reasons for the late commitments mentioned were the requirement to enter into licensing agreements prior to January 1st of each year to maintain continuity and the time required to establish and negotiate costs and schedules for complex new work.
The Agency will continue its efforts to reduce the proportion of transmissions related to this.
The risks associated with the situation described have been assessed by management and controls have been put in place to mitigate the risks.
The remaining risk is considered acceptable.
This situation will be reassessed as part of a review of security sensitive tasks to be held in mid-2007.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/41 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Agency for Reconstruction (hereinafter ăthe AgencyŇ) was established by Council Regulation (EC) No 1628/96(1), as last amended by Regulation (EC ) Council No. 756/2006 of 28 November 2006 (2), created.
Established in 2000, the agency was originally tasked with managing the European Union's aid programs in Kosovo.
Later, her mission was extended to Serbia-Montenegro and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
The Agency implements institution-building and good governance programs to support the development of a market economy and the basic infrastructure for civil society.
The mandate of the agency should in principle expire on 31 December 2008.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 contain, for information purposes, key information from the Agency's annual accounts for the financial year 2006.
STATEMENT OF ASSURANCE 3. This Statement of Assurance is submitted to the European Parliament and the Council in accordance with Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (3).
It is based on an audit of the Agency's accounts, which the Court is required to carry out under Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
4. The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (4) were drawn up by its Director in accordance with Article 8(2) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2667/2000 (5) and transmitted to the Court, which issues a statement on the reliability of the annual financial statements and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
Reliability of the accounts The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 are reliable in all material respects.
The following observations do not call into question the Court's assurance work.
OBSERVATIONS 7. The budget implementation rate was satisfactory.
However, the Agency's attention is drawn to the level of funds still to be committed, which will require special monitoring of the Agency's programs as its mandate expires at the end of 2008.
8. As regards the accounting system and the internal control system, the Court noted improvements compared to previous years, in particular as regards the monitoring of funds managed by external bodies and the application of procurement procedures.

C 309/42 EN Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 Community areas of competence under the Treaty Competences of the Agency (Council Regulation (EC) No 2667/2000 of 5 December 2000) Governance Resources made available to the Agency (data for 2005) Products and services in 2006 Within the limits of its competence, the Community implements economic, financial and technical cooperation activities with third countries.

Objectives Scope Tasks Governing Body Final Budget By operational centers (main developments): (Article 181 a) operational centers in Belgrade, Pristina, Podgorica and Skopje with extensive management autonomy.
