11/30/2018 Number Page 1.1-1.3 5 1.4-1.21 5 1.4-1.14 5 1.8-1.9 7 1.10 8 1.11-1.14 8 1.15-1.20 8 1.21 13 1.22-1.32 13 1.22-1.24 13 1.25-1
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/5 INTRODUCTION 1.1.
According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (1), the European Court of Auditors is the external auditor of the EU finances.
In this capacity, the Court exercises the role of independent guardian of the financial interests of the citizens of the Union, in particular by helping to improve EU financial management.
More detailed information on the Court's work can be found in its annual activity reports and annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget, as well as in its special reports, landscape reviews and opinions on new or amended EU legislation or other decisions affecting financial management (2nd ).
As part of its mandate, the Court annually audits the annual accounts and the transactions underlying them of all the institutions, agencies and other bodies of the Union (3).
This report presents the findings of our audit of the EU agencies and other Union bodies (collectively ăthe AgenciesŇ) for the financial year 2017.
The report is structured as follows: Ń Chapter 1 gives an overview of the agencies and the nature of the Court's audit. Ń Chapter 2 presents the overall results of the test. Ń Chapter 3 contains a statement of assurance for each of the 41 agencies, together with the audit opinions and the Court's observations on the reliability of the agencies' accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying revenue and payments (transactions).
THE EU AGENCIES Different types of agencies contribute to the shaping and implementation of EU policies 1.4.
Agencies are separate bodies with their own legal personality, created by a secondary act to perform specific technical, scientific or managerial tasks, thereby helping to shape and implement the policies of the EU institutions.
Many agencies are highly visible and have a significant impact on important areas relevant to the everyday lives of European citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice.
Accompanying their statements of assurance in Chapter 3 is a brief description of the tasks performed by each agency.
In this report, the agencies are referred to by their respective abbreviations, which can be found in the list at the beginning of this report.
There are three types of agencies: decentralized agencies, executive agencies and other bodies.
Their main characteristics are explained below.
The number of agencies has increased over the years and in 2017 there were 41 agencies as shown in Box 1.1.
(1) Articles 285 to 287 (OJ C 326, 26.10.2012, pp. 169-171).
(2) Available on the Court's website: www.eca.europa.eu (3) Three agencies active in the field of defense (the European Defense Agency, the European Union Institute for Security Studies and the European Union Satellite Centre) composed of contributions from the Member States are not audited by the Court but by other independent external auditors.

Like the Commission itself, the executive agencies of the Commission are based in Brussels or Luxembourg.
Decentralized agencies and other bodies are based throughout the EU and are spread across 23 different Member States, as shown in the list of acronyms and Figure 1.2.
The seat of the agencies is decided by the Council or jointly by the Council and the European Parliament.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/7 Illustration 1.2 Location of agencies in Member States Source: European Court of Auditors.
Decentralized agencies address specific policy needs 1.8.
The 32 decentralized agencies (4) play an important role in the preparation and implementation of EU policies, particularly as regards technical, scientific, operational and/or regulatory tasks.
The primary aim here is to meet special political requirements and to strengthen European cooperation by pooling the technical and expert knowledge of the EU and national governments.
The decentralized agencies have been set up for an indefinite period by regulation of the Council or of the European Parliament and of the Council.
Decentralized agencies work under the control of a Management Board composed of representatives of the Member States, the Commission and, in some agencies, other parties.
The Governing Board sets the operational framework to be followed by the agencies such as the multi-annual and annual work programme, the draft budgets and the establishment plans, which are implemented under the responsibility of the respective Executive Directors/Directors.
Each decentralized agency is subject to its own discharge procedure in relation to the implementation of its budget, covering staff, administrative and operational expenditure. In most cases, discharge is granted by the European Parliament and the Council (5).
(4) Cedefop, Eurofound, EEA, ETF, EMA, EMCDDA, CdT, CPVO, EUIPO, EU-OSHA, FRA, EASA, EFSA, EMSA, Eurojust, ECDC, ENISA, ERA, Frontex, GSA, EPA, EFCA, ECHA , EIGE, ACER, BEREC Office, Europol, EASO, EBA, EIOPA, ESMA and eu-LISA.
(5) Two self-funded agencies (CPVO and EUIPO) are subject to the discharge procedure by their Management Board.
EN C 434/8 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 The Commission's executive agencies implement EU programs 1.10.
The Commission's six executive agencies(6) are responsible for implementation and operational tasks related to one or more Union programmes. Their validity is limited in time.
They were set up by decision of the Commission and operate under the supervision of a steering committee appointed by the Commission.
Its work is based on multiannual and annual work programs that are established and implemented under the responsibility of an Executive Director.
They are subject to individual discharge procedures by the European Parliament and Council for their own budgets.
Unlike decentralized agencies, their budgets only cover staff and administrative expenditure, while all operational expenditure they make comes from the Commission's budget and is therefore part of the overall discharge given to the Commission.
The executive agencies' own budget therefore represents only a very small part of the budget they actually implement.
The other institutions have special tasks 1.11.
The three other bodies are the EIT, the Euratom Supply Agency and the SRB.
The EIT in Budapest is an independent, decentralized institution of the EU that pools resources from the fields of science, business and education in order to strengthen the innovative power of the Union by providing financial support.
The Institute was set up by the European Parliament and the Council for an indefinite period.
It is managed by a Director and overseen by a Management Board, and is subject to its own discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
The Euratom Supply Agency in Luxembourg was set up by the Council for an indefinite period to support the objectives of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community.
It is subject to its own discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
An Advisory Board, composed of members from the Member States, assists the Euratom Supply Agency in fulfilling its tasks by issuing opinions and providing analysis and information.
The Director General of the Euratom Supply Agency works under the supervision of the Commission.
The SRB is the central resolution authority in the banking union and is based in Brussels.
The mandate of the SRB is the orderly resolution of banks threatened with insolvency with the least possible impact on the real economy, the financial system and the public finances of the participating member states and beyond.
The SRB is represented by its Chair, who also acts as the Appointing Authority.
The Chair of the SRB is subject to a separate discharge procedure by the Board, which comprises members of the national resolution authorities of the participating Member States.
Agencies are funded from different sources and under different MFF headings 1.15.
The total budget of all agencies (excluding the SRB) was €3.5 billion in 2017 (2016: €3.4 billion). This corresponds to around 2.7% of the total EU budget in 2017 (2016: 2.4%), as shown in Box 1.3.
The agencies with the highest increase in appropriations in 2017 were the GSA and EIT, funded under MFF (7) subheading 1a (Competitiveness for growth and jobs), and Frontex, EMA and EASO, funded under MFF (7) Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) will be funded.
Added to this is the SRB's 2017 budget of EUR 6.6 billion (2016: EUR 11.8 billion) (8).
It consists of the contributions paid by credit institutions into the Single Resolution Fund.
(6) INEA, REA, EACEA, ERCEA, Chafea and EASME.

The Commission's operational expenditure, implemented by the six executive agencies, amounted to around €6.8 billion in 2017; this is more than double the total budget of all other agencies combined excluding the SRB.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/13 The EU agencies network promotes inter-agency cooperation and communication with stakeholders 1.21.
The EU Agencies Network (EUAN) was set up by the agencies as an inter-agency collaborative forum to increase the agencies' visibility, identify and promote potential efficiency gains and add value.
The EUAN works on the basis of the priorities set by the agencies in a 5-year strategic agenda (2015-2020) and the annual work programs that define the activities and the results to be achieved.
An important role for the EUAN is to ensure efficient communication between the agencies and the stakeholders, mainly the EU institutions.
THE COURT'S AUDIT The Court's mandate is to audit the agencies' accounts and operations 1.22.
In accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), the Court shall have (a) the annual accounts of all agencies, consisting of the annual accounts(10) and the reports on budgetary implementation (11) for the financial year ended 31 December 2017 and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions on which these financial statements are based.
On the basis of the results of its audit, the Court provides the European Parliament and the Council or the other discharge authorities referred to in Chapter 3 of this report with a statement for each agency on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions .
In accordance with Article 208(4) of the EU Financial Regulation (12), the annual accounts of 32 agencies receiving contributions from the EU budget have been audited by independent external auditors.
The Court verified the reliability of the results of this review in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing and took these into account when preparing its own audit opinions.
The Court's audit addresses the risks identified 1.25.
In order to obtain reasonable assurance, the Court has designed its audit to highlight the main risks identified. The reliability of the agencies' accounts is generally at low risk 1.26.
Overall, the Court assesses the risk to the reliability of the accounts as low for all agencies. The agencies' accounts are prepared using accounting rules adopted by the Commission's Accounting Officer, which are based on internationally accepted accounting principles for the public sector.
The number of material errors identified in the past was small.
Title I (staff expenditure) 1.28.
The management of salaries by the Commission's PMO (Office for the Administration and Settlement of Individual Claims) is audited by the Court as part of its specific assessments of administrative expenditure.
No material errors have been identified in connection with personnel expenses in recent years.
However, if the agencies need to recruit large numbers of additional staff in the short term, there is a medium to high risk to the legality and regularity of the recruitment procedures.
(10) The financial statements comprise the balance sheet, the statement of financial results, the cash flow statement, the table of changes in net assets and a summary of significant accounting policies and other explanatory notes.
(11) The reports on the implementation of the budget include the statements summarizing all revenue and expenditure transactions, as well as explanations.
(12) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (OJ
EN C 434/14 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Title II (Administrative expenditure) 1.29.
The procurement of various services (with increasing amounts in IT) involves complex procurement rules and procedures and agencies' administrations sometimes do not achieve satisfactory transparency and best value for money.
Serious procurement errors affecting payment conditions have regularly been one of the main reasons for the Court's qualified opinions and observations.
Title III (operational expenditure) 1.30.
There is a low to high risk.
This depends on each agency and the nature of its operational spend.
In general, the risks associated with procurement are comparable to those of Title II, although the amounts involved may be higher.
Concerning the grants paid under Budget Title III, previous audits found that, despite general improvements, the agencies' controls were not always fully effective.
There is a medium risk in terms of sound financial management, identified mainly in the areas of IT and public procurement.
The Court has already reported its findings on different IT landscapes in the agencies, weaknesses in IT project management and procurement procedures that did not ensure best value for money.
Generally speaking, there is a risk in terms of administrative efficiency associated with the large number of small agencies (see Figures 1.4 and 1.6) which have their own administrative structures and procedures.

EN C 434/16 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 INTRODUCTION 2.1.
This chapter provides an overview of the results of the Court's annual audits of the agencies for 2017, as well as other agency-related audit work carried out by the Court during 2017.
THE RESULTS OF THE ANNUAL AUDITS OF THE AGENCIES FOR THE YEAR 2017 ARE POSITIVE OVERALL 2.3.
Overall, as regards the agencies' accounts for the year ended 31 December 2017 and the revenue and payments underlying those accounts, the Court's audit confirms the positive results of previous years.
The Court has given unqualified audit opinions on the accounts of all agencies.
In his opinion, the agencies' annual accounts present their financial position as at 31 December 2017 and the results of their operations and cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with their respective financial regulations and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer (13) appropriate in all material respects.
Emphasis of matter paragraphs are fundamental to understanding the financial statements 2.5.
With regard to EASO, the Court pointed out that the staffing situation at the Office was deteriorating exponentially.
The office currently does not have the administrative capacity to fill the many vacancies.
Overall, the continuation of the office's activities to the current extent is considerably threatened by the personnel situation.
In the case of the SRB, the Court highlighted that the contributions to the Single Resolution Fund are calculated on the basis of the information that credit institutions provide to the Board through the national resolution authorities.
However, the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation does not provide a comprehensive and consistent control framework to ensure the reliability of this information.
The Court also found that the method for calculating contributions set out in the legislation is very complex, which entails risks for accuracy.
For reasons of confidentiality, the Committee may not disclose the bank data used to calculate the fund contributions; this reduces transparency.
Regarding ECHA, the Court highlighted that the agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from any company applying for the registration of chemicals, as foreseen by the REACH Regulation(14).
The agency calculates and invoices the fees on the basis of the information provided by the companies at the time of application.
The ex-post reviews carried out by the Agency have revealed the need for significant fee revisions, the total amount of which was not known at the end of 2017.
This finding demonstrates the limitations of a system that relies too heavily on self-reporting by applicants.
With regard to the GSA, the Court pointed out that the outcome of the public procurement procedure for one of the agency's main contracts (framework agreement worth €1.5 billion) was contested by one of the bidders.
With regard to the two London-based agencies (EMA and EBA), we noted that they will leave the UK in 2019 and that their annual accounts and accompanying notes have been prepared on the basis of the information available at the time of their signature.
The Court also drew attention to the impact of the current lease arrangements in London and the possible loss of revenue as a result of the UK's exit from the EU.
These are based on internationally recognized accounting principles for the public sector. Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 18, 2006 on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) (OJ
L 396 of 30.12.2006, p. 1).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/17 Unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the accounts of all agencies 2.12.
For all agencies, the Court has issued unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the accounts for the year ended 31 December 2017.
In the Court's assessment, the revenue was legal and regular in all material respects.
Unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the agencies' accounts (except EASO) 2.13.
For 40 agencies the Court issued unqualified opinions on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts for the year ended 31 December 2017.
In the Court's assessment, the payments were legal and regular in all material respects.
Since the violations occur systematically, the internal control system is obviously inadequate.
The cumulative error due to irregular payments is at least €7.7 million or 10.3% of the total payments made by the Office in 2017.
Paragraphs referring to other facts deal with questions of special importance 2.15.
Miscellaneous Matters paragraphs are intended to alert the reader to important matters that are not presented or disclosed in the financial statements or affect the legality and regularity of receipts and payments.
Regarding the EIT, we found that the original reimbursement rates for Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) were increased towards the end of the eligibility period.
In addition, two KICs have retrospectively included some new activities in their annual business plans.
For one of the KICs, this resulted in a significant change to the original grant decision.
Significant changes may affect the equal treatment of KICs and are not in line with the Financial Regulation.
In the case of Frontex, the Court has repeatedly reported since 2014 that the cooperating states often provide insufficient evidence of the expenditure they claim.
This was also confirmed by this year's test results.
In response to the Court's recommendation in 2016, Frontex is currently introducing a simplified cost reimbursement model.
With regard to EBA, EIOPA and ESMA, we pointed out that their budgets are funded partly by European Union funds and partly by direct contributions from the supervisory authorities and/or supervised entities of the EU Member States.
As a result of the UK's decision to leave the EU, government revenues could decrease in the future.
With regard to the GSA, the Court reported that the Agency operates both the Galileo Security Center (GSMC) and Galileo Earth Stations in the UK, which may need to be relocated.
With regard to the CdT, the Court drew attention to the fact that several agencies were increasingly resorting to in-house or other alternative translation solutions, which meant that the capacity of the center was not being used to the maximum.
In addition, there is a duplication of effort at the European level with regard to the development of translation systems and the running costs.
The Office of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC's Office) commissioned the CdT in December 2016 to translate four calls for expressions of interest with a view to drawing up reserve lists, even though all the posts approved by the Budgetary Authority in the Office's establishment plan were filled .
In our opinion, the translation order issued in December 2016 was not justified.
The payment made on this contract in March 2017 amounted to 2.5% of the 2017 budget.
EN C 434/18 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Box 2.1 Annual opinions 2014-2017 on the agencies' accounts and operations Source: European Court of Auditors.
The Court's observations cover a wide range of issues 2.22.
The Court made a total of 145 observations, covering 37 agencies, to underline important issues and identify areas for improvement.
These comments, set out in Chapter 3, are summarized below.
Major risks lead to major weaknesses in EASO 2.23.
In the case of EASO, the Court drew attention to the major risks posed to the Office by the nature of its activities and the exceptional challenges posed by the migration crisis.
These risks have not been mitigated by sound governance and effective controls, resulting in numerous material breaches of the law.
The office has been struggling with high staff turnover since 2014. The recruitment procedures were suspended in December 2017.
In addition, the Office does not have an internal audit function or a legal service, and legal documents are not systematically checked.
Almost all the audited services based on public procurement or recruitment procedures were systematically affected by significant deficiencies related to the identification of the office's needs, the drafting of the specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the evaluation and award procedures, the changes and renewals of contracts, the execution of the contracts and the verification of the services rendered, etc. affected.
These shortcomings are contrary to the principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/19 Progress towards a more unified IT landscape 2.26.
The operative activities of the agencies are wide-ranging and require suitable, sometimes tailor-made IT solutions.
However, core operational and administrative activities are performed under the same legal framework, suggesting that their procedures are similar and that similar IT solutions can be used to support these procedures.
While the agencies have made very good progress in deploying similar budgeting and accounting systems - the Court reported on this in its 2016 summary report on the results of the agencies' audits - work has been done in other key areas such as human resource management and procurement and administration still uses a variety of IT solutions.
The agencies are considering further standardizing IT solutions in these areas, primarily to increase cost-efficiency, reduce risks associated with internal control and strengthen IT governance.
In 2017, a number of advances were made in IT tools for human resources management, when 20 agencies signed agreements with the Commission to use the SYSPER II tool, which will create a more unified IT landscape in this area.
The majority of agencies are expected to start using the Commission's tool from 1 January 2019, while some agencies will start using it from the third quarter of 2018.
In this fragmented IT landscape, the use of similar electronic tools to procure supplies and services (e-procurement) would also represent an important step towards a more unified IT framework among agencies.
According to the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation, which entered into force in 2012 and 2013 respectively, all EU institutions and agencies ădesign as far as possible solutions for the submission, storage and processing of data submitted in grant and procurement procedures and implement To this end, they set up a common area for electronic data exchange for applicants, applicants and biddersŇ (15), (16).
While no target date has been set in the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation for the introduction of e-procurement, the EU Public Procurement Directive(17), adopted in 2014, requires the use of electronic means for public procurement in EU Member States by 2018, and according to the EU directive on electronic invoicing(18), also issued in 2014, all public institutions must allow the receipt of electronic invoices by 2019.

EN C 434/20 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 2.29.
All agencies publish their calls for tender electronically via TED (Tenders Electronic Daily), the online version of the EU's Official Journal for Public Procurement. In addition, the Commission launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic submission of tenders (2015). Most agencies had introduced e-invoicing and e-tendering for certain procedures by the end of 2017, but not e-submission.
Improvement in the area of IT consulting services and project management at the EMA and eu-LISA IT consulting services and project management at the EMA 2.30.
During the audit carried out last year, the Court analyzed how the Agency manages consultancy services.
Over-reliance on consulting firms has led to a critical reliance on outside expertise.
The Court also reported that there was insufficient control over project development and implementation and that projects were experiencing significant delays and cost increases.
During 2017, the Agency took several measures to improve the situation.
However, it will take time to reduce the agency's critical reliance on consulting firms and the impact of the actions taken will only be felt over the years.
IT consulting services and project management at eu-LISA 2.32.
Due to the nature of its activity, the Agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects.
In 2017, the agency's IT projects were implemented within budget and on schedule.
The Agency uses an outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, with around 90% of the relevant work being carried out by three contractors.
Although IT projects are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model where development activities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced on this scale risks over-dependence on contractors.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/21 2.34.
At the same time, the small number of staff in key operational units creates a risk for the continuity of operations.
Public procurement aims to ensure competition between economic operators and to ensure the most economically advantageous purchase, operating in a transparent, objective and consistent manner, based on the applicable legal framework.
The Court found weaknesses in public procurement, mostly related to 14 agencies (BEREC Office, EPO, Chafea, eu-LISA, EASO, EBA, EEA, EFSA, EIGE, EUIPO, ERA, EASA, FRA and SRB). to services that harbor risks for the optimal use of funds.
The most common shortcomings identified are the lack of a good balance between price and quality aspects in the award criteria, the sub-optimal design of the framework agreements, the use of framework agreements that allow the procurement of services whose description and/or price were not sufficiently specified and the use of intermediary services.
Most agencies analyzed the impact of Brexit 2.36. On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to leave the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, five agencies (ACER, Office of BEREC, EPO, ENISA and EU-OSHA) did not undertake a comprehensive analysis of the possible impact of Brexit on their organisation, operations and accounts.
Vacancy notices could be published on the EPSO website 2.37.
Most Agencies (ACER, Cedefop, EPA, Chafea, EASA, EBA, ECHA, EUA, EIGE, EIOPA, EIT, EMA, EMCDDA, EMSA, ENISA, ESMA, eu-LISA, Eurojust, Europol, Frontex, GSA and SRB) publish vacancies on their own websites and social media, but often not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
A publication on the EPSO website would increase transparency and publicity and allow citizens to consult vacancies in all European institutions and bodies.
The main reason given by the agencies is that EPSO requires publication of vacancy notices in all official EU languages, which entails high translation costs.
Fewer comments on legality and regularity of payments 2.38.
The number of observations on the legality and regularity of payments decreased to eight (2016: 11), reflecting the agencies' ongoing efforts to comply with the legal framework, in particular the provisions of the Financial and Framework Financial Regulations and the Staff Regulations.
While five observations again concerned shortcomings related to procurement procedures (EASO, EASA, EIGE and Frontex), three related to recruitment procedures (EASO, Cedefop and Frontex).
Housekeeping has improved 2.39.
According to the Financial Regulation, budget appropriations granted for a given year may be carried over to the next budget year under certain conditions (19).
It is true that the Financial Regulation does not set any upper limits for transfers of this type, and the multi-annual nature of the activities means that the transfers are largely justified. However, excessive carry-overs may indicate delays in the implementation of work programs or procurement plans and may also run counter to the budgetary principle of annuality.
Box 2.4 shows for how many agencies we reported high carryovers in 2017 and previous years.
The decrease to only two agencies (Chafea and EU-OSHA) in 2017 is due to the agencies' better and more transparent explanation and justification of the transfers, but also to the Court's changed approach to reporting in 2017.
(19) The conditions for transfers are explained in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation.
EN C 434/22 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Box 2.4 Fewer comments on excessive or high carryovers Source: ECA based on information from the agencies.
The Court also found that two agencies (Frontex and EUIPO) canceled budgets carried over from previous years.
This was an indication that budgetary needs were being overstated, particularly by the public administrations of Member States and other cooperating countries.
Accounting could be further improved 2.42.
During this year's audits, the Court also examined the agencies' accounts, which play an important role in the production of reliable accounts.
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, each agency has its own accounting officer. This has resulted in a total of 37 accounting officers being responsible for 2% of the EU budget.
The most important tasks of the accounting officer are ensuring payments, accepting receipts and collecting claims, preparing and presenting the annual accounts and keeping accounts, defining and validating the accounting systems and managing the cash.
In order to increase efficiency, in 2012 the Commission's Accounting Officer asked all agencies to delegate their accounting function to him on a contractual basis.
The first agency to adopt this proposal was the EPA in 2014.
By the end of 2017, only three other agencies (GSA, BEREC Office and ACER) had joined this regulation.
The hierarchical position of an accounting officer within an agency may affect his/her independence.
In particular, the accounting officers must be independent of persons who have (subsidiary) authority to make budgetary commitments, enter into legal commitments and authorize payments.
This comment affects a total of 13 agencies (CdT, EACEA, EASA, EASME, EUA, EFSA, EIOPA, EMA, EMCDDA, ERA, EU-OSHA, Eurofound and FRA).
The appointment and annual assessment of the accounting officer would then also have to fall under the responsibility of the board of directors.
According to the Financial Regulation, the accounting officers have to confirm that the agencies' accounting systems work reliably (validation).
While the validation of the accounting systems of most agencies is up to date, the Court found that the accounting systems of seven agencies (ACER, Office of BEREC, EPO, EASME, EIT, EMA and GSA) require timely re-validation due to major changes .
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/23 Box 2.5 Status of the independence of the agencies' accounting officers and the revalidation of the accounting systems Source: ECA based on information from the agencies.
In three agencies (EASO, CPVO and REA) procurement, grant and recruitment procedures were poorly documented.
In three agencies (ACER, EIT and Frontex) shortcomings were identified in the implementation of the internal control standard related to contingency plans.
These deficiencies could pose a significant risk to business continuity in the event of a major disaster, as data could be irretrievably lost.
Agencies follow up audit findings from previous years 2.47.
Where relevant, the Court reported on the state of play of follow-up actions taken by the agencies on observations made in previous years.
Box 2.6 shows that the corrective actions related to the 170 outstanding comments at the end of 2016 were in most cases completed or ongoing.
Of the 13 outstanding observations, the corrective actions required for three observations were not under the Agency's control.
EN C 434/24 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Box 2.6 Agencies' efforts to follow up observations from previous years Source: European Court of Auditors.
The Court forwards cases of suspected fraud to OLAF 2.48.
OLAF is then responsible for investigating and following up on these cases, where necessary in cooperation with the national judicial authorities.
In 2017, as part of our audit of around 1000 transactions and 150 procurement procedures related to the agencies' declarations of assurance, we identified three cases of suspected fraud, which we reported to OLAF.
The Court provides information on Commission Internal Audit Service (IAS) reports and external evaluation reports 2.49.
The Court also referred to IAS audit reports and external evaluation reports commissioned by the Commission for information.
In 2017, 26 IAS reports were prepared, and an agency was externally evaluated in nine cases.
The Court has not reviewed the relevant audit or evaluation processes.
AUDIT RESULTS FROM OTHER AGENCIES-RELATED REPORTS PRODUCED BY THE COURT IN 2017 The Court's Rapid Case Review on the implementation of the 5% reduction in posts 2.50.
In 2017 we carried out a quick analysis (20) on how the European Union institutions and agencies implemented their commitment to reduce staff in their establishment plans by 5 % over the period 2013-2017 (for agencies 2014-2018).
The Court concluded that the agencies implemented the 5 % staff reduction, albeit with some delays.
While decentralized agencies with traditional tasks managed to reduce their staff by 8.9%, certain decentralized agencies and executive agencies with new tasks and responsibilities increased their headcount by 19.9% and 42.9% respectively.
Box 2.7 shows the resulting percentage changes in posts in the establishment plans of all institutions, bodies and agencies.
(20) Rapid Case Review on the implementation of the 5% reduction in posts; published on December 21, 2017.

Court's special report on the SRB 2.51.
The Single Resolution Board (SRB), based in Brussels, was set up in August 2014. It is part of the political response to the financial crisis.
The task of the committee is the resolution of banks threatened with insolvency that fall within its area of responsibility.
In January 2017, the SRB covered 139 banks, including 130 banking groups (21).
Audit (22) examined whether the Board is equipped to resolve banks effectively. Particular attention was paid to the quality of resolution planning for individual banks and whether the Committee was adequately prepared to comply with resolution planning legislation and had sufficient human resources to carry out its duties.
The Court identified gaps in all of these areas. However, given that setting up the Committee as an entirely new structure was a formidable challenge, it is against this background that the weaknesses have to be seen.
The Court made a number of recommendations to the Board with a view to developing resolution plans and completing its rules and guidelines, as well as increasing staff and improving human resources management procedures.
(21) As of January 1, 2018, the number has decreased to 127 banks and 119 banking groups.
(22) Special Report No 23/2017: 'Single Resolution Board: First steps have been taken on the challenging road to Banking Union, but there is still a long way to go', published on 19 December 2017.
EN C 434/26 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Court's special annual report on contingent liabilities resulting from the Single Resolution Board carrying out its duties 2.54.
Under the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (23), the Court is required to report on any contingent liabilities arising from the Board, the Council and the Commission carrying out their duties under that regulation.
As at 31 December 2016, the Committee's contingent liabilities resulting from ex ante contributions amounted to €842 million, increasing to €1 420 million as at 30 September 2017.
In 2016, the Committee did not initiate any bank resolutions and consequently no contingent liability related to resolution decisions was recognized for the 2016 financial year.
However, by the time the ECA's 2016 report on contingent liabilities resulting from the Board's performance of its duties was published, there were until the end of October due to the June 2017 resolution decision regarding Banco Popular Espa–ol SA In 2017, 90 legal cases were brought against the Board before the General Court of the European Union and 46 appeals were lodged with the SRB Appeals Committee.
The Commission and the Council have been informed of 26 cases brought before the Court in connection with the above resolution decision.
Other special reports from the Court relating to one or more agencies 2.55.
Apart from audit reports dedicated specifically to the agencies, throughout 2017 we produced a number of special reports and analyzes on EU policy implementation, covering a number of agencies (see Box 2.8).
(23) Article 92(4) of the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.

EN C 434/28 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLIES OF THE NETWORK OF EU AGENCIES The agencies welcome the Court's positive conclusions on the reliability of their accounts and the transactions underlying those accounts.
The network would like to express its concern that given that the Commission only provides them with a basic set of modules in Sysper, agencies are - and will be - forced to continue using separate tools for assessment, teleworking , flextime and personnel reporting.
The IT landscape in the area of human resources management will thus only become partially more uniform and even a lot less than the Commission could have decided.
The agencies are also examining the possibility of introducing a common solution for the concerned services to support recruitment processes not currently covered by Sysper.
In the area of procurement, there has definitely been a move towards harmonization of electronic tools over the last two years.
This evolution gradually started in 2015/2016 when the e-PRIOR/e-procurement tools designed by DG DIGIT in cooperation with DG BUDG were developed.
Since that time, this set of electronic modules for all phases of the procurement cycle has become a standard to which agencies adhere.
In 2018, this trend was further reinforced when new modules for electronic filing and the ABAC LCK module were introduced and made available to agencies.
Agencies are gradually phasing out the use of their own siled tools - some rapidly, some less rapidly - but no matter how rapidly this evolution occurs, the trend itself is unstoppable.
The proposed efficiency gains that could be achieved by delegating accounting tasks to the European Commission are difficult to achieve in practice.
Because the amount of work required not only depends on the balance of the budget, but it must also be taken into account that the annual accounts have to be completed at the beginning of each year within a narrow time frame.
Experience shows that closing more than one set of accounts (ie where additional funding is provided through delegation agreements) requires almost twice as many staff, although the amounts involved are smaller (and the financial operations are fewer in number).
If these activities were delegated to the Commission, each agency would still need an accounting team, as there would still be accounting-related tasks to be performed.
As long as this is the case, any savings in staff would not correspond to a full-time equivalent.
The annual fee must also be paid.
For this reason, few agencies have decided to delegate this task to the Commission.
The network would like to point out that no research or risk assessment has yet been carried out which could justify the conclusion that the accounting officer's independence would be strengthened if he reported directly to the authorizing officer and not to an authorizing officer by delegation.
Some agencies have chosen to adopt an Accounting Officers Charter which, among other things, includes arrangements for reporting to the governing body, if required.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/31 3.1.
We conducted our audit in accordance with the IFAC International Standards on Auditing (ISA) and Codes of Ethics and the INTOSAI International Standards of Supreme Audit Institutions (ISSAI).
Our responsibilities under these standards are further described in the auditor's responsibilities section of our report.
We are independent in accordance with the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants' Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants (IESBA Code) and the ethical requirements relevant to our audit, and we have maintained our other ethical responsibilities consistent with those requirements and the IESBA code met.
We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Responsibilities of management and those responsible for monitoring 3.1.2.
In accordance with Articles 310 to 325 TFEU and the Agencies' Financial Regulations, management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of the accounts on the basis of internationally accepted accounting principles for the public sector and the legal and regularity of the transactions underlying these accounts .
This includes designing, establishing and maintaining internal control structures as required for the preparation and presentation of financial statements that are free from material - intentional or unintentional - misstatements.
The management of the agencies bears the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions on which their annual accounts are based.
In preparing the financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the agencies' ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless: management either intends to liquidate the facility or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so.
Auditor's responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements and underlying transactions 3.1.5.
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance as to whether the agencies' accounts are free from material misstatement and the transactions underlying them are legal and regular, and to the European Parliament and the Council or other relevant discharge authorities on the basis of our to provide audit statements on the reliability of the agencies' accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
Misstatements and errors may be intentional or unintentional and are considered material if, individually or collectively, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.
3.1.6.
With regard to revenue, we review the grants that the agencies have received from the Commission or Cooperating States and assess their procedures for collecting fees and other revenue where relevant.
3.1.7.
For spending, we examine payment transactions after spending is made, recorded, and accepted.
Prepayments will be checked after the beneficiary has proven their proper use and the agency has accepted the proof by clearing the prepayment Ń in the same year or later Ń.
3.1.8.
As part of an audit in accordance with the ISAs and ISSAIs, we exercise professional judgment and maintain a critical attitude throughout the audit.
In addition, we Ń identify and assess the risks of material Ń intentional or unintentional Ń misstatements in the financial statements and material Ń intentional or unintentional Ń violations of the legal framework of the European Union in the underlying transactions, design and perform audit procedures responsive to these risks and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinions.
The risk that a material misstatement or violation of the law resulting from fraud will not be detected is higher than that resulting from error, since fraud involves collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations or the overriding of internal controls can
C 434/32 Ń Ń Ń Ń Ń Ń Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 we gain an understanding of the internal control system relevant to the audit in order to plan audit procedures that are appropriate in the given circumstances, but not with the aim of to issue an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system; Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by management and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by management; Conclude on the appropriateness of management's use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on an agency's ability to continue as a going concern .
If we conclude that there is a material uncertainty, we are required to comment in our auditor's report on the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if the disclosures are inappropriate, to modify our opinion.
We base our conclusions on the audit evidence obtained to the date of our auditor's report.
We are responsible for directing, supervising and administering the exam.
EN 3.1.9.
We communicate with management, among other things, about the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in the internal control system that we identify during our audit.
3.1.10.
From the matters that we communicated with the agencies, we determine those matters that were of most significance in the audit of the financial statements of the current period and are therefore the key audit matters.
We describe these matters in our auditor's report, unless law or regulation precludes public disclosure about the matter or when, in extremely rare circumstances, we determine that a matter should not be communicated in our auditor's report, because it could reasonably be expected that the negative consequences of such a communication would outweigh the benefits to the public interest.
(24) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.2.8. In the course of this year's audit of all EU agencies, the Court analyzed the accounting, including the aspect of timely (re)validation of the accounting systems.
In October 2017, the Agency delegated its accounting function to the Accounting Officer of the Commission.
Despite this drastic change, the accounting system was last validated in 2011.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.2.9.
In 2011, the Agency received an additional task related to the Monitoring of the Wholesale Energy Market (REMIT).
In 2017, all components provided for by the REMIT monitoring framework were implemented for the first time.
However, the disaster recovery site originally set up in Maribor, Slovenia was relocated to the Agency's main data center in Ljubljana in April 2017.
As a result, the backup data is now stored in the same location as the original data.
As a result, there is a considerable risk for the maintenance of business operations in the event of major disasters, since data could be irretrievably lost. COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.2.10. On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom (UK) informed the European Council of its decision to leave the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, the Agency did not undertake a comprehensive analysis of the possible impact of Brexit on its organisation, operations and accounts.
3.2.11.
The agency publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and allow citizens to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies in one place.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/35 3.2.12.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a common solution for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (30) (31). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
By the end of 2017, the agency had not implemented any of these tools.
INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE REPORTS 3.2.13.

C 434/36 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous years' observations Court's observations According to the Headquarters Agreement between the Agency and the Slovenian Government, a European School is to be established in Slovenia, more than four years after the completion of the However, the agreement has still not happened.
In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the urgent need to clarify roles and responsibilities and to analyze the contracting authority's workload in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that there is a need for significant improvement in procurement planning and monitoring. The Agency and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan.
The Agency carried over 4.9 million euros or 86% of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: 1.4 million euros or 59%).
As in previous years, these transfers of funds were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market and amounted to EUR 4.7 million in 2016 (2015: EUR 1.1 million).
For Title II (Administrative Expenditure), the Agency carried over 1 million euros or 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: 0.8 million euros or 35%).
The higher transmission rate is directly linked to the fact that procurement procedures and contracts are largely completed or signed towards the end of the year, which leads to a deferral of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 contracts were signed in November and December (EUR 5,976,122.47 or 40% of the total value of contracts concluded in 2016).
The Agency may consider introducing differentiated budget appropriations to better reflect the multiannual nature of activities and unavoidable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments. Year 2014 2016 2016 2016 Corrective Action Status (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a)
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/37 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.2.8.
The Agency agrees with the finding and clarifies that the Agency records all financial transactions in the financial system provided by the European Commission, which is updated, maintained and validated by the Commission.
With the outsourcing of the accounting services to the Commission from October 2017, the Agency will accept the validation of the accounting system to be provided by the Commission in 2018.
Since the ARIS primary site and disaster management site migrated to ACER's internal data center in early April 2016 and were integrated into a single site in June 2017 to optimize and boost performance and manage increasing space requirements, maintaining the operation can no longer be guaranteed.
However, it should be noted that the current situation, in which business continuity cannot be guaranteed, has been imposed on the Agency by the significant reduction in its budget over the past two years.
The Agency has repeatedly warned the Commission and the budgetary authorities about the serious consequences of the budgetary restrictions, but with no result in terms of additional funds.
The agency will continue to explore the possibility of restoring a disaster management site for ARIS, but without having the resources to do so in 2018.
Restoration of the disaster management site would require additional funding to be provided to the agency.
Given that the risks associated with BREXIT were considered to be low and limited, management conducted only an informal analysis of Brexit in 2017.
In early 2018, the agency published a comprehensive analysis of the impact of Brexit on governance, operations and finance, highlighting the impact and the actions needed.
In 2014, the Agency's Management Board adopted Resolution AB No. 15/2014 on the Agency's language regime.
Notwithstanding this, the Agency still has to translate the vacancy notices published on the EPSO website into all official EU languages.
Due to the very limited financial resources, which have been repeatedly pointed out to the budgetary authority, the Agency cannot afford the translation costs for each individual vacancy notice in all official EU languages for the publication of this notice on the EPSO website.
In 2017, four out of nine vacancy notices, including two public calls, were still published on the EPSO website and therefore translated into all official EU languages.
The other five advertisements for vacancies in operational departments were only published on the agency's website, since these were mainly of interest to applicants who were already working in the area and who usually also use the agency's activities on our website pursue.
This approach represents a pragmatic balance between outreach to potential applicants and efficient use of limited resources.
3.2.12.
In 2018 the Agency will start using e-procurement, which will be expanded in 2019 to include e-invoicing and e-submission of bids.
3.2.13.
Following the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) report on human resource management, the Agency has agreed an action plan with the IAS and is implementing the proposed improvements.

NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.3.10.

The financing of 2018 activities from the 2017 budget is contrary to the budget principle of annuality.
The office launched a call for tenders in August 2015 for a cascading multiple service framework agreement for an estimated market volume of 3 million euros for the organization and planning of events such as meetings, workshops, conferences, etc.
In addition, only the bidder's administration fees were covered by the competitive procedure, but not the potential event costs.
The award procedure therefore did not ensure appropriate price competition, which means that the most economically advantageous offer may not have been accepted.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/41 ANNEX Follow-up to previous observations Court's observations The appropriations in the 2014 budget for contributions from national regulators of EFTA(1) countries that have observer status in BEREC have been increased in the absence of agreements with them countries not paid.
In March 2016, the Office launched a procurement process with the aim of signing a framework contract for the children of its staff with the two Riga-based international schools.
The framework agreement signed in July 2016, worth 400,000 euros, is therefore based on contradictory concepts, creating legal uncertainty for the office and the schools.
In addition, a framework agreement was unnecessary in this specific case.
As part of a reclassification, one staff member was assigned directly to step 2 instead of step 1 of a higher grade. This violates the EU Staff Regulations.
In March 2016, the office concluded a contract worth 60,000 euros for the provision of professional support and consulting services in the field of human resources.

A possible reason is the weighting applied to salary costs for the host country (73%).
Periodic external performance evaluations are not required by the Office's founding regulation.
The Office, together with the Commission, should consider commissioning such an evaluation at least every five years, as do most other agencies.

EN C 434/42 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE OFFICE 3.3.7. Considering the high turnover of staff, which management saw as a risk factor for the implementation of its work programme, the management committee of BEREC's office requested that reserve lists be drawn up for at least 75% (39) of the job profiles in the agency.
In order to comply with the obligation to publish calls for expressions of interest (40) on the EPSO website (41), BEREC's office had to translate the documents into all official EU languages.
With reserve lists prepared in advance, the Agency is able to meet the Management Committee's target of keeping the vacancy rate below 15% and to send out vacancies within one month of identifying a need for recruitment.
In order to avoid the high cost of mandatory translations in the future, BEREC's office intends to develop standard templates for calls and short job-specific sections for translation.
3.3.9.
In 2016, the BEREC Office delegated its accounts to the European Commission.
Therefore, the Accounting Officer of the European Commission (within DG Budget) provides all the services required under Article 50 of the Framework Financial Regulation applicable to the Agencies, including the validation of local systems.
The validation approach is currently in progress and was announced by the Accounting Officer of the European Commission in an official memo with reference number Ares(2018)3149885 dated 14 June 2018.
The services of the Accounting Officer of the European Commission will complete the process and report on the results in the fourth quarter of 2018.
3.3.10.
The BEREC office had already started preparing for the training in November 2017, contacted potential trainers and checked the availability of the venues.
It was therefore necessary to sign the contract with the organizer to ensure the availability of both the trainers and interviewers and the venue for the scheduled dates of the training.
The contract was signed in December 2017, so a corresponding financial regulation commitment was made before the contract was signed.
Experience shows that it is extremely difficult to organize a training course in the first quarter of a year without carrying over funds from the previous year; the BEREC office will therefore consider later dates for future training courses.
3.3.11.
The decision for a framework agreement was made in 2015.
Fixed salary considered compatible with the Financial Regulation as other EU bodies have and are still making several such contracts (e.g. for travel agency or banking services).
Due to the specific nature of BEREC's activities, a large part of the expenditure on BEREC events borne by the BEREC office relates to the remuneration of experts, mostly from public bodies located in the EU Member States (e.g. national regulatory authorities Ń NRAs ).
Therefore, it should be noted that the contractor has no control over this type of expenditure.
Following the comments and the valuable exchange of views with the Court, when reopening the procurement procedure, BEREC's office will also consider other types of framework contracts that were not foreseen under the 2015 legal framework.
The Office of BEREC takes note of the Court's observations and informs the Court that it intends to introduce these modules by the end of 2018, taking into account the availability of corresponding Agency budgets.
3.3.13.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.5.8.
The Court considers it necessary to strengthen the independence of the Accounting Officer by reporting directly to the Director (administrative matters) and the Management Board (functional matters) of the Agency. COMMENTS ON THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF OPERATIONS 3.5.9.
Framework agreements are made with companies to set out the terms and conditions that apply to specific purchases (single orders) during the term of the agreement.
The agency used a framework agreement with three contractors in the cascade system to award IT services worth up to EUR 22 million.
In this procedure, following a competitive procedure, the contractors are ranked (the cascade), which must be observed for all individual orders.
However, the terms of the framework agreement were not specific enough to allow for fair competition and to justify prioritizing the contractors for all future individual contracts.
According to the rules of application of the Financial Regulation(54), the specific contracts must in these circumstances be awarded through a competitive procedure between the selected contractors.
3.5.10.
According to the Agency's financial rules (55), procurements must be approved by the Governing Board, either in the Agency's annual work program or through an ad hoc financing decision.
An IT framework agreement for a maximum amount of 15 million euros was tendered and signed, although the funding decision only covered an amount of 5 million euros.
In 2014, the Commission, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including EASA), concluded a framework agreement with a contractor for the purchase of IT hardware and software, and for maintenance and support services (IT services) away.
The framework contractor acts as an intermediary between the Agency and companies that can provide the IT services.
Although most of these IT services and the associated prices were specified in the framework agreement concluded as a result of the competitive award procedure, this also allows the procurement of IT services that are not specifically mentioned.
In the case of an audited payment of around EUR 300,000, the agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without a competitive process.
In 2017, payments totaling EUR 2 million were made to the framework agreement contractor.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/57 Emphasis of matter 3.7.5.
Without calling into question the opinion expressed in paragraph 3.7.4, the Court would like to underline that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from any company applying for the registration of chemicals, as foreseen by the REACH Regulation (72).
The applicable fees depend on the size of the companies (micro, small, medium and large) and the volume of chemicals registered (different volume thresholds).
3.7.6.
As foreseen in the Implementing Regulation(73), the Agency calculates and invoices the fees on the basis of information provided by the companies at the time of application.
Since the first registrations in 2009, around 30% of companies have stated that they are micro, small or medium-sized enterprises.
The Agency has made significant efforts to put in place a system for ex-post verification to verify the company size information provided by these applicants.
As a result, the Agency was able to determine that, based on the reviews completed so far, around 55% of the above companies that self-reported to be micro, small or medium-sized enterprises (16% of all companies) had misrepresented their size, resulting in lower fees.
To remedy this, the Agency has charged around 16.4 million euros in correction fees as a result of ex-post verifications over the years.
However, verifications are significantly backlogged and the remaining amount of necessary fee corrections was not known at the end of 2017 (74).
This finding demonstrates the limitations of a system that relies too heavily on self-reporting by applicants.
The REACH regulation stipulates that checking the quantities declared by companies is the task of the member state authorities responsible for enforcement.
The Agency is therefore not involved in the verification of this second element for the fee calculation.
Payments Opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments on which the annual accounts are based 3.7.8.
In our opinion, the payments underlying the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2017 are legal and regular in all material respects.
3.7.9.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.7.10.
The Agency's ex-post reviews showed that more than half of the companies that registered chemicals and claimed to be micro, small or medium-sized enterprises had false information about their size (see emphasis paragraph of a fact in Section 3.7.5).
This can be partly explained by the Commission's complex rules on company sizing (75) and partly by the financial incentive to under-declare, as registration fees are far higher for larger companies.
Because initial registration fees are based on reported company size, misrepresentations can have a significant negative impact on the Agency's revenue if not detected.
While the Agency verifies the reported size for smaller companies as part of ex-post reviews, the reviews are significantly backlogged and will only be completed by 2012 (for the years with the largest registered volumes of chemicals).

If errors are found, the Agency will charge the difference between the fee originally paid and the fee ultimately due, plus an administration fee.
On December 31, 2017, the amount to be recovered was EUR 4.7 million, of which EUR 3.2 million related to overdue management fees.
However, the agency appears to be encountering difficulties in collecting the administrative fees.
The Agency recorded a provision for bad debts of 2.8 million euros in its 2017 accounts (ie 600,000 euros more than at the end of 2016).
3.7.12.
The verification of the quantities declared by the companies is the task of the member state authorities entrusted with enforcement; the Agency has no enforcement powers (see the emphasis of matter paragraph in paragraph 3.7.5).
Actions taken by Member State enforcement authorities are coordinated by the Enforcement Information Exchange Forum.
On 6 December 2017, the Forum adopted new Strategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of Chemical Regulations, providing a framework for developing national enforcement strategies.
The Agency's ability to fulfill its mission depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of this framework by the national authorities.
In its 2017 general report, the agency states that around two-thirds of companies did not update registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle.
This affects the effective implementation of the REACH regulation and also the accuracy of the fee calculation.
COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.7.13. The agency publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
OTHER REMARKS 3.7.14.
The agency's revenue from fees is linked to the registration deadlines for chemicals in the EU set in the REACH regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
As a result, the agency has no recurring fees and struggles with a mismatch between relatively stable spending and more volatile, less predictable revenues, making budgeting difficult.
The Agency is being helped in dealing with this situation by a grant it has received from the Commission.
With the third and final registration deadline for chemicals under REACH in 2018, revenue from fees and charges is expected to decrease from 2019 and the Agency to rely more on grants from the EU to fund its operations. household will be dependent.
FOLLOW-UP TO REMARKS FROM PREVIOUS YEARS 3.7.15. The Annex provides an overview of the corrective action taken in response to the Court's observations from previous years.
30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/59 Year 2014 2016 2016 2016 Status of corrective action (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a) Ongoing (1) Ongoing Ongoing Pending ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court's observations Expenditure on procedures related to a new specific activity of the Agency, the implementation of the Biocidal Products Regulation, was in principle covered by fees for the assessment of applications for registration of these products.
However, the fees collected in 2014 only covered 17% of this expenditure, so the rest was actually financed by contributions to the Agency's budget made by the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros). At 10.1 million euros or 39% (2015: 7.3 million euros or 32%), the rate of commitments carried over to the following financial year for Title III (operational expenditure Ń REACH) remained high. In the case of Title IV (operational expenditure → biocides), it was even higher at 1.3 million euros or 68% (2015: 1.5 million euros or 74%).
Such a high transmission rate is contrary to the budgetary principle of annuality. The Agency may consider making more use of differentiated budgetary appropriations to better reflect the multiannual nature of activities and unavoidable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.
According to the Biocidal Products Regulation, ECHA contributes to the functioning of the market for biocides and biocidal products.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the structure and operational implementation of ECHA's internal control system in relation to the Agency's processes and activities under the Biocidal Products Regulation is effective and efficient.
Although no serious deficiencies were identified, the IAS still sees room for improvement.
Unlike most other agencies, ECHA's founding regulation does not explicitly require periodic external evaluations of its activities, which are essential for the performance evaluation.
(1) In 2017, in the field of biocides, the Agency received fees and charges of 8.1 million euros (2016: 7.6 million euros), covering 65% of the expenditure on biocides (2015: 62% and 2016: 88%).
The remainder was financed by contributions to the Agency's budget from the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros).
EN C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.7.10.
The relevant legislation (REACH Fees Regulation (EC) 340/2008) does not provide that the Agency should carry out an ex-post verification of the size of all SME registrants.
The Agency's Management Board approved an approach whereby SME registrants with the greatest financial impact (ie with the most registrations within the largest tonnage band) are screened as a matter of priority.
The Agency is currently verifying the company size of SME registrants who submitted their dossiers up to 2015. In 2017, the Agency also turned its attention to UK SME registrants to verify their company size ahead of the UK's withdrawal from the European Union.
In the future, the agency will increasingly conduct reviews of the size of SMEs on the basis of the cost-benefit principle.
3.7.11.
The REACH Fees Regulation (EC) No. 340/2008 does not provide the agency with any instruments that would be necessary to enforce the collection of overdue administrative fees.
The agency proactively reminds debtors of their payment obligations. When this is unsuccessful, she hires local law firms to claim the outstanding fees and charges directly in the Member States.
The law firms have so far contacted 74% of the companies that have overdue administrative fees to pay. The outcome of this initiative will then be subjected to a cost-benefit analysis to determine next steps.
The member states bear the main responsibility for the enforcement of the REACH and the CLP regulation, in particular the obligation to register chemical substances.
The Agency's ability to fulfill its mission and to generate reasonable revenue from fees depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of enforcement strategies by national authorities.
Discussions are being held with the Commission to address this issue.
3.7.13.
The Agency takes note of the preliminary remark. This is a horizontal issue affecting a number of agencies.
The Agency publishes vacancies similarly to other agencies on its own website, on social media and on the EU Agencies Network (EUAN) website (https://euagencies.eu/).
In order to increase transparency and publicity and to enable citizens to consult vacancies, the Agency recommends that the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) in turn refer to the EUAN website.
3.7.14.
The preliminary remark is correct.
The agency is funded from a combination of revenue from fees and charges and a compensatory grant from the European Union.
The agency has submitted a number of alternative funding proposals to the Commission, including the introduction of recurring fees, like some other EU agencies.
The agency points out that according to its communication on the review of the REACH regulation of 5 March 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final), the Commission will examine all possible options to ensure sustainable funding of the agency in the future.

EUROPEAN INSURANCE AND OCCUPATIONAL PENSION SUPERVISORY AUTHORITY (EIOPA) INTRODUCTION 3.8.1.
The European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (hereinafter ădie BešrdeŇ, also ăEIOPAŇ), based in Frankfurt, was established by Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (76).
The authority's task is to contribute to the establishment of high-quality common regulatory and supervisory standards and practices, to contribute to the coherent application of legally binding Union acts, to stimulate and facilitate the delegation of tasks and responsibilities among competent authorities, to monitor market developments in its jurisdiction to monitor and evaluate and to promote the protection of policyholders, pension members and beneficiaries.

EN C 434/64 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.
EUROPEAN INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1.
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter ădas InstitutŇ, also ăEITŇ), based in Budapest, was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82).
The aim of the institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increasing competitiveness by strengthening the innovative capacity of the Member States and the European Union.
The Institute provides grants to a growing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs), which bring together higher education, research and business to foster innovation and entrepreneurship.
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.
