Other remarks 3.9.7.
In December 2016, just before the end of the eligibility period (1 January 2016-31 December 2016), the EIT signed amendments to the specific grant agreements with the KICs EIT Digital, InnoEnergy, Health and RawMaterials.
The amendment to the individual grant agreement with Climate KIC was even signed in January 2017, after the end of the eligibility period.
The increase in individual reimbursement rates agreed in these amendments allowed the KICs to receive an additional EUR 15 million in grants from the EIT (EUR 6.0 million additional for Climate KIC, EUR 5.6 million for EIT Health, 2.2 million euros for KIC InnoEnergy and 1.2 million euros for EIT RawMaterials).
This approach runs counter to the intention to encourage KICs to seek funding sources and to incentivize them to progressively reduce their financial dependency on the EIT.
It could also affect fair competition between KICs as co-financing of expenditure also plays a role in annual grant decisions.
3.9.8.
Due to changes in the business plans of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital, some activities not provided for in the original business plans were added retrospectively, with a total value of around EUR 3.3 million and EUR 0.6 million, respectively.
The activity added in the case of KIC InnoEnergy represents, in the Court's view, a significant change to the original business plan on the basis of which the initial maximum grant amount was awarded.
Since the level of grants awarded to each KIC is the result of a merit-based review process applied to their initially proposed business plans, subsequent significant changes to those plans call into question the grant decisions and the equal treatment of the KICs, thereby breaching Article 180(4). of the rules of application of the Financial Regulation.
3.9.9.
OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.9.10.
In 2017, the institute introduced a paperless payment system.
Although this has resulted in changes to its procedures and accounting system, the accounting system has not been re-validated since 2012.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11.
To further strengthen the internal control system for grants to KICs, the EIT introduced centralized ex-ante controls for those KIC partners whose cost claims exceeded 325 000 euros.
The controls were carried out by two auditing firms on behalf of the EIT (86) and resulted in certified cost statements from the KIC partners.
The results of the ex-post controls carried out by another auditing firm contracted by the EIT confirm that the new approach of the certified cost claims is effective and important, as most of the material errors found concerned cost claims using this ex-ante - had not been subjected to controls.
(86) In previous years, the attestation audit was carried out by numerous private auditing firms on behalf of each KIC partner, whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of 325 000 euros (reimbursement of actual costs and unit costs).
EN C 434/66 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.12.
The EIT business continuity plan and disaster recovery plan were adopted in 2013 and are outdated.
For example, more than half of the crisis management team members were no longer working for the EIT in 2017.
An updated version of the plans has been in the works for two years but has not yet been adopted.
As in previous years, the KICs did not fully absorb the financial support provided by the EIT.
The accepted total eligible costs of the KIC value-added activities of the five KICs operational before 2016 (first and second wave KICs combined) were 15% lower than assumed in the specific grant agreements concluded in early 2016 (87).
The main reason for the non-implementation of the funds was the incomplete implementation of business plans, partly due to the late approval of grant agreements and the multi-annual nature of KIC activities, and the self-financing rate of administrative costs, which was higher for some KICs turned out as planned.
Part of this appropriation has been used to increase the individual reimbursement rates originally set for eligible costs related to KIC value-added activities (see paragraph 3.9.7).
In particular, the second wave KICs (EIT Health and RawMaterials) have faced delays in starting their activities.
For the first wave KICs, according to the EIT assessment reports, the performance of Climate KICs in particular was insufficient.
3.9.14.
The EIT performed a performance assessment of the implementation of the business plans and then calculated some corrections.
However, these corrections had no financial implications for any of the KICs.
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for grant calculation, the EIT only applies the higher of the two for corrections that become necessary due to financial controls and performance evaluations.
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less appropriate for the grants awarded to the KICs, which fund a wide range of different activities.
It is questionable whether it is justified to offset corrections due to performance, for example in educational activities, against corrections due to financial controls, which may concern, for example, innovation projects.
3.9.15.
In 2017, all KICs adopted Funding Sustainability Strategies in line with the EIT Guidelines, marking an important step towards making the KICs more sustainable in the future.
However, the first wave KICs continued to generate little revenue (between 2% and 6% of the cost of KIC value-added activities) and little progress was seen in 2017.
Co-funding from the KIC partners also remains low (and lower than foreseen in the individual grant agreements originally signed): the KIC value-added activities are still funded from 62% to 90% through EIT grants, depending on the KIC.
3.9.16.
The EIT publishes vacancies on its own website and on the website of DG Human Resources and Security, but generally not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.9.17.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for e-invoicing (2010), e-tendering in the online edition of the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and e-submission of bids (2015).
OTHER REMARKS 3.9.18.
The current Interim Director of the EIT took office in July 2014.
A selection process to appoint a new director was launched in 2016 but was unsuccessful.
Since then, no new recruitment process has been initiated.
Holding this post ad interim for such a long period of time is contrary to the Staff Regulations, which stipulate that a post may be occupied temporarily for a maximum of one year.
3.9.19.
Pursuant to Article 5(1) of the Statute of the EIT, EIT staff shall be directly employed by the EIT on fixed-term contracts and shall be subject to the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Union.
Consequently, the EIT can only offer its temporary agents fixed-term employment contracts for a maximum period of five years, renewable once for a period of five years.
Those staff who joined the EIT shortly after its creation in 2009 will reach the maximum contract term of 10 years in 2020, which could create disruption to the continuity of operations and management in the coming years.

C 434/68 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Year 2012 2014 2014 2014 2015 2015 Status of corrective action (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a) Completed (1) Ongoing (2) Ongoing (3) Completed In Ongoing Completed ANNEX Follow-up of previous years' observations Court's observations The grant agreements did not set specific thresholds for certain cost categories (staff costs, subcontracting, legal services, etc.).
The institute overestimated its need for budget funds for 2014 by 13.1 million euros or 5.6% (2013: 3.4 million euros or 2.5%), so that only 220 million euros of the available 233.1 million euros euros were tied.
The low implementation rate is mainly due to unused grant appropriations (€11.4 million) to finance KIC activities.
According to the business plans of the KICs, on the basis of which the grant agreements were concluded, the Institute's 2014 budget did not have to be fully utilised.
The unused appropriations will be included in the 2015-2017 budgets in accordance with the Financial Regulation of the Institute.
Although the KICs need to develop strategies for sustainable funding, to date, in their fifth year of existence, they still depend entirely on funding from the Institute and the KIC partners.
Since its establishment in 2009, the institute has had to contend with high staff turnover and instability at management level.
Two of the three head of department positions have been vacant since 2013.
One of them has been filled ad interim since 2013, contrary to the statute, which stipulates a maximum duration of one year.
The other is currently held by the COO, who is also interim director and thus fulfills three functions at the same time.
In its special report 4/2016, the Court concluded that the eligibility condition that the EIT contribution to the KICs must not exceed 25% does not offer any significant benefit and its removal would reduce the burden on the KIC partners operational and financial reporting would be significantly reduced (4).
However, these certificates are of extremely different quality, so that the security that can be derived from them is limited and the institute has to carry out additional controls.
30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/69 EN Court's observations According to the EIT founding regulation, the Institute's tasks include mobilizing funds from public and private sources and deploying the resources in accordance with the provisions of that regulation.
In particular, the Institute aims to raise a significant and growing proportion of its budget from private financial contributions and from revenues generated through its own activitiesŇ.
Despite this provision, which clearly refers to the budget of the EIT, the contribution from Horizon 2020 funds accounted for 99% of its 2015 budget.
Although the Institute is allowed to use unused funds (i.e. funds not committed during the year or funds released at the end of the year) in the budgets for the following three years, it has not adjusted its procedures in time to allocate 26.6 million euros available from the 2014 grant agreements in the budgets for the years 2015-2017.
These funds were available because the KICs took up less funding than expected.
According to the Commission's original objective, the institute was to achieve financial autonomy in 2010.
In June 2011, however, the Institute was granted only partial financial autonomy, as grant transactions and procurement procedures worth more than 60,000 euros remain subject to the prior approval of the (supervisory) Directorate-General for Education and Culture.
The Institute sponsors the EIT Digital Masters School program, in which 16 European universities participate.
The model for reimbursement of the universities' costs is based on a combination of a lump sum of maximum 8 000 euro/student (according to the regulations of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs including indirect costs calculated as a lump sum.
On this basis, in 2015 the universities received an average total of 15 000 euros/student (including the lump sum).
However, the model was never formalized and it is not possible to distinguish which activities fall under the lump sum and which fall under actual costs.
The institution should move to a clear and formalized model for claiming costs, based on a single method, such as a single lump sum based on cost evidence.
Year 2015 Corrective Action Status (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a)
C 434/70 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observation The principle of sound financial management was breached when another KIC partner, through a procurement procedure, provided public relations services with daily rates ranging from 800 euro to 3 250 euro EUR per person, which were reimbursed in full by the institute (7).
The Institute used a framework contract from the Commission to organize conferences scheduled for 2015 and 2016 on the theme of innovation.
The agreed prices for these services ranged from EUR 800 per day for a junior consultant to EUR 2 250 per day for a senior consultant (almost four times the tariff stipulated in the framework contract for an executive).
The services procured at these prices amount to more than 100,000 euros per conference.
The Court found weaknesses related to the ex post verifications of the procurement procedures carried out by the legal entities of the KICs.
At least for one of the legal entities of the KIC, the selection of the procurement procedures to be reviewed was not representative of the population.
In addition, the Court came to a different conclusion regarding the legality and regularity of two procurement procedures.
In these cases, the Institute had accepted the direct specification or excessive expansion of the orders.
The Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded in its audit report 'Grant Management: Transition to Horizon 2020' that the Institute has successfully aligned its procedures with the rules applicable to Horizon 2020, in particular the Rules for participation, and that the controls carried out by the Institute during the start-up phase have generally proved to be an effective means of supporting new KICs.
The IAS also concluded that urgent action is needed to ensure the reliable application of the legal framework applicable to Horizon 2020 and to further improve the start-up phase of new KICs. The Institute and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan.
At EUR 0.4 million or 40% (2015: EUR 0.4 million or 44%), the rate of commitments carried over to the following financial year was high for Title II.
These transfers mainly relate to multi-year contracts for IT services and meeting expenses for which no invoices have yet been received.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/71 EN Court's observations The grants for calendar year 2015 were only awarded in April 2015 and the grant agreements were signed in June and July 2015.
For the 2016 calendar year, the grants were awarded and the grant agreements were signed in April 2016.
Despite an improvement in 2016, these delays in grant decisions and the signing of grant agreements create uncertainty and reduce partners' willingness to commit resources and kick-start activities at the beginning of the year.
Recent calls for new KICs, thematic areas of which have been identified in the EIT's Strategic Innovation Agenda for 2014-2020, have sparked little competition.
Only seven proposals were submitted to the 2014 call for two KICs (Health and RawMaterials).
As a result of the call for two additional KICs (Food and Manufacturing) published in 2016, three proposals were received and the single KIC Manufacturing (Added Value in Manufacturing) proposal was not selected for quality reasons.
The director's post has been filled ad interim since August 2014 and another managerial post since February 2013.
Not only does this violate the statute, according to which the temporary appointment may not last longer than a year, the frequent changes and long-term interim solutions also unsettle the stakeholders and affect strategic continuity. The institute is a key player in the implementation of the Horizon 2020 programme, with a budget of €2.4 billion over the period 2014-2020.
The Commission has created a central support point for Horizon 2020 to ensure coherence between the program implementing bodies in areas such as legal services, IT tools, grant management, dissemination and exploitation of research results, etc.
However, unlike bodies such as the Commission's executive agencies and public-private partnerships, the Institute does not have direct access to the support body, but has to have each case approved by the Commission's overall Directorate-General.
This requirement affects the efficiency of the Institute's activities.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are almost entirely funded by the Institute.
During its audit, the Court paid particular attention to the procurement procedures carried out by these bodies, which it considers to be a high-risk area.
According to the 2015 Grant Agreements, KIC legal entities and/or KIC partners must ensure that procurements achieve best value for money or, where appropriate, the lowest price criterion.
For all contracts over EUR 60 000, the grant agreements require the KIC legal entities and/or KIC partners to invite at least three economic operators to submit bids and to document the procurement process to demonstrate its transparency.
We audited a sample of procurement procedures, worth around 7 million euro, carried out by the legal entities of the KICs and fully funded by the EIT.
The audit revealed significant deficiencies, such as direct award of contracts, missing essential elements in tenders, significant extensions of the original contracts in terms of duration and/or scope, contracts without limitations in duration and/or scope, or quality/price weightings that eliminate price competition.
The Institute had also identified the shortcomings in the procurement procedures of one KIC legal entity and prepared an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KIC legal entities in the future.
Despite the significant increase in budgetary resources from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and although there have been six KICs since the end of 2016 instead of the previous three, the number of KICs approved has increased Places hardly changed (see Table 2).
As noted by the Court in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have sufficient capacity to cope with the increased workload.
The Interim Director of the Institute has highlighted this risk in the Institute's 2015 Annual Activity Report.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 REPLY OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7.
The EIT would like to clarify that amendments to the Specific Grant Agreements under the EIT KIC Framework Partnership Agreements can be submitted at any time during the eligibility period.
The KICs' amendments were subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and pre-approval by the European Commission.
The amendments were then signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally notified of the approval of the amendment request on 21 December 2016 (i.e. within the eligibility period).
Regarding the increase of the individual reimbursement rates, the EIT notes that no additional grant amount was paid to the KICs as a result of the changes to the 2016 Individual Grant Agreements.
The total amount of the grant finally awarded (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the amount initially awarded (274.9 million euros).
Regarding the call for KICs to find their own funding sources and become financially viable, we refer to our reply to section 3.9.15.
As part of the assessment of the amendments, the EIT, after consultation with the European Commission, came to the conclusion that the adjustment of the individual reimbursement rates corresponds to the applicable legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual reimbursement rates was open to all KICs on the same terms.
Regarding the second observation, the EIT considers that the changes complied with Article 180(4) of the Rules of Application of the Financial Regulation as they did not call into question the decisions awarding grants and did not go against the equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold that indicates which change to an action is to be considered “substantial” when assessing whether the change is relevant to the award of the grant.
The compliance with said provision of starting new activities has to be determined on a case-by-case basis on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the overall KIC business plan.
The EIT carried out the assessment before approving the amendments and concluded that the amendments did not call into question the decisions to award grants.
As each KIC had the possibility to include new eligible activities in their amended business plans on equal terms, the equal treatment of KICs was also ensured.
Finally, the EIT points out that in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity at issue represented only 3.9% of the amended budget of the KIC business plan.
At EIT Digital, this share was 0.6%.
3.9.10.
3.9.12.
The updated versions of the contingency plan and the disaster recovery plan will be adopted by the EIT in 2018.
3.9.13.
The 2016 Individual Grant Agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed later than expected as the Framework Partnership Agreements had to be signed first.
The specific grant agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, allowing the KICs to start their activities early in each year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-paced nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or plans do not live up to expectations of their potential and have to be suspended while the grant agreements are being implemented. Moreover, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as masters and doctoral courses or long-term research and innovation projects, are inherently multi-annual.
To address this issue, the EIT intends to enter into multi-annual grant agreements with KICs after 2020, provided the EIT budget allocates appropriate funds for commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has fully followed the methodology for grant calculations required by the Horizon 2020 legal basis and will continue to do so in the future.
The financial viability of KICs is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most challenging aspects of the EIT's mission.
Some of the Innovation Communities already have significant co-financing to support their activities and generate substantial income compared to their budget.
For example, EIT Digital had 26% co-financing (€22 million) to cover the cost of the 2016 KIC value-added activities. In addition, complementary KIC activities worth more than 200 million euros have been implemented and paid for by the partner organisations.
Another example is EIT Health: the KIC generated over €6 million in revenue in its first year of operation Ń a respectable amount compared to the total funding it had received from the EIT (around €19 million).

3.9.18.
The European Commission advertised the post of EIT Director on 1 June 2018 (91).
The first staff joined the EIT in 2010, reaching the maximum ten-year tenure in 2020.
In doing so, the EIT is aware of the risks, which were also highlighted in the EIT's 2017 Annual Activity Report.
The EIT formally requested the legal opinion of the European Commission by letter dated 14 May 2018.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), concluded a framework agreement with a contractor for the purchase of software licenses, maintenance and support services.
The framework contractor acts as an intermediary between the Agency and companies that can meet the Agency's needs.
For these intermediary services, the contractor of the framework agreement receives a surcharge of two to nine percent on the supplier prices. In 2017, payments totaling EUR 1.7 million were made to the contractor for the framework agreement.
The Agency did not systematically check the calculated prices and surcharges against the companies' offers, nor did it systematically check the invoices issued to the framework contractor. COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.10.9. The agency publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.10.10.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (96) (97). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/77 EN ANNEX Follow-up of previous years' observations Court's observations In 2014, the Agency concluded a 6-year framework contract worth 3,5 million euro for the purchase of IT goods and services -area off.
The agency underestimated the need and the expected contract value, resulting in an 80% contract utilization at the end of 2016.
A new procurement procedure has to be initiated four years earlier than expected, which means additional administrative costs.
In 2016, the Agency concluded seven framework contracts for the purchase of oil pollution response systems.
Each framework contract (one lot each in the procurement procedure) referred to a specific piece of equipment.
The procurement procedure was launched on the assumption that the total value of the seven framework contracts would be 7 million euros.
However, this assumption underestimated the Agency's needs and seven framework contracts were signed, each worth 7 million euros, bringing the total value of the contracts to 49 million euros.

3.10.9.
Following a court decision, EPSO decided that only vacancy notices in all official EU languages or in the languages specified in the agency's founding act can be published on the EPSO website.
Due to the high translation costs of this new policy (around EUR 19000 per advertised vacancy), EMSA Ń as well as many other agencies Ń no longer use EPSO services in their vacancy advertisements.
This issue was raised with EPSO by some agencies in December 2015.
EMSA would welcome a solution that offers both sufficient transparency and respects the principle of sound financial management.
The agency strives to promote its job postings to a wide audience by sharing them on various social media used by many people.
It should be noted that most EMSA vacancies are addressed to technical professionals who regularly check the EMSA website.
In 2017, EMSA made extensive preparations to adapt all internal procedures to the use of e-procurement.
EMSA can confirm that since the beginning of 2018 it has been introducing the e-procurement modules.
The deadline for EU bodies to use e-procurement is October 2018.

Year 2015 2016 Status of corrective action (completed/ongoing/pending/N/A) Ongoing N/A 2016 N/A EN ANNEX Follow-up to observations from previous years Court's observations The Agency plans to partially transfer administrative staff in 2016 from Heraklion to Athens.
The rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year is high for Title II (administrative expenditure) at 0.3 million euros or 25% (2015: 0.15 million euros or 22%).
This high rate is mainly due to transfers in Title I (staff expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is mainly related to IT investments and the purchase of a company car just before year-end.
As foreseen in the Agency's Financial Regulations, external evaluations of the Agency's performance have been carried out for 2014 and 2015; the final reports were presented in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the core operational activities carried out under the 2014 work program clearly relate to the legal mandate of the Agency; the effectiveness of the agency was rated as good.
However, room for improvement was identified regarding the division of the agency between Heraklion and Athens, which leads to cumbersome work processes and a lack of communication and collaboration.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs respond to network and information security needs across the EU and Member States and that the Agency is effective in meeting the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stressed that communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, who consider the Agency's mandate and outreach too limited, needs to be improved.
The Agency is currently implementing an action plan which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the agency transferred eight more staff to Athens, reducing the number of staff in Heraklion to 14(1).
As the Court highlighted in its 2013 report, pooling all staff in one location could probably further reduce costs.

The new accounting officer also received updated training on SAP to ensure a good understanding of the accounting system.
Nonetheless, ENISA will take remedial action to ensure an appropriate handover between outgoing and new staff.

All vacancy notices published by EPSO must be translated into all official EU languages.

ENISA has not carried out a formal operational and financial impact assessment of Brexit as it is not expected to have a material direct impact on ENISA's budget, operations and administration.

In December 2016, the Agency's Accounting Officer was appointed Interim Head of Finance and Procurement in addition to this role.
As part of this additional role, he is responsible for managing the staff responsible for initiating and verifying commitments and payments.
The agency's financial rules stipulate that these financial actors report to the authorizing officer.
However, according to the principle of segregation of duties, authorizing officers and accounting are separate and mutually exclusive functions.
In 2014, the Commission, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), concluded a framework agreement with a contractor for the purchase of IT hardware and software, as well as maintenance and support services (IT services) away.
In the case of an audited payment of around EUR 47,000, the agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without a competitive process or prior market analysis. In 2017, payments totaling EUR 1.1 million were made to the contractor.

NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.14.9.
The appropriations carried over for Title II (administrative expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) were high at 40% for each title or a total of 3.5 million euros, which is contrary to the budgetary principle of annuality.
There is no indication that the appropriations carried over are linked to expenditure planned during the budgetary process.
In December 2017, for example, the agency ordered IT equipment and office furniture for an amount of EUR 220,000.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (123) (124). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the online edition of the EU Official Journal (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
The agency had not implemented any of these tools by the end of 2017.
3.14.11.

EUROPEAN FOUNDATION FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF LIVING AND WORKING CONDITIONS (EUROFOUND) INTRODUCTION 3.15.1.
The European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions (hereinafter ăthe FoundationŇ, also ăEurofoundŇ), based in Dublin, was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 (125).
The Foundation's mission is to contribute to the design and creation of better living and working conditions in the Union through the promotion and dissemination of relevant knowledge.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.15.8.
As part of this year's audit of all EU agencies, the Court analyzed accounting, including the hierarchical position and independence of their accounting officers.
At the Foundation, the head of the administration and finance department is the superior of the accounting officer.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (129) (130). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017 the Foundation had introduced e-invoicing and e-tendering for certain procedures, but not e-submission of tenders.

C 434/96 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years The Court's observations In its report on the 2014 annual accounts, the Court pointed to under-pay for staff in the period 2005-2014, linked to the transition to new EU staff regulations in 2005.
Although the reasons for the underpayments are different (2014: non-compliance with the guaranteed minimum wages; 2015: application of an incorrect multiplication factor to the salaries), the Court again found underpayments (43350 euros) and some overpayments (168930 euros) which 30 active and former employees were affected.
Eurofound corrected all underpayments but will not recover the overpayments (in line with Article 85 of the current Staff Regulations).
The Foundation should re-analyze what mistakes may have been made in the transition to the 2005 Staff Regulations and carry out a comprehensive evaluation of its payroll.
In its December 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the need for the Foundation to improve its project management, particularly in terms of governance, monitoring and reporting.
The Foundation and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan.
The rate of commitments carried over to 2016 increased in Title III (operational expenditure) to 2.8 million euros or 43% (2015: 2.1 million euros or 31%), mainly due to cross-year projects (studies and pilot tests).
The Foundation may consider introducing differentiated budget appropriations to better reflect the multiannual nature of activities and unavoidable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.
External evaluations of its activities are not expressly required in the founding regulations of the Foundation.
The Commission's proposal for a new founding regulation stipulates that an evaluation must be carried out every five years.
Year 2016 2016 2016 2016 Corrective Action Status (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a)
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/97 REPLY FROM THE FOUNDATION 3.15.8.
The Management Board is satisfied with the current independence of the Accounting Officer, in particular with regard to his pre-existing power to report directly to the Chair, in accordance with Article 6.1 of the Charter of the Accounting Officer, and the Management Board's involvement in the appointment process.
However, a new founding regulation currently being discussed between the institutions is likely to give the role of Appointing Authority to the Management Board rather than the Director.
This will allow Eurofound to reassess the issue of greater independence for the accounting officer in the future.
3.15.9.
However, two pilot agencies have encountered significant problems with the software.
In addition, the e-procurement software is currently only available for open calls (but not for negotiated calls), of which Eurofound has very few per year.
Therefore, Eurofound will continue to monitor developments and is ready to invest in e-procurement once satisfied with its stability and functionality.

AGENCY FOR THE EUROPEAN GNSS (GLOBAL NAVIGATION SATELLITE SYSTEM) (GSA) INTRODUCTION 3.16.1.
The Agency for the European GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System) (hereinafter ăthe AgencyŇ, also ăGSAŇ), whose seat was transferred from Brussels to Prague(131) on 1 September 2012, was created by Regulation (EU) No. 912/2010 of European Parliament and of the Council (132) repealing Council Regulation (EC) No. 1321/2004 (133) on the management bodies of the European satellite navigation programs and amending Regulation (EC) No. 683/2008 of the European Parliament and of the rates(134).
Established under Council Regulation (EC) No. 1321/2004, the European GNSS Authority officially took over on 1 January 2007 all the tasks previously entrusted to the Galileo Joint Undertaking. The Agency continues to carry out these tasks as the ăAgency for the European GNSSŇ on the basis of Regulation (EU) No. 912/2010 as amended.
The Commission has also delegated the operation of the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) to the Agency through a delegation agreement.

Emphasis on a Fact 3.16.7.
On December 15, 2016, the Agency signed a framework agreement worth 1.5 billion euros for the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement process.
One of the bidders involved has brought proceedings against the Agency before the Court of Justice of the European Union to challenge the outcome of the procurement procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will rule on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and all associated individual orders and future payments.
The Agency disclosed and explained the matter in the 2017 Preliminary Financial Statements and further stated that in 2017 EUR 49 million (7% of the 2017 budget including amounts received through the Delegation Agreements) was disbursed in connection with the Framework Agreement .
Note 3.16.8.
Negotiations for an agreement on the details of the withdrawal are currently underway.
The Agency operates both the Galileo Security Center (GSMC) and Galileo Earth Stations in the UK.
In the annual accounts, in the chapter 'Events after the balance sheet date', the agency refers to the Commission's decision, adopted on 24 January 2018, to relocate the second location of the Galileo Security Center (GSMC) from the United Kingdom to Spain.
3.16.9.

The Agency revised its financial rules in 2014 and delegated its accounting function to the Accounting Officer of the Commission in 2015.
Although these events have resulted in significant changes to the Agency's procedures, the accounting system has not been re-validated since 2012 (138).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/101 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous years' observations Court's observations Fixed assets (net book value: 1,0 million euro) are not insured.
The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.
The promised validation of the systems did not take place due to the expected extensive changes in the procedures and in the flow of information after the agency's move.
The new accounting officer plans the next validation for 2020.
The agency has prepared business continuity plans for the security sites in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
However, there is no emergency plan for the headquarters in Prague and the agency as a whole.
The Agency's 2015 annual work plan was only adopted in March 2015 and its multi-annual work program 2014-2020 has yet to be adopted.
The late acceptance of central planning documents harbors risks for the achievement of the agency's goals.
In 2015, the agency had a high staff turnover with 14 leaving and 26 new employees.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no Agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not mentioned in its planning documents or activity reports.
In addition, the IAS noted that the terminology used for the different elements of the performance measurement system is not consistent, making performance monitoring difficult.
The Agency and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan. At 2.8 million euros or 46% (2015: 2.5 million euros or 42%), the rate of commitments carried over to the following financial year was high for Title II (administrative expenditure).
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's observation.
In 2015, GSA outsourced its accounting to the European Commission, so the Commission's Accounting Officer (within DG Budget) provides all services, including validation of local systems, required by Article 50 of the Framework Financial Regulation applicable to agencies.
The validation concept is currently being discussed and planned within the services of DG Budget.
3.16.11.
The publication of vacancies on the EPSO platform requires a translation into all official EU languages, whereas English is the agency's sole working language and the publication of vacancies in English is seen as a useful pre-selection step to ensure our working language is understood at first becomes.
In addition, the translation of job advertisements into all official EU languages would mean additional financial and time expenditure for the agency, so that no benefit can be derived from it Ń also for the above reasons Ń. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all vacancy notices on the inter-agency portal, which the agencies consider equivalent to EPSO and which offers EU citizens a sufficient level of transparency.
In addition, the agency also publishes its vacancies on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (provided by the Publications Office) for the publication of contract notices, contract award notices, notices of rectification, notices of changes, etc. are currently used in the GSA whenever appropriate under Article 264 of the Rules of Application.
The agency also intends to use the TED e-tendering system to create and publish tenders.
With this in mind, the GSA is currently coordinating with the Publications Office to register and create a system account.
With regard to high value bids (above the thresholds of Article 118(1) FR), the GSA is currently taking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe-SubmissionŇ module of the ăe-PRIORŇ information system developed by the European Commission (available from DG DIGIT provided) to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all bids meets all the requirements of the HO and AB.
It is pointed out that the ăe-SubmissionŇ module currently only supports open procedures and the GSA may therefore only use it for such procedures.
In this context, the GSA has already held a first coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of finalizing and signing an agreement with them to define the framework for ăe-SubmissionŇ and start its implementation.

EUROPEAN ENVIRONMENT AGENCY (EEA) INTRODUCTION 3.17.1.
The European Environment Agency (hereinafter ăthe AgencyŇ, also ăEUAŇ), based in Copenhagen, was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90(143).
The Agency's task is to set up an environmental monitoring network that will provide the Commission, Parliament, Member States and, more generally, the public with reliable information on the state of the environment.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.17.8.
As part of this year's audit of all EU agencies, the Court analyzed accounting, including the hierarchical position and independence of their accounting officers.
The Agency's Accounting Officer is subordinate to the Head of Administrative Services.
COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.17.9. The EEA noted that one of the European Topic Centers (ETC Inland, Coastal and Marine) implemented the 2016 Action Plan with significant delays.
It therefore did not accept some of the results and rejected part of the costs claimed by the ETC.
The correction of the amount of the final payment also shows that the financial and performance controls related to the grants awarded to the ETC have been further improved.
3.17.10.
Some shortcomings were identified in several award procedures.
For several tenders, the agency used specifications that did not contain minimum requirements for economic and financial capacity in the selection criteria.
Based on these criteria - contrary to their objective - it is therefore not possible to determine whether a bidder fulfills the necessary requirements for the implementation of the contract.
3.17.11.
Price competition for some high value tenders was based solely on the daily rates offered for specific profiles and not on the estimated time required to complete the tasks.
Framework agreements were concluded with only one bidder, although a reopening of competition between different bidders would lead to better results in relation to the individual contracts.
3.17.12.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (147) (148). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
3.17.13.
In particular, the decisions made in the minutes of the selection committee were not justified in sufficient detail.
The criteria used at each stage of the selection process and the role of each member of the selection committee need to be clarified in order to improve transparency and equal treatment of candidates.
(147) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Government (ăe-GovernmentŇ).
(148) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012, Article 95(2) Electronic Government (ăe-GovernmentŇ).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/105 3.17.14.
The agency publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and allow citizens to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies in one place. The main reason given by the Agency is the high cost of translating EPSO publications, which have to be translated into all official EU languages.
NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.17.15.
In order to implement the Copernicus delegation agreement concluded with the Commission, the Agency made several Copernicus-related legal commitments before receiving the pre-financing from the Commission.
Although these commitments had an exceptional report signed by the Director of the Agency, this practice is in breach of the rules of application of the Financial Regulation.
FOLLOW-UP TO REMARKS FROM PREVIOUS YEARS 3.17.16. The Annex provides an overview of the corrective action taken in response to the Court's observations from previous years.
C 434/106 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous years' observations Court's observations In 2016 the Agency updated its security policy, but many of its other internal procedures are outdated.
The Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) performed a performance audit of the processes used to produce the State of the Environment Report 2015 (SOER).
In 2014, the Commission, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), concluded a framework contract with a contractor for the purchase of software and licenses, as well as related IT maintenance and consultancy services.
In 2016, the agency used this framework agreement to purchase software licenses totaling EUR 442,754.
The largest order concerned the renewal of software licenses provided by an exclusive Scandinavian reseller (112 248 euros).
In this case, the use of the framework contract, which led to unnecessary surcharges, was not justified. Year 2016 2016 Corrective Action Status (Completed/Ongoing/Pending/N/A) Completed N/A 2016 Ongoing
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/107 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.17.8. The Agency has discussed the Court's observation with the auditor and is satisfied that the functional independence is guaranteed by the fact that the auditor is a senior grade (AD 12) official and direct has access to the board of directors.
COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the Court's recognition of the further improvement in its management of ETC, both in terms of financial and operational controls.
In order to avoid a repeat of the problem encountered in 2017 at ETC Inland, Coastal and Marine waters, the task in question has been removed from the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency endeavors to maintain the current level of controls on grants awarded to ETCs.
The Agency confirms that it changed the requirements related to the verification of the financial capacity of bidders during 2017 and that bidders are now required to provide information on financial ratios (liquidity, solvency and profitability); in addition, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the Application Rules (AB), a minimum turnover is now required, which must be at least twice the estimated annual contract value.
The Agency would like to reiterate that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors was made consciously and with due regard to the limited competition in the relevant markets and the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
When awarding specific contracts on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency takes into account not only the contractually agreed daily rates, but also the estimated number of days required to carry out the tasks in order to calculate an estimate of the budget available for a specific Individual order to be applied.
Only then will negotiations begin with the contractor on the details of his bid, always making sure to get the best value for money.
If the tender is resumed, the agency has no means of further negotiations on the bidders' offers.
In accordance with the decision of the Board of Directors of November 9, 2015 to introduce a solution for the electronic processing of procurement procedures in the EEA, the Agency introduced electronic invoicing for certain procedures in the course of 2014 and is now in the process of applying this module to all expand their procedures; the electronic tender, on the other hand, has been valid since January 1, 2015 for all general tenders.
The integration of electronic submission of tenders started in early December 2017 and the first call for tenders using this module was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002 Ń Provision of publishing services to the EEA).
The Agency takes note of the Court's observation and confirms that it is currently adapting its selection/recruitment procedures on the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the different phases (pre-selection, selection, application interview and written test) is described in the relevant Documents additionally confirmed with the time (not only with the date). b) Expected answers to the questions given for the interview and the written test are systematically worked out in the pre-selection phase. c) An electronic (paperless) procedure will be introduced to improve reporting.
3.17.14.
EPSO has refused publication for the agency on the grounds that the precondition that all vacancies are translated into all official languages is not met.
However, the Agency does not have the means or the resources to respond to EPSO's request.
In this case, not only would all job offers have to be translated, but also the applications in all official languages would have to be processed, which would involve prohibitively high additional costs.
Like most other EU agencies, the agency has therefore looked for an alternative to the EPSO website and has been using a website for its announcements since May 2018 that serves the same purpose; it is the agency job advertisement board set up and maintained by the network of EU agencies .
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and its own Facebook pages to ensure the best possible dissemination.
EN C 434/108 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 BUDGETARY REMARKS 3.17.15.
Before finalizing the delegation agreement for Copernicus with DG GROW, the Agency underlined that the pre-financing conditions are incompatible with the Financial Regulation (Article 7 QD to the Financial Regulation 2014).
Initially, DG GROW was understanding in its reply; however, DG BUDG, responsible for preparing the standard template, refused to amend the delegation agreement.
After the start of the implementation of the delegation agreement, the agency continued to point out the problems and explained that it is regularly forced to claim exceptions in order to be able to continue its operational activities; this eventually led DG GROW to amend the pre-financing terms of the Delegating Agreement in August 2017 and to undertake an additional pre-financing in November 2017.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.19.8.
The Agency delegated its accounting function to the Accounting Officer of the Commission in 2014.
In addition, in 2014 the agency's headquarters were relocated and in 2016 its mission was redefined.
Although these events have resulted in changes in the Agency's procedures, the accounting system has not been re-validated since 2013.
In December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement with an economic operator worth EUR 1.6 million and lasting four years for the provision of temporary staff.
The only competition criterion in the award procedure was the price.
A framework agreement with several companies selected on the basis of price and quality criteria would have been better in order to provide quality services in a timely manner.
3.19.10.
On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to leave the European Union (Brexit).
3.19.11.
The agency publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and allow citizens to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies in one place.
3.19.12.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a common solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (160) (161). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE REPORTS 3.19.13.
The Commission's Internal Audit Service issued an audit report in 2017 on the Agency's training needs assessment, planning and budgeting (162).
The Agency prepared an action plan to take remedial action in areas where there was potential for improvement. FOLLOW-UP TO REMARKS FROM PREVIOUS YEARS 3.19.14.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/115 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.19.8.
CEPOL agrees with the Court's observation.
In 2014, CEPOL outsourced its accounting to the European Commission, so the Commission's Accounting Officer (within DG Budget) provides all services, including validation of local systems, required by Article 50 of the Framework Financial Regulation applicable to agencies.
The validation concept is currently being discussed and planned within the services of DG Budget.
3.19.9.
The Agency has taken note of the Court's observations but does not share its opinion.
The quality criteria were included in the technical specifications and tenderers who did not confirm their ability to meet the criteria were to be excluded.
The decision to award a single framework contract is based on previous experience and specificities of the national labor market.
The Agency has taken note of the Court's observations.
Brexit was discussed in executive meetings; the discussions in the NAPO (inter-agency network for procurement officers) and in the IALN (inter-agency legal network) as well as the communications sent by the Commission were closely followed.
The risks for CEPOL were assessed as low, but not officially documented.
The estimated cost of translating vacancy notices into all official EU languages, as required for publication on the EPSO website, is considered to be too high given the expected benefits.
From 2018, CEPOL will also publish all vacancies on the interagency job exchange developed by the network of EU agencies.
The Agency has taken note of the Court's observations and has confirmed that progress is being made towards the introduction of electronic submission of tenders in cooperation with DG DIGIT.
3.19.13.
The Agency confirms that progress has been made in the implementation of the action plan, with two out of four recommendations rated as implemented by the Internal Audit Service.
EN C 434/116 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.
EUROPEAN ASYLUM SUPPORT OFFICE (EASO) INTRODUCTION 3.20.1.
The European Asylum Support Office (hereinafter ădas OfficeŇ, also ăEASOŇ), based in Valletta, was established by Regulation (EU) No 439/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (163) to promote practical cooperation in the field of asylum and to To support Member States in fulfilling their European and international obligations to protect vulnerable people.
Since 2015, the office has been supporting Greece and Italy in the context of the migration crisis.
3.20.2.

Payments Basis for adverse opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the accounts 3.20.6.
Paragraphs 3.20.9-3.20.31 describe material and systematic violations of the Office's financial regulations and other rules and regulations in the payments. Payments made in connection with procurement and hiring procedures were particularly hard hit.
The cumulative error due to irregular payments is at least €7.7 million or 10.3% of the total payments made by the Office in 2017.
Opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.20.7.
In our opinion, the payments underlying the financial statements for the financial year ended December 31, 2017 are material because of the significance of the matters described in the section Basis for Disagreed Opinion Regarding the Legality and Regularity of Payments Underlying the Financial StatementsŇ buggy.
Emphasis of Matter 3.20.8.
From the end of 2017, the staffing situation at the office deteriorated exponentially.
At the management level of the Office, four out of ten Head of Unit posts and 18 out of 27 Head of Division posts were vacant.
In the ăAdministrationŇ department, three out of four head of department posts and five out of ten department head posts were vacant. This poses a significant challenge to the senior management of the office.
In addition, at the end of May 2018, 129 temporary staff positions were filled, but 78 were still open.
Of the posts for contract staff, 71 were filled and 13 were still open.
The office currently does not have the administrative capacity to fill that many vacancies (see Table 2).
Overall, the continuation of the office's activities to the current extent is significantly jeopardized by this situation.
EN C 434/118 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Table 2 Office organizational chart at the beginning of June 2018
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 COMMENTS ON THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF PAYMENTS AND THE RELEVANT INTERNAL CONTROLS The nature of its activities poses major risks for the Office 3.20.9.
Since 2016, the Office has faced an unprecedented expansion of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis.
This is reflected in an increase in the budget from an initial €19 million in 2016 to €79 million after the second budget change in 2017.
The number of award procedures rose from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017.
Payments increased by 225% from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017.
3.20.10.
The office is one of the few institutions in the European Union that has multiple locations.
In addition to the headquarters in Malta with 179 permanent staff, the Office manages two major support operations in Greece and Italy, involving in 2017 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural mediators (interpreters), 178 temporary staff and 21 permanent staff of the Office.
3.20.11.
As already noted by the Court in our special report 6/2017 'EU response to the refugee crisis: the hotspot approach', the Office is highly dependent on Member States providing sufficient resources.
The efficiency of the activities is hampered in particular by the fact that Member States send their experts for very short periods (six to eight weeks).
The exceptional operational challenge caused by the migration crisis has not been mitigated by sound governance and effective internal controls 3.20.12.
When it started supporting Greece and Italy in 2015, the Office was confronted with Member States providing insufficient resources for deployments.
The office had previously encountered difficulties in filling the posts foreseen in its staffing plan.
Since 2014, the Court has regularly repeated its remark that the Office is struggling with high staff turnover.
The Court has repeatedly emphasized in its previous annual reports that this situation poses a significant risk to the achievement of the objectives set in the annual and multiannual work programmes.
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment processes and 100 new contracts in 2017) the Office has not managed to recruit and retain sufficient staff (see also the 'Emphasis on a matter' paragraph in paragraph 3.20.8).
3.20.13.
The extraordinary operational challenge caused by the migration crisis was not mitigated by a solid management structure.
The Management Board did not set up an internal audit function at the Office and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to internal audit.
Until the end of 2017, the Board of Directors exercised only limited oversight over the financial management.
3.20.14.
The Office does not have an internal legal service, nor is there any systematic internal review of legal documents.
The office outsources most legal issues (mainly personnel and procurement issues) without internal resolutions or guidelines clearly specifying who may outsource which legal issues, to which law firm and under what conditions.
Although the office consults at least eight different law firms, it lacks a comprehensive inventory of all relevant contracts, cases and opinions.
3.20.15.
Legal services are not adequately reviewed by the Office to ensure that they are solely in defense of the Office's interests and not in defense of the interests of any individual.
Appropriate procedures to protect against conflicts of interest are not always effective.
In general, the use of external lawyers reduces the possibility of settling disputes before a lawsuit is filed.
3.20.16.
The matters set out in paragraphs 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the Office to risk of financial loss and damage to its reputation.
The Office is currently investigating these matters internally.
Numerous material breaches of regulations due to lack of internal controls Payments for contingency services 3.20.17.
In 2017, payments totaling 7.7 million euros were made for temporary work.
In the absence of a competitive public procurement procedure, the Court found the contract for auxiliary services in Greece to be irregular in its audit carried out in relation to 2016.
Nevertheless, in 2017 the Office still made payments of 4.8 million euros under this irregular contract.
EN C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18.
The procurement procedures for temporary services carried out in Malta in 2017 (payment volume in 2017: 1.0 million euros) were inadequate in their execution (e.g. short deadlines for submitting offers, lack of transparency in the case of deadline extensions), which made the competition Ń one of the most important principles in public procurement procedures Ń was impaired.
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no offers were received.
3.20.19.
Contracts were inadequately checked for compliance with national regulations on temporary employment, exposing the office to significant financial and reputational risks.
In addition, the verification of time sheets for temporary workers and identified irregularities showed significant weaknesses.
Payments for personnel expenses 3.20.20.
Personnel-related payments amounted to 13.5 million euros in 2017. The Court found serious weaknesses in four of the 14 recruitment procedures audited.
3.20.21.
For example, the Office did not publish a vacancy notice to fill the post of senior consultant, but instead recruited directly from a reserve list prepared for the post of department head.
The extensions of deadlines were not always justified in view of the number of applications received by the original deadline.
3.20.22.
Some procedures for recruiting AD staff were not appropriate for the grade advertised.
In a procedure for filling a managerial post in the 'Administration' department, the vacancy notice was more restrictive than for the same posts in other departments.
In another procedure, the office did not adequately document the suitability of the applicants.
Payments for Rent and Related Works 3.20.23.
The total rent for all offices at the various locations amounted to two million euros in 2017.
The Court found that the Office had signed the leases for the expansion of the headquarters in Malta and several new offices in Athens, Lesvos and Chios without having properly analyzed the local market beforehand.
3.20.24.
In June 2017 the office signed a lease for office space in Lesvos.
It also accepted a contract with the landlord - without any competition - for works to adapt the rented building to the needs of the office.
The value of the construction contract (0.7 million euros during the first months of the lease) exceeded the annual value of the lease many times over.
Investing significant amounts in rented buildings involves significant financial and operational risks.
3.20.25.
In 2018, the office decided to terminate a lease for office space in Chios and related construction work.
It is currently trying to limit the financial risk exposure caused by the termination.
Payments for travel expenses 3.20.26.
The Court found a contract for travel services worth €4 million for 2016 to be irregular in its audit.
The contract was awarded to a bidder who did not meet all the selection criteria.
The Office continued to make payments of 1.5 million in 2017 based on this irregular engagement.
3.20.27.
In 2017, the Office found significant deficiencies in the recognition of travel services, in particular the lack of supporting documents to prove that the travel services in question were actually requested or provided.
The Office is currently investigating this matter internally.
Other payments 3.20.28.
In addition, other services such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services, which were based on public procurement procedures, were also systematically affected by the same deficiencies.
The Court found significant weaknesses in the needs assessment for the office, the drafting of the specifications, the choice of contract type, the procurement procedures used, the deadlines for submitting tenders, the evaluation and award procedures (ie the weighting of price criteria versus quality criteria), the € Changes and renewals of contracts, the execution of the contracts and the review of the services provided.
These shortcomings affect the principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of bidders.
The following paragraphs contain some examples of the above deficiencies.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/121 3.20.29.
The Office directly awarded a service contract in 2017 for consultancy services related to the implementation of the Action Plan on Greek islands.
The contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without using any of the procurement procedures provided for in the Financial Regulation.
The procurement procedure and all related payments (992000 euros) were therefore irregular.
3.20.30.
The office has since amended the original contract concluded in 2016 with a law firm for 5,000 euros several times and increased it to 259,000 euros in 2018.
Payments totaling EUR 98,332 were made under the contract in 2017, partly for consulting services that required a competitive public procurement process.
The changes and payments relating to these consulting services were therefore irregular.
3.20.31.
The execution of the contract concluded in 2013 (value: 120,000 euros, increased to 132,000 euros in 2017) for the organization of four to six major events in an international hotel over a period of four years was not in accordance with the original subject matter of the contract.
The office instead used the contract for about 50 smaller events.
The contract was therefore not executed in accordance with the regulations.
NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.20.32.
According to the agreements between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway, the Swiss Confederation and the Principality of Liechtenstein (also referred to as Associated Countries) regarding their participation in the Bureau, the Associated Countries are fully involved in the work of the Bureau and are entitled to Office support measures.
The Office received a grant from the Commission in 2016 to ensure adequate capacity building in Greece, support the implementation of the Declaration of European Union and Turkey and significantly speed up the relocation to alleviate the current heavy burden on Greece.
All of these activities form part of the Office's core business of supporting activities of common interest.
The Office used the grant to pay (6.4 million euros in 2016 and 1.7 million euros in 2017) commitments related to these activities.
However, it did not include these amounts in the calculation of the associated countries' contributions.
If these contributions were included, the associated countries would have to pay EUR 0.5 million more.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/123 The Court's observations In February 2016, the Office directly awarded a 12-month framework contract worth EUR 3,6 million for support services related to the management of the migration crisis.
The framework contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without using any of the procurement procedures provided for in the EU Financial Regulation. The award is therefore not in line with the relevant EU rules and the resulting 2016 payments of EUR 592 273 are irregular.
In August 2016, the Office launched an open procedure (five lots) to award a framework contract to cover its needs for cultural mediators/interpreters in different countries.
The total value of the framework contract for the four awarded and tested lots (lots 2-5) was 60 million euros over four years.
However, this contractor met the financial requirements of the selection criteria (annual turnover of EUR 1 million) for only two of the three previous years; for the other year, a declaration of commitment was concluded with a non-profit organization, according to which it made its "sales" available to the contractor (approval loan).
At the extraordinary meeting of the European Council on April 23, 2015 and in the ten-point plan on migration adopted by the foreign and interior ministers on April 20, 2015, Member States were called on to introduce fingerprinting for all secure migrants.
This required the purchase and subsequent donation to the Greek State of 90 fingerprint scanners and 90 compatible computers (equipment) for an amount of €1.1 million under a grant agreement between the Commission and the Office.
However, no officials from the office were on hand to meet this request. Furthermore, confirmation from the Greek competent authorities that the fittings had been delivered to the hotspots in February and early March 2016 and put to their intended use only came in July 2017.
