EN C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OFFICE The Office thanks the Court for the extremely helpful report.
At the same time, the Office is grateful to the Court for its acknowledgment of the extremely difficult situation in which the Office found itself during the reporting period, due to the enormous increase in its tasks: it was given additional mandates to support Member States and to participate in the implementation of initiatives to participate at EU level; these included the redistribution and the EU-Turkey Statement, the budget increase, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in procurement procedures (both in number and in complexity).
In addition, the office has to manage a large number of locations and numerous management positions (heads of departments, heads of divisions, heads of sectors) are vacant.
In its present reply, the Office will elaborate on some of the Court's observations; overall, however, it accepts the report and the findings it contains.
3.20.6. and 3.20.13.
Regarding the systematic breaches of policy in the Office, the Office – under new management – has begun to take the necessary steps to ensure that compliance is a priority and central to the culture and execution of all its actions.
This includes an objective, honest and open internal control, ăself-assessmentŇ.
The Office accepts the Court's finding that the supervisory and internal control structures for which the Office is responsible have not in the past received the attention required to ensure reasonable legality and regularity.
Here, too, the Office would like to state that the development of the structures and procedures for the systematic guarantee of legality and regularity (and the correspondingly precise and comprehensive reporting) will have absolute priority under the new management.
3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.
The Court rightly underlines the fact that the staffing situation in the office has deteriorated and is insufficient, and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system.
The current staffing situation is one of the main challenges facing the Office in addressing the shortcomings identified by the Court in its observations, which can largely be seen as a consequence of the lack of resources to work in a structured and orderly manner.
The Office is taking a head-on approach to solving this problem and, on the basis of a thorough recruitment plan, which has been preceded by a needs assessment, is pursuing urgent recruitment procedures to fill managerial and other key positions (operational and administrative).
In addition, the office is making efforts in the area of employee satisfaction to solve the problem of staff turnover. Although in this context it must be borne in mind that the low weighting plays an important role compared to the rather high cost of living in Malta, the Office recognizes that more effort needs to be made to improve staff satisfaction.
Some measures such as flexible working options, improved internal communication and the organization of employee events have already been introduced.
3.20.9. and 3.20.19.
The Court gives a correct account of the difficulties and the rapid growth, in absolute terms, of financial transactions and procurement procedures.
These figures speak a clear language, but basically they do not adequately reflect the constraints in terms of finances and allocation.
These figures do not take into account other facts and measures that add to the procurement dilemma, such as the following two aspects: Ń The use of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulations), which is a heavy workload for the procurement sector.
This is expected to deteriorate further in the years to come as the Office will need to call in [medical] experts to assist with COO medical information tasks.
Ń market-specific difficulties and limitations associated with our geographic areas of operation.
In rural regions of Italy and Greece, the conditions for a competitive market for the provision of office services and products are not very good.
In addition, the Office is atypical in terms of contract size for Maltese economic operators as clients, who tend to lack the capacity to meet the needs of the Office's larger contracts.
3.20.10.-3.20.12. and 3.20.19.
This feature is essential for understanding the relatively large amount of administrative support required and the extremely complex environment when it comes to introducing functioning internal control structures.
It should also be noted that the Office relies to an unusually large extent on contractors due to its operational activities, its geographically widespread area of work and (as the Court rightly notes) the limitations in the use of Member State experts.
This is a factor causing a multiplication of tasks related to procurement and finance (including decentralized financial actors) since for sites in Greece, Italy and Cyprus
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/127 specific contracts are required for hotspots in Greece and Italy (leasing contracts, contracts for cleaning, security, water supply and essential contracts, e.g. for the provision of temporary and interpreting services) .
In this case too, human resources are of crucial importance and the Office is currently (acknowledging the multiplication factor due to its nature as a multi -site agency) exploring the possibility of allocating the necessary resources to ensure overall accuracy and quality in the procurement and financial cycles as well as to ensure legality and regularity and to have the decentralization checked by a consulting firm.
3.20.14., 3.20.15. and 3.20.16.
The Office recognizes the need for in-house legal expertise and accepts this need.
In addition, the Office fully agrees that legal services must always strictly represent the interests of the Office and not the interests of any individual (but are not mutually exclusive).
The Office acknowledges that the involvement of outside legal services was not adequately controlled.
As the Court states in its report, internal investigations into this matter are continuing and the results are being communicated to the Court.
3.20.17. and 3.20.26.
The office accepts the remarks.
These corrective actions were taken immediately after the Court identified the irregularity in its 2016 audit report (Court's report received in September 2017).
Unfortunately, however, due to the deadlines and the fact that the Office replaced the contracts as soon as possible after finding them non-compliant, payments under the contract did occur in 2017.
3.20.18. and 3.20.19.
The Office accepts the comments and reiterates that these problems can be seen as a result of insufficient resources and deficiencies in internal control and management, all of which the Court identifies in its report.
3.20.23.-3.20.25.
As the Court mentions in its report, an internal investigation into this matter is ongoing.
3.20.29.-3.20.31.
3.20.32.
As regards the last paragraph of the report (43), the Office has some doubts as it carried out its work in 2016 according to the agreements with DG BUDG.
The Office has been in contact with DG BUDG on this matter to further clarify this matter and will take immediate action should DG BUDG change its previously communicated position.
EN C 434/128 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.21.
EUROPEAN CENTER FOR DISEASE PREVENTION AND CONTROL (ECDC) INTRODUCTION 3.21.1.
The European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (hereinafter ăthe CentreŇ, also ăECDCŇ), based in Stockholm, was established by Regulation (EC) No 851/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council (167).
It is also intended to coordinate the Europe-wide networking of bodies active in this area.

The Accountant of the Authority is supervised by the Head of Administration/Corporate Services.

EFSA welcomes the Court's unqualified opinions on the reliability of the accounts, and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts.
3.22.8.
In order to ensure the independence of the Accounting Officer, the formal requirement set out in EFSA's Financial Regulations is implemented at EFSA as follows: The current Accounting Officer was appointed in 2008 by EFSA's Management Board.
The accounting officer reports to the head of the BuS department. To ensure the accounting officer's functional independence in the performance appraisal procedures, the head of the BuS department acts as assessor and the chairman of the audit committee acts as countersigning officer.
The Board of Directors may at any time remove the Accounting Officer temporarily or permanently from his post.
3.22.9.
On the issue of single tenders versus cascading framework agreements, there is no obligation to use the single tender model and either model may be appropriate depending on the particular scenario.
EFSA believes that single competitive calls are again more appropriate for standard services and are used in EFSA contracts for statistical services, systematic literature review and target group research.
EFSA uses the cascade model in cases where the focus is on a long-term contractual relationship.
In particular in the case of the framework contract for external audit services, the main issues are to ensure i) a proper understanding of EFSA's activities, ii) a coherent audit methodology and iii) credibility at all levels of governance.
EFSA has control over the budget for proposals made in the cascade system by the contractor.
3.22.10.
EFSA will duly implement the agreed post-IAD action plan on the assessment of regulated products/assessment phase in pesticide authorization.

3.23.7.
The following observations do not call into question the Court's opinion. COMMENTS ON THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF OPERATIONS 3.23.8.
At the end of the 2017 financial year, the Institute was a defendant in four disputes brought before the courts by rejected bidders in connection with three procurement procedures.
In each of these cases, the applicant sought annulment of the award decision and an award of damages.
The damages claimed in these four cases amount to 700 000 euros or 9% of the Institute's annual budget.
According to the assessment of the Institute's external lawyer, a provision of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) has been booked to cover expected losses.
The judgment rendered by the court in each of these cases will determine the legality and regularity of the award procedures for these contracts and future payments.
In 2016, the institute issued an open call for tenders for travel services.
The specifications and the evaluation process did not offer a sufficient guarantee of the best value for money.
The award formula and pricing mechanism were inappropriate as they did not allow for a proper evaluation of the bids submitted by the bidders.
The framework agreement was concluded for a maximum period of four years and a maximum amount of 700,000 euros.
In 2017, payments amounting to 137,000 euros were made.
3.23.10.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017 the institute had introduced e-invoicing for certain procedures, but not e-tendering and e-submission of bids.
3.23.11.
The Institute publishes vacancies on its own website and social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and allow citizens to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies in one place.
INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICE REPORTS 3.23.12.
The Commission's Internal Audit Service issued an audit report in 2017 on EIGE's management of stakeholder relations and external communication' (182).
FOLLOW-UP TO REMARKS FROM PREVIOUS YEARS 3.23.13. The Annex provides an overview of the corrective action taken in response to the Court's observations from previous years.

In 2016, the Institute launched an open call for a framework contract for the maintenance and updating of its gender statistics tools and sources for a maximum amount of 1.6 million euros.
When asked by a bidder, the institute clarified on its website that the maximum amount per lot was 800,000 euros.
However, two separate framework contracts were signed with the same bidder for a maximum amount of 1.6 million euros per lot, with an option to further increase the amounts by up to 50% per lot, allowing the Institute to continue throughout the term of the framework contract (up to four years) to conclude individual orders of up to EUR 4.8 million or three times the amount specified in the contract notice.
In 2016 payments amounting to 87 920 euros were made.
In response to the audit, the Institute signed addendums to both framework contracts reducing the maximum amounts to EUR 800000 each (with a potential maximum increase of 50%).
In the invitation to tender under a negotiated procedure with a single bidder for the procurement of services for the maintenance and support of IT tools and databases, the maximum price for all three services described was capped at 81 000 euros (excluding VAT) and it was stipulated that higher offers would not be considered.
However, after receiving offers for two of the three requested services, the institute concluded a service contract with a price of 97 410 euros.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/143 3.24.14.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (187) (188). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. Administration of Consulting Services 3.24.15.
In the previous year it was checked how the agency manages consulting services. Among other things, two selected projects for the implementation of the Pharmacovigilance Regulation (Regulation (EU) No. 1027/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (189)) and the regulation on clinical trials (Regulation (EU) No. 536/2014 of the European Parliament and Council (190)), which required the construction of complex EU-wide networks, which required extensive technical IT developments.
As the number of posts in the agency's establishment plan was not increased, which would have allowed it to build up the necessary expertise in-house, the agency turned to consultancies to carry out these tasks.
However, the over-reliance on consulting firms has left the agency critically dependent on this outside expertise.
3.24.16.
In order to bring the projects back under its control, the agency determined which functions must not be outsourced but must be carried out internally.
In addition, the agency is no longer awarding consultancy contracts based on the criteria of time and resources, but on a fixed price basis.
It also set up a more appropriate process for approving project changes.
3.24.17.
It will take time to reduce the Agency's critical reliance on consulting firms and the impact of the actions taken will only be felt over the years.
One of the two major projects reviewed in 2016, the pharmacovigilance project (EudraVigilance Adverse Drug Reactions Database), was completed in 2017 at an additional cost of around EUR 0.5 million.
The clinical trials project is still ongoing. A date for the start-up was not set, but the budget was increased again in 2017 by a further 4.9 million euros (191).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/145 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous years' observations Court's observations The Regulation on the Agency's fees specifies due dates for the collection of fees from applicants and the related payments by the Agency to the competent national authorities fixed(1). Most of the transactions audited by the Court failed to meet these deadlines.
In 2014, the Agency conducted an administrative procedure against its Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) staff member.
Since the introduction of a new IT accounting system in 2011, the reporting on the work processes related to the commitments and on the utilization has not been transparent enough.
The agency negotiated business rate agreements for accommodation of experts with 25 hotels in London without using a competitive tendering process.
The six agreements on business tariffs and the payments based on them in 2016 amounting to around 2.1 million euros are therefore illegal.
In 2014, the Commission, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), concluded a framework contract with a contractor for the purchase of software and licenses, as well as related IT maintenance and consultancy services.
In 2016, payments totaling EUR 8.9 million were made to the contractor for the framework agreement.
The Agency did not systematically check the calculated prices and surcharges against the suppliers' offers, nor did it systematically check the invoices issued to the framework contractor.
C 434/146 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations Since 2014, the Agency has undergone two major reorganizations, with senior and middle management positions being reassigned internally.
The reallocation of key IT and administrative staff was unsuccessful, leaving the Agency and its operations at significant risk of instability.
In addition, there is no system in place to analyze available skills, identify gaps, and recruit and allocate appropriate staff.
Year 2016 Status of corrective action (completed/ongoing/pending/N/A) Completed 2016 Consulting services In addition to the audit work carried out annually for all agencies, we analyzed how the agency used consulting services in two major projects.
The Parliament and the Council have entrusted the Agency with the implementation of the regulation on pharmacovigilance (Regulation (EU) No. 1027/2012) and the regulation on clinical trials (Regulation (EU) No. 536/2014), making the structure more complex EU-wide networks required.
The Agency was given these tasks at a time when it was expected to reduce its staff, in line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Budgetary Discipline of 2 December 2013.
The number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan has not been increased, which would have allowed it to acquire the necessary expertise in business and IT development.
Extensive use of external consultants With only 13 employees in its IT delivery department, the agency relied on the services of consulting firms in the areas of business analysis, information technology, project management and quality assurance.
In the second quarter of 2016, the agency had 131 on-site consultants and another 60 off-site consultants.
The agency has therefore been critically dependent on external expertise since the projects began, but does not have a strategy governing the use of consultants.
Insufficient control over project development and implementation When the Agency was given its new tasks in 2012 and 2014, it did not have an adequate method to manage projects of this size.
In 2014 a new method was introduced, which had to be made more precise in September 2016.
Ongoing (See paragraphs [3.24.15-3.24.17])

3.24.11.
The Agency complies with the EMA Financial Regulations: The Accounting Officer is already nominated by the Management Board under Article 50(1) of the EMA Financial Regulations, and the Management Board has adopted a detailed charter of the duties and responsibilities of the Accounting Officer.

3.24.13.
The EMA offers the necessary level of transparency and publicity by publishing on or having access to the EMA website, LinkedIn, inter-agency job boards or in specialist publications, depending on the profile.
As a result, the EMA is attracting great interest from applicants across the EU. Some selection procedures involved more than 1 000 applicants.
In addition, the General Implementing Rules relating to the recruitment and use of temporary agents state that the selection letters for temporary agents under Article 2(f) of the CEOS may only be published in the working languages of the agencies; Agencies that do not have a fixed working language, on the other hand, publish the selection notices in all official languages of the European Union.
Since June 2015, the working language of the EMA has been English, following a decision by the Administrative Director, supported by the Management Board.
However, EPSO has informed EMA that, for publication on its website, it still requires EMA to translate the vacancy notices into all official EU languages and to make these language versions available on the EMA website.
It should be noted that advertising vacancies in all official EU languages has a significant impact on the length of the selection procedure and is associated with higher costs.
3.24.14.
By the end of 2017, the agency had introduced electronic tendering for all procedures above the specified limit and email tendering for all procedures below the specified limit.
Although the Agency has not implemented e-invoicing or e-submission, in September 2017 the Agency signed an agreement with the European Commission on access to and use of e-submission and is awaiting a date from the European Commission Commission.
The Agency welcomes the Court's acknowledgment that EMA has implemented several important actions to respond to the Court's observations from the 2016 audit in relation to the management of advisory services.
For the two projects audited, it is acknowledged that additional budgetary resources were needed for clinical trials due to the complexity of the ecosystem of the stakeholders and the desired system to be built.
This change request was made and approved as part of the portfolio regulation. The project status was discussed in detail with the EMA Board of Directors.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/151 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court's observations In 2012 the Observatory signed a framework contract for a maximum amount of 250 000 euro in order to be able to sign individual contracts.
At the end of 2015, payments made under this contract totaled 382 181 euros, ie exceeding the ceiling by 50%.
For two framework contracts with a maximum value of EUR 135 000 and EUR 650 000 respectively, an officer of the Center acted as authorizing officer by delegation in setting up the evaluation committee, taking decisions on awards and signing the contracts.
However, the delegation of powers granted by the authorizing officer was limited to EUR 130000 and framework contracts were not explicitly mentioned.
In 2016, payments amounting to 35,310 euros were made.
In its January 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the urgent need for the Observatory to improve the management of IT projects.
In particular, the IAS concluded that there was a lack of an overall long-term strategic vision for the IT systems supporting the Observatory's core operations, that the Observatory's IT project management methodology was only partially adapted to its needs, and that the method for managing system requirements is inadequate.
The Observatory and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan.
EN C 434/152 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE MONITORING CENTER 3.25.8. The Observatory considers that the current organizational structure has not compromised the independence of its accounting officers.
On the contrary, this independence has been consistently ensured in accordance with the relevant rules, in particular through the appointment of the accounting officers by the Observatory's Management Board, the functional reporting and accountability of these accounting officers to the Management Board and the careful observance of the rules on the segregation of duties of the various financial actors of the Observatory observatory.
In this context, the Observatory stands ready to act on the Court's recommendation, ensuring that the actions taken are proportionate to the size of the organization and the effectiveness and efficiency of its functioning are maintained.
3.25.9.
The Observatory also advertises its vacancy notices by way of standard dissemination via the members of its governing bodies, the national contact points involved in Reitox and the other EU agencies.
In addition, the Observatory's next competitions will also be published on the inter-agency job portal; the network of EU Agencies has developed this common online platform to increase public awareness of Agencies' recruitment processes.
In this context, the Observatory will examine the cost-benefit ratio of an additional publication on the EPSO portal.
The Observatory fulfills the requirements set in relation to e-procurement, in line with the relevant EU legal framework and the timetable established for the introduction of e-procurement in the EU.
Already in August 2015, the Observatory, in cooperation with the relevant services of the European Commission, set up the technical configuration/ICT tool needed for e-invoicing (and used by the European Commission's DG DIGIT to execute the framework contracts of the DG DIGIT provided).
In addition, in 2017 the Observatory planned the preparatory actions needed to be able to use the e-tendering and e-submission modules under the above-mentioned legal framework from October 2018.
Implementation of this plan is ongoing and the Observatory expects to meet this deadline without major problems.

COMMENTS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of bidders in several medium-value procurement procedures.
3.26.9.
The Agency currently manages three standalone, non-integrated large-scale IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac), all of which process data related to the EU's Freedom, Security and Justice policy area.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
Current considerations to expand the Agency's mandate to manage several additional IT systems in the coming years underscore the increasing urgency of this issue.
The Agency, in consultation with the Commission and Member States, should prepare a detailed cost-benefit analysis to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project to construct a new building at the Strasbourg site was significantly delayed.
Although the agency had already paid full price for the construction works in 2016, at the end of 2017 these were still not completed and the progress reports on the works accepted covered only around 70% of the works.
Some of the Agency's staff have already moved into the new building, although the work is still ongoing.
The agency and the contractor blame each other for the delays. The contractor made financial claims against the agency in December 2017 and filed a lawsuit.
The agency is examining its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.
According to their framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a common solution for the electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (206) (207). Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015).
Consultation 3.26.13.
Due to the nature of its activity, the Agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects.
According to the Agency's records, IT projects in 2017 were implemented within budget and on schedule.
Exception reports were written for the few engineering maintenance projects that were slightly behind schedule.
(205) See also the Agency's 2017 annual accounts, section 2.1.5 'Events after the balance sheet date'. (206) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Government (ăe-GovernmentŇ).
(207) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012, Article 95(2) Electronic Government (ăe-GovernmentŇ).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14.
The Agency uses an outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, with around 90% of the related work being carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
Payments made under these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of IT projects, from defining requirements and milestones to deploying new system components, are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which development activities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced on this scale entails , significant risks of over-dependence on contractors.
This is all the more true in view of the limited number of potential contractors who can handle systems of this size and these requirements due to operational and safety-related reasons.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the small number of staff in key operational units, particularly in the ăApplication Management and Maintenance UnitŇ (AMM) poses a significant risk to the continuity of operations.
In the second half of 2017, the Head of Unit AMM also temporarily held the post of Head of the 'Operations Department' and the post of Head of the 'Operations and Infrastructure Unit', thus combining the top three management positions in the Operations Department, which further poses risks for continuity.
3.26.16.
The framework agreements concluded with the respective consortia for the operation of the main IT systems cover not only the normal maintenance but also the developmental maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The agency calculates the prices for the individual contracts on the basis of a combination of a fixed price and an estimate of the time and resources involved, aiming at sound cost control.
For the VIS contract, the Agency also relied on the IFPUG(208) method, a standard method based on function point analysis for pricing development activities.
The Agency could consider using the IFPUG method for other systems as well.
NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.26.17.
The Agency made global budget commitments totaling 69.9 million euros to cover future expenditure on new tasks and IT systems, which were originally due to be entrusted to it in 2017 but for which the legal basis will either not be available by the end of the year (Eurodac Recast and Post-Dublin Allocation System) or recently adopted (Entry/Exit System Regulation of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding payment appropriations were reduced by two amending budgets of EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153.3 million in the initially approved budget to EUR 85.6 million in the final adopted budget.

In addition, as part of the revision of the Agency's mandate (in the final stages to be adopted), responsibility for the development of interoperability measures will be established, subject to the adoption of relevant legislative proposals.
The Agency has so far contributed its technical expertise and know-how to the discussions of the High Level Expert Group on Information Systems and Interoperability.
At the same time, a study (which is not yet completed) was carried out to get a clear picture of the future architecture of interoperable IT systems.

3.26.14.
The Agency confirms the high involvement of external contractors in IT projects (operational and organizational).
This high outsourcing rate is directly related to the Commission Communication COM(2013) 519 on the financial and human resources planning for the decentralized agencies in the period 2014-2020.
When the agency was founded in 2012, the establishment plan did not provide enough posts for the scope of the tasks assigned to it.
In addition, the scope of the agency's tasks has increased significantly from 2013; however, their requests for additional staff were rejected and the Agency had to reduce staff (a total of seven posts) as requested in the Commission Communication.
In order to ensure a proper separation of tasks, the contractors involved in quality assurance do not provide any external support services for the operational management of large IT systems.
The Agency confirms this exceptional situation, in which one staff member had to take on additional duties on a temporary basis.
The appointment was inevitable due to the long absence of the head of the ăOperations DepartmentŇ and the ongoing recruitment process for the remaining vacant managerial position.
To remedy the situation, the Agency appointed another staff member, the Head of the Security Unit, as interim Head of the Operations and Infrastructure Unit until the newly hired manager took office on 1 July 2018.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/167 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous observations Court's observations As in previous years, the rate of carry-over of commitments for Title II (Administrative Expenditure) was EUR 3.5 million and 39% (2015: 4.2 million euros or 41%) high.

Year 2016 Corrective Action Status (Completed/Ongoing/Pending/N/A) N/A
EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
Europol employs over 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organizations.
The common working language at Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language rules, adopted by the Management Board, stipulate that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures are to be carried out in English.
For this reason, Europol's vacancy notices are published in English.
Europol has an effective and transparent recruitment process with a 0% vacancy rate at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures conducted in 2017, there were an average of 58 applicants per selection procedure.
In addition to the English version, a translation into the official EU languages is required for publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
Due to the high number of vacancy notices per year, translation into the official EU languages would entail high costs and lengthen the procedures.
Europol focuses budget spending on operational needs, therefore translation of vacancy notices into all official EU languages, including publication through EPSO, is only done in specific cases (e.g. Executive Director(s)/Deputy Executive Directors). .

EUROPEAN BORDER GUARD AND PRICES AGENCY (FRONTEX) INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Border and Coast Guard Agency (hereinafter ăthe AgencyŇ, also ăFrontexŇ) was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (ănew founding regulationŇ), which amends Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 of the Council (229).
It was expanded Ń while retaining the abbreviation ăFrontexŇ and the seat in Warsaw Ń on the basis of the European Agency for Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States.
With the new founding regulation, the mandate of the agency is extended; in addition, the agency is entrusted with the task of ensuring integrated border management at the external borders at the European level in order to efficiently control the crossing of the external borders.
This includes addressing the migratory pressures and potential future threats at these borders, while contributing to the fight against serious crime with a cross-border dimension, in order to maintain a high level of internal security within the Union, with full respect for fundamental rights and respect of freedom of movement in this space.

Note 3.30.7.
The Agency's expenditure on grants saw a significant increase from €123 million (2016) to €167 million (2017).
Unlike in previous years, the Agency did not subject the reimbursements of grant-related expenditure in 2017 to ex-post verifications.
She considers that the ex-ante checks carried out before reimbursement have been improved and now - once they reach a certain level - offer the necessary certainty.
However, the Court has consistently reported since 2014 that cooperating countries often under-declare the expenditure they declare, as confirmed again in this year's audit (see paragraphs 3.30.12 to 3.30.13).
3.30.8.
In 2016, we recommended that the Agency conduct an in-depth analysis to identify the most appropriate funding mechanism (233).
In this context, the Court notes that, at the end of 2017, the Management Board decided to increase the use of unit costs instead of reimbursement of actual costs for operational activities.
At the same time, a pilot project was launched in 2018 to determine the unit costs for resources sent by cooperating states.
In addition, in June 2017, the Management Board approved a new organizational structure for the Agency, to be operational from 2018, which includes the creation of a new Inspection and Control Office reporting directly to the Executive Director and the Management Board, in order to adapt the previous organization to the new mandate ( see paragraph 3.30.9).
3.30.9.
In 2016, the agency's mandate was significantly expanded in response to the migratory crisis facing the Union.
The Agency's budget increased by 75% in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21% higher than last year.
The workforce was increased by 18% in 2016 and by a further 43% compared to the previous year.
The systems and procedures are still being adapted to the new mandate and circumstances.
The following observations do not call into question the Court's opinion and should be read in the light of the challenges the Agency has faced.
COMMENTS ON THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF OPERATIONS 3.30.10.
Following an open call for tenders, the Agency received four offers for ferry services for the transportation of migrants within Greece.
After checking the selection criteria, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only award criterion was the price.
In April 2017, the agency signed a framework agreement for 2 million euros over three years with the carrier that had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's transport capacity was seasonally limited and it was struggling to fulfill the contract, leading the agency to terminate the contract at the end of 2017.
To ensure continuity of service, the Agency signed a new framework agreement for the remainder of the period for 1.8 million euros with the second-ranked bidder in November 2017, having offered the second-lowest price.
It did not negotiate the terms of this replacement contract with the second and third-ranked bidders, but instead signed the new contract based on the original bid submitted by the second-ranked bidder.
The outright award of the replacement contract was irregular because the original procurement procedure had been completed and there was no negotiated procedure to agree on the terms of the contract pending the completion of a new open procedure.
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the event of an external competition, temporary agents will only be recruited at grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency recruited two staff (2016: 14) at AST senior grades.
(233) Special Report No 12/2016 'Agencies' use of grants: not always appropriate or proven to be effective'. (234) Article 53(2) of the Staff Regulations.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/175 COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
In 2017, the Agency provided financial assistance to the Icelandic Coast Guard in connection with the deployment of an aircraft in Greece.
Before reimbursement of the expenditure declared by Iceland, the Agency required invoices as evidence for one category of expenditure declared.
Although the invoices were never presented, the agency reimbursed around 440,000 euros.
In this case, the ex-ante verification was therefore ineffective.
3.30.13.
The Agency also co-funded the deployment of an aircraft used by the Spanish Civil Guard.
In the absence of supporting documents for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance work, the Agency reimbursed 430,000 euros on the basis of an average cost per flight hour.
These average costs were calculated using cost caps used in contracts between the Spanish authorities and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work.
There is a risk that higher costs were reimbursed than were actually incurred.
3.30.14.
Although the agency moved into its current offices in 2014, it has still not put in place a comprehensive contingency plan approved by the Board.
NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.30.15.
The Agency again canceled a large amount of committed appropriations carried over from the previous year for the reimbursement of the expenditure of States participating in joint operations, namely 7.7 million euros or 16.5% (2016: 5.6 million euros or 17 .6%).
This shows that the cooperating states had again overestimated the expenses to be reimbursed by the agency.
Although appropriations carried over for joint actions had to be canceled for two consecutive years, in 2017 the Agency carried over an amount of 9.6 million euros from other budget lines to joint actions, again carrying over an amount of 40.5 million euros to the following financial year.
Joint actions account for 69% of the total canceled appropriations in 2017 (11.1 million euros) and 46% of the total appropriations carried over to 2018 (87.6 million euros).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were available for return campaigns. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The agency therefore repaid the Commission 13.5 million euros or 20.3% (2016: 23 million euros or 37.5%).
In addition, the Agency repaid 4 million euros of appropriations entered in Title I of the budget (staff expenditure) due to the inability to recruit as many new staff in 2017 as planned.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 included €8.8 million for the mandatory operational financial reserve to fund rapid border interventions and return operations (235).
However, in September and again in October 2017, the Agency each transferred EUR 1.9 million (total EUR 3.8 million) from the reserve to its operational budget to fund other activities.
3.30.18.
After making transfers from other budget lines and preparing an amending budget, the appropriations entered in the reserve amounted to 24.7 million euro or 8.1% of the initial budget.
However, the agency used the reserve mainly to fund standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to fund a remote air surveillance project (drones, 7 million euros) for which it had budgeted only 1.1 million euros.
The assessment and use of non-prescribed reserves is not compatible with the budgetary principle of the specialty and impairs the budgetary transparency.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020.
It consists of two instruments: the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, and the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, worth EUR 2.8 billion (external borders and visas) and EUR 1 billion (police cooperation). ) to finance missions.
Under the Instrument for Financial Support for External Borders and Visas, the Commission reimburses Member States for the cost of purchasing equipment such as vehicles or ships and operating costs such as fuel or maintenance costs.
The Agency also reimburses such costs to participants in joint actions.
There is therefore a risk of double funding (4) which is not addressed.
States participating in border operations declare the costs incurred on the basis of cost claim forms, which include 'fixed costs' (depreciation and maintenance costs), 'variable expenses' (mainly fuel) and 'operational costs' (mainly compensation and other crew member expenses).
Reported costs are based on actual values and comply with national standards. The approaches of the participating states consequently differ from one another, which leads to a particularly complex system for all those involved.
In our special report 12/2016, we recommended that the agencies use simplified cost options whenever appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5).
The agency's founding regulation, which was in force until October 5, 2016, provided for the financing of joint repatriation operations carried out with participating states.
However, from January to October 2016, the agency funded national return campaigns with an amount of 3.6 million euros.
These payments are illegal.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the event of an external competition, temporary agents shall only be recruited at grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (6).
In 2016, the Agency recruited 14 staff at AST senior grades.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/181 RESPONSE OF THE AGENCY OBSERVATIONS ON THE LEGALITY AND REGULARITY OF TRANSACTIONS 3.30.10.
After Frontex decided to terminate the contract, it was necessary to ensure the continuity of the services pending the selection of a new contractor.
Considering the limited market for the required services in the region (extremely small number of economic operators), the most appropriate solution was to enter into a 'bridging agreement' with the company selected as the second-best provider had cut off.
In this case, therefore, it is not a matter of continuing a tendering procedure that has already been completed.
In making its decision, the agency took into account that the company already had experience in providing ferry services to Frontex and the feedback on this was extremely positive; the offered ferry fulfilled all minimum technical requirements.
The contractor agreed to provide the services on the same terms requested and offered in the original tender.
An exemption agreement was signed in November 2017, explaining the reasons for this decision.
The bridging agreement was signed by both parties in December 2017 and came into effect in January 2018.
The use of price as the sole criterion had been carefully considered and was based on Frontex's experience in the past two years of contracting out ferries for readmission operations between the Greek islands and Turkey.
Due to the market limitations in the geographic region - extremely small number of operators with a limited offer of ferries - it was not appropriate to apply qualitative award criteria.
The services requested by Frontex were short voyages between Greek islands and Turkey to transport returnees under the EU-Turkey Readmission Agreement, ensuring that these operations were carried out in a safe environment and in full respect of the fundamental rights were implemented.
In line with the last sentence of Article 31(2) of the Staff Regulations (ăIn order to meet specific needs of the institutions, the recruitment of officials may also take into account the labor market situation in the Union.Ň), Frontex took into account the recruitment to higher AST grades the labor market conditions (= low correction coefficient compared to the professional experience required).
This decision was fully in line with the establishment plans (which form part of the budget) and had never been questioned by the budgetary authorities.
Since March 2017, Frontex has not recruited external applicants at grades higher than AST 4 grade.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
The cost of inspection/maintenance work is defined as “the cost of all inspection/maintenance work throughout the lifetime of the resource (...).
Rate based on data provided by the manufacturer or service center to the agency using the productŇ.
This means that the hourly rate can take the form of a cost declaration from the beneficiaries, based either on the manufacturer's estimates, or on a price calculated on the basis of actual costs incurred in previous years, or on a cost estimate using reference data for similar assets if the asset is new and no data is available.
Invoices (or equivalent booking documents due to the volume of data) can only be provided if the hourly price is based on the costs actually incurred in the reference year.
However, the beneficiary also has the possibility to set an hourly rate based on average reference prices if in fact no invoices have been issued.
This was the case for the payment selected, with the Icelandic Coast Guard providing Frontex with an estimate of hourly maintenance costs.
The documents submitted by the Icelandic Coast Guard incorporate the results of ex-post controls carried out by a Frontex ex-post control team during a visit to the maintenance center in Iceland in 2015; the team had checked the documents submitted by the Icelandic Coast Guard and used as the basis for their calculation methods.
Therefore, Frontex considers that the document submitted by Iceland provides sufficient grounds to authorize the issuance.
The total amount of an hourly rate for all inspection/maintenance work of an aircraft with fixed wings results from three contracts with special regulations: Ń Maintenance of the engines Ń The signed contract provided for a maximum amount of 9 010 475.50 EUR; however, payments are based on the hourly rate for servicing an engine.
The Guardia Civil charges Frontex the hourly rate for engine maintenance in accordance with the contractual specifications.
If less time is spent servicing the engines, the overall cap will not be reached.
Therefore, in this case, it is not the total value of the contract that is relevant, but the hourly rate.
EN C 434/182 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Ń General maintenance work Ń According to the provisions of the relevant contract, this is an all-in-one price contract (not a framework contract) with monthly invoices for each contractor's work .
The Agency understands that upon termination of the contract, the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount specified in the contract.
The amount of an hourly price is calculated by dividing this total cost by the number of flight hours.
Ń Supply of spare parts Ń According to the terms of the contract, as above, this is a contract for a total price (not a framework contract), with monthly invoices foreseen for the specific work carried out by the contractor.
The Agency understands that upon termination of the contract, the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount specified in the contract.
For the above reasons, the Agency cannot agree with the Court's risk assessment, since the amounts reimbursed to the Guardia Civil, estimated on the basis of a contract for a total price, would ultimately correspond to the amounts reimbursed on the basis of actual invoices.
The applicable concept for the measures to ensure operation, the applicable strategy and the resulting emergency plans were developed and (annually) updated on the basis of the legal framework and structure that were in force until the end of 2016.
Due to the expanded mandate and the corresponding new structure, the emergency plans in particular are being revised by the responsible bodies , since the organizational changes also require a complete revision of the underlying processes.
NOTES ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 3.30.15.
The main challenge relates to the availability of commitment appropriations during a given year.
Additionally, to avoid the risk of high cancellations, in the fourth quarter of 2016 Frontex contacted beneficiaries to submit their final payment requests for operations that ended in the first half of this year and to provide Frontex with precise estimates of the costs for current deployments (December 2016) or planned deployments (January 2017) as part of the operational activities in 2016.
The main objective of these calls was to identify any overestimates, reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and recycle the funds in 2016.
Despite some positive results from this action, transfers of appropriations were still relatively high.
Consequently, despite a proper estimate of the actual financial needs, Frontex needed additional funds to ensure the financial coverage of the operations in autumn 2016, since the funds set aside from the completed and ongoing operations were not available at that time.
The Agency has developed a simplified funding scheme, which will be implemented from the 2018 operational cycle onwards, in which unit costs are applied to a significantly higher extent for grants of up to one year; not only is the Agency stepping up its monitoring of grant processing, but it is also striving to reduce the cancellation of transfers.
Return Despite the repayment of funds to the Commission, the Agency's main objective related to return operations was achieved: it provided technical and operational support to Member States for the implementation of return operations and implemented specific pre-return activities ( for identification of returnees, training/education, exchange of knowledge between Member States, etc.).
In 2017, the number of return operations coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: the number of migrants in an irregular situation increased from 10,700 in 2016 to 14,200 in 2017, with an increase of 47% compared to the previous year.
This corresponds to a share of almost 10% of the total number of EU migrants actually returned to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding value was 2%).
Recruitment The repayments of appropriations for staff expenditure were mainly due to the difficulties and related delays in the recruitment process: lengthy procedures, long notice periods, insufficient number of applicants and geographical imbalance due to a low weighting.
Nevertheless, the agency considers it a success that over 250 new employees were hired and trained within a year.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/183 3.30.17.
For the agency, 2017 was the first year of implementation of the new EGKW regulation.
for operational measures in its budget to finance RABIT and return operations .
At least one quarter of the reserve should remain available by October 1st of each year to meet any needs that may arise through the end of the year.
The operational reserve requirement was introduced to allow the Agency to have a certain reserve at any time during the year to conduct rapid border interventions and to cover the initial costs of such rapid interventions.
The European Parliament had amended the original text of the ECR regulation proposed by the Commission to add that as of October 1st only a quarter of the reserve must remain available for the remaining three months of the year.
The EGKW regulation is silent on what should happen to the remaining three quarters of the reserve after October 1st; this point is unclear.
The first transfer, at the end of September, was intended to fund increased air and sea operations and the acquisition of its own air surveillance services; the second transmission took place after October 1st.
The Board of Directors was informed of transfers in the monthly report.
The Agency believes that legislators should provide clarity.
The non-mandatory reserve had already been envisaged during the preparations for the Single Programming Document (SPD) 2017-2019.
In accordance with Article 75 Paragraph 3ff of the EGKW-Regulation, the preparation of the SPD and the revenue and expenditure estimation started in year N-2 and was completed in the late autumn of year N-1.
The EGKW regulation came into force in October 2016.
The Agency had to plan the detailed annual work program 2017 (as part of the SPD 2017-2019) throughout 2016 without a final result of the deliberations on the EGKW regulation and thus without a clearly defined legal basis.
By the end of 2016, the SPD 2017-2019 was already finalized and awaiting approval by the Management Board, which fully supported the creation of the non-mandatory reserve in view of the transition to the European Border and Coast Guard.
The Commission stated in its Opinion on SPD 2017-2019, (C92016)8722, in paragraph 63: “The Commission welcomes that contingency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work program and that the Agency accounts for almost 10% of its operational budget intended for so-called 'operative flexibility' (...).
In this context, the Commission invites the Agency to establish within its budget two separate reserves, the first being fully in line with Article 75(13) of the ECT Regulation and the second allowing the Agency to maintain operational flexibility to respond to emergencies , which are not emergency responses.Ň REMARKS ON SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.30.19.
As the Agency publishes its vacancies in English, while EPSO requires translations into all EU languages, given the large number of vacancies, this would mean that costs would increase significantly and that the process of filling vacancies could be delayed.
Frontex disseminates the information about vacancies through other channels, ie the network of EU Agencies, Management Board, Permanent Representations, Eurobrussels and social media.
After the signing of an agreement with the Commission (DG DIGIT), the instrument will be used for the first time.
The formal deadline for this instrument was set at the end of October 2018 in accordance with Article 90 Paragraph 2 of the procurement directive, which the Commission applies to the agencies accordingly; Frontex will meet this deadline.

C 434/186 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years Court's observations In 2016 an external evaluation of the Foundation was carried out on behalf of the Commission.
This was the first step in a cross-sectional evaluation of the four agencies working in the field of employment, social affairs and inclusion(1).
The evaluators concluded that the significant restructuring of the Foundation since 2011 has not had any significant negative impact and is mostly positively assessed by internal and external stakeholders, in particular in terms of strategy and effectiveness.
The governance structure of the Foundation was considered to be efficient and effective.
The evaluation also underlines that the Foundation has continued to improve its monitoring capacity since 2011, but that it still needs to present its activities and achievements more clearly.
A standardization and simplification of the indicators within a single intervention logic as well as the use of a common terminology throughout the Foundation would contribute to an improvement.
The foundation developed a plan to implement the evaluators' recommendations.
Already in its report on the Foundation's 2011 accounts, the Court stressed that the situation regarding the Foundation's premises is unsatisfactory and that there is a risk that the Foundation will not be able to continue its activities on a continuous basis.
The situation has remained unchanged since the consortium in charge of managing the building complex, which occupied part of the premises in the complex itself, was liquidated in 2011, leaving the corresponding rooms empty.
The Member State where the Foundation is located urgently needs to find a solution to this problem.
Adequate premises are guaranteed in the headquarters agreement until 2027.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.33.8.
In 2017, procurement and grant award procedures were not adequately documented.
For the procurement of services by means of low and medium value contracts, there were inconsistencies in the published contract documents, there were no records explaining the pre-selection of candidates in low value procurement procedures, and the Office did not produce evaluation reports for the procurement procedures for hiring temporary workers.
In addition, the award criteria were not clearly stated.
With regard to the granting of grants, the risk assessments were not adequate and the expert reports were not signed.
According to its Financial Regulations (253), the Office should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures.
The Office had not implemented any of these tools by the end of 2017.

3.34.7.
In 2017, the Office canceled 3.2 million euros or 15.9% of the commitments carried over from FY2016.
The Office continued to use mainly fixed prices for service contracts (258).
The prices used in each service contract are based on unit prices (price/person-day, etc.) established in framework agreements and the estimated number of units required for the service in question.
When checking contractors' price offers, the Office will ensure that the unit prices are correctly applied.
3.34.10.
However, in a procedure for the award of a framework agreement valued at EUR 80 million for general consulting, auditing and project management services and studies, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not exhaustive.
With regard to the evaluation of the bids, the terms of reference contained two business cases related to the management of a project and a multi-project program.
This framework agreement is a mixed multiple framework agreement, partly using a cascade process (general consulting and project management services) and partly a reopening of competition (testing and studies).
The units protected were pre-determined by the Office, but tenderers were invited to determine the distribution between the different profiles.
The framework agreement and also some of the associated specific orders were therefore tendered on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not the estimated number of units required, which is another essential element in calculating a fixed price contract.
3.34.11.
For this framework agreement, an individual order with a fixed price of EUR 145,447.50 was examined, which primarily relates to the provision of support services for the execution of a document management project.
The person days required for the provision of these services can neither be derived from the business cases set out in the service descriptions nor from the description contained in the individual order.
With a fixed price as specified in this individual order, there is therefore a risk that the services will not be provided in the most economical way.
3.34.12.
If not all the conditions for the provision of services can be specified when awarding the framework agreement, it is more appropriate for the individual orders to reopen competition among several contractors of the framework agreement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 EN Year 2016 Corrective action status (completed/ongoing/pending/n/a) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up to previous years' observations Court's observations The Office's budget implementation rate was 89 % low, indicating an inaccurate estimate of his 2016 budget expenditures.
Recent changes to the Office's founding regulations and financial rules have made it more important for the Office to establish an accurate budget, if necessary through an amending budget, as there are now mechanisms linked to budgeted amounts, such as the allocation of surpluses to a reserve fund (1) and an associated balancing mechanism (2) are provided.
In 2014, the Office launched a call for tenders for a four-year framework contract with an estimated market volume of EUR 30 million for the procurement of consultancy services covering a wide range of activities, including audit services, project management, general consultancy services and studies .
However, the procurement process and the subsequent use of the framework contract were sometimes not properly managed.
The objectives and the activities to be carried out had not been defined with sufficient precision to allow a precise estimation of the volume of the framework contract.
Therefore, the funds of the framework agreement were already fully exhausted after only two years and six months.
In addition, despite the variety of services to be procured and the very different amounts of expenditure per activity, no lots were used.
The use of lots could have encouraged smaller companies to participate in the process for low value activities.
Finally, price competition was neutralized and dependency on the contractor increased as fixed price offers were requested from a single contractor using the framework contract.
The Office should consider entering into multi-supplier agreements and re-opening competition if necessary.
The Office's founding regulation stipulates that the Translation Center for the Bodies of the European Union (CdT) carries out the translations required for the Office's work, with the result that the Office is the Centre's main client.
The Office is increasingly turning to internal solutions such as linguistic and translation memories and related software.
These tools are designed to improve the Office's cost-effectiveness and economy.
From the perspective of the European Union, however, the current situation could lead to a duplication of effort and the corresponding costs.
2016 Ongoing (4) 2016 Ongoing (1) Pursuant to Article 89(1) of its Financial Regulations, the Office shall set up a reserve fund, the appropriations of which will ensure the continuation of its activities and the performance of its tasks for one year, ie at the level indicated in the appropriations entered in Titles 1, 2 and 3 of the Office's budget.
(2) Pursuant to Article 139(4) and (6) of its founding Regulation, the Office shall compensate each year the costs incurred by the industrial property offices of the Member States, the Benelux Office for Intellectual Property and any other relevant authority appointed by a Member State to be identified as a result of the specific tasks they perform as functional parts of the European Union's trademark system within the framework of various services and procedures; this obligation only applies to the extent that there is no budget deficit in that year.

EN C 434/198 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OFFICE BUDGETARY OBSERVATIONS 3.34.8.
While the cancellation rate is just over 15%, the amount of bound transfers canceled is EUR 3.2 million, the lowest in the last ten years (since 2008).
The Office continues to work with national offices to reduce canceled transfers through interim implementation reports and semi-annual reviews with enhanced control measures, which are an integral part of any new cooperation agreement.
Other measures were also implemented internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with the financial stakeholders.
Furthermore, before the end of 2017 the Office expected the level of canceled transmissions to exceed 15% and proactively took additional measures to reduce transmissions for the next year.
The Office takes note of the Court's observations.
As a preliminary it should be noted that the scenarios described in the procurement documents for the future uses of the contract aimed to be as illustrative and representative as possible and were not expected to be linked in detail to each and every specific contract.
As for the adequacy of the re-opening of the competition mechanisms, and as detailed in the Office's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been introduced in the audited Framework Contract on Audits and Studies.
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the associated administrative costs and, given the Office's extensive use of the consultancy and project management services, has concluded that this is not to be considered the most efficient way to use the latter types of contracts manage.
Taking into account that the current framework contract is valid until 2020, extending this mechanism to the consultancy and project management services would require a new call for tenders at that time, which the Office does not consider appropriate.
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the office repeats the answer to the 2016 audit on the use of the fixed price procedure.
The main reason for choosing this option is that the Office has pending cases before the Spanish Labor Courts in relation to 'illegal transfer of staff', related, inter alia, to the use of the former 'Time and Means' regime.
In the case of the fixed price procedure (as part of the cascade system), the Office has experience in evaluating the offers.
The EUIPO has set up a dedicated team which, based on past practice and expertise, is able to assess what resources are required to fulfill the tasks behind the fixed price services.
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed through contractual methods other than 'fixed price', such as the 'Quoted Time and Means' method, a method which the Office may consider in the future on a case-by-case basis.
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own estimates of the resources required to fulfill the tasks for Fixed Price Services before the Request for Proposal is issued, in order to provide upfront evidence of the Office's above-mentioned experience.

Emphasis of Matter 3.35.9.
Without calling into question the opinions expressed in paragraphs 3.35.6-3.35.8, the Court would like to point out that the contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by the credit institutions (and some investment firms).
The Court relied on this information in examining the Committee's revenue, but did not check its reliability.
The SRM Regulation does not provide a comprehensive and consistent control framework to ensure the reliability of the information.
In addition, the Committee cannot disclose details of the contributions per credit institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are linked and include confidential information about other credit institutions.
3.35.10.
Administrative complaints or court proceedings between credit institutions and national resolution authorities and the Board in relation to contributions to the fund, as well as complaints brought before the Court of Justice of the European Union by former shareholders and creditors of Banco Popular Espa–ol, SA following the adoption of the resolution scheme were included in our audit so that the position of the parties in these proceedings is not influenced.
See item 8 of the Committee's financial statements for detailed information.
3.35.11.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.35.13.
In accordance with Article 92(4) of the SRM Regulation, the Court reports in particular on the contingent liabilities arising for the Board, the Council and the Commission from the performance of their tasks under this Regulation.
According to the preliminary procurement plan attached to the work program 2017, contracts were to be awarded for 16 different services, but only contracts for the provision of legal advice were actually awarded.
In addition, the estimated value of the contract for the provision of legal advice in the preliminary procurement plan was EUR 3 million, while the actual contract volume was EUR 29 million.
This indicates inadequate procurement planning.
3.35.15.
Of the EUR 29 million in legal advice contracts, EUR 20 million was awarded through 11 negotiated procedures without prior publication.
In addition, two contracts worth 3 million euros for advice and assistance in economic and financial assessment (as foreseen in the 2016 annual work program) were also awarded through such a procedure.
Excessive use of such methods leads to the restriction of competition.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/201 3.35.16.
According to its Financial Rules, the Committee should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (263).
Since a corresponding specification also applies to the EU bodies, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT solution that includes all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), electronic publication of contract notice documents in the online edition of the EU Official Journal (2011) and electronic tender submission (2015). As of the end of 2017, the committee had not implemented any of these tools.
3.35.17.
The Committee publishes vacancies on its own website and on social media, but generally not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would respect the principle of transparency, increase publicity and allow citizens to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies in one place.

C 434/202 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up of previous years' observations The Court's observations The Board became operational in 2015 and gradually established its internal control environment.
