The Accounting Officer has not yet validated the Committee's accounting system.
Of the funds available, only 62% (2015: 67%) or EUR 35 million (2015: EUR 15 million) (1) were implemented.
The committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year amount to 3.1 million euros or 35% (2015: 3.3 million euros or 70%) of the total committed appropriations for title II (administrative expenditure).
They mainly relate to IT orders placed in 2016 (1.9 million euros) and security services provided this year that have not yet been invoiced and paid for (0.6 million euros).
Committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year for Title III of the budget (operational expenditure) amount to 5.3 million euros or 66% (2015: 1.6 million euros or 40%) of the appropriations committed.
They relate mainly to services provided by the European Central Bank (EUR 1.9 million), legal services (EUR 1.5 million) and IT contracts (EUR 1.3 million) for which payments are to be made in 2017.
Between July and October 2016, the committee committed 2 million euros for the procurement of legal services. These services were not included in the annual work program or budget, nor was a funding decision taken prior to the commitment.
Applying the negative interest rate to the European Central Bank's deposit facility in 2016, the Fund paid €24 million of negative interest (2) to the national central banks.
This reduced the amount of accumulated premiums available for future settlements.
30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/203 EN Court's observations The Board needs to streamline its recruitment procedures, set clear minimum marks to be achieved by candidates and clarify the roles and responsibilities of the members of the selection board.
Year 2016 In 2017 the execution rate was 71% or 71 million euros.
50 million euros in 2017.
EN C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 COMMITTEE REPLY 3.35.9.
The annual ex ante contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of information provided to the Committee by credit institutions and certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide a comprehensive and consistent control framework to ensure the reliability of this information, the SRF devotes all the attention it can to this aspect.
The data provided are checked against the data reported by the institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB database.
Deviations are reported to the national resolution authorities, who are asked to clarify the situation. This made it possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles.
In addition, the Committee cannot provide details of the ex-ante contributions per institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are linked and would thus reveal confidential information about other institutions.
However, the SRF has disclosed the calculation method and detailed calibrations in order to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, due to a combination of an unexpectedly high workload, an unfortunate turnover of staff in the finance team and general difficulties in finding experienced employees, the finance team was not sufficiently capacity to ensure the efficient processing of all finance operations, including invoices.
Since the 4th quarter of 2017, the team's capacity has been strengthened again and measures have been taken to ensure the timely processing of invoices.
To date, in 2018 almost 98% of invoices have been paid within the set deadlines.
Each case of late payment is now being closely examined in order to make further improvements in this area.
3.35.14.
The SRB's Provisional Procurement Plan for 2017 was adopted in 2016, when the Board was only in its second full year of existence.
At that time, no resolution cases had been processed and the Agency had little experience on which to base its procurement plan.
As a new agency, the SRB was able to use various inter-institutional framework contracts managed by the European Commission.
As a result, several award procedures that were supposed to be initiated by the SRB in 2017 were ultimately not carried out.
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts will be made to improve the planning of procurement processes.
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of €20 million on providing legal advice.
Almost all negotiated procedures without prior publication of a procurement notice concerned legal disputes (eight out of ten contracts with a total value of 10.9 million euros) which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU.
This also includes a large number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the SRB's first resolution procedure.
The SRB therefore does not consider that it is overusing such procedures.
Regarding the orders for the economic and financial evaluation in two out of twelve procedures in 2017, the renewed holding of a competition proved unsuccessful. The SRB was therefore forced to resort to negotiated procedures.
Due to the subject matter of the contract and the need for maximum confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules.
3.35.16.
Online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators on the SRB website since the Board's inception and has been fully integrated into the e-tendering platform since late 2017.
In June 2017, the SRB requested to be able to use the electronic submission of bids as well. However, the Commission has not yet granted access.
The SRB found that such publication on the EPSO website does not increase the quality or number of applications and is also very costly due to the required translation of the vacancy notices.
Therefore, the SRB preferably publishes its vacancy notices on its own website, EU_CV online and LinkedIn and informs its stakeholders (central banks, finance ministries, national authorities, other EU agencies and permanent missions).

Note 3.36.7.
The Centre's mission is to provide EU agencies and bodies with the translation services they need to run their jobs. It also performs this task vis-à-vis the organs of the EU, which can use the centre's services.
The founding regulations of most agencies and bodies provide for their use of the Centre's translation services.
Some agencies and bodies (which account for more than half of the Centre's revenues) are increasingly turning to in-house options or other alternatives.
However, this means that the capacity of the Center is not being used to the maximum, there is duplication in the development of systems and running costs at European level, and that the business model and continuity of the Center could be jeopardized.
In 2017, an external assessment of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out.
The final evaluation report had not been adopted at the time of the Court's audit (268).
3.36.8.

EN C 434/220 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.39.8. Electronic submission of tenders is currently limited to open procedures (the threshold is set by Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement and was EUR 135 000 in 2017).
As the Agency did not initiate such a procedure in 2017 and will not do so in 2018 either, the Agency was not able to use electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
In addition, according to the Commission's roadmap, the use of electronic submission of tenders will become mandatory for all EU institutions and agencies by the end of 2018.
Therefore, in 2018 the onboarding process was started and the Agency will be able to start electronic submission of tenders before the end of the year.
For negotiated procedures, the Agency will use electronic submission of tenders once the Commission has integrated this option into the module.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/227 EN ANNEX Follow-up to previous observations Court's observations In its December 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the Agency's overall human resource management is adequate.
The Agency and the IAS agreed on a corrective action plan for the finding included in the report.
In another audit report from May 2016, the IAS concluded that the Agency, together with the Commission, has set up an efficient internal control system for the management of the grants awarded under the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Agency and the IAS, together with the Commission, agreed on a corrective action plan for the finding considered to be of great importance.
On behalf of the Commission, the Agency's performance in the period 2012-2015 was subjected to an external evaluation, for which the final report was presented in May 2016.
The conclusion of the evaluation is that the Agency has carried out its tasks in an effective, efficient and cost-effective manner during the period under review, that its mission remains highly relevant for the Commission and the beneficiaries served by the Agency and that the Transfer operational tasks from the commission to the agency was successful.
However, the evaluators also identified opportunities for making the activities even more effective and efficient. The Agency and the Commission were asked to improve their internal dialogue and cooperation, external communication and certain aspects of IT and human resource management.
The Agency and the Commission agreed on a corrective action plan.
EN C 434/228 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY FROM THE AGENCY 3.41.9.
The audited recruitment process, where weaknesses were identified, was introduced in 2016. A reserve list was then drawn up and adopted in 2016, which was used in 2017 to submit a job offer.
REA's selection process for contract staff was revised taking into account the 2016 recommendation of the IAS and later implemented in 2017.
The revised selection process for contract staff takes into account the requirements for clearly documented CV search criteria and eligibility checks, as well as eligibility and selection criteria.
The search criteria used by the selection committees to screen CVs are documented in their meeting minutes.
Thus, the weaknesses mentioned by the Court in the revised procedure have already been addressed.
In the area of procurement, the REA relies on service agreements with the Commission or on framework contracts of the Commission.
The REA would only initiate a special procurement procedure if there was a special need that was not covered by these agreements or contracts.
In 2017, REA only carried out one procurement procedure for a low-value contract.
The current tools for e-tendering and e-submission of bids are only applicable to public procurement procedures above the 144 000 euro threshold. As the REA has not yet initiated a procurement procedure above this threshold, it was not able to use the e-tendering and e-submission tools in 2017.
In addition, according to the Commission's roadmap, the introduction of e-tendering and e-submission of bids will become mandatory for all EU institutions and agencies by the end of 2018, and thus the implementation process only started in 2018.
The Agency already uses e-invoicing and will also use the e-tendering and e-submission modules when launching a tendering process, once these modules also cover medium and low value contracts.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors is the body responsible under the Treaty for auditing the finances of the European Union (EU).
As the EU's external auditor, we help improve EU financial management while acting as the independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
More detailed information on our work can be found in the annual activity report, which is available on our website www.eca.europa.eu, as well as the special reports on EU spending programs and revenue, and opinions on new or amended legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget; it relates to the 2014 financial year.
The annual report on the European Development Funds is presented separately.
0.3.
The general budget of the EU is decided annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, following a recommendation from the Council, decides whether the Commission has carried out its budget implementation tasks satisfactorily.
At the same time as we send it to the European Parliament and the Council, we send our annual report to the national parliaments.
0.4.
The central element of our annual report is the statement of reliability of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union and of the legality and regularity of transactions (hereinafter "regularity of transactions").
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments on each major area of EU activity.
0.5
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF); our report is therefore even more pertinent.
The financial framework came into force in 2014 and is used to determine the size and distribution of EU spending in the period up to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to relate the findings of our report to the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate financial statements for each MFF heading; therefore, the conclusions presented in specific assessments do not constitute audit opinions.
0.7.
Our report this year is structured as follows: — Chapter 1 contains the Statement of Assurance and summarizes the results of our audit on the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of transactions. — In Chapter 2, our findings on budgetary and financial management are presented. — Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic goal of improving EU public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and steer progress towards Europe 2020. — Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. — Chapters 5 to 9 (on MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) provide the results of our transactional regularity audits and audit of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's replies (or replies from other EU institutions and bodies where relevant) to our comments are included in the report. When presenting our findings and conclusions, the respective replies of the audited entity are taken into account.
However, as the external auditor, it is our sole responsibility to present our audit findings, to draw conclusions from these findings and thus to make an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of transactions.
(1) We do not provide specific assessments on MFF headings 3 ('Security and Citizenship') and 6 ('Compensations') spending.

EN C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 COURT'S STATEMENT OF ASSURANCE DELIVERED TO THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND THE COUNCIL — INDEPENDENT AUDITOR'S REPORT I. We have a) the consolidated accounts of the European Union, which consist of the consolidated accounts(1) and the aggregated statements of budgetary implementation (2) for the financial year ended 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying these accounts, in accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) checked.
Responsibility of management II. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated accounts of the European Union based on internationally accepted public sector accounting principles and for the legality and regularity of the basis on which they are based lying processes.
This responsibility includes designing, establishing and maintaining internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
The Commission bears ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
Responsibility of the examiner III. Our task is to provide the European Parliament and the Council with a statement on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them, based on our audit.
We conducted our audit in accordance with the IFAC International Standards on Auditing and Codes of Ethics and the INTOSAI International Standards of Supreme Audit Institutions.
Those standards require that we comply with ethical requirements and that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance as to whether the consolidated financial statements of the European Union are free from material misstatement and that the underlying transactions are legal and regular.
IV. An audit involves performing procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
The choice of audit procedures is at the discretion of the auditor. This includes assessing the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether intentional or unintentional, and of material non-compliance with European Union law in the underlying transactions, whether intentional or unintentional.
In assessing those risks, the auditor considers all internal controls relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements and the legality and regularity of underlying transactions in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used, the reasonableness of accounting estimates and the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements.
V. In the area of revenue, we use the macroeconomic aggregates relevant to their calculation as a starting point for our audit of the VAT-based and GNI-derived own resources and assess the Commission's systems for processing this data pending receipt of contributions from Member States and until their disclosure in the consolidated financial statements.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the accounts of the customs authorities and analyze the flow of duties until they are received by the Commission and the amounts are recorded in the accounts.
(1) The consolidated financial statements comprise the balance sheet, the statement of operations, the statement of cash flows, the statement of changes in net assets and a summary of significant accounting policies and other notes (including segment reporting).
EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenses, we review the payment transactions after the expenses have been made, recorded and accepted. All types of payments other than advances (including payments for the purchase of assets) are checked only after they have been made.
Prepayments are checked when the beneficiary provides or is required to provide evidence of their proper use and the advance is cleared or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinions.
Reliability of accounts Opinion on the reliability of the accounts VIII. In our opinion, the consolidated accounts of the European Union for the year ended 31 December 2014 present the Union's net assets and financial position as at 31 December 2014, the results of its operations and its cash flows and the changes in net asset values for the financial year then ended in accordance with the Financial Regulation and accounting standards based on internationally accepted accounting principles for the public sector, in all material respects, fairly overall. Legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the financial statements Revenue Payments Opinion on Legality and regularity of the income underlying the annual accounts IX. In our opinion, the revenue underlying the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2014 is legal and regular, in all material respects.
Basis for negative opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the accounts X. The expenditure recorded in 2014 under headings 1 to 4 of the multiannual financial framework (3), which represent operational appropriations, is affected by a material error.
Our estimated error rate on the payments underlying the financial statements is 4.4%.
Our conclusion is supported by the analysis of the amounts at risk presented by the Commission in the synthesis report.
No opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the accounts XI. In our opinion, the payments underlying the accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2014 are materially affected by error because of the significance of the matters described in the paragraph “Base for disagreement on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the accounts”. .

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS INTRODUCTION EU spending is an important tool to achieve policy objectives 1.1.
EU spending is an important tool to achieve policy goals.
Other important instruments are legislation and the free movement of goods, services, capital and people throughout the Union.
On average, EU spending accounts for 1.9% of total government spending in EU Member States (see Figure 1.1).
According to the Treaty, our role is, inter alia, to: — assess whether the use of the EU budget is in accordance with the relevant laws and regulations; — express our audit opinion on the EU accounts; — report on the economy, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU spending; — to provide opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications.
With our assurance work to support the Statement of Assurance, we meet the first and second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that affect economy, efficiency and effectiveness.
It also provides important input into the opinions we provide on proposed financial regulations.
(4) Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ
OJ L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1), these terms are defined as follows: “The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its [sic] activities are used at the right time, in sufficient quantity and reasonable quality and at the lowest possible cost.
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relation between the means used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness concerns the achievement of specific set goals and desired results.”
EN C 373/14 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 Figure 1.1 — EU expenditure in 2014 in each Member State as a share of total general government expenditure Sources: European Union expenditure (accounting data from the European Commission, compiled by the Court).
Total general government expenditure of the Member States (Eurostat — Financial statistics of general government — Government revenue, expenditure and main aggregates — Total general government expenditure 2014) (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/government-finance-statistics/data/database) .

THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS 1.3.
In this chapter of the Annual Report — we provide background information on the Statement of Assurance and an overview of our audit approach (see Appendix 1.1), our audit findings and our audit conclusions; — we analyze the nature of the various risks associated with EU spending; — we describe the actions taken by the Commission in response to observations and recommendations on the reliability of the accounts that we submitted in previous annual reports (see Annex 1.2).
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/15 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS FINANCIAL YEAR 2014 AUDIT FINDINGS The accounts were free of material misstatements 1.4.
Our observations relate to the consolidated accounts (5) (the "Accounts") of the European Union for the financial year 2014.
We received the annual accounts together with the declaration of completeness from the accounting officer on 23 July 2015 (6).
The financial statements are accompanied by a financial statement discussion and analysis(7), which is not the subject of our opinion.
However, in accordance with auditing standards, we have verified its consistency with the information contained in the financial statements.
1.5.

EU spending consists mainly of two types of spending programmes, each with very different risk patterns (12): — entitlement-based programmes, where payment depends on certain conditions being met; such programs include student and research grants (Chapter 5), direct grants to farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support(13) (Chapter 8), and salaries and pensions (Chapter 9); — reimbursement schemes where the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities, such schemes include research projects (Chapter 5), schemes for investments in regional and rural development (Chapters 6 and 7), training programs (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8 ).

EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS A new audit approach...
For 2014, we have redesigned our approach to quantifying serious violations of procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these violations.
In particular, we introduced a proportional approach for calculating errors related to contract changes.
1.14.
To ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we have adjusted the 2012 and 2013 figures in Table 1.1 and Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 to reflect this new approach.
Annex 1.4 contains the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates calculated for the period 2009-2013.
As a result of this adjustment, the estimated total error rate was reduced by 0.2% in 2013 and by 0.3% in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions we reached for those years and the level of error remains clearly material.
1.15.

While we will continue to report on the information that the Commission provides on cross-compliance, this element will no longer be part of our audit procedures.
This year we found numerous cross-compliance errors in relation to one in four of the farms visited.

For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross-compliance breaches do not affect eligibility conditions for payments (see Commission reply to point 7.7).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 THE COMMISSION'S REPLIES EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS Expenditure type and error rates are closely related 1.20.
We analyzed the relationship between spend type and risk of error.
Characteristic of EU spending is the extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by the beneficiaries themselves.
This applies to the largest category of entitlement-based expenditure schemes: area payments to farmers.
This is of particular importance in the area of reimbursement rules: beneficiaries must provide information in their application to demonstrate that they are participating in an eligible action and have incurred costs that qualify for reimbursement.
All types of management are affected (15).

On the one hand, this is to meet our stakeholders' wishes for more information on the different risk profiles, and on the other hand, it is intended to help the Commission to take action in relation to areas with persistently high error rates.
1.20.
The Integrated Administration and Control System (IACS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), makes a significant contribution to preventing errors and reducing the error rate (see paragraph 7.32).
LPIS is set up and maintained by the national authorities.
Payments to final beneficiaries can only be made after their claim has been checked against the data available in the LPIS.
Thanks to LPIS, the error rate for area payments is lower than for all other types of payments under shared management.

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 THE COMMISSION'S REPLIES EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under MFF Heading 3 "Security and Citizenship" The subject of our sample was a payment from the Commission to a beneficiary who acted as coordinator of a cooperation project under the program "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship".
The beneficiary public body seconded two permanent employees (officials) to the project on a part-time basis; she invoiced part of her salaries in the project cost statement.
Seconded staff only justifiably incur additional costs if additional staff have to be recruited to replace officials in their usual work and this actually results in costs.
As the beneficiary organization has not made arrangements to replace the officials, these costs are not eligible.
In total, the ineligible costs reported by the beneficiary amounted to 58 000 euros out of the total costs invoiced of 237 000 euros.
We identified ineligible costs, which were reimbursed by the Commission, in eight of the 25 projects sampled for MFF Heading 3.
Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under MFF Heading 3 "Security and Citizenship" The Commission was aware of the public bodies' difficulties in complying with the eligibility rules relating to staff costs for public bodies (which include other staff commission to replace civil servants in their usual work) apply, known.
For this reason, as of 2011, the Commission modified the eligibility rules applicable to staff of public bodies, making use of the flexibility provided by the implementing rules of the Financial Regulation in this regard.
Therefore, the ineligible costs identified by the Court in the grant mentioned (staff costs for staff in public bodies who do not allocate a replacement) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 REPLIES OF THE COMMISSION EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS There are many forms of corrective action with different impacts 1.30.
Our examination of “Errors and Corrections” aims to shed light on the complex mechanisms involved in taking and recording corrective action and the many ways in which these mechanisms can affect our audit work.
In some spending areas, new tools will be available to the Commission when spending for the new programming period.
Corrective Actions 1.31.
We aim to accommodate corrective actions taken by Member States and the Commission ahead of the payment or our investigation.
We also take note of corrections that occur after our audit announcement. However, whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate (24).
We verify the application of these corrections (which include beneficiary recoveries and project-level corrections) and adjust the error rate calculation where necessary.
However, the impact of corrective action varies significantly by spending area and by corrective action.
1.32.
In 24 of the transactions sampled in 2014, the Commission and Member State authorities had applied corrective actions that had a direct impact on the transaction concerned and were relevant to our calculations.
These corrective actions reduced our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points); this corresponds to around 1.6 billion euros.
Changes in the number of transactions affected and the impact on our estimated error rate do not indicate that the corrective actions are more or less effective: since these actions apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations from year to year are to be expected.
1.30
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be seen in the context of the Commission's corrective capacity as reported in the various annual activity reports and the synthesis report.
The Financial Regulation requires adequate consideration of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multiannual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.
1.31.
Common reply to paragraphs 1.31 and 1.32: In the 2014 Synthesis Report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of corrective mechanisms at €2.7 billion, representing 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
For a breakdown of the figures by policy area, see Table 1 in the synthesis report.
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude irregular expenditure from reimbursement from the EU budget (see note 6 to the financial statements).
(24) See paragraphs 1.19 to 1.37 of the 2012 annual report.
The Commission uses the terms "financial corrections" and "recoveries" to cover a wide range of corrective actions that apply both before and after the Commission has made (or reimbursed) expenditure.
1.34.
A total of €3285 million for corrective actions in 2014 is disclosed in note 6.2.2 to the financial statements.
Figure 1.7 shows how we classify the corrections made at different stages of the spending cycle.
A quarter of all corrective actions in 2014 consist of corrections and recoveries made 'at source', ie before the Commission made the related payment (25).
Another quarter takes the form of withdrawals and replacements of expenditure on cohesion projects (either during implementation or at the closure of the operational programmes). 1.33.
The Commission considers that the terms "financial corrections" and "recoveries" are used in accordance with the legal framework set out in the Financial Regulation and the relevant sectoral legislation.
More detailed information on the various preventive and corrective mechanisms provided for in the applicable legislation is provided in note 6 to the EU financial statements and in the Communication on the protection of the EU budget.
(25) For the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund, the 'at source' corrections reported as made in 2014 amount to 430 million euro; 75% of these had already taken place in previous years.

THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS 1.35.
The corrective actions discussed in this section of the Annual Report also cover the work of the Member State authorities and the recoveries made by the National Agencies and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLIES OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS The impact of corrective action is to a large extent tangible at the point at which the Commission accepts the expenditure 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations in the field of shared management contain rules on the primary controls to be carried out by national authorities or reductions in the amounts declared by the final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified.
Sometimes national authorities also agree to reduce or eliminate certain costs that are consistently reported because of errors with long-term effects (such as ongoing payments under a contract where there is an error in the public procurement rules).
Such adjustments can have a measurable impact on the amount of reimbursement claimed for individual projects or the aid paid to individual farmers. The correction then helps to reduce our estimated error rate.
1.37.
In the area of direct and indirect management, the 'recoveries' recorded by the Commission include the deduction of ineligible amounts from cost claims before payment is authorized.
The eligibility of the amounts is determined on the basis of desk reviews of the documents available or on the basis of the results of checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to lower our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections" in the agricultural sector) are often made in a lump sum.
In general, they relate to systemic weaknesses rather than errors at final beneficiary level.
In the rarest of cases, they result in recoveries from the affected farmers.
Corrective actions of this type are an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of transactions at final beneficiary level if they result in constant improvements in the cost claims accepted by paying agencies (see Boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services also carry out recoveries 'at source' by deducting ineligible expenses (identified in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections made by the Commission on agricultural spending aim to protect the EU budget and are imposed on Member States.
They do not directly lead to recoveries from farmers as the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly but reimburses payments made by Member States to farmers.
However, if these irregular payments are identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect Member States to follow them up through recovery actions against the beneficiaries.
See answer to Box 1.3.
Paying agencies implement compliance decisions by reducing future applications for reimbursement from the Commission for payments to farmers.
The Commission accounts for the full amount paid to farmers as expenditure, ie the correction does not result in a reduction in the amount of payments recorded.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and reimbursements to paying agencies is booked as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
More than two thirds of the 'financial corrections' recorded in the Cohesion area in 2014 consist of replacements with new expenditure,...
1.40
In the cohesion area, more than two thirds of the total amount covered are "financial corrections" where Member State authorities reverse expenditure declared and replace it with new expenditure.
In the case of some "withdrawals", no specific projects can be identified as having been withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and thus de facto receive a lower co-financing rate.
1.40 The Commission considers that all financial corrections, including those where Member States are allowed to bring in new projects and new expenditure to reuse the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget from unlawful spending and act as an incentive for Member States to make recoveries from beneficiaries (thus helping to improve management and control systems).
Nevertheless, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, where Member States cannot reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose the funds, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if an agricultural paying agency is subject to a financial correction of 5% and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will reimburse it EUR 95 million. For its part, however, the Commission will record expenditure of EUR 100 million, offset by assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 THE COMMISSION'S REPLIES EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS ...while net corrections are made less frequently 1.41.
If replacement is not possible, the corrections result in a loss of EU funds for the Member State concerned(27). This case, albeit relatively rare, can arise when Member States are unable to provide sufficient eligible expenditure and replacement is no longer possible (28) or permitted (29).
The Commission expects that as a result of changes in legislation, net corrections will be applied more widely in the future. 1.41.
Following the example of the agricultural sector, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections to cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 programming period.
This gives the Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect and remedy serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before submitting the annual accounts to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies are still identified by the Commission or the Court after the submission of the annual accounts, the Commission has to apply net financial corrections under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the funds are lost for the Member State.
Furthermore, the Commission considers that under shared management all financial corrections and recoveries, regardless of the method of implementation, have a negative impact on national budgets.
In order to avoid a loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace ineligible expenditure with additional eligible operations.
This means that the Member State has to bear, through its national budget, the financial consequences of losing EU co-financing of expenditure deemed ineligible, unless it recovers the amounts from the individual beneficiaries.
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or as a return to the EU budget, leading to assigned revenue (see Figure 2.2).
(28) After completion of the programs.
(29) In the event of a disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see paragraph 1.25(b) of the 2012 annual report).
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union REPLIES OF THE COMMISSION C 373/35 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS In 2014, the Commission and Member States applied all these forms of corrective action 1.42.
Boxes 1.2-1.4 illustrate different types and effects of corrective action. Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: cleaning up the Land Identification System The Commission has taken action to enforce the improvement of the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), which is used as the basis for payments to farms — such as in the framework of the Single Payment Scheme (the largest single EU spending scheme).
This process went through different stages and resulted in the 'eligible' permanent grassland recorded in the Greek LPIS decreasing from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014.
Irregular applications for 'permanent grassland', which is ineligible for EU aid, has been a key factor in our estimated error rate for 'natural resources' for several years.
We considered the impact of corrections related to individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of EAGF and European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) transactions.
Another impact is that the Paying Agency rejected many ineligible claims, resulting in the relevant expenditure being excluded from our sample.
Box 1.2 — Example of improving management and control systems — Greece: cleaning up the LPIS Other examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7.
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission closely monitors their implementation and reports on the remedial actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The land identification system prevents beneficiaries from making claims for farmland that does not exist or does not meet the eligibility conditions, or for farmland for which claims have already been made by another beneficiary.
When implemented properly, it is a very effective tool for reducing the error rate.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
As shown in the 2014 Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development, area-based payments have lower error rates than other measures.
C 373/36 Official Journal of the European Union REPLIES OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS Box 1.3 — Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures (30) — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted a correction of 1.1 billion euros (984 million euros for the EAGF and 94 million euros for the EAFRD)(31).
The national authorities explained that this would not affect farmers and that the amount would be paid from the national budget.
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such an approach would not incentivize beneficiaries to correct errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were deficiencies in the LPIS/GIS (€695 million) and exceeding the payment entitlement ceiling, leading to overpayments to farmers (€141 million).
Another reason, albeit to a lesser extent, was breaches of the cross-compliance obligation for timely notification of animal movements (123 million euros).
All these reasons are related to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made for 2014 and breaches of the entitlement ceiling and ineligible land recorded in the LPIS France contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated level of error for 'Natural Resources' for that year.
Box 1.3 — Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that the control systems work properly.
The financial correction of 1.1 billion euros will be paid back to the EU budget in three annual installments (2015, 2016 and 2017).
The Commission points out that, due to the nature of the conformity clearance procedure that applies ex-post, after the annual accounts have been closed and after an adversarial phase in which the Member State concerned can put forward its own reasoning and calculation, it is very rare that a financial correction is already decided in the year following the expenditure concerned.
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014.
Box 1.4 — Example of corrections leading to additional expenditure: ESF — Romania We reported corrective actions in Romania in our 2012 and 2013 annual reports.
In 2013, we were able to reduce our estimated level of error in relation to a number of Romanian European Social Fund (ESF) projects, as the national authorities had identified the impact of the corrections at project level.
This was also the case in 2014.
Some of the projects we examined still have errors due to issues not covered by the fixes.
In its Annual Activity Report for 2014, the Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG EMPL) indicates that it will continue to monitor the implementation of the agreed action plan.
The financial corrections made do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funding, as Member States can use the possibility to declare a larger amount of expenditure (33).
(30) A multi-annual procedure allowing for the recovery of amounts paid to Member States where those payments have not met EU rules or where there are deficiencies in the Member State's management and control systems.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/37 REPLIES OF THE COMMISSION EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS In its reporting on corrective actions, the Commission does not always quantify their different impacts,...
1.43.
Note 6 to the financial statements largely represents a voluntary disclosure of information not required by accounting regulations.
A significant part of this information does not come from accounting systems.
A description of the different impacts of the various corrective adjustments to the EU budget is provided in the explanatory note, although not always in a quantified form. ... and further improvements would allow better analysis 1.44.
The Commission's ability to improve the quality of spending is related not only to the amounts involved, but also to their impact.
A rigorous assessment of the impact of corrective action requires better information about the nature of the error being corrected and how corrections are being made (34).
When the relevant Directorates-General of the Commission assess the impact of their corrective actions, they make the necessary adjustments to the figures in note 6 (see paragraph 1.55).
The Commission's synthesis report confirms material errors in transactions 1.45.
Each Directorate-General of the Commission draws up an annual activity report.
This report includes — a report on the achievement of the main policy objectives (discussed in Chapter 3), — a management report from the Director-General to the College of Commissioners, and — a declaration by the Director-General to ensure that the the financial information contained in the report is fairly presented and the transactions under his/her responsibility are legal and regular.
1.43.
The legislator has given the Commission the tool of financial corrections to ensure that the EU budget does not finance unlawful expenditure.
These financial corrections mainly relate to system deficiencies leading to a risk of error.
It is up to the Member States, not the Commission, to identify and recover from the beneficiaries any amounts that are not in order.
If this does not happen, the EU funds will be replaced by national funds as the national budgets have to bear the burden of the financial corrections.
1.44.
Several services have duly adjusted their EU budget protection figures presented in note 6 to provide an estimate of future corrections in view of their specific circumstances.
(34) See paragraphs 1.13 to 1.15 of the 2013 annual report.
C 373/38 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS 1.46. The Synthesis Report provides a summary of this information and a declaration that by adopting the Synthesis Report, the Commission assumes overall political responsibility for the management of the EU budget.
1.47.
This section of the chapter presents the results of our analysis of the DGs' annual activity reports and the Commission's synthesis report(35).
The focus is on the consistency and adequacy of the Commission's estimates of: — the level of error at the time the Commission reimburses or pays its own expenditure (the Commission calls this the “amount at risk”), — the extent to which errors are caused by later corrections (the Commission refers to this as its 'corrective capacity' or 'estimated future corrections' (36)).
The Directors-General report annually on regularity 1.48.
When the Directors-General are unable to provide assurance on a significant part of the expenditure, they issue a reservation (see Box 1.5).
Directors-General should do so when — an event has occurred which has a serious impact on the reputation of the Commission, or — the impact of the estimated error rates less financial corrections and recoveries already made is still material.

EN THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS 1.50.
In response to the request of the discharge authority, in 2014 the Commission further developed its internal guidance (45) on the presentation of information in annual activity reports.
The directors-general are now supposed to present an “average detected error rate” (46).
Applying this error rate to the total payments for the year leads to the calculation of the 'amount at risk'(47).
This amount is shown in the Synthesis Report together with the estimate of the future corrective capacity of the ex-post controls carried out by the Commission. The Commission accepts that there is a material error in the expenditure...
1.51.
In the 2014 Synthesis Report, the Commission shows the “amount at risk” as ranging from 3.7 to 5 billion euros.
This represents between 2.6% and 3.5% of the 2014 payments covered by the synthesis report(48).
These figures show that the total expenditure is affected by a material amount of error. ... but refers to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52.
The 2014 Synthesis Report provides an expected total amount of estimated future corrections (corrective capacity).
On the basis of the corrections(49) recorded during the last six years, the Commission estimates that over the coming years it 'will be able to identify and correct errors totaling around EUR 2 700 million' (50).
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553).
(46) This is the detected or estimated error rate at the time payments were made (not the residual error rate), ie without adjustment for errors corrected ex post.
